headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago       Prime rate   4.00   4.00   4.25       Federal Funds   1.00   1.02   1.22       3-month Libor   1.34   1.33   1.25       3-month T-bills   1.16   1.13   1.02       6-month T-bills   1.44   1.40   1.01       10-yr. T-infl.   2.01   1.94   1.64       10-yr. T-note   4.74   4.70   3.29       30-yr. T-bond   5.43   5.40   4.36       Telephone bd.   6.56   6.49   5.42       Municipal bds.   5.26   5.25   4.51          (Sources by Bloomberg News; Telerate; The Bond Buyer; British Bankers' Assoc.)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Oil Profit Rises
abstract: BP reports $4.7 billion in profit for first quarter, 17 percent increase from period year earlier (S)

headline: MDC Partners Acquires Stake in Henderson Bas
abstract: MDC Partners acquires majority stake in interactive agency Henderson Bas; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Big Auditing Firm Gets 6-Month Ban On New Business
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission chief administrative law judge Brenda P Murray rules that Ernst & Young acted improperly by auditing PeopleSoft Inc, company with which it had highly profitable business relationship; bars accounting firm from accepting new audit clients in US for six months; unusual order, which includes $1.7 million fine, ends bitter fight in which SEC contends that Ernst violated rules on auditor independence; Murray also criticizes Edmund Coulson, Ernst partner in charge of independence issues (M)

headline: Revenge of Pac-Man: Vintage Games Are Back
abstract: Video games from 1980's are reissued by multiple manufacturers for play on modern consoles and with new retro consoles, resembling originals, with games included; photo (M)

headline: KPMG Ordered to Disclose Data on Tax-Shelter Buyers
abstract: Federal Judge Thomas F Hogan orders accounting firm KPMG to surrender names and related documents of tax-shelter clients within 10 days; firm says it is reviewing order and court opinion; rules that KPMG must comply with nine summonses issued by Internal Revenue Service in 2002; IRS Comr Mark W Everson comments (M)

headline: North Korea Is Studying Softer Stance From the U.S.
abstract: United States presents North Korea with proposal for phasing out its nuclear program in exchange for aid and security guarantees; senior Bush administration officials acknowledge they are softening their hard-line stance on opening day of six-nation nuclear talks in Beijing; last summer, Pres Bush ruled out any benefits to North Korea before it completely abandons its nuclear program; North Korea seems likely to push for considerably longer timetable for phasing out its weapons program than US has proposed; photo (M)

headline: A Different Tack On Heartburn: Go On, Indulge
abstract: GlaxoSmithKline's ad campaign for heartburn medication Tagamet suggests shifting focus of heartburn medications from treating unintentional excess to providing prophylactic for customers whose excess is very intentional; campaign, aimed at young males, was developed by CAS/Masterson; photo (M)

headline: Profit at Eli Lilly Declined 1.6% On Increased Marketing Costs
abstract: Eli Lilly & Co says that first-quarter profit fell 1.6 percent, to $400.4 million, as it spent more to market new drugs and pay for acquisition; (S)

headline: Up, Yes. But How Much, How Fast?
abstract: Federal Reserve Chmn Alan Greenspan, expected to begin raising short-term interest rates, may have to move more quickly and less gently than he apparently hopes; is under continuous second-guessing and criticism from bond traders and investors who hold he has waited too long to start curbing inflation; federal funds target rate graph; photo (M)

headline: Service Industries Index Climbs to a Record
abstract: Institute for Supply Management's index of service industries rose unexpectedly to record 65.8 in March from 60.8 in February as orders and employment climbed; survey's employment index rose to 53.9 from 52.7, sixth consecutive month of growth (M)

headline: U.S. Said to Overstate Value Of Guantánamo Detainees
abstract: Contrary to repeated assertions of senior Bush administration officials, none of detainees at Guantanamo Bay rank as leaders or senior operatives of Al Qaeda, and only handful are sworn Qaeda members; dozens of high-level military, intelligence and law-enforcement officials in US, Europe and Middle East say that Guantanamo detainees have provided only trickle of intelligence with current value, and none that has enabled intelligence or law-enforcement services to foil imminent attacks; top-secret study by Central Intelligence Agency in Sept 2002 raised questions about detainees' significance, suggesting that many of accused terrorists appear to be low-level recruits who went to Afghanistan to support Taliban or even innocent men swept up in chaos of war; nearly two years later, military officials say evidence against many of detainees is still so sparce that only 6 suspects have been designated as ready for trial by Pres Bush; detailed description of flawed initial screenings of detainees and their treatment once inside Guantanamo Bay; photos (L)

headline: OPEC Rejects a Saudi Proposal to Increase Production Quotas
abstract: OPEC energy ministers, meeting in Amsterdam during International Energy Forum, reject Saudi proposal to increase oil production by half million barrels per day to ease high prices; OPEC Pres Purnomo Yusgiantoro of Indonesia says meeting was not to set policy but to exchange views; says many factors contribute to current price above $40 per barrel, including speculation in futures markets and tension in some oil-producing regions (M)

headline: U.S. TRANSFERS POWER TO IRAQ 2 DAYS EARLY
abstract: American authorities turn over formal sovereignty of Iraq to its new leaders in surprise ceremony called two days ahead of schedule, to foil timing of any terrorist attacks that might be in works; American administrator L Paul Bremer III hands new Prime Min Iyad Allawi note from Pres Bush indicating that Coalition Provisional Authority led by Bremer since last May is dissolved; ceremony is held deep inside heavily fortified area known as Green Zone; it is unclear how much control Allawi's government will exercise, particularly over 160,000 troops from US, Britain and other countries that will remain, or even over Iraq's own army and police force; after ceremony Bremer leaves country; hours later, new American Amb John D Negroponte arrives, re-establishing American diplomatic ties with Iraq for first time since Persian Gulf War in 1990; following formal transfer of sovereignty, Allawi and Sheik Ghazi Ajil al-Yawar, new Iraqi president, and other members of new government take oath of office; ceremony occurs 15 months after Pres Bush ordered invasion of Iraq, sweeping Saddam Hussein from power; 850 American service members have died; photo; organization chart of new Iraqi leadership (L)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Schlumberger Selling Shares In Unit
abstract: World Business Briefing: Schlu

headline: Blair to Put Union's Constitution to a Vote
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair is expected to announce plan to submit any European Union constitution that emerges this year to British electorate in referendum; his decision could have far-reaching effect on Britain's integration with Europe and on his political career; opposition parties have been pummeling his previous refusal to allow referendum; it could have greatest effects within Europe itself, sparking demands for similar referendums in France, Netherlands, Ireland and Denmark; if referendum should fail, it could deal another blow to efforts to consolidate maze of founding treaties, laws and amendments into constitution that is intended to serve as foundation of European government as EU expands to 25 nations next month (M)

headline: Facing Eviction, Some Gaza Settlers Are Defiant and Some Pragmatic
abstract: Settlers in Gaza Strip show markedly different temperaments about Prime Min Ariel Sharon's plan to evacuate 21 settlements there; some settlers say they will go peaceably if government gives them enough money to relocate; others say they are prepared to battle Israeli soldiers rather than leave; photos (M)

headline: STEEL DYNAMICS SAYS PROFIT WILL EXCEED ESTIMATES
abstract: Steel Dynamics Inc says second-quarter profit will rise to as much as 90 cents a share, higher than analysts' estimates (S)

headline: Make It Happen
abstract: make it happ

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Defense Dept confirms death of service member in Iraq (S)

headline: 6 Agencies Receive Awards at Conference
abstract: Ad industry's O'Toole Awards are presented (S)

headline: ONLINE DIARY
abstract: Online Diary; Study Response Project helps conduct online surveys that offer incentives for participation in social science research; new site randomnumbers.info can generate truly random numbers using principles of quantum mechanics; Telltale Weekly sells audio version of mostly public domain texts for as little as 25 cents; miscellaneous Web sites noted; drawings (M)

headline: Bill to Curb Online Piracy Is Challenged As Too Broad
abstract: Telecommunications and electronics industries representatives and others oppose bill proposed by Sens Orrin G Hatch and Patrick J Leahy to curb illegal copying of music files and other media and protect children from lure of technology intended to help them break law; say it is too broad; bill would make liable anyone who intentionally induces or abets copyright violation; is aimed primarily at makers of file-sharing software, which is used to trade copies of digital files over Internet; Hatch defends bill (M)

headline: Stewart Stock Case Is Jolted by Charge That an Agent Lied
abstract: Case against Martha Stewart takes strange twist as government charges that Larry F Stewart, Secret Service laboratory director who served as prosecution expert witness, lied at her trial; prosecutors charge him with perjury; accuse him of exaggerating his role in analyzing critical documents used as evidence and of lying about his knowledge of technical book his lab colleagues were writing; lawyers say it is too early to tell whether his statements will result in successful appeal by Marth Stewart; Larry F Stewart photo (M)

headline: Israeli TV Station Says Sharon May Avoid Bribery Charges
abstract: Israeli television station reports that Justice Ministry team investigating possible bribery case against Prime Min Ariel Sharon is moving toward decision not to file charges against him; he has denied charges stemming from payments made by wealthy developer, mostly to his son Gilad, beginning in 1999; in Gaza Strip, Palestinian bomber is killed when his jeep, packed with hundreds of pounds of explosives and heading towards Jewish settlement, blows up after being fired on by Israeli troops; Hamas claims responsibility for blast (M)

headline: Caste in Nepal Inherits Destiny of Prostitution
abstract: Caste has become destiny for many communities, but few have inherited so vexed a destiny as the Badis of Nepal--their profession is prostitution.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Cellphones Banned
abstract: North Korea bans use of cellphones; The Chosun Ilbo, South Korean newspaper, holds that legislation is related to April 22 train explosion that may have targeted North Korean leader Kim Jong Il (S)

headline: Sun Shifts Tactics and Will Share Code of Its Server Software
abstract: Sun Microsystems newly appointed chief executive Jonathan Schwartz tells corporate customers in Shanghai that company has decided to release source code from its Solaris operating system through open-source license, same free distribution strategy promoted by developers of Linux (S)

headline: Allianz Funds Settle Lawsuit
abstract: Units of German insurer Allianz will pay $18 million to settle lawsuit filed by New Jersey over suspected improper mutual fund trading; New Jersey drops case against Pimco, Allianz's $400 billion bond fund unit; New Jersey Atty Gen Peter C Harvey says PEA Capital, which oversees about $12.5 billion of stocks, allowed hedge fund to make frequent trades that hurt returns of other shareholders (M)

headline: Ruling Party's Slick Campaign in Mongolia Has Rough Edges
abstract: Center-left government of Mongolia is conducting slick and omnipresent advertising campaign in advance of national elections; on paper, Prime Min Nambaryn Enkhbayar appears invincible; but government may have misread Mongolia, island of feisty multiparty politics where nomadic lifestyle combined with near universal literacy has forged people with strong streaks of individualism and political contrariness; photo (M)

headline: Claude (Fiddler) Williams, 96, Jazz Violinist
abstract: Claude (Fiddler) Williams, who began swinging on string instruments before word jazz was commonly used, went on to become Count Basie's first recorded guitarist and continued playing violin with other jazz greats into his 90's, dies at age 96; photo (M)

headline: Exile With Ties to C.I.A. Is Named Premier of Iraq
abstract: Iyad Alawi, who seemed to be a compromise candidate, is a secular-minded Shiite and a member of the Iraqi Governing Council.

headline: For Orthodox Israelis, Views Differ on Yielding Gaza
abstract: Prime Min Ariel Sharon's plan to withdraw from Gaza Strip is encountering far less opposition from Israel's Orthodox Jews than proposals to leave West Bank, because Gaza offers little Jewish history, unlike places in West Bank, like Hebron, that witnessed momentous biblical and historical events; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: New Charges For Aid Group's Founder
abstract: Bangladesh government charges Proshika, aid organization, founder Qazi Faruque Ahmed and six others in organization with sedition; Ahmed is already in jail on corruption charges and claims anti-Islamic fundamentalist government is harassing him with false charges (S)

headline: Worldcom Changes Its Name and Emerges From Bankruptcy
abstract: The bankruptcy process has allowed MCI to dramatically pare its debt from $41 billion to about $6 billion.

headline: Harvesting Different Fruit
abstract: Interview with Steve Wozniak, Apple Computer founder, whose latest company, Wheels of Zeus, is polishing technology that will allow wireless tracking of anything using inexpensive ID tags that can be located via Global Positioning System satellite data through Internet; photo (M)

headline: BIOGEN IDEC SEEKS EARLY APPROVAL OF ANTEGREN
abstract: Biogen Idec Inc and Irish partner Elan Corp file application with Food and Drug Administration for approval of their Antegren multiple sclerosis drug (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Arbitrators Find Merrill Was Biased Against Women  Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's biggest brokerage firm, discriminated against women who worked as stockbrokers, according to a panel of arbitrators who awarded $2.2 million to one of them.      The decision was the first legal ruling to find that a Wall Street firm engaged in systematic discrimination. It could be used to bolster the claims of about 40 current and former Merrill brokers who have not settled their discrimination claims against the firm. Merrill has already paid out more than $100 million in class-action settlements. [Page A1.]

headline: In a Fast-Moving Web World, Some Prefer the Dial-Up Lane
abstract: Majority of Americans who surf Internet still do so by dialing in on regular telephone lines, despite rapidly narrowing price gap between high-speed and dial-up connections; many consumers are content to pay for service that is less than optimal, and at times frustratingly slow, because they say greater speed is not worth trouble of starting over with new telecommunications provider and getting new e-mail address; high-technology industry executives have proclaimed spread of high-speed, or broadband, connections to be integral to industry's growth, essential to American competitiveness and indispensable to consumers; situation is likely to change as more users move to broadband; Yankee Group, research firm, reports number of people with high-speed connections grew in 2003 from previous year, while number with dial-up connections decreased; photo; graph (M)

headline: Another Executive Resigns At Take-Two Interactive
abstract: Take-Two Interactive Software announces resignation of chief executive Jeffrey A Lapin; company has had four chief financial officers and three chief executives since 2000; Securities and Exchange Commission has been investigating company for possible accounting irregularities for more than two years; company lowers its expectations for 2004 sales; Richard W Roedel, who became chairman in March, is interim chief executive; Paul Eibeler is named president (M)

headline: PRESIDENT BACKS HIS DEFENSE CHIEF IN SHOW OF UNITY
abstract: Pres Bush delivers unqualified endorsement of Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld; says he is doing 'superb job'; seeks to quash speculation that he will seek Rumsfeld's resignation by visiting Pentagon and arraying other senior aides around him--including Vice Pres Cheney, Secretary of State Colin L Powell and Gen Richard B Myers--to show that national security team is united in its determination to deal with repercussions of Iraqi prisoner abuse cases, quell insurgency in Iraq and transfer governance to Iraqis; at Pentagon, Bush is shown more than dozen images of Iraqi prisoners being abused by American soldiers, most of which have not been publicized; White House, Pentagon and Congress are grappling with whether and how to release more pictures of prisoner abuse; many of Bush's political and communications advisers advocate moving quickly to get images out and avoid prospect of weeks or months in which they leak out piecemeal; officials must consider effect of any release on pending criminal inquiries and privacy of people shown in images; separately, Pentagon and Congressional leaders continue to negotiate ways to allow lawmakers to view images in absence of public release; photos (M)

headline: U.S. to Offer North Korea Incentives in Nuclear Talks
abstract: Pres Bush reportedly authorizes American negotiators at multilateral talks in Beijing to offer North Korea new but highly conditional set of incentives to give up nuclear weapons program; aid would begin when Kim Jong Il commits to dismantling plutonium and uranium weapons programs; China, Russia, Japan and South Korea would send tens of thousands of tons of heavy fuel oil every months, while US would offer 'provisional' guarantee not to invade or try to topple Kim's government; Kim would get only three months for preparatory period to seal nuclear sites; Bush has been criticized by those countries and by Democratic rival John Kerry for not making serious offer to North Koreans; new plan retreats on key point, with Bush now agreeing to allow resumption of oil shipments, though not American oil, before North Korea actually dismantles anything (M)

headline: At Computer Associates, Jobs on the Line
abstract: Computer Associates International is reportedly ready to consider fate of Sanjay Kumar, chairman and chief executive, who has become focus of federal investigation into accusations of accounting fraud and obstruction of justice at company; up to a dozen employees are expected to lose their jobs as board tries to demonstrate that it is serious about changing its corporate culture (M)

headline: For Airlines, a Long Argumentative Summer
abstract: Airline labor leaders and company executives face agonizing choice of waiting or leaping; waiting means biding time to see what happens at United Airlines, which failed to win federal loan guarantees and must try to persuade its workers to accept substantial new cuts in wages and benefits so it can attract lenders willing to finance its emergence from bankruptcy protection; any major cuts in labor costs at airline, where workers have already accepted reductions worth $2.5 billion each year, will put pressure on executives of rival carriers to get similar savings; analysts say uncertainties and brutal competition in industry make leaping attractive; competitors may try to reach cost-cutting deals quickly with their own unions without waiting for developments at United, to put themselves in better shape to absorb high jet fuel prices that have ruined industry's prospects for profitable 2004; danger for airlines is that deals made in haste may lock in labor costs that proved to be higher than what desperate United can ultimately get from its workers, leaving rivals either having to swallow competitive disadvantage or to go back to bargaining table yet again, asking for contract amendments; photos (M)

headline: Coming Soon: More Memory For the At-Home Director
abstract: New line of DVD recorders from Sony can record data to two layers on single disc, making it possible to store 8.5 gigabytes of data at once; connection options noted; photo (S)

headline: Several States Likely to Follow California on Car Emissions
abstract: California's plan for sharp cuts in automotive emissions of global warming gases could eventually lead much of coastal US to turn to vehicles that are substantially cleaner, and by extension more fuel efficient, than those in rest of nation; New Jersey, Rhode Island and Connecticut have said they intend to start following California's car rules instead of those of federal government; New York, Massachusetts, Vermont and Maine already do so; photo (M)

headline: Costs Put Delta in the Cross Hairs of Crisis
abstract: Micheline Maynard analysis of financial crisis facing Delta Air Lines, which has begun warning that it may have to seek bankruptcy protection; discusses pressure of soaring jet fuel costs, which Delta failed to hedge against and which airlines cannot easily pass on to consumers because of stiff competition from low-fare airlines; says cost-cutting by Delta's rivals since Sept 11, 2001, have erased much of Delta's onetime efficiency advantage; notes Rep John L Mica's statement to airline executives during June 3 Congressional hearing that they cannot expect any more significant help from government; photos; graph of flying costs of 13 airlines between 2001 and 2003 (M)

headline: Pakistan Says It Killed a Tribesman Who Aided Militants
abstract: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 18 — Pakistani military officials said today that their forces had killed Nek Muhammad, a 27-year-old tribesman and former Taliban fighter whose defiance of Pakistan's military establishment had made him a folk hero among Islamic militants.

headline: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Boston Scientific Posts Big Stent Sales
abstract: Boston Scientific Corp sold about $163 million of its newest drug-coated Taxus stent devices in US in April; worldwide sales totaled $205 million (S)

headline: Powell Says C.I.A. Was Misled About Weapons
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L Powell says for first time that he now believes Central Intelligence Agency was deliberately misled about evidence that Saddam Hussein was developing unconventional weapons; says he regrets citing evidence that Iraq had mobile biological laboratories in his presentation to United Nations on Feb 5, 2003; hints at widespread reports of fabrications by engineer who provided much of most critical information about labs; intelligence officials have since found that engineer was linked to Iraqi National Congress, exile group pressing Pres Bush to unseat Hussein (M)

headline: Who Hacked the Voting System? The Teacher
abstract: Profile of Johns Hopkins University Prof Aviel D Rubin, who has become face of growing revolt by computer security experts against high-technology voting systems; effort has led California to ban use of 14,000 electronic voting machines made by Diebold Inc in November election because of security and reliability concerns; photos (M)

headline: Better Pricing And Cost Cuts Raise Profit At Ford
abstract: Ford Motor Co reports first-quarter net income of $1.95 billion, up from $896 million in period year earlier; revenue rises 9.5 percent, to $44.7 billion; company raises its full-year earnings forecast (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Sharon Said To Threaten Arafat
abstract: Television station in Israel reports that Prime Minister Ariel Sharon might consider attack on Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, who has not left his West Bank compound for last two years; officials refute report; American envoys Stephen Hadley, Elliott Abrams and William J Burns meet with Sharon and Palestinian Prime Minister Ahmed Qurei to discuss stalled peace process (S)

headline: Fox TV Studio Creates a Unit To Produce Cheaper Shows
abstract: 20th Century Fox television studio announces creation of separate unit called Fox 21 specifically designed to generate new shows at much lower cost; long-time studio executive Jane Leisner will head division; 20th Century Fox Television president Dana Walden says studio hopes to shave hundreds of thousands of dollars off typical $1 million to $2 million show, using techniques like shooting dramas on 16-millimeter film, not usual 35-millimeter, hiring less-known actors, and offering writers profit-participation percentages instead of large script fees; two executives at rival studio say moves do not seem to amount to more than what other studios have tried in past--and continue to try; photo (M)

headline: COURT APPROVES BERKSHIRE PURCHASE OF OAKWOOD HOMES
abstract: Berkshire Hathaway's $373 million purchase of Oakwood Homes wins final court approval as part of Oakwood's bankruptcy reorganization plan (S)

headline: Judge Rejects Plea Deal of Enron Figures Wife
abstract: Lea Fastow withdrew a plea agreement today after a judge rejected a proposed five-month term. A trial is set for June.

headline: CHECHNYA BOMB KILLS PRESIDENT, A BLOW TO PUTIN
abstract: Bomb explodes in stadium in Grozny, capital of Chechnya, killing republic's president Akhmad Kadyrov and delivering severe blow to Pres Vladimir V Putin's efforts to end long, deadly conflict in region; Kadyrov, former rebel leader who was elected president in vote widely considered to be fraudulent, was political figure Putin entrusted to wind down war in Chechnya; his death plunges Kemlin's strategy into ominous uncertainty; there is no immediate claim of responsibility for bomb, which kills 13 others and wounds more than 50; explosion occurs as Kadyrov and other Russian and Chechen leaders attend parade and concert in Grozny; Putin announces that Sergei B Abramov, Kremlin-appointed prime minister of Chechnya, will take over as acting president, as stipulated in republic's new constitution, until elections are held sometime before Sept; photos; map (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Opens German Research Center
abstract: Microsoft opens research center in Aachen, Germany, that will work on projects earmarked by European Commission to further region's technological competitiveness (S)

headline: Some Push Adelphia to Sell Assets While Still in Bankruptcy Court
abstract: Growing number of Adelphia Communications investors and partners are pushing cable operator to sell some or all of its assets even before it emerges from bankruptcy protection; ML Media Partners, co-owner with Adelphia of cable systems in Puerto Rico, has asked Bankruptcy Court to force Adelphia to provide data on systems to prospective bidder James Vaughn; current fight is flashpoint for investors because it is similar to other arguments being made by some Adelphia bond and equity holders (M)

headline: Prosecutors Seek More Time in Another Tyco Case
abstract: New York prosecutors ask Federal Judge Michael Obus more time to prepare case against former Tyco International's general counsel Mark A Belnick, citing both length of six-month trial against company's former executives L Dennis Kozlowski and Mark H Swartz and publicity around its collapse in mistrial last week; Obus says jury selection will begin April 26 and that lawyers would probably give their opening statements late following week; Belnick trial had been scheduled to begin April 12; Belnick faces trial on charges of larceny and falsifying business records (M)

headline: Allegheny Technologies Reports a Profit
abstract: Allegheny Technologies says net income in second quarter will be 22 cents to 32 cents per share, compared with loss of $26 million, or 32 cents, year earlier; will be first profit in more than two years (S)

headline: The Transfer Date, June 30, Is Crystal Clear, but Hardly Anything Else Is
abstract: American occupation authority in Iraq declares on its Web site that there are '46 days until Iraqi sovereignty,' but nowhere does it give identity of new Iraqi leadership, or precise powers of new Iraqi government over many important matters, including full authority over Iraqi armed forces; other subjects that remain unclear include to what extent Iraq will have say in practices of American-run prisons that hold Iraqi suspects, and over Iraqi criminal justice system that might prosecute Americans for crimes against Iraqis; nor is it clear to what extent World Bank and other international agencies will continue to have accounting authority over spending of huge sums derived from Iraqi assets and oil income; United Nations Security Council decision to put off these issues is source of tension and confusion in Bush administration (M)

headline: A Russian Fighting Hate Is Killed in Hate
abstract: Nikolai M Girenko, Russian ethnologist who fought racist groups, was shot and killed by two young men in his St Petersburg apartment on June 19; wrote booklet to guide prosecutors and police officers investigating explosion of ethnically motivated crimes by skinheads, neo-Nazis and other hate groups; officials concede that he may have been killed for his work against these groups; photo (M)

headline: World Leaders Get a Glimpse of America's High Life
abstract: Pres Bush's choice of Sea Island, Ga, playground of Southern rich, as site of summit meeting of leading industrial nations, discussed; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Red Brigades Added To Terror List
abstract: European Union adds Red Brigades and nine other radical Italian groups to list of suspected terrorist organizations; Italian news reports that Brigade will soon be indicted for involvement in deaths of labor reformists Massimo D'Antona and Marco Biagi (S)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Defense Dept confirms deaths of two service members in Iraq, bringing death toll to 701 since war in Iraq began (S)

headline: Citizens Financial Acquires Charter One
abstract: Citizens Financial Group to acquire Charter One Financial for about $10.5 billion in cash; purchase of Charter One is further evidence that Royal Bank of Scotland, Citizens' parent, intends to expand its operations in US (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Palmone Wins Patent Dispute With Xerox
abstract: PalmOne wins 1997 lawsuit filed by Xerox Corp over handwriting-recognition technology after Federal Judge Michael A Telesca says patent covering software was invalid; ruling will lead to dismissal of lawsuit being fought by PalmOne and its former parent 3Com Corp; graph (S)

headline: Reality TV Takes a Twist as a Kingdom Bares Its Secrets
abstract: Crittercam, created by biologist Greg Marshall for National Geographic, was designed for research and documentary filmmaking; device is now in use for reality television shows featuring what animals do when not being watched; photos (M)

headline: Ad Agencies Win Marketing Awards
abstract: Leo Burnett USA and J Walter Thompson tie for most Effie Awards, 8, to be presented by New York chapter of American Marketing Association; other winners noted (S)

headline: Ban on Weapons of Doom Is Extended to Qaeda-Style Groups
abstract: Security Council unanimously approves resolution that extends reach of chemical, biological and nuclear weapons non-proliferation treaty beyond states alone to 'non-state actors'--diplomatic language for terror groups; this was first proposed in United Nations General Assembly speech by Pres Bush in Sept; 15-to-0 vote follows months of negotiating and redrafting to win over one reluctant permanent member--China, which ended threat to use its veto when language is dropped that called for interception of ships at sea suspected of carrying banned weapons; no specific enforcement power is included in resolution, although UN charter rules allow for sanctions against non-cooperating countries (M)

headline: Former Banker Refines Testimony At His Retrial
abstract: Former Credit Suisse First Boston investment banker Frank P Quattrone takes witness stand in his trial of alleged obstruction of charges trial and calmly offers jury carefully prepared explanation of his role in events that led to charges against him; photos (M)

headline: Spread of Polio in Africa Makes U.N. Fear a Major Epidemic
abstract: WHO and Unicef warn that polio is surging in Nigeria and spreading to other countries, putting West and Central Africa on brink of largest epidemic in recent years; map showing number of cases since last year; 60 cases were reported by Nigeria in last week of April and Sudan is now tenth country with strain that originated in Nigeria; health organizations and Rotary International say goal of eradication by end of decade can still be met if funding is provided to immunize 74 million children in 22 African countries in synchronized program this fall (M)

headline: How Fears of Rising U.S. Interest Rates Sent World Markets Reeling
abstract: Floyd Norris comment on how fears of rising US interest rates are sending world stock and commodities markets reeling; chart (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: RealNetworks Posts Wider First-Quarter Loss
abstract: RealNetworks says first-quarter loss widened to $10.4 million from $2.84 million year earlier; sales rose 29 percent, to $60.4 million president Lawrence Jacobson resigns; no replacement is expected to be named (S)

headline: Falluja Role Gives Stature to Islamic Party
abstract: Iraqi Islamic Party has taken on added importance as Bush administration and many Iraqis search for way to end violence in Falluja; Sunni-dominated party has become one of principal mediators between Americans and city's leaders (M)

headline: Broker to the Queen Prefers Offering but Will Consider Bids
abstract: Cazenove, leading financial institution and broker to Queen Elizabeth II, says it is considering overtures from potential buyers but would prefer to sell shares in public offering (M)

headline: RESPIRONICS TO BUY PROFILE THERAPEUTICS OF BRITAIN
abstract: Respironics, maker of treatments for breathing disorders, agrees to buy its British distributor, Profile Therapeutics, for about $44.6 million (S)

headline: In Health and Social Services, A More Violent Workplace
abstract: Incidents of workplace violence in health care and social services are increasing in number and intensity, escalating from verbal abuse to assault; fewer workers are delivering fewer services to more people, causing more stress, leading to increase of incidents; photo (M)

headline: US Airways Said to Be Seeking More Concessions
abstract: US Airways board approves framework for streamlining program that includes labor concessions; Bruce Lakefield, new chairman tells employees that 'fundamental changes' will be needed in way US Airways does business; says they will have to participate in restructuring so that airline can compete with low-fare carriers (M)

headline: The Odd Couple vs. Nielsen
abstract: News Corp, whose media properties are popular with conservatives, joins forces with Democrats, including people who have worked with Pres Bill Clinton and Sen Hillary Rodham Clinton, in effort to stop Nielsen Media Research from making changes to way it measures television viewership in big urban centers; Fox Television Stations Group, News Corp division, owns local stations in Chicago, Los Angeles and New York that are part of Fox and UPN networks, which have significant numbers of black and Hispanic viewers; tests in New York using Nielsen's new measuring system, which involves people meters, showed steep declines in ratings for series on UPN that are favored by black viewers and increase in ratings of programs on stations not owned by Fox stations group; photos (M)

headline: Shareholders Voice Anger Toward Interpublic
abstract: Shareholders voice anger toward Interpublic Group of Companies, complaining about poor performance of its stock and rich bonuses awarded to executives, annual meeting (M)

headline: WIDE GAPS SEEN IN U.S. INQUIRIES ON PRISON ABUSE
abstract: Lawmakers from both parties and outside military experts say inquiries into abuses of prisoners in Iraq and Afghanistan leave crucial questions of policy and operations unexamined; there is no independent investigation into what led to abuses at Abu Ghraib and no impetus in Congress or elsewhere to create one, but even some Republicans have begun to question whether Pentagon's inquiries are too narrowly structured to establish causes of abuses, and are urging more aggressive review; top military spokesman in Iraq Brig Gen Mark Kimmitt defends range and scope of ongoing investigations; timeline shows when six inquiries began and describes focus of each (M)

headline: Ousted Chairman of Shell Got $1.93 Million Package
abstract: Sir Philip D Watts, who was asked to step down as chairman of Royal Dutch/Shell Group in March, receives severance package worth 1.06 million pounds ($1.93 million), amount he would have earned if he stayed on until retirement; photo (M)

headline: Kazakhstan Wants a Piece Of Its Oil Field
abstract: Kazakhstan's Energy Min Vladimir Shkolnik says government is determined to take stake in country's Kashagan oil field, signaling that there might be further turmoil in development of world's largest oil find in more than three decades; at issue is nearly fifth of Kashagan oil field, which lies under Caspian Sea; large area will cost estimated $29 billion to develop, and yield some 13 billion barrels of oil; BG Group, ENI, Royal Dutch/Shell, ExxonMobil, Total of France, ConocoPhillips and Impex of Japan agreed to develop field after its discovery in 2000, but BG has since opted to sell its 16.67 percent stake (M)

headline: Guantánamo Memories, From Outside the Wire
abstract: Four former detainees at Guantanamo Bay describe their incarceration; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Low-Cost Airline Planned
abstract: Japan's All Nippon Airways is preparing to set up new, low-cost carrier flying Boeing 737 planes to compete more effectively with rivals on shorter routes (S)

headline: Rodale Joins Pursuit of the Young Male Reader
abstract: Rodale Inc, which publishes Men's Health magazine, now plans BestLife, magazine for middle-aged men; magazine will have tilt toward moneyed male consumers; editorial director David Zinczenko comments; graph photos (M)

headline: Fed Leaves Interest Rates Alone, but Hints at Changes Ahead
abstract: The Federal Reserve kept short-term interest rates steady today, but said that hikes could come at a "measured" pace.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Mazda's Profit Rises
abstract: Mazda Motor Corp says net profit rose 40.5 percent, to 33.9 billion yen ($299.8 million), for year ended March 31; revenue rose 23 percent, to 2.92 trillion yen (S)

headline: Act of Hatred, Hints of Doubt
abstract: Analysis: visceral hatred for Americans that pours forth from crowds in Falluja as bodies of four slain Americans are mutilated does not fit theory put forward by American military that Islamic militants, including foreigners, are increasingly behind terrorist attacks; Falluja, volatile center of support for Saddam Hussein, has become major battleground since American marines entered city to challenge insurgents who have taken control of entire neighborhoods; although American military command, in lock step with civilian administrator L Paul Bremer III, remains relentlessly positive about situation in Iraq, there are hints that American generals are not as sure as they were only weeks ago that they have turned corner in conflict (M)

headline: A Marketing Effort Falls Flat In Both Spanish and English
abstract: ''The Alamo,'' by almost any measure, is a difficult movie to market to Latino audiences. Though the Mexican army won the Battle of the Alamo, it ultimately lost both the war and Texas, which became a bastion of Anglo power in the Southwest and a place where Tejanos, or Texans of Hispanic descent, were relegated to second-class status.     But as Latino moviegoers grow in number and importance in the United States, few marketing experts were surprised when the Walt Disney Company went out of its way to highlight the role of Latinos in its version of ''The Alamo,'' with Tejano folk heroes like Juan Seguin figuring prominently.

headline: European Labels Hope Piracy Succumbs to Digital Services
abstract: European record companies hope arrival of new digital music services from Apple Computer, Roxio Inc and Sony will help revive market that has been damaged by file-sharing even more than US market has; losses in European operations have forced many labels to cut expenditures on music marketing and winnow their repertoires of poorly selling artists; back-office employees are being let go by hundreds, and several smaller independents have been forced into bankruptcy; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Gemstar To Settle S.E.C. Case
abstract: Gemstar-TV Guide International will pay $10 million to settle Securities and Exchange Commission charges that it overstated its advertising and licensing revenue by almost $250 million from 1999 through 2002; SEC says money will be distributed to investors who suffered financial losses (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Foreigners Buying Stocks
abstract: Foreign investors bought record amount of Japanese stocks in March and for fiscal year ended in March; bought net 2.69 trillion yen worth of Japanese shares in March (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Economic Outlook Raised
abstract: Singapore's Ministry of Trade and Industry raises forecast for gross domestic product for year to 5.5 percent to 7.5 percent from previous prediction of 3.5 percent to 5.5 percent; exports, excluding oil and other petroleum products, rose 15.1 percent in April compared with month earlier (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Cyprus: Greece Endorses Reunification
abstract: Greek Prime Minister Costas Caramanlis announces his support for United Nations plan to reunify Cyprus and urges Greek Cypriots to ratify referendum (S)

headline: Prices in April Rose a Bit; Energy Costs Stir Concern
abstract: Bureau of Labor Statistics reports Consumer Price Index rose 0.2 percent, Apr; so-called core inflation rate rose 0.3 percent; Federal Reserve reports industrial production index rose 0.8 percent, Apr, while capacity utilization index edged up to 76.9 percent from 76.5 percent in Mar; graphs and table of economic data (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Colburn Aker , managing partner at Aker Partners, Washington, was named president of the Public Relations Global Network, Washington, a network of independent agencies. Mr. Aker, who will serve a one-year term, succeeds John Echeveste , partner at Valencia, Pérez & Echeveste, Pasadena, Calif. Also, three additional agencies joined the network: the Aces Group, Vienna; the Castle Group, Boston; and Cullen Communications, Dublin.

headline: Where Has Your Car Been? A Digital Diary Can Tell You
abstract: If you have ever wondered what happens to your car in the hands of parking lot attendants or your teenagers, the CarChip by Davis Instruments has your answer.    The chip logs driver performance, including speed (measured every five seconds), hard braking, hard acceleration, distance driven, date and time. It can also track engine diagnostics like coolant temperature and fuel pressure, and it will tell you in plain English why your check-engine light is on: ''P030: cylinder 4 misfire detected.'' In an accident, the EX model works as a black box, generating a log of the car's status in the 20 seconds leading up to the crash.

headline: Chile, the Rich Kid on the Block (It Starts to Feel Lonely)
abstract: Chile's new free trade agreement with US, intended to certify entry into elite club of stable, democratic, prosperous nations, reignites debate on whether country is somehow losing its Latin American identity; country where most people pay their taxes, laws are rigidly enforced and police only rarely seek bribes is curiously unpopular in region with few such virtues; photos (M)

headline: Prison Chief Defends Using M.P.'s to Help Interrogators
abstract: Maj Gen Geoffrey D Miller, chief of interrogations and detentions in Iraq, defends strategy of having prison guards prepare prisoners for interrogation; recommended approach last fall as insurgency was growing and military was frustrated by lack of information; it is unclear whether recommendations were officially adopted, but systematic abuse of prisoners began about two months later; Miller assumed control of Abu Ghraib prison in April; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
Battles Flare, but U.S. Still Hopeful on Truce With Cleric
abstract: Battles broke out in Kufa between U.S. troops and rebels loyal to Moktada al-Sadr, one day after an agreement to end fighting.

headline: Game Maker Misses Earnings Target and Cuts 2004 Forecast
abstract: Take-Two Interactive Software says earnings were far below its own estimates and those of industry analysts in second fiscal quarter ended April 30; says sales were $153 million, down from $170 million year earlier; posts loss of 33 cents per share, compared wiht projections of loss of 15 cents; cuts 2004 forecast; announces interim chief executive Richard W Roedel has been named permanent chief executive (M)

headline: Soaring Gas Prices. Traffic Nightmares. Let's Hit the Road!
abstract: AAA reports that 37 million people, 3.6 percent more than last year, plan to travel 50 miles or more on Memorial Day weekend, in spite of soaring gas prices; chart (S)

headline: Debts and Drought Drive India's Farmers to Despair
abstract: India's Andhra Pradesh states have been hit hard by farming crisis brought on by droughts and debt; estimated 2,000 to 3,000 farmers have killed themselves in past six years to escape their troubles; farmers were ill-equipped to compete when government began economic reforms in 1991; banks and cooperative societies are under pressure to show more fiscal responsibility, and so are pressing debtors hard; new state government that took office in mid-May has promised relief; photos; map (M)

headline: Corporate Art Lovers Who Hate That Big Tax Bill
abstract: Rich and powerful executives like Joe L Allbritton and Robert J Hurst are being probed, or in case of L Dennis Kozlowski, indicted, for possible tax avoidance on their art purchases from Manhattan's discreet world of galleries and private dealers; New York State Taxation and Finance Department says it probes about 90 people it suspects of evading sales tax, largely on high-priced art and jewelry; says it has collected some $11 million in unpaid sales taxes on high-end goods over last year, mostly from tardy buyers spurred into action by publicity about Kozlowski; Manhattan Dist Atty Robert M Morgenthau has collected some $22 million in unpaid sales taxes since he began probing high-end art deals in early 2002; photos (M)

headline: In Gaza, Bodies, Rubble and a Lost Zoo
abstract: Israeli Army announces that it is redeploying some of forces it sent to Rafah, Gaza Strip, in major operation intended to sever weapons-smuggling routes in tunnels from Egypt; about 40 Palestinians were killed during four-day Israeli incursion; partial pullback enables some Palestinians to return to their bulldozed homes; map; photo (M)

headline: Rumsfeld Tells West Point Class U.S. Needs Help to Prevail in Iraq
abstract: Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld, addressing graduating class of West Point, says struggle in Iraq is international cause and success will depend on help from allies; says military needs to strengthen partnerships around world; class of 2004 is last class to graduate that enrolled before Sept 11, 2001, terrorist attacks; photo (M)

headline: Ex-Detainees Sue Companies For Their Role In Abuse Case
abstract: Lawyers for former detainees who say they were sexually humiliated, beaten, and tortured at Abu Ghraib prison sue Titan Corp and CACI International Inc, which provided translators and interrogators at prison; suit, filed by Center for Constitutional Rights and Philadelphia law firm, charges companies conspired to abuse detainees to win more United States government contracts; says companies and three of their employees, Stephen A Stefanowicz, John B Israel and Adel L Nakhla took part in illegal conduct to squeeze information from detainees; companies dispute charges (M)

headline: You Deserve a Raise. Now Try Telling the Boss.
abstract: Cheryl Dahle column offers advice for employees on when and how to ask for raise; drawing (M)r

headline: I.B.M. Takes Aim at Microsoft With Server-Based Software for PC's and Hand-Held Devices
abstract: IBM plans software strategy for corporate desktop personal computers and hand-held devices that has most of key software residing on server computers in corporate data centers; will offer alternatives to Microsoft's Office programs build on free software from open source project; says system offers improved security and cost savings of up to 50 percent over Microsoft desktop suite (M)

headline: U.S. Planning to Turn Over Baghdad Airport to Iraqis
abstract: U.S. administrators will turn over civil aviation operations a new Iraqi government assumes limited sovereignty on June 30.

headline: Justice Memos Explained How to Skip Prisoner Rights
abstract: Series of Justice Dept memorandums written in late 2001 and early 2002 provide legal arguments to support Bush administration officials' claim that Geneva Conventions do not apply to detainees from Afghanistan war; also suggest how officials could inoculate themselves from war crimes charges by claiming abused prisoners were in some other nation's custody; methods of detention and interrogation used in Afghanistan conflict are at heart of probe into prisoner abuse in Iraq; one memorandum suggested several arguments Pres Bush could make about why Geneva Conventions would not apply in Afghanistan; White House counsel Alberto R Gonzales sent memorandum to Bush saying advice was sound; that provoked response from Secretary of State Colin L Powell, who strongly suggested that advantages of applying Geneva Conventions far outweigh their rejection; photo (M)

headline: Stock Offerings This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:      CB Richard Ellis Group, an initial public offering of 24 million Class A shares. Credit Suisse First Boston and Citigroup Global Markets.    Digirad, an initial public offering of 5.5 million shares. Merrill Lynch and J.P. Morgan.

headline: Saudis Uneasily Balance Desires for Change and Stability
abstract: Saudia Arabia's Consultative Council, royal family's handpicked legislature, studiously avoids discussing greatest ills facing country, such as increasing spasms of Islamic violence, ever-growing unemployment rate and growing public impatience with extravagant lives of royal family; interviews conducted in 18-day reporting trip in country suggest that average Saudis seem caught between competing desires; they want royal family to yield power so citizens may have more say over their own lives, but they fear chaos spread by Islamic militants and worry that replacing clear authority with something more diffuse may usher in that chaos; photos (M)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Defense Dept confirms deaths of nine service members in Iraq (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Deals: Applied Micro To Acquire I.B.M. Microchip Line
abstract: Applied Micro Circuits Corp agrees to pay IBM $227 million for line of microprocessors and licenses that could almost double its annual revenue (S)

headline: U.S. Pressure to Hold Militant Sets Off Outcry in Indonesia
abstract: Bush administration seeks to ensure that Abu Bakar Bashir, leader of militant Islamic organization Jemaah Islamiyah, remains in jail in Jakarta, Indonesia, and is fully prosecuted on terrorism charges; effort sets off diplomatic and political tempest in Indonesia; Islamists and nationalists denounce what they see as undue interference in Indonesia's internal affairs; Bashir was convicted of only relatively minor offenses last Sept and Supreme Court ruling makes him eligible for release; Australia joins US in opposing his release; photo (M)

headline: Afghan Gives Own Account Of U.S. Abuse
abstract: Sayed Nabi Siddiqui, former Afghan police colonel, says he was subjected to beating, kicking, sleep deprivation, taunts and sexual abuse during 40 days he spent in American custody at three sites in Afghanistan, interview sparked by disclosure of abuse at Abu Ghraib, Iraq, prison; says he was repeatedly photographed, often while naked; Afghan Independent Human Rights Commission members say story matches one he gave to them shortly after his release last fall, long before abuse in Iraq came to light; say they mentioned details of case, apparently first involving sexual abuse of detainee, to American military officials last year; Afghan military and police officials say they have heard similar stories from detainees and their families; United States military opens probe; Amb Zalmay Khalilzad says that, to best of his knowledge, it is first time military command or American Embassy had heard of alleged abuse; map; photos (M)

headline: Clashes in Najaf and Kufa Cause Cease-Fire to Fray
abstract: Cease-fire between US forces and Moktada al-Sadr's insurgents appears to be unraveling as fighting erupts in centers of Najaf and Kufa; four Iraqi civilians and three US soldiers are wounded in Najaf; CNN reports heavy attack on soldiers trying to take police station in Kufa; Shiite leaders in Nafaf meet to discuss seemingly intractable problem posed by Sadr (M)

headline: Bank Leader In Germany Jeopardized By Hotel Tab
abstract: Bundesbank president Ernst Welteke is facing pt

headline: Oracle, Seeking PeopleSoft, Says It Is Forced to Compete Broadly
abstract: PeopleSoft Corp executive vice president W Phillip Wilmington says PeopleSoft sometimes competes against companies other than Oracle and SAP for big software customers, federal antitrust trial involving Oracle's proposed $7.7 billion takeover of PeopleSoft; Oracle says testimony refutes Justice Department arguments that it should be blocked from buying PeopleSoft because only Oracle, PeopleSoft and SAP supply software to large corporations; Oracle also introduces documents indicating that PeopleSoft viewed Microsoft as competitor (M)

headline: A Marketing Division At Saatchi & Saatchi
abstract: Saatchi & Saatchi is forming division in Springdale, Ark, called Saatchi & Saatchi X; division is being formed around ThompsonMurray, which Saatchi & Saatchi has just acquired; ThompsonMurray chief executive Andy Murray is named chief executive at Saatchi & Saatchi X; Kevin Roberts becomes chairman of division and Mel Korn is named vice chairman (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Investor Confidences Rises
abstract: ZEW Center for European Economic Research survey finds German investor confidence in economy rose slightly in June (S)

headline: Chief Executive of Janus Capital Steps Down
abstract: Janus Capital Group says that its chief executive, Mark B Whiston, is resigning and that he will be succeeded by chairman, Steven L Scheid; company, which is struggling to stanch billions of dollars in redemptions by investors in its mutual funds, says Whiston's departure is not part of discussions with regulators about settling their investigation into market timing abuses at fund company; photo of Whiston (M)

headline: Past Haunts Future in Slovakia's Election
abstract: Vladimir Meciar, autocratic former prime minister who led Slovakia after split from Czech Republic in 1993, has unexpectedly emerged as favorite to win April 17 runoff election for presidency; won 32.7 percent of vote in first round of elections, while governing party's candidate Foreign Min Eduard Kukan did not win enough votes to qualify in runoff; Slovak presidency is largely symbolic role, but some Slovaks fear Meciar is wrong symbol to offer world when Slovakia has just been admitted to NATO and is soon to join European Union; photo (M)

headline: Income Climbs at Talbots
abstract: Talbots Inc says first-quarter earnings rose 13 percent, first increase since 2002; net income rose to $33.3 million from $29.4 million year ago; sales in quarter ended May 1 rose 6.1 percent, to $419 million; sales at stores open at least one year rose 1.7 percent (S)

headline: Wrapping a Familiar Name Around a New Product
abstract: If you yanked open the drawers and cupboards of American kitchens in the consumer-crazy years after World War II, you would have found some of the same products in almost every home.       There was a box of plastic wrap and one of aluminum foil -- and maybe some dishwasher detergent, if the house was affluent enough to have the latest appliance. And, in the laundry room, there would be some fine-fabric wash along with the regular soaps.

headline: Technology Briefing | Deals: Lucent To Buy Telica For $295 Million
abstract: Lucent Technologies acquires Telica Inc for $295 million in stock to add higher-capacity switches that use Internet technology to transmit calls (S)

headline: DUPONT LAYING OFF 3,000 AND CLOSING CANADIAN PLANT
abstract: DuPont Co will lay off 3,000 workers, eliminate 950 other jobs and shut down spandex plant in Canada as part of plan to trim annual costs by $900 million; job cuts will be completed by Dec 31; about 70 percent of cuts will be in North Amercia, and most of rest will be in Western Europe (S)

headline: Screenwriters Denounce Offer From Studios as 'Unacceptable'
abstract: Hollywood screenwriters say studios' lastest offer for new three-year contract is unacceptable, four days after contract expiration, and they want to consider one-year deal unless better offer is forthcoming; Hollywood studios have offered no increases in royalties in lucrative DVD and videocassette market, one of main issues dividing two side, and have not addressed status of writers on television reality shows or royalties on Internet sales; leaders of East and West Coast branches of Writers Guild of America say studios' offer on health care also falls short (M)

headline: EUROPE GIVES APPROVAL FOR J.P. MORGAN TO BUY BANK ONE
abstract: J P Morgan Chase & Co receives European Union approval to buy Bank One Corp for about $55 billion (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Debt Rating Raised
abstract: Standard & Poor's raises outlook for its rating on Indonesia's foreign debt, citing government's improving fiscal position and its lower debt payments (S)

headline: SPRING CLEANING
abstract: Sumner M Redstone, making major changes at his main companies, also raises his private stake in video game maker Midway Games to 68 percent; subsequent resignation of Midway chairman Neil D Nicastro spurs speculation that Redstone's daughter, Shari Redstone, may replace him (S)0

headline: Should You Stay, Or Should You Go?
abstract: Cheryl Dahle Career Couch question-and

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Samsung Profit Nearly Triples
abstract: Samsung Electronics Co says its first-quarter net income almost tripled as sales of its flat-screen displays and cellphones rose; net income was 3.1 trillion South Korean won ($2.7 billion), compared with 1.1 trillion won in period year earlier (S)

headline: Trump Plans Radio Career
abstract: Premiere Radio Networks in June will begin syndicating 60- to 90-second radio commentaries by Donald J Trump; Trump is set to speak mostly about business-related matters in daily commentary to be called 'Trumped!'; Premiere suspects Trump will also have plenty to say about current events (M)

headline: Bond Trading Helps Lehman Increase Profit
abstract: Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc says profit rose 39 percent in second quarter ended May 31; net income increased to $609 million from $437 million year earlier; net revenue rose 28 percent, to $2.93 billin, from $2.29 billion (M)

headline: Out of Sight, Afghans Register Women to Vote
abstract: Women in Afghanistan are registering to vote for first time, but strict rules of tribal culture are hampering process; women in conservative Muslim districts of southern provinces rarely leave their homes, and female registration teams must visit every household individually; whether women will vote in fall's parliamentary and presidential elections may depend on whether their husbands let them out of house; photos (M)

headline: A Smooth, Clear Complexion With No Spa Visit Required
abstract: Digital Gem airbrush plug-in from Eastman Kodak for Adobe Photoshop analyzes digital portraits and selectively smooths skin; photo (S)

headline: BEST BUY AND CIRCUIT CITY REPORT STRONGER PROFITS
abstract: Best Buy and Circuit City, largest electronics retailers, report increases in profit in fourth quarter; Best Buy earned $469 million on 21 percent increase in sales; Circuit City earned $89.6 million on 1.8 percent increase in sales; Circuit City acquires InterTan, which operates 980 electronics retail stores in Canada, for about $284 million, and MusicNow, privately held company that sells music downloads, for undisclosed amount (S)

headline: A Stuffed Doppelgänger
abstract: S Brandon letter suggests buying two of child's favorite toy to avoid heartbreak if mishaps occur (April 29 article)

headline: Voices of the Dead Echo Across Algeria
abstract: More than 150,000 people died in Algerian civil war after military coup in 1992 kept Islamic government from taking power; both sides are guilty of killings, but most deaths are undocumented; families of those killed face great difficulty in finding missing relatives; government has only recently conceded that people are missing and will not investigate mass graves; many remains disappeared years ago; photos; map (M)

headline: Land Quarrels Unsettle Ivory Coast's Cocoa Belt
abstract: Ivory Coast civil war has spawned ugly ethnic feud over cocoa land; largely northern and immigrant workers who cultivate cocoa have been expelled from plantations, spurring deadly reprisal attacks; much of violence erupted at lucrative cocoa harvest time, which ended in Apr; violence has begun to overturn land laws and open-border policies that have made nation producer of 40 percent of world's cocoa and turned it into economic magnet; violence so far has hardly touched global cocoa trade, with nation, buoyed by high wartime prices, producing bumper crop of 1.36 million tons; Pres Laurent Gbagbo's forces control most of cocoa territory; war is officially over, but peace remains elusive, with resentment over people of foreign ancestory who work and have come to own some cocoa lands at heart of conflict; map; photos (M)

headline: A Top Pakistani General Escapes an Assassination Attempt That Kills 10 People
abstract: Suspected Islamic militants ambush motorcade of top Pakistani general, Ahsan Salim Hayat, in heart of Karachi, killing six soldiers, three policemen and civilian; Hayat is unharmed; spate of such attacks appears aimed at destabilizing Pres Pervez Musharraf's government; map (M)

headline: A Haitian Village Gets a Barrage of Care
abstract: Aid workers and US soldiers in Haiti bring food and medical treatment to Mapou but military's departure will leave huge gap in desperately poor community where people say no Haitian leader has ever come; photos; map; Haitian government has only about $3 per person to help estimated 75,000 people affected by recent floods (M)

headline: Two Countries, Two Tales of Jobs
abstract: Edmund L Andrews column compares weak job creation in United States with strong job growth in Canada; notes Center for American Progress blames Pres Bush's tax cuts, aimed at upper-income taxpayers, for part of weak job performance; notes Canada's unemployment rate remains higher than in US; job growth graphs (M)

headline: After Attack, Company's Staff Plans to Leave Saudi Arabia
abstract: ABB Lummus, international engineering company whose offices in Yanbu, Saudi Arabia, were hit by deadly attack, says all its employees there have chosen to leave kingdom within days, and work on that project--revamping oil refinery--will be suspended; says several hundred other foreign employees working on ABB projects elsewhere in Saudi Arabia will remain; in Yanbu attack, at least one Saudi security officer and five foreign engineers were killed, and up to 33 people were wounded; company officials say four gunmen were not ABB employees, as initially reported, but that they worked elsewhere on industrial site, thus had passes needed to get through security; say gunmen singled out senior employees in killing two Americans, two Britons and an Australian; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Austria: Tourists Hurt In Danube Boat Crash
abstract: European Viking, passenger boat cruising Danube River, hits pillar of Reichsbrucke bridge in Vienna injuring 19 passengers; minor damage is done to boat and bridge; American, British and Canadian passengers are on board during accident (S)

headline: Loss Narrows as Sales Increase at Goodyear
abstract: Goodyear Tire and Rubber Co reports its fir

headline: Better Late Than Never
abstract: Letter from Nelson Marans, who began using computer at age 77, praises technology for ease of use (March 25 article)

headline: World Briefings
abstract: AMERICAS.

headline: Technology Briefing | Services: Computer Sciences Wins Contract From Sears
abstract: Computer Sciences Corp wins 10-year contract valued at $1.6 billion to run part of Sears, Roebuck's computer systems (S)

headline: Dow Jones Sales Rose in Quarter
abstract: Dow Jones & Co says its first-quarter sales rose 12 percent on surge in financial advertising; profit fell 73 percent from year earlier; sales advanced to $401.6 million, from $358.2 million; net income fell to $17.8 million from $66.9 million (S)

headline: Vanquish Opponents, Then Find Your Way Home
abstract: I-Top from Itoys stores record spin counts and answers yes-or-no questions; photo (S)

headline: Wells Fargo Adds Strong Financial's Assets
abstract: Wells Fargo will buy $34 billion in assets managed by Strong Financial, which has played prominent role in probes into mutual fund industry; analysts estimate that Wells Fargo will initially pay $500 million and make additional payments later as long as Strong's assets retain their value (M)

headline: 9/11 Set Army Contractor On Path to Abu Ghraib
abstract: Steven Stefanowicz, 33-year-old contract interrogator possibly implicated in abuses at Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq, is former Navy intelligence analyst hired by CACI Inc last fall; 6-foot-5-inch tall Stefanowicz, described by associates as nonthreatening and deferential, is mentioned in Gen Antonio Taguba's report on prison as 'directly or indirectly responsible' because he directed some of military police officers involved; he is not shown in any photos, is not charged with crime and, as civilian, is in legal limbo (M)

headline: Bush and King of Jordan Ease Tensions Between Them
abstract: Pres Bush and King Abdullah II of Jordan hold White House meeting, both seeking to defuse tensions over Palestinian issue that caused postponement of earlier meeting; Bush reiterates promise that any settlement between Israel and Palestinians would have to come through negotiation; Jordan's deep concern, shared by other Arab nations, is over Bush's letter last month to Israeli Prime Min Ariel Sharon, endorsing Sharon's plan to withdraw from Gaza and Israel's position on right of return; Sharon's own party voted against plan, leaving Bush administration to wonder what letter accomplished, beyond infuriating American allies thoughout Arab world; Bush says he will send letter explaining his views to Palestinian Prime Min Ahmed Qurei; diplomats say it is striking that Bush will send letter to man thought by Israel and Bush administration to be powerless figurehead taking orders from Yasir Arafat; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of advertising account changes (S)

headline: Sharon Reportedly Will Avoid Bribery Charges
abstract: Israeli television stations are reporting that Atty Gen Menachem Mazuz has decided against indicting Prime Min Ariel Sharon on charges of accepting bribes from real estate developer; threat of indictment has been political handicap for Sharon as he tries to cajole and press ministers in his coalition government to support his plan to 'disengage' from Palestinians without peace agreement; Mazuz, whose spokesman refuses to confirm TV reports, is expected to make formal announcement of his decision on June 15 (M)

headline: PILGRIM'S PRIDE TO SHED PLANT AND LAY OFF 1,300
abstract: Poultry processor Pilgrim's Pride Corp will close processing plant in Hinton, Va, and lay off its 1,300 workers in bid to end losses in fresh turkey business (S)

headline: Muckraking Accountant Stirs Canada's Political Scene
abstract: Canadian Auditor Gen Sheila Fraser has become unexpected celebrity after issuing series of reports that criticize Liberal government for sloth and fraud; her reports have put Liberal government of Prime Min Paul Martin, in office only since December, on defensive, giving Conservative Party outside chance to take power before end of year; Fraser's plain and deliberate manner gives her credibility with public, which has grown skeptical of politicians; photo (M)

headline: Turmoil in Iraq Reverberates Back Home for Allies of U.S.
abstract: Even in Britain, Foreign Secretary Jack Straw said "there is no doubt that the current situation is very serious and it is the most serious that we have faced."

headline: FedEx Raises Its Prediction for Yearly Earnings
abstract: FedEx Corp reports net income for fiscal fourt-quarter ended May 31 rose 47 percent, to $412 million; raises earnings forecast for new fiscal year (M)

headline: TELEFLEX PAYS $460 MILLION FOR HUDSON RESPIRATORY CARE
abstract: Teleflex acquires Hudson Respiratory Care for $460 million in cash (S)

headline: Building Character, Wrinkle by Wrinkle, in a 3-D World
abstract: How It Works column on improvements in computer hardware and 3-D graphics mapping; overall results make video game images more realistic; illustrations show how technology works; photo (M)

headline: 135 Days of Counting Sideways
abstract: Jonathan Fuerbringer column notes stock market that has been stalled for 135 days and is likely to continue to move sideways; notes sideways periods have occured fairly regularly and have sometimes been painfully long; notes investors are currently demanding relatively high risk premium to buy stocks; graph of longest bull-market pauses (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Profit For Brewer
abstract: Asahi Breweries Ltd's net income was 2.35 billion yen ($21.6 million) in three months ended March 31 compared to loss of 5.07 billion yen year earlier; sales rose to 277.2 billion yen from 273 billion yen (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago       Prime rate   4.00   4.00   4.25       Federal Funds   1.00   1.02   1.22       3-month Libor   1.34   1.33   1.25       3-month T-bills   1.16   1.13   1.02       6-month T-bills   1.44   1.40   1.01       10-yr. T-infl.   2.01   1.94   1.64       10-yr. T-note   4.74   4.70   3.29       30-yr.
