headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Oil Profit Rises
abstract: BP reports $4.7 billion in profit for first quarter, 17 percent increase from period year earlier (S)

headline: MDC Partners Acquires Stake in Henderson Bas
abstract: MDC Partners acquires majority stake in interactive agency Henderson Bas; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Big Auditing Firm Gets 6-Month Ban On New Business
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission chief administrative law judge Brenda P Murray rules that Ernst & Young acted improperly by auditing PeopleSoft Inc, company with which it had highly profitable business relationship; bars accounting firm from accepting new audit clients in US for six months; unusual order, which includes $1.7 million fine, ends bitter fight in which SEC contends that Ernst violated rules on auditor independence; Murray also criticizes Edmund Coulson, Ernst partner in charge of independence issues (M)

headline: Revenge of Pac-Man: Vintage Games Are Back
abstract: Video games from 1980's are reissued by multiple manufacturers for play on modern consoles and with new retro consoles, resembling originals, with games included; photo (M)

headline: KPMG Ordered to Disclose Data on Tax-Shelter Buyers
abstract: Federal Judge Thomas F Hogan orders accounting firm KPMG to surrender names and related documents of tax-shelter clients within 10 days; firm says it is reviewing order and court opinion; rules that KPMG must comply with nine summonses issued by Internal Revenue Service in 2002; IRS Comr Mark W Everson comments (M)

headline: North Korea Is Studying Softer Stance From the U.S.
abstract: United States presents North Korea with proposal for phasing out its nuclear program in exchange for aid and security guarantees; senior Bush administration officials acknowledge they are softening their hard-line stance on opening day of six-nation nuclear talks in Beijing; last summer, Pres Bush ruled out any benefits to North Korea before it completely abandons its nuclear program; North Korea seems likely to push for considerably longer timetable for phasing out its weapons program than US has proposed; photo (M)

headline: A Different Tack On Heartburn: Go On, Indulge
abstract: GlaxoSmithKline's ad campaign for heartburn medication Tagamet suggests shifting focus of heartburn medications from treating unintentional excess to providing prophylactic for customers whose excess is very intentional; campaign, aimed at young males, was developed by CAS/Masterson; photo (M)

headline: Profit at Eli Lilly Declined 1.6% On Increased Marketing Costs
abstract: Eli Lilly & Co says that first-quarter profit fell 1.6 percent, to $400.4 million, as it spent more to market new drugs and pay for acquisition; (S)

headline: Up, Yes. But How Much, How Fast?
abstract: Federal Reserve Chmn Alan Greenspan, expected to begin raising short-term interest rates, may have to move more quickly and less gently than he apparently hopes; is under continuous second-guessing and criticism from bond traders and investors who hold he has waited too long to start curbing inflation; federal funds target rate graph; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Gas Network Discussed
abstract: Indonesia will hold talks with other major exporters of liquefied natural gas, including Brunei, Oman and Qatar, to explore possibility of setting up supply network to back up their own sales obligations; such network could help reduce risk that supply disruptions would prevent any one exporter from meeting its contractual obligations to sell liquefied natural gas to long-term buyers (S)

headline: Germans Free Moroccan Convicted of a 9/11 Role
abstract: German court releases Mounir el-Motassadeq, only man convicted in connection with 9/11 terrorist attacks in United States, pending new trial later this year; his release follows decision by German appeals court to reverse his conviction, ruling that he had been denied fair trial because of refusal of US to allow testimony by captured terrorist suspect Ramzi bin al-Shibh; Motassadeq appealed his conviction after another 9/11 suspect Abdelghani Mzoudi was acquitted when US refused to permit bin al-Shibh to testify at his trial; Motassadeq's case is sure to present same legal issues that resulted in collapse of case against Mzoudi (M)

headline: CHEVRONTEXACO'S PROFIT ROSE 33% IN FIRST QUARTER
abstract: ChevronTexaco Corp says first-quarter earnings rose 33 percent, to $2.56 billion (S)

headline: UAL Posts a Loss in April
abstract: UAL Corp, parent company of United Airlines, reports loss of $137.3 million for April, compared with loss of $34 million in March; revenue was $1.4 billion, compared with revenue of $1.5 billion in March (S)

headline: Sales Rise but Income Drops Sharply for Verizon
abstract: Verizon Communications says net income fell by half in first quarter compared with period year earlier; earned $1.2 billion compared with $2.41 billion year ago; sales rose 3.9 percent, to $17.1 billion (S)

headline: U.N. Chief Rebuts Critics of the Iraq 'Oil for Food' Program
abstract: Sec Gen Kofi Annan strikes back at critics of United Nations and his leadership, saying they are treating unproven charges as facts and ignoring good that 'oil for food' program brought Iraqis despite its scandal-ridden management; says Benon V Sevan, former head of program, has promised to cooperate with investigation and has again denied charge that Iraqi officials gave him illegal oil allotment worth up to $3.5 million (M)

headline: 'My Deepest Apology' From Rumsfeld; 'Nothing Less Than Tragic,' Says Top General
abstract: Excerpts from statements by Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld and Joint Chiefs of Staff chairman B Myers before Senate Armed Services Committee and their responses to questions from Sens John McCain and Edward M Kennedy about Iraqi prisoner-abuse scandal; Rumsfeld photo (M)

headline: 3 More Moroccans Arrested In Madrid Train Bombings
abstract: Fouad el-Mourabit, 28-year-old aeronautical engineering student from Morocco, is charged with 'collaborating with an armed group' after police in Spain conclude from his cellphone records that he spoke with most of men who have been identified at core of Mar 11 plot to bomb trains in Madrid; court officer says Mourabit made calls before and on day of bombings on Mar 11; says he is well acquainted with Sarhane Ben Abdelmajid Fakhet, Tunisian believed to have been operational head of plot and who died with several others in suicide bombing as police closed in on them; police announce arrest of three more Moroccans, all of whom have been linked to Fakhet and others who blew themselves up (M)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Hill & Knowlton is acquiring Dome Communications (S)

headline: Witness Tells Of Debt Deal At Adelphia
abstract: Adelphia Communications former treasury supervisor James Helms testifies that former finance chief Timothy Rigas signed receipt that falsely showed his family used cash to buy $400 million in company debt in January 2002; says receipt said family business paid $395 million in 'immediately available funds' for 3.25 percent covertible subordinated notes (M)

headline: Battles With Shiite Rebels
abstract: American-led occupation forces battled with insurgents and militias loyal to a rebel Shiite cleric in at least four Iraqi cities, killing at least 38 Iraqis. Page 16.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Stock Offering
abstract: Brazil's Natura Cosmeticos will seek to raise up to $211 million (US) in iital public offering on Sao Paulo stock exchange in late May; hopes to sell stock between $10.85 and $12.88 per share (S)

headline: Video Shows U.S. Soldier Held by Insurgents
abstract: The Arab TV station Al-Jazeera aired video footage Friday showing a U.S. soldier in the custody of insurgents, surrounded by masked gunmen.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Russian Oil Stake Considered
abstract: French oil group Total reports first quarter earnings of 2 billion euros ($2.4 billion), down 8 percent from 2003 period; chief financial officer Robert Castaigne says Total would consider buying stake in Russian oil company Sibneft if Sibneft ends its merger plan with Yukos (S)

headline: Entertaining Miss Daisy
abstract: DVD-based entertainment systems that were originally designed for family vehicles are now being installed in all types of vehicles; video games, satellite television broadcasts and DVD movies are popular ways to spend time while traveling; photos (M)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Defense Department confirms death of one American service member in Iraq

headline: World Briefing | Asia: The Philippines: Marcos Film Blocked
abstract: Release of documentary film Imelda, about life of former Philippine first lady, is blocked by Manila court because film may depict her in negative way; Imelda Marcos accuses filmmaker Ramona Diaz of causing her stress and planning to release film without her permission (S)

headline: Ex-Chief of Freddie Mac Sues Regulator
abstract: Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight, which regulates Freddie Mac, is sued by Freddie Mac's former chief executive Leland C Brendsel for refusing to pay more than $50 million in severance payments; suit contends regulator overstepped its authority and deprived him of his constitutional right to due process when it ordered payments withheld last year; seeks court order to force office to release his severance (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Retailer's Profit Rises
abstract: Swedish retailer Hennes & Mauritz reports second-quarter net income rose 5.6 percent, to 1.76 billion kronor ($232 million); says its United States outlets were profitable, before depreciation, for first time last quarter; stock price graph (S)

headline: Infants in Chinese City Starve on Protein-Short Formula
abstract: Local scam in central China, where protein-short infant formula sickened nearly 200 babies, including at least 13 who died, has resonated into nationwide scandal; consumer protection is often nonexistent in nation where counterfeits and fakes fill shelves, particularly in poorest regions, which often become dumping grounds for cheap, unregulated goods; formula scandal has become blaring news in nation of doting parents; investigators sent by Prime Min Wen Jiabao blame illegal manufacturers around nation and say 45 brands sold in region and elsewhere are substandard; reports of problem had been percolating in city for almost year, with local officials taking no action; map; photos (M)

headline: Subject: Heard of Your Loss
abstract: Raleigh Mayer letter comments on privacy issues raised by Google's new e-mail system (April 8 article)

headline: Politicus : In Monaco, they're asking:How about a little respect?
abstract: MONTE CARLO—  Deep in its spangled and flinty heart, Monaco above all has always wanted to be legit.

headline: For Bush and Chirac, It's a Cow Connection
abstract: Pres George W Bush and French Pres Jacques Chirac strain to get along as Bush visits France for D-Day commemoration; Bush invites Chirac to visit Crawford, Tex, ranch to see some cows, perhaps without knowing that Chirac, as former agriculture minister, is a cow expert; Bush and Chirac still have differences over question of Iraqi security but seek common ground elsewhere, including need to ensure Iranian cooperation on its nuclear program; photo (M)

headline: Bush Lays Out Goals for Iraq: Self-Rule and Stability
abstract: The president outlined the administration's plans for reconstruction and for the transition of power. He also announced plans to destroy Abu Ghraib prison.

headline: IRAQ UPDATE
abstract: Iraq update; map (S)

headline: COEUR D'ALENE MINES INCREASES BID FOR WHEATON RIVER
abstract: Coeur d'Alene Mines Corp raises bid for Wheaton River Minerals, Canadian gold producer, by 11 percent (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nextel Partners Raises Profit Forecast
abstract: Nextel Partners, which sells combined mobile-phone and walkie-talkie service, raises its 2004 profit forecast (S)

headline: Israeli Army Moves on Rafah Refugee Camp in Gaza
abstract: Israeli armored bulldozers reinforced by helicopter gunships advance into Rafah refugee camp in southern Gaza Strip after Israeli troops seal camp off for what army calls large-scale operation to root out militants and weapons-smuggling tunnels; frightened Palestinians flee camp as troops and tanks draw cordon around it; other residents of camp pick through wreckage of dozens of homes smashed by Israeli forces during fierce fighting last week; raid follows killings last week of 13 Israeli soldiers in Gaza, including seven in Rafah area, and 32 Palestinians; national security adviser Condoleezza Rice offers mild criticism of Israel's demolition plan in Rafah, but European Union foreign ministers condemn action and UN Secretary General Kofi Annan appeals to Israeli government to stop destruction; photo (M)

headline: Bush Cites a Parallel With World War II
abstract: In his commencement address at the United States Air Force Academy in Colorado Springs, President Bush likened the struggle against terrorism to World War II as the historic challenge of the time and ''the storm in which we fly.''

headline: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Mandela Parks The Plane
abstract: Nelson Mandela, the Nobel Prize winner and South Africa's first post-apartheid president, said he would severely reduce his public activities, saying he wanted to spend his remaining years resting, thinking and completing his memoirs. Mr. Mandela, who turns 86 on July 18, has maintained a hectic international schedule, recently flying to Switzerland to promote South Africa's winning World Cup bid, despite increasing frailty and difficulty walking. ''I'm confident that nobody present here today will accuse me of selfishness if I asked to spend time, while I'm still in good heath, with my family, my friends and also with myself,'' he said, adding, ''Don't call me; I'll call you.''   Michael Wines (NYT)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Gambling Concern Accepts Bid
abstract: Gambling company Tab Ltd accepts rival Tabcorp's sweetened takeover bid of 2.2 billion Australian dollars in cash and stock (S)

headline: Google to Sell Type of Ad It Once Shunned
abstract: Google, Web search engine, decides to sell graphic banner ads, which it once scorned; graphic ads will not appear on Google.com for now, but will appear on sites of other Web publishers where Google sells advertising (M)

headline: Qaddafi Makes First Visit to Europe in 15 Years
abstract: The Libyan leader paraded into the heart of Europe today to announce his country's return from the diplomatic outback.

headline: A Man, a Plan, a Can: Boosting Wireless Signals
abstract: How It Works column on different types of antennas to increase range of wireless computer networks; drawings (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Uncertain Future For Airline
abstract: Alitalia auditor Deloitte & Touche warns that airline might have to consider liquidation because it has not been able to stem losses; graph (S)

headline: Small Parties Start Strong in Indonesia Vote
abstract: Election experts warned, however, that this trend was unlikely to hold in the vital rural areas where the two major secular parties have strongholds.

headline: JOHNSON & JOHNSON SPINAL DISK CLOSER TO F.D.A. APPROVAL
abstract: Johnson & Johnson moves closer to winning first Food and Drug Administration approval of artificial spinal disk, device intended to replace natural cushioning between vertebrae (S)

headline: Fellowship for the Fiber-Fixated
abstract: Jean Rutter Online Shopper column on Web sites for knitting supplies, information and discussion; drawing (M)

headline: Adelphia Pressed to Explore Possible Sale
abstract: Adelphia Communications Corp, nation's fifth-largest cable operator with 5.4 million subscribers, says it will explore possible sale of company because of pressure from its creditors; creditors say Adelphia, which is in Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings, could attract several bidders and fetch about $20 billion (S)

headline: Deutsche Telekom to Buy Some of Cingular's Networks in U.S.
abstract: Seeking to expand its presence in the U.S., Europe's largest phone company said today that it planned to buy wireless networks in California and Nevada for $2.5 billion.

headline: U.S. May Cut Third of Troops In South Korea
abstract: Bush administration gives South Korea detailed plan for withdrawing one-third of 37,000 US troops on Korean peninsula by end of 2005, as part of wider effort to reposition US forces around globe; removal of 12,500 troops would be first reduction since 1992 and would include previously announced transfer of brigade of about 3,600 soldiers to Iraq this summer; South Korean conservatives accuse Pres Roh Moo Hyun of allowing anti-American views to flourish, provoking US; photo; conservatives also say shift would surrender bargaining chip useful in nuclear arms talks with North Korea; Sec Donald Rumsfeld is reassessing strategies and new technologies worldwide

headline: Prison Interrogations in Iraq Seen As Yielding Little Data on Rebels
abstract: Civilian and military officials say questioning of hundreds of Iraqi prisoners last fall in newly established interrogation center at Abu Ghraib yielded very little valuable intelligence about insurgency that was killing American soldiers almost every day; say most of prisoners held in special cellblock that became setting for worst abuses at Abu Ghraib apparently were not linked to insurgency; say most useful intelligence came from battlefield interrogations, and at battalion, brigade and division-level interrogation facilities; Gen John P Abizaid, in Senate testimony last week, defended interrogation practices used in Iraq, saying information obtained served to save American lives; he made no specific mention of Abu Ghraib, and military officers say kind of intelligence he was referring to was obtained more often by soldiers in the field; Abizaid did make clear that intelligence-gathering effort he and Lt Gen Ricardo S Sanchez set in motion fell short of its intended goal of getting clear picture of insurgency (M)

headline: Bush Says Iraq Should Be Example for Rest of Middle East
abstract: The president wrapped up a NATO summit by urging the Middle East to "recognize the direction of the events of the day."

headline: Dynegy Ruling Set Aside
abstract: Texas Judge Bruce Oakley grants Dynegy Inc's motion to set aside $3.2 million jury award to Apache Corp in contract dispute over gas Apache says it delivered for processing; Apache to appeal (S)

headline: For Ex-Nurses, Real Money's in Takeout
abstract: Home Front article on Winsome Cunningham, registered nurse who worked in New York City hospitals for nearly 15 years until she left to open fast food restaurant; photo; she now owns three franchises of Golden Krust Caribbean Bakery and Grill; recent state survey finds 48 percent of nurses under age 52 plan to leave positions or profession in next five years because of stress (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Boeing Co., Chicago, the military contractor, said it had acquired the closely held Frontier Systems Inc., Irvine, Calif., a maker of military reconnaissance helicopters. Terms were not disclosed.    Journal Register Co., Trenton, a newspaper publisher, said it had acquired the assets of Mohawk Valley Media, Rome, N.Y., a group of nondaily publications. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Staples Plans to Replace Martin/Williams
abstract: Staples, office supply retailer, unexpectedly places in review its television creative account that has been handled by Martin/Williams (M)

headline: E-Commerce Report; A handful of marketers get personal, summoning consumers by name with customized ads on the Internet.
abstract: Visitors to Web sites like About.com, Lycos and nytimes.com will soon be shown customized ads that will address them by name, mention some of their past purchases at site and urge them to return; ads will be seen only by people who have agreed to receive electronic messages from companies they have done business with; analysts and industry executives say new approach will offer online sellers new and inexpensive way to retain customers they have spent heavily to acquire; company behind new ads is Dotomi, brainchild of Yair Goldfinger, who created technology that eventually became AOL's instant messaging service and who sees his 'direct messaging' system as kind of commercial analog to instant messaging; photo (M)

headline: Guard Left Troubled Life for Duty in Iraq
abstract: Specialist Charles A Graner Jr, who is emerging as central figure in abuse scandal at Abu Ghraib prison, had personal and work problems at home before going to Iraq; brief profile; photo (M)

headline: Hospitals Turn Off the Pagers and Find the Doctor Faster
abstract: So far, hospitals are the front line in the integration of wireless into the workplace.

headline: Mogul vs. Mavericks: A Search for Heroes
abstract: William C Taylor article says Donald J Trump, star of The Apprentice on television, and Google's founders, Larry Page and Sergey Brin, have become heroes of American business; say Trump does not deserve that status, while Page and Brin do; drawing (L)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    Today  None

headline: Senators Assail Request for Aid For the Military
abstract: Senate Democrats and Republicans attack Bush administration officials for submitting vaguely worded request to add $25 billion to pay for operations in Iraq and Afghanistan beginning Oct 1; say request lacks specific details and seeks to circumvent Senate's oversight role; Sen John McCain calls it 'blank check'; new money is in addition to $400 billion already sought for military uses worldwide in fiscal 2005; Sen Robert C Byrd predicts that Senate will approve extra money to pay for fuel, body armor, troop transportation and supplies, but with some strings attached; during contentious three-hour hearing, Democratic Sen Jack Reed accuses Deputy Defense Sec Paul D Wolfowitz of botching his job and Sen Edward M Kennedy objects to Sen John W Warner's effort to limit scope of questions to budget request; some lawmakers say some interrogation methods used in Iraq violate Geneva Conventions; Wolfowitz and Gen Peter Pace acknowledge that taken individually some of approved techniques could be interpreted as violating conventions; double-barreled jousting over two sensitive parts of Iraq policy, cost and treatment of prisoners, underscores growing unrest on Capital Hill over operations there; photo (M)

headline: Janus Agrees to Lower Fees In $225 Million Settlement
abstract: Janus Capital Group will lower fees on its mutual funds as part of $225 million settlement with regulators over improper trading in its funds; New York State Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer demanded fee reduction of $125 million over five years even though fees on Janus mutual funds are already below average; Janus also agrees to pay $100 million to compensate investors harmed by improper trading, including $50 million in restitution and disgorgement and $50 million in civil penalties; will also pay $1.2 million that will be held in trust by Colorado attorney general for consumer and investor education and to finance future actions by attorney general related to mutual funds or other consumer protection matters (M)

headline: Mac Office: Windows All Over
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column on Microsoft Office 2004 for Macintosh; includes Word, Excel, PowerPoint and Entourage, e-mail and calendar program; photo; drawing (M)

headline: Two states hire agencies to establish a broad brand identity for them.
abstract: Kentucky and Oregon are seeking to cultivate positive images, among residents as well as visitors, with ambitious advertising campaigns meant to speak with one voice for governmental departments like agriculture, business development, commerce, education and tourism; Oregon recently introduced its campaign, from Wieden & Kennedy, which carries theme 'Oregon. We love dreamers'; Kentucky selected agencies Fitzgerald & Co and New West to develop initiative to unite its disparate pitches; photo (M)

headline: Repentant? No. Bitter? Less.
abstract: Orlando Joseph Jett, banned from Wall Street trading f

headline: India's Communists Seek Capitalist Help
abstract: Buddhadev Bhattacharjee, Communist chief minister of India's West Bengal state, is using capitalist methods in effort to remake Calcutta with software parks, factories and malls as example for all India; has enacted sweeping land reforms, invested heavily in small-scale manufacturing, convinced Marxist labor unions to end constant strikes and attracted foreign investment; critics complain he has sold out party's principles, but Bhattacharjee says dogma will not work and globalization must proceed on level playing field; photo; map (M)

headline: A Flurry Of Diplomacy In Asia on Eve Of Arms Talks
abstract: Pieces in Northeast Asia's long frozen security puzzle are starting to shift as envoys from United States, China, Japan, Russia and North and South Korea converge in Beijing for midlevel talks on North Korea's nuclear arms program; changes include rumored plan for Japanese Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi to visit North Korea and planned meeting of South and North Korean army generals; moves come in face of US pressure for united front on nuclear arms program (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Auto Stake Sale
abstract: DaimlerChrysler AG confirms that it has agreed to sell its 10.5 percent stake in Hyundai Motor Co, ending four-year alliance; will sell stake, valued at $860 million, to several unidentified investors (S)

headline: Networks Speed Up Sales Talks on Ads
abstract: Big broadcast television networks pick up pace of negotiations with advertisers to sell commercial time ahead of 2004-5 season (S)

headline: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Manhattan; Bigger Home For Pfizer Takes Shape
abstract: Article on Pfizer Inc's restoration of 31-story office building it bought at 685 Third Avenue; first phase of project, 10 floors and 195,000 square feet, has been completed, with employees moving in this March; four other floors are almost complete, another is under construction, and work on additional 10 floors is scheduled to start in September; contractor is Hennegan Co; photos (M)

headline: REORGANIZATION CAUSES $93 MILLION LOSS FOR UAL
abstract: UAL Corp, parent of United Airlines, posts $93 million loss for May, mainly because of reorganizing costs (S)

headline: Rebels Flee Philippine Prison; Many Captured or Killed
abstract: Fifty-three prison inmates in the southern Philippines escaped over the weekend, but many have been captured or killed, officials said today.

headline: Patents; Cookouts without a cook, plates that stick to the table, and a way to move around a feast.
abstract: Roundup of patents awarded for inventions that make eating outside easier and more fun; drawing (M)

headline: Bush and Blair: Two Allies Who Share a Vision for Iraq
abstract: Excerpts from statements by Pres Bush and Prime Min Tony Blair on situation in Iraq and Arab-Israeli conflict (M)

headline: To Frenzied Scenes, Abu Ghraib Frees 624 Prisoners
abstract: The prisoner release was the fourth from Abu Ghraib this month and the largest since the publication of photographs showing U.S. soldiers abusing prisoners.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: JDS Uniphase Loss Narrows To $7.3 Million
abstract: JDS Uniphase Corp says its net loss in third quarter ended March 31 narrowed to $7.3 million from $136.8 million year earlier; sales fell 2.6 percent, to $161.4 million; operating expenses fell 44 percent from year earlier, to $77.3 million (S)

headline: World Markets Fall; Lows for Year in U.S.
abstract: Stock markets worldwide fall sharply as prospect of higher interest rates in US, high oil prices and war in Iraq unnerve investors; all three of Wall Street's main market gauges fall more than 1 percent to new lows for year; Dow Jones industrial average is off 4.4 percent for year while Nasdaq composite index is down 5.4 percent; Japan's main stock market falls nearly 5 percent, while South Korea's market declines 5.7 percent and Brazil's drops 5.4 percent; major European markets are off more than 2 percent; oil stocks fall after Saudi Arabia's oil minister calls on OPEC to increase output to avoid hurting global economy; price of crude oil for June delivery, which broke through $40 per barrel on May 7, falls $1, or 2.5 percent, to $39.35 in New York trading, though gasoline prices in US are at record levels and price of oil is still near 13-year high; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declines 11.58 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,087.12; Dow Jones industrial average declines 127.32 points, or 1.3 percent, to 9,990.02; Nasdaq composite index drops 21.89 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,896.07; US Treasury prices fall; 10-year note declines 5/32, to 93 27/32; yield rises to 4.80 percent from 4.78 percent; euro falls to $1.1867 against dollar from $1.1895 on prospect of higher interest rates in US; dollar rises to 113.72 yen from 112.15 graphs; charts; photos (M)

headline: Wall Street Sees a Future For a Maker Of Software
abstract: Wall Street analysts see future for software maker Computer Associates International despite recent guilty pleas by former executives for accounting fraud and obstruction of justice (M)

headline: Display of Warships Signals Hong Kong of China's Resolve
abstract: Chinese warships sailed down Victoria Harbor today as democracy advocates in Hong Kong say they face growing intimidation.

headline: Despite drops in some ratings, the broadcast networks will probably be able to raise prices.
abstract: Television broadcasters, set to present their 2004-5 prime-time schedules to advertisers and their agencies, will apparently again be able to raise rates, even though ratings for 2003-4 season among viewers ages 18 to 49 are expected to fall about 6 percent from previous season; analysts forecast revenue increases for six broadcast networks, ABC, CBS, Fox, NBC, UPN and WB, of 3 to 5 percent, to $9.6 billion to $9.8 billion, from $9.3 billion sold in upfront market in spring 2003; say cable, Hispanic TV and syndicated fare on local stations will also make gains; photo (M)

headline: Rayovac Hires 2 Grey Units for North America Batteries
abstract: Rayovac Hires 2 Grey Units.

headline: World Business Briefing | The Americas: Brazil: Unemployment Declines
abstract: Jobless rate in Brazil falls in May for first time in 2004, dropping to 12.2 percent from 13.1 percent a month earlier; real wages, which are adjusted for inflation, slip 0.7 percent (S)

headline: JOINT VENTURE TO MAKE CHEMICALS FROM BACTERIA
abstract: DuPont Co and Tate & Lyle form joint venture to make synthetic fibers with genetically modified bacteria that convert sugar into chemicals, first commercial use of process (S)

headline: Eric Mower Group Buys Price McNabb
abstract: Eric Mower Group.

headline: Beijing Asserts New Control Over Election Laws in Hong Kong
abstract: Standing Committee of China's National People's Congress approves new rules interpreting how far Hong Kong can go in pursuing greater democracy; committee official says Hong Kong government is required to work with congress before making any changes regarding how leaders are chosen, but that changes can be made 'if necessary' before next chief executive is chosen in 2007; Hong Kong's mini-constitution says chief executives elected after 2007 can be elected by more democratic means; current laws only allow committee of prominent citizens, mostly loyal to Beijing, to select candidates (M)

headline: Bush, on 'a Special Day,' Greets New Iraqi Leader
abstract: Pres Bush meets for first time with Iraq's newly designated interim president, Sheik Ghazi Ajil al-Yawar, during Group of Eight summit meeting, Sea Island, Ga; Yawar thanks him and American people for deposing Saddam Hussein; Bush, in effort to use apparent progress in Iraq as springboard to addressing broader roots of terrorism, lunches with leaders of several Mideast nations and Turkey, promoting plan to spur democracy in region; administration officials insist Mideast leaders who chose not to attend formal unveiling of plan will eventually, if reluctantly, join in Bush's efforts to use establishment of Iraq's new government to change region's political culture; Bush and other Group of Eight leaders call for new push for world trade agreement; agree on one-year moratorium on international sale of nuclear technology that could be used to produce fuel for bomb; deplore Iran's unwillingness to cooperate fully with International Atomic Energy Agency's probe of its nuclear program; discuss whether to invite China and India to join group of what is now eight big industrial and military powers; map (M)

headline: News Corp. Says Net Profit Jumped 69 Percent in Quarter
abstract: The success of Fox's "American Idol," as well as strong performances from News Corp.'s television and cable units helped drive earnings.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Copper falls on concern that demand will slow as dollar's rise against euro makes metal more costly in Europe; copper for May delivery falls 3.75 cents, to $1.3095 per pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Nortel Names A Director
abstract: Nortel Networks, which is being investigated for possible accounting irregularities, names John Manley, former Canadian finance minister and deputy prime minister, to its board; photo (S)

headline: Magazine Ads Slip Again in April
abstract: Publishers Information Bureau reports magazine advertising pages fell 0.5 percent in Apr from Apr 2003 (S)

headline: Pakistan Bombs Compounds Used by Foreign Militants, as Fighting Intensifies in Tribal Areas
abstract: Pakistani military bombs three compounds, including one that foreign militants used as terrorist training camp, in tribal areas of northwest Pakistan; Maj Gen Shaukut Sultan says as many as 50 people--15 soldiers and 35 militants--died in fighting in South Waziristan tribal area; hundreds of foreign militants, including Osama bin Laden, are believed to be hiding there (M)

headline: Oracle, Locked in Acquisition Struggle, Reports Good Quarter
abstract: Oracle Corp says profit rose 15 percent in its fiscal fourth quarter; income was $990 million compared with $858 million year earlier; revenue increased to $3.08 billion from $2.83 billion; chief executive Lawrence J Ellison comments (M)6

headline: Israeli Army Ends Weeklong Attack in Gaza
abstract: Israel withdraws its troops from Gaza Strip town of Rafah after punishing weeklong military operation; Palestinians promptly fill soccer stadium in mass funeral for many of those killed; Israeli military official describes operation as necessary and successful raid that uncovered three tunnels and eliminated large number of terrorists in Rafah; says additional operations are likely if army receives new information about weapons shipments across nearby border with Egypt, or tunnels to smuggle them; photos (M)

headline: Federal Help For United Appears to Be Less Likely
abstract: Treasury decides to keep Under Sec Brian C Roseboro, who voted against $1.6 billion in federal loan guarantees for United Airlines, as its Air Transportation Stabilization Board member, dimming chances for carrier's new bid; United reportedly weighs seeking smaller guarantee for shorter period, while seeking more private financing; Treasury and air board officials say United is down to last bid and must seriously address repayment plans to win approval (M)

headline: Allies Suspect Al Qaeda Link to Bombings in Basra; Death Toll Is Reduced
abstract: British and American military officials in Iraq say that while they have no proof, five nearly simultaneous car bombings in Basra on April 21 bear hallmaks of Qaeda terrorist network; death toll is lowered to 50, including 20 children; more than 100 people were injured; several hundred supporters of militant Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr march in streets, expressing anger and grief over bombing (M)

headline: Grab the Brass Ring, or Just Enjoy the Ride?
abstract: grab the brass ring, or just enjoy the riª

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Saudi Arabia: Cleric Condemns TV Show
abstract: Saudi Arabian lead cleric Grand Mufti Sheik Abdulaziz bin Abdullah al-Sheik proclaims that Star Academy, Arabic television show, goes against teachings of Islam (S)

headline: Europe Agrees To Let U.S. Get Passenger Data
abstract: European Union bows to pressure from US and approves deal to provide records of airline passengers to American authorities despite angry criticism by members of European Parliament who say agreement violates union's privacy laws; 25 governments in union effectively makes formal procedure in place since March 2003 that provides passenger information, like credit card numbers and addresses, to US customs officials before arrival of aircraft on American soil; US government says information speeds up immigration procedures and is needed to fight terrorism (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Apple Creates iPod Unit
abstract: Apple Computer Inc reorganizes its product development activities, creating new division for its fast-selling iPod digital music players; Jon Rubinstein will head new division; Timothy D Cook will be in charge of newly organized Macintosh division; Tim Bucher will lead Macintosh hardware engineering (S)

headline: Where the Land Is a Tinderbox, the Killing Is a Frenzy
abstract: Land disputes, worsened by religious and tribal differences, resentment against outsiders, competition for political power and overabundance of guns and frustrated young men to use them, fueled recent orgy of violence across Yelwa, central Nigerian state; reprisal attacks spread until government imposed emergency rule in mid-May; conflict resembles many others across Africa's midsection as desert has spread and population soared, intensifying competition between herders and farmers for land; photo (M)

headline: Spitzer Inquiry Expands to Employee-Benefits Insurance
abstract: Three big insurance companies, Aetna, Cigna and MetLife, say they received subpoenas from New York Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer as investigation widens into field of employee benefits--health, disability and group life insurance; Hartford, which operates substantial business in group life and disability insurance as well as in commercial and personal lines of insurance, says that it, too, received subpoena (M)

headline: Keep the Sounds to Yourself With Game Boy Headphones
abstract: Majesco introduces headphones for Nintendo's Game Boy that do not need special adapter; photo (S)

headline: Oh, Yeah, He Also Sells Computers
abstract: Profile of Apple Computer; focuses on how chief executive Steven Jobs is shifting stress from computers to products for digital way of life, like iPod digital MP3 music player; wild success of iPod comes as Apple's overall PC business grows more slowly than that of competitors; Apple faces competition from horde of consumer goods and computing companies offering computerized gadgets, but Jobs's Hollywood prominence gives him influence over how life is lived in digital age unmatched by even most powerful computer industry rivals; Apple's growth seen defined by Jobs's ability to create consumer markets, not PC sales; computer sales graph; photos (M)

headline: How to Do What He Did
abstract: Setting up wireless home explained, from essentials like routers and wireless cards to wide variety of add-ons; drawing (special section, Wireless Living) (M)

headline: Letter From the Founders
abstract: Following is a letter to potential Google shareholders from company founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin. The letter is located in Google's registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: World Briefings
abstract: EUROPE; ASIA; AMERICAS; AFRICA

headline: Character to Be Major Issue in Tyco Trial
abstract: Trial of former Tyco International chief counsel Mark A Belnick begins, and outcome may well turn more on what jurors think about his character than on facts; Belnick is charged with stealing money from Tyco in form of unauthorized bonuses and loans, and with failing to disclose payments he received; prosecutors hope to introduce evidence that they believe shows that Belnick has lied repeatedly in his personal life to try to illustrate his character; photo (M)

headline: Some Critics Of Wal-Mart Joining Forces To Change It
abstract: Union leaders, academics and community activists plan to hold unusual meeting in Washington to begin mapping out strategy to check Wal-Mart's growing power and to press company to improve its wages and benefits; meeting is organized because union leaders fear Wal-Mart Stores is pushing down wages and benefits, not just among retailers but throughout economy; Service Employees International Union president Andrew Stern convenes meeting, which will bring together union leaders, professors who have studied Wal-Mart and leaders of Acorn and other community groups; organizers also say Barbara Ehrenreich, author of Nickel and Dimed, account of making living as blue-collar worker, will attend; meeting will not focus on developing strategies to unionize Wal-Mart but rather on assessing Wal-Mart's influence on nation and on strategies to check Wal-Mart's downward pull on wages (M)

headline: Yukos Offers a Settlement to Avoid Bankruptcy
abstract: Russian oil company Yukos offers to settle government's $3.4 billion tax claim in desperate attempt to avert bankruptcy; Yukos executives write to Prime Min Mikhail Fradkov asking wether company can negotiate tax ministry's claim or sell assets to pay it off; indicate it is wiling to issue shares that could be sold to raise cash or offers as stock settlement to end legal battle with government; if court rules in favor of tax authorities, company would be forced to start making payments, outcome that Yukos has warned would cause it to go bankrupt; unusual offer comes on eve of resumption of trial of Yukos's largest shareholdes Mikhail B Khodorkovsky and Platon L Lebedev on charges of fraud and tax evasion; photo (M)

headline: NBC's 'Friends' finale is the Super Bowl of sitcoms with 30-second commercials selling for $2 million.
abstract: Finale of NBC sitcom Friends is expected to draw 50 million or more viewers, inspiring advertising industry frenzy comparable to that spurred by Super Bowl; NBC is charging average of $2 million for each 30 seconds, record for sitcom; will run programs related to Friends before and after hourlong finale with lower ad rates; advertisers are producing spots specifically for final show; photo (M)

headline: On With the Show
abstract: The Boss interview with Gary Loveman, chief executive of Harrah's Entertainment; photo (S)

headline: 2 PIPELINE BLASTS HALT OIL EXPORTS AT TOP IRAQ PORT
abstract: Two pipeline explosions in southern Iraq, one caused by bombing and other by bombing or malfunction, shut down oil exports from Basra for what is expected to be about 10 days, costing Iraq up to $1 billion in revenue; attack is most devastating so far in series of ambitious infrastructure assaults clearly intended to paralyze nation as new interim government prepares to assume formal control; snipers lining highway and overpass near Baghdad airport stage well-organized ambush on convoy, killing at least four foreign contractor workers; hundreds of furious Shiite Muslim mourners stage funeral march through Baghdad demanding vengeance against Sunnis for murder of six Shiite truck drivers in Sunni-dominated Falluja they say was ordered by Sheik Abdullah al-Janabi; Janabi denies issuing order; Iraq Revenue Watch, Open Society Institute project, charges United States-controlled board in charge of Iraqi budget until June 30 hurriedly authorized spending of nearly $2 billion of oil revenues on ill-advised projects before power switches hands; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Loss At Japan Airlines
abstract: Japan Airlines System, Asia's largest carrier, posts record loss of 88.6 billion yen ($807.2 million) in year ended Mr 31, compared with year-earlier profit of 11.6 billion yen; sales fell 7.3 percent, dragged down by international travel slump; company says it expects business travel to improve and help it return to profit (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Airline's Profit Rises
abstract: British Airways reports fourth-quarter pretax profit of 45 million pounds ($80 million) compared with loss of 200 million pounds year earlier; full-year income rose 70 percent, to 230 million pounds ($407 million); chief executive Rod Eddington warns rising fuel costs could affect future profits; photo (S)

headline: Nielsen Responds To Univision Suit
abstract: Nielsen Media Research, responding in court to Univision Communications suit seeking to stop it from changing way it measures television ratings in Los Angeles, charges that Univision tries to maintain inflated ratings for certain of its programs over those of its competitors whose ratings are rising; Univision charges that changes would undercount its core viewers in city: younger Hispanics in large families who speak mostly Spanish; members of Don't Count Us Out Coalition, group that opposes Nielsen's plans, tells Los Angeles City Council that change would cause local stations to carry fewer programs aimed at black and Hispanic viewers; News Corp, which owns stations in city, backs coalition (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Birds Eye Foods Inc., Rochester, a maker of frozen foods, said it had agreed to sell its Freshlike canned vegetable business to Allen Canning Co., Siloam Springs, Ark. Terms were not disclosed.    CBL & Associates Properties Inc., Chattanooga, Tenn., an owner of shopping malls, said it had bought a mall in Chesapeake, Va., from closely held Gregory Greenfield & Associates, Atlanta, a real estate developer, for $102.5 million in cash.

headline: WHEATON RIVER REJECTS OFFER FROM COEUR D'ALENE MINES
abstract: Wheaton River Minerals rejects $2.1 billion takeover offer by Coeur d'Alene Mines, urging its shareholders instead to approve proposed share exchange with Imagold Corp (S)

headline: An Oral History, Most of It Acidic
abstract: Comment on some of colorful phrases Sun Microsystems chief executive Scott McNealy has used over the years to describe Microsoft and its products (S)

headline: Fitness Training In the Workplace
abstract: Letter from Dr Sheila Feit says May 23 article on employer-sponsored health programs underscores need for universal, government-sponsored health program for all (S)

headline: Is It the Wrong Time For Inflation Bonds?
abstract: Advice on investing in TIPS, Treasury inflation-protected securities; some analysts say TIPS's popularity has pushed up prices so high that ordinary Treasury bonds may be better alternative; TIPS have interest rates with two components: one fixed and other tied to inflation; bond's yield and principal value eventually rise and fall with changes in inflation rate; table; photo (M)

headline: PLATINUM EQUITY WILL BUY COMPUCOM FOR $254 MILLION
abstract: Platinum Equity to buy CompuCom Systems, distributor of computer-networking products, for $254 million; will also buy preferred stock held by Safeguard Scientifics, which owns 58 percent of CompuCom, for $15 million (S)

headline: Israel to Begin Controversial Phase of Barrier Construction
abstract: Palestinians quickly denounced the move; President Bush has called the fence's route a "problem."

headline: MUTUAL FUND MANAGER TO PAY $50 MILLION FINE
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission says Massachusetts Financial Services, manager of oldest mutual fund in nation, agrees to pay $50 million penalty to settle allegations it improperly disclosed brokerage arrangements; SEC says investment company made arrangements with about 100 brokers to direct commissions on portfolio transactions toward them if brokers would highlight their funds to clients (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    Today  Construction Spending: March    Tomorrow  Factory Orders: March

headline: Buying art:A gamble at best of times
abstract: NEW YORK—  Tell an investment banker that a picture bought in 1950 for $30,000 sold this month for $104.1 million and you will be unlucky if you fail to get his attention. That was the case with the portrait of a young boy by Picasso when Sotheby's dispersed on May 5 the tail end of the famous collection formed by the late John Hay Whitney and his wife Betsy Cushing Whitney. Sales added up to almost $190 million within two hours

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Cuba And Mexico Agree To Return Ambassadors
abstract: Mexican lower house of Congress approves measure that would strike down immunity from prosecution for Mexico City's Mayor Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador; full house must radify measure for it to become law (S)

headline: Seoul Says Killing Won't Alter Plans for Iraq
abstract: South Korea says 'inhuman' beheading of Korean hostage in Iraq will not alter plans to send 3,000 more troops to Iraq this summer; government braces for protests against increasingly unpopular deployment; shock rolls through country with images of hostage Kim Sun Il, 33-year-old interpreter and evangelical Christian from Pusan (S)

headline: Google Is Said To Pick Bankers To Lead Its I.P.O.
abstract: Credit Suisse First Boston and Morgan Stanley emerge as Google's choice to lead underwriting of eagerly sought initial public offering (M)

headline: Deal to End Falluja Standoff Takes Shape; 10 Americans Die
abstract: Under the tentative plan, ex-Iraqi soldiers and officers will replace U.S. forces encircling Falluja and try to pacify rebels.

headline: Age May Trump Regionalism for Voters in South Korea
abstract: Age has replaced regionalism as single most important factor in two-week campaign leading up to parliamentary elections in South Korea on Apr 15; younger voters appear intent on voting based on issues important to their generation; results of elections will indicate what direction country will take on issues like North Korea and South Korea's security alliance with United States; campaign's defining moment may have occurred when chairman of Uri Party, which draws support from younger voters, said that older Koreans 'don't need to vote'; rivals pounced on blunder, and chairman resigned as campaign manager; photos (M)

headline: OBITUARY : Steve Williams, longtime editor
abstract: PARIS:—  Stephen Williams, 63, a longtime editor at the International Herald Tribune, died of a cerebral hemorrhage on Tuesday at a hospital in Nice.

headline: Ex-Adelphia Executive Tells Of Inflating Subscriber List
abstract: Karen Chrosniak, former director for investor relations at Adelphia Communications Corp, testifies in fraud trial of four company executives, saying company issued several false financial statements by inflating number of subscribers to its basic cable and high-speed Internet services; says Adelphia began inflating number of basic subscribers starting in early 2000 because company's growth was not keeping pace with its projections; is one of several Adelphia executives who have agreed to testify in exchange for immunity against prosecution (M)

headline: As oil tops $40, response is muted
abstract: PARIS:—  The price of oil rose above $40 a barrel on Friday for the first time since the build-up to the Gulf war of 1991, stoking concerns that global economic growth might be curbed by higher energy costs.

headline: So Much History, So Little Finance
abstract: Paul B Brown reviews Ron Chernow book Alexander Hamilton; photo (M)

headline: Federal Witness in Martha StewartTrial Is Charged With Perjury
abstract: Authorities asserted that the false testimony by an expert from the Secret Service should not invalidate Stewart's conviction.

headline: AON IS SUBPOENAED BY NEW YORK'S ATTORNEY GENERAL
abstract: Aon Corp receives subpoena from Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer of New York as part of investigation into payments between insurance companies and brokers (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    Today  None

headline: France Gets Clearance To Give Aid To Alstom
abstract: Mario Monti, Europe's competition commissioner, will approve France's aid to ailing industrial Alstom, after getting firm commitment from French government to find privately owned partners for company's main businesses; approval of more than 3 billion euros ($3.63 billion) in state aid is seen as only way of averting bankruptcy for Alstom (M)

headline: Britain Cracks Down on Nasties Like the 'Neighbor From Hell'
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair's government has enacted array of measures since 1999 to confront what is widely seen as erosion of civilized norms in Britain; about 1,600 Britons have been served so-called 'antisocial behavior orders' as part of aggressive effort by state to police behavior that would once have been purview of families or neighborhoods; authorities can fine or jail parents of children who are chronic truants, impose on-the-spot fines for defacing public property and evict 'neighbors from hell' from public housing; recipients of antisoical orders can be banned from entering certain neighborhoods or hanging out with particualr group of people--even from wearing certain clothes or visiting members of their own families; critics say new antisocial orders stigmatize and marginalize population that is already on fringes of society, leaving offenders with litle hope of improvement or rehabilitation; Home Office, in 24-hour experiment, recorded 60,000 instances of antisocial behavior; some examples cited; many in government attribute rise in antisocial behavior to emergence of social security-dependent culture that promotes feeling of entitlement but not feeling of responsibility; photo (M)

headline: KAISER SELLS STAKE IN VENTURE TO RUSSIAN ALUMINUM
abstract: Kaiser Aluminum Corp, which sought bankruptcy protection to wipe out asbestos liabilities, wins Judge Mary F Walrath's approval to sell its stake in Jamaican joint venture Alpart to Russian Aluminum for $295 million; Norsk Hydro, which owns remaining 35 percent of Alpart, has 30 days to decide whether to buy Kaiser's interest at price specified by court (S)

headline: 3 Marines Are Killed in a Roadside Bombing in Baghdad as Insurgency Continues Attacks
abstract: Three American marines are killed by roadside bomb, Baghdad, first reported deaths of American soldiers since United States formally transferred sovereignty to interim Iraqi government; two other marines are hurt in blast; Prime Min Iyad Allawi says his cabinet weights declaring state of emergency in some parts of country, news conference; insurgent group says it will free three kidnapped Turkish workers; Turkish Min Abdullah Gul says hostages have been freed (M)

headline: Telmex Plans to Buy a Stake In a Cable Operator in Brazil
abstract: Mexico's Telmex plans t

headline: Smoothing the Way To a New C.E.O.
abstract: smoothing4

headline: MediaTalk; From Walt Disney's Chief, a Reflective Letter Full of Regret
abstract: Documents released in shareholder suit against Walt Disney Co include those dealing with chief executive Michael D Eisner's unease and regrets about hiring of Michael Ovitz; 1996 Eisner letter attributes move in part to his wife's request that he get help in running company; photo (S)

headline: Low-Rated ABC Ousts Top Executives of Entertainment Unit
abstract: One month before it presents a new lineup of programs to advertisers, ABC fired both the chairman, Lloyd Braun, and the president, Susan Lyne, of its entertainment division.

headline: Concerns That Nanotech Label Is Overused
abstract: Asensio & Co, charging misuse of nanotechnology label has become favorite tactic for fraudulent stock promotion, asks New York Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer to probe Merrill Lynch for including many companies that have little or nothing to do with field in its new index of 25 publicly traded nanotechnology companies; Merrill Lynch says it probes complaint; says inclusion in index is not endorsement of stock; its analysts track only 3 of companies; Asensio chief executive Manuel P Asensio comments (M)

headline: Spare the Rolling Pin, Spoil the Mother
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column on shopping for Mother's Day gifts on Internet; drawing (M)

headline: Consumer Borrowing Slows, Defying Analysts' Predictions
abstract: Federal Reserve says borrowing by American consumers rose $3.9 billion in April, less than half rate of month before, to total of $2.03 trillion; graph (S)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: List of Americans newly confirmed dead in Iraqø

headline: Looking in the Mirror, And Finding the New Boss
abstract: Excerpts from interview with Rakesh Khurana, professor at Harvard Business School and author of Searching for a Corporate Savior: The Irrational Quest for Charismatic CEO's; he notes that overwhelming majority of chief executives are white men and says business schools, executive search firms and corporate boards all limit diversity of candidates for chief executive; finds that corporate boards of directors are most responsible for maintaining cultural homogeneity; drawing (M)

headline: Frozen in Fear? Mighty Mouse To the Rescue
abstract: Logitech's Performance Optical Mouse is faster and more reliable and designed for game playing; photo (S)

headline: CARDINAL HEALTH IN $1.6 BILLION DEAL FOR ALARIS
abstract: Drug wholesaler Cardinal Health acquires Alaris Medical Systems for $1.62 billion; Alaris makes computerized system that controls how much of a drug patient receives intravenously (S)

headline: A Montreal Magazine Is Big, Trendy and Back After 13 Years
abstract: Manoeuvres magazine has been resurrected in Montreal after 13-year hiatus; it is two feet by three feet; first oversize issues were published from 1987 to 1991, before demands of time and money became too great; Daniel Charron, co-editor and co-creator, says time seems right to bring it back; photo (M)

headline: Entr'acte : Islamic art as a bridge to understanding in West
abstract: PARIS—  Given the disturbing level of animosity between the West and much of the Islamic world, can increased appreciation of Islamic art in the West help bridge the cultural divide? Optimistic? Perhaps. But encouragingly, since the shock of Sept. 11, 2001, interest in understanding the Islamic world through its art has been growing.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Lexmark Reports 28% Profit Increase
abstract: Lexmark International, nation's second-biggest maker of computer printers, says that first-quarter profit rose 28 percent, to $121 million, on demand for new machines that combine printing, faxing and copying; graph (S)

headline: Thomas F. Willers, 84, Executive Of Paper and Chemical Concerns
abstract: Thomas F Willers, former top executive of Hooker Chemical, Occidental Petroleum and Champion International, dies at age 84 (S)

headline: A Statement Of Apology
abstract: Text of statement by Richard S Strong, which is released with announcement of $175 million settlement between regulators and Strong and Strong Capital Management (S)

headline: Comdex, the Computer Show, Canceled for Lack of Interest
abstract: MediaLive International cancels Comdex, fall computer event that was once nation's largest trade show, citing failure of industry's largest companies to take part; hopes to hold redefined show next year; show reached its peak in 2000 during Internet bubble, when 211,000 people attended (M)

headline: WATSON PHARMACEUTICALS CUTS QUARTERLY FORECAST
abstract: Watson Pharmaceuticals Inc cuts its second-quarter sales and profit estimates and says it plans to lay off half of its sales force; will close factory in Miami and end contract sales-force agreement with Ventiv Health Inc, helping to save $80 million to $90 million each year (S)

headline: Briton Defends Response on Abuse; Says Charges Are Near
abstract: The prime minister said he only recently became aware of accusations that British and U.S. troops had abused Iraqi prisoners.

headline: Gap Adds Board Member
abstract: Gap Inc names Domenico De Sole, former chief executive of Gucci Group, to its board (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Industrial Output Surges
abstract: Industrial production in Brazil rose 11.9 percent in March from year-earlier period; oputput in March rose 2.1 percent from February; production rose 5.8 percent in first quarter over three months of 2003 (S)

headline: Fed Suggests Past Won't Be a Guide For Its Moves
abstract: Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan says interest rates should rise much more slowly that in past; Greenspan, in May 14 letter to Sen Paul S Sarbanes, says central bank raised short-term rates fairly sharply when it moved to curb inflation in 1988 and 1994, and more modestly in 1999; stresses that past is no guide to future because consumer prices are climbing more slowly today and are likely to continue to do so (M)

headline: CHIEF QUITS AND SUCCESSOR IS NAMED AT NEOPHARM
abstract: NeoPharm's chief executive James M Hussey resigns and will be succeeded by Gregory P Young, who was executive at Baxter International (S)

headline: World Bank Meeting to Focus on Poverty
abstract: Top economists at World Bank will focus at annual meetings on further reducing poverty; will try to persuade wealthy nations to drastically increase their aid to developing nations and bolster programs to halt spread of AIDS and improve education in poor countries; will also wrestle with Bush administration's desire to see World Bank and other United Nations affiliates do more to smooth Iraq's transition to sovereign government; World Bank president James D Wolfensohn argues that bank and other institutions cannot do much more for Iraq until its dangerous security situation improves (M)

headline: For Google, Going Dutch Has Its Rewards And Its Risks
abstract: Experts say Google Inc's unusual plans to auction shares in its public offering, while producing highest possible offering price, has risks; say such auctions have in some cases caused speculative frenzies that hurt both investors and companies in long run; note auction structure has sometimes eliminated incentive for investors to back new and untested companies, leading to lower-than-expected prices; economists who favor auctions hold benefits far outweigh risks; drawing (M)

headline: MediaTalk; Hip-Hop Mogul Is Among Magazine's Creditors
abstract: OneWorld, urban living magazine that featured Russell Simmons as editorial director, leaves some freelance contributors unpaid when it closes; Simmons says he was not owner of magazine and is magazine's largest creditor; publisher John N Pasmore agrees Simmons is not responsible for debts; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Luxembourg: Economic Growth Accelerates
abstract: Eurostat agency reports economic growth in dozen euro nations rose 0.6 percent in first quarter; revises fourth-quarter growth to 0.4 percent from 0.3 percent; European Commission leaves its second-quarter forecast unchanged at 0.3 to 0.7 percent growth (S)

headline: Nurses Bid With Their Pay In Auctions for Extra Work
abstract: Growing number of hospitals are using auctions that allow nurses to bid for more hours in areas where they are qualified by posting offer to work available shifts at specific rate; auctions award shifts to employees who ask lowest prices for their work; system lets nurses set their own schedule and helps hospitals deal with severe nursing shortage while keeping costs in check; many nurses' unions oppose practice saying it has potential for abuse and harms nurses' image as professionals; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: ASIA; MIDDLE EAST; EUROPE; AFRICA; AMERICAS

headline: Deepening Poverty Breeds Anger and Desperation in Haiti
abstract: Life in Haiti, already poorest nation in hemisphere, has gotten worst since ouster two months ago of Pres Jean-Bertrand Aristide; mounds of garbage choke streets, electricity in capital is scarce, police are in deeper disarray and crime has spiked; Western diplomat cites concern that Prime Min Gerard Latortue's interim government will face mass unrest that could reignite violence between Aristide supporters and rebels; brevity of United States troop commitment and slow trickle of foreign aid undermine reconstruction hopes; photos (M)

headline: WITH POWER DEAL, ALCOA TO PROCEED ON BRAZIL EXPANSION
abstract: with power deal, alcoa to proceed on brazil e5

headline: Witness in Rigas Trial Dissatisfied by His Pay
abstract: James R Brown, main government witness in fraud trial of Adelphia Communications' founder John J Rigas and two of his sons, testifies that he was 'offended' that many people at company made more money than he did; Brown ends 14 days of testimony (M)

headline: Using Your Miles? Often, It's Now Double or Nothing
abstract: Business travelers are increasingly complaining about problems booking airline award travel, raising concern that airlines are quietly reducing number of seats available at standard redemption level, while promoting their costlier premium-redemption plans; Continental denies reducing number of conventional award seats for frequent fliers; graph of percentage of people in each frequent-flier program who fear their miles will have 'no value' in future; photo (M)

headline: Copter Attack Kills Rantisi and Two Others in Gaza
abstract: The attack on Dr. Abdel Aziz Rantisi today came hours after a Palestinian suicide bomber blew himself up near the crossing between the Gaza Strip and Israel.

headline: Local Broadcasters Offer Cheaper Premium Services
abstract: Companies like US Digital Television in Salt Lake City are using surplus bandwidth from local broadcasters to offer subscribers high-quality picture and premium channels over air, without need for cable or satellite, at relatively low cost; US Digital chairman and chief executive Steven R Lindsley says excess bandwidth could shift power back to broadcasters in their competition with cable; other stations are finding different ways to profit from improvements in digital signal compression that leave them with extra bandwith; photo (M)

headline: Former Tyco Counsel Testifies He Considered Stepping Down
abstract: Tyco International's former general counsel Mark A Belnick tells jurors at his criminal trial that he considered quitting months before he received $17 million bonus that prosecutors accuse him of stealing from company; prosecutors say Tyco's former chairman-chief executive L Dennis Kozlowski gave Belnick bonus in 2000 in exchange for his silence about fraud t company; Belnick says money was reward for leading Tyco through regulatory investigation (M)

headline: Henry Ries, 86, Photographer Who Captured Berlin Airlift
abstract: Henry Ries, Berlin-born photographer who fled Hitler and returned to take evocative pictures of postwar Germany, most memorably his images of Berlin airlift in 1948 and 1949, dies at age 86; photo (M)

headline: Yesterday's Back! At Last, an I.P.O. To Drool Over
abstract: Fervent interest in initial public offeri

headline: Gaza Pullout Is Endorsed, With Proviso, By Envoys
abstract: Senior envoys of United States, Europe, Russia and United Nations, meeting at UN to try to revive Mideast peace talks, give qualified backing to Israeli Prime Min Ariel Sharon's stated intention to withdraw from Gaza and part of West Bank in spite of opposition by his own Likud Party; stop short of approving plan, stressing need for Israel to negotiate with Palestinians and not confront them with unilateral steps; insist any future disposition of Israel's borders and status of Palestinian refugees who want to return to Israel must be mutually agreed to by Israelis and Palestinians; some diplomats see reversal of Pres Bush's Apr stand that Israel would not have to return to its pre-1967 borders or accept return of Palestinian refugees; State Sec Colin L Powell denies shift; envoys also deliver slap at Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, calling for 'empowered' Palestinian prime minister and reforms of Palestinian security and economic structures; photo (M)

headline: China Unveils Plan to Curb Rapid AIDS Spread
abstract: Chinese government warns that AIDS is continuing to spread rapidly in country, and announces 'urgent measures' to improve prevention and education efforts that include holding local officials directly responsible for curbing the disease; Deputy Prime Min Wu Yi, who oversees Health Ministry, cautions that China is at crucial stage because disease might soon jump from high-risk groups like prostitutes and intravenous drug users into general population; experts predict that China could have 10 million AIDS patients by 2010 if government fails to adequately fight the disease (M)

headline: Diageo Selects Grey for Tanqueray Brand
abstract: Diageo Selects Grey.
