abstract: World Business Briefi

headline: Around Iraq, Fighting and Bombs Create Grisly Scenes
abstract: A car bombing in the Adhamiya neighborhood in Baghdad killed at least 5 Iraqis and wounded 38 on Wednesday.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Phone Directories For Sale
abstract: World Business Briefing: The Netherlands:

headline: SABMILLER DROPS FIGHT FOR CHINESE BREWER
abstract: SABMiller of Britain will not counter $720 million offer from its rival, Anheuser-Busch, for Harbin Brewery of China; owns 29.4 percent of Harbin and will get $211 million from Anheuser-Busch (S)

headline: Trials of Istanbul Bomb Suspects Are Delayed
abstract: Confusion over recent change in Turkey's Constitution forces government to postpone trials of 69 men charged in connection with four suicide bombings last year in Istanbul that have been linked to Al Qaeda; government has yet to set up new security tribunal to replace state security courts that Parliament agreed to abolish; security tribunal is more in keeping with standards of European Union, which Turkey hopes to join; targets of bombings were two synagogues, British Consulate and office tower of British-owned bank; attacks killed 61 people; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Federated Department Stores will raise its dividend 8 percent, after reinstating payment last year (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Applied Materials Posts $373.3 Million Profit
abstract: Applied Materials says net income was $373.3 million in fiscal second quarter ended May 2; net income was 22 cents per share, compared to year-earlier loss of 4 cents per share, or $62.1 million; sales rose to $2.02 billion (S)

headline: Need a Superlawyer? Take a Number
abstract: Interview with

headline: G.M. Tops Expectations, but Profits Decline
abstract: General Motors reports first-quarter profit of $1.28 billion, down from $1.48 billion a year earlier, but results are better than expected, driven by record performance in its financing business, surging Asian auto sales and shrinking tax bill in United States; company raises its profit estimate for year; chart (M)

headline: They Don't Need A Ticket To Ride
abstract: Patrick McGeehan column notes corporate boards, while trying to rein in chief executive pay, allow or insist that top executives use corporate planes and cars for personal trips, usually at company expense; cites study that found large company shares fall 2 percent, on average, when companies disclose they have extended travel perquisite and underperform their market benchmarks by over 4 percent; graph of companies reporting executives' personal use of corporate jets (M)

headline: Pipe Down, PC
abstract: David Knight letter touts Apple's approach to noise generated by computers (May 27 article)

headline: Big Money in Small Fashions
abstract: Yuzo Narumiya is at center of one of most vibrant areas of Japan's retail sector with chain of shops selling high-end fashions to fashion-conscious 9-to-14-year-old girls; his company, Narumiya International, now has 850 shops in Japan; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Deals: Cisco To Buy Actona For $82 Million
abstract: Cisco Systems pays $82 million in cash for Actona Technologies Inc to increase sales of software that links offices in different locales (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Georgia: Province Hands Over Prisoner
abstract: Adzharia (Georgia) Province leader Aslan Abashidze, responding to ruling by European Court of Human Rights, releases political prisoner Tengiz Asanidze; President Mikhail Saakashvili pressures province to disarm local renegade forces (S)

headline: Europeans Punish Governments in Vote
abstract: Europeans from Estonia to Portugal also sent a strong message of apathy by largely staying away from polling stations.

headline: Earnings Fall At Times Co. But Increase At Gannett
abstract: New York Times Co and Gannett Co report newspaper advertising climate is showing steady signs of growth so far this year; Gannett reports gain in earnings, while New York Times shows decline; Times Co posts first-quarter net income of $58.4 million, down 15.1 percent from year ago, when it reported profit of $68.8 million; revenue rose 2.3 percent, to $801.9 million from $783.7 million year earlier; chief executive Russell T Lewis comments; Gannett reports net income rose 9.8 percent, to $274.4 million from $249.8 million year earlier; revenue rose 11.4 percent, to $1.73 billion; chairman-president-chief executive Douglas H McCorkindale comments (M)

headline: Demand for PC's Spurs Chip Sales, Sending Profit Up 89% at Intel
abstract: Intel reports its first-quarter profit rose 89 percent from year ago on strength of increased demand for new computers; disappoints Wall Street slightly with conservative forecast for second quarter; net income was $1.73 billion on revenue of $8.09 billion; earned $915 million on sales of $6.75 billion year earlier; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Tries to Soothe Southeast Asia on Security Initiative
abstract: Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld sought to ease fears that an initiative for the region's naval lanes might encroach on nations' sovereignty.

headline: In Clerics Base, Vows to Keep G.I.s Out, or to Die Trying
abstract: The Grand Mosque of Kufa has now become the Grand Mosque of Guns.

headline: Fuel Economy Barely Rises; S.U.V.'s Are Blamed
abstract: Environmental Protection Agency's annual fuel economy report shows fuel economy of new cars and trucks rose slightly in 2003 model year, but has remained stagnant over last five years (M)

headline: British Police Foil Airport Robbery Attempt
abstract: Scotland Yard police, acting on tip, thwart holdup by eight would-be robbers trying to steal $140 million-worth of gold and cash at Swiss Port cargo warehouse just outside Heathrow Airport, London (S)

headline: PG&E UNIT WINS APPROVAL TO EXIT BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
abstract: National Energy and Gas Transmission, power-generation unit of PG&E, wins judge's approval of plan to come out of bankruptcy protection by giving creditors control of its 21 power plants, $1 billion of notes and at least $1.2 billion of cash from sale of 1,400-mile natural gas pipeline network (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    Today  None    Tomorrow  Consumer Confidence: May  Existing-Home Sales: April

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Siemens To Expand China Operations
abstract: Siemens plans to invest 1 billion euros ($1.19 billion) in China; aims to increase production of cellphones by 40 percent by next year and double sales in China in five years (S)

headline: Greenspan Says Inflation Is Not Yet a Concern
abstract: The Fed chairman said that policy makers were watching the effect of rising energy prices on the world and U.S. economies very closely.

headline: A Demure Pixar Takes No Notice Of Eager Suitors
abstract: Pixar Animation Studios chief executive Steven P Jobs, bouyed by five wildly succssful movies, is showing surprisingly little interest in finding new partner for studio once its joint venture with Walt Disney Co ends in 2005; says he is seeking distribution-only deal, meaning Pixar will fully finance its films, negotiate its own merchandising accords and keep most of films' profits; many analysts say he would prefer to remain with Disney, particularly if it ousts chief executive Michael D Eisner; frost between companies seems to be thawing; graphs of Pixar stock price and earnings; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: National Semiconductor Sales Rise 34%
abstract: National Semiconductor Corp reports profit of $126.4 million in fourth quarter ended May 30, compared with loss of $4.4 million year earlier; sales rose to $571.2 million from $425.3 million (S)

headline: S.E.C. ELEVATES ITS INQUIRY INTO CAREER EDUCATION
abstract: Career Education Corp, operator of secretarial schools and for-profit colleges, says Securities and Exchange Commission has raised to formal probe its inquiry into charges that company inflated enrollment at two schools; its share price drops 25 percent (S)

headline: From Top of the Head to the Bottom Line
abstract: Daniel J Wakin Home Front column on business of making wigs from human hair; people buy wigs for variety of reason, among them chemotherapy and Jewish law; photo (M)

headline: Executive Quits as Turmoil Continues at Coke
abstract: Coca-Cola's general counsel Deval L Patrick resigns; interim successor will be Geoff Kelly (M)

headline: Quartet Tentatively Backs Sharon Gaza Plan
abstract: Meeting at the U.N. amid signs of growing Arab antipathy toward American policies in the Middle East, the envoys stopped short of an outright endorsement.

headline: Martha Stewart's Legal Team Requests a New Trial
abstract: Martha Stewart's lawyers request new trial, arguing that lies told by government witness Larry F Stewart prevented her from receiving fair treatment; ask for hearing to determine whether any prosecutors knew that witness was lying; lawyers for Peter E Bacanovic, Martha Stewart's broker, who was convicted at same trial as she, also request new trial (M)

headline: Katmandu Asks: Is Gyanendra Smoking as Nepal Burns?
abstract: Nepal's King Gyanendra dismissed elected prime minister and took control of government 19 months ago, promising to steady it after 13 years of erratic civilian democracy; has spent most of his time sitting in his palace chain-smoking, writing vaguely worded speeches and providing little direction; has promised to hold elections, but failed to set firm date; peace talks with Maoist insurgents collapsed in late 2003, and 2,300 people have been killed; street demonstrations demanding elections are growing; photos; map (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | People: Accenture Names New Chief Executive
abstract: Accenture names William D Green to succeed Joe W Forehand as chief executive; photo (S)

headline: U.S. Announces It Intends to Move Tons of Uranium From Sealed Baghdad Repository
abstract: US informs International Atomic Energy Agency that it intends to move hundreds of tons of uranium from repository in Tuwaitha to more secure place outside Iraq; Western diplomat says agency has taken position that uranium is Iraqi property and that it cannot give permission to remove it (M)

headline: Dick's Sporting Goods to Buy Galyans
abstract: By Reuters.

headline: U.S. PRESSES U.N. ON ROLE IN IRAQ FOR POLITICIANS
abstract: Bush administration says it presses United Nations envoy Lakhdar Brahimi to prominently include politicians, not just technocrats, in transitional Iraqi government; now doubts government of technocrats would be strong enough; says leading Kurdish and Shiite political figures, many of them members of Iraqi Governing Council, seek change; wants larger role for Adnan Pachachi and figures tied to political groups loyal to Shiite Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani; photo (M)

headline: Skin (and Mind) Care For Pregnant Women
abstract: Belli Cosmetics offers luxury skin care line for pregnant women; founder Annette Rubin seeks to develop cosmetics devoid of anything that might be remotely harmful to baby; notes some ingredients are easily absorbed through skin into bloodstream; each of her products also offers pregnancy-oriented health benefit; photo (M)

headline: China's Squeeze on Credit Shows Signs of Success as Economy Slows
abstract: Government-orchestrated credit squeeze is producing pockets of deceleration in China's economic growth, bringing inflationary pressures under control but possibly creating new headaches for government; China's consumer price index abruptly drops 0.1 percent in May from April, after rapid advances earlier this year; China runs trade surplus in May for first time in five months, as Chinese become more cautious about buying imported goods; data show breakneck growth in new loans and industrial production through spring has also slowed in May; photo (M)

headline: Milestone in Iraq
abstract: Guide to articles on milestone in Iraq on June 28; photo (S)

headline: MORE ON IRAQ
abstract: NEW STRATEGY IN SOUTH -- The Army, battling the heat (right) and a rebel cleric's militia around Karbala, is recruiting Shiite fighters to rebuild security forces.   PAGE A12    ADDITIONAL PHOTOS -- The Pentagon has decided to give Congress more pictures of the abusive treatment of prisoners, but not whether to make them public.   PAGE A8

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Shipper To Sell Shares
abstract: America Latina Logistica, largest shipping and logistics company in Latin America, says it will seek to raise up to 563.5 million reais ($180 million) in initial public stock offering on June 24, becoming third Brazilian company to sell shares to public in just over a month (S)

headline: Europe and South America Near Trade Accord
abstract: South America's biggest economies move step closer to sealing long-sought trade deal with European Union, shift that could complicate efforts to forge free trade area stretching fom Alaska to Argentina by end of year; officials from European Union and Mercosur--trade bloc that includes Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay as full members and Bolivia and Chile as associates--exchange offers over weekend in Buenos Aires with eye on closing deal by October; talks also manage to make progress in agriculture, sector that has proved to be deal breaker repeatedly in global trade talks; photos (L)

headline: Sharon's 'Big Bang'
abstract: Missile strike in Gaza City that killed Dr Abdel Aziz Rantisi suggests Israeli Prime Min Ariel Sharon is eager to weaken Hamas and demonstrate that he is not running from fight even he is planning to unilaterally pull out of Gaza; Sharon needs to win support for withdrawal plan within Likud Party, where some members have accused him of caving in to terrorism; Likud is set to vote on plan in May 2 party referendum (M)

headline: Powell's Interview Is Cut Off
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell was abruptly cut off for a few seconds by an aide during an interview on Sunday on the NBC News program "Meet the Press."

headline: Executive Pay Increases at Cablevision
abstract: Charles F Dolan, chairman of Cablevision Systems Corp, received 2003 pay package, not including stock options, of about $12 million, up from about $2.2 million previous year; compensation for Cablevision's chief executive, James L Dolan, rose to about $16.4 million from less than $2 million in 2002 (S)

headline: SECURITY COUNCIL BACKS RESOLUTION ON IRAQ TURNOVER
abstract: UN Security Council votes unanimously in favor of US-British resolution to end formal occupation of Iraq June 30 and transfer 'full sovereignty' to interim Iraqi government; resolution gives international legitimacy to caretaker government, outlines UN role and authorizes US-led force to take all necessary measures to bring peace, in partnership with Iraqi forces; major success for Pres Bush is sharp contrast with bitter divisions over war; Amb John Negroponte and Sec Colin Powell welcome vote; photos (M)

headline: Bank Money Accounts
abstract: Annual percentage yields, in percent, on money market accounts, three-month certificates of deposit and six-month C.D.s expected at selected institutions on Wednesday, March 31, 2004. Yields are based on the method of compounding the interest rate stated for the lowest minimum to open an account, but minimums may vary. Higher yields may be offered for larger deposits. C.D. figures are for fixed rates only. Rates subject to change without notice.

headline: Iraqi Official Says U.S. Raid Aimed to Kill Foreign Rebels
abstract: Senior Iraqi official, speaking on condition of anonymity, says 23 of 26 people killed in American airstrike in Falluja were foreign terrorists, including men from Algeria, Saudi Arabia and Yemen; American officials had said that six homes singled out were being used by agents of Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, one of most wanted terrorists in Iraq and suspected mastermind of dozens of suicide attacks; Iraqi official acknowledges that three Iraqis were killed and two were wounded; says it is not clear if Zarqawi was inside one of homes, but that homes did house terrorists; photo (M)

headline: Cisco Profit For Quarter Slightly Beats Estimates
abstract: Cisco Systems reports profit in its fiscal third quarter ended May 1 that narrowly exceeds investor expectations; chief executive John T Chambers suggests that corporate spending on technology appears to be gaining momentum; company reports net income of $1.2 billion, up 23 percent from $987 million year earlier; sales rose 22 percent, to $5.62 billion from $4.62 billion year ago, and up slightly from $5.4 billion in second quarter; photo (M)

headline: Don't Have $1 Million? Will Take $25,000 Now
abstract: Financial firms are having easy time selling new breed of managed accounts, which previously required $1 million minimums, for as little as $25,000 to $100,000; big allure of these accounts is that they let investors own securities directly, instead of pooled in classic mutual fund setup; investors can also instruct managers to exclude certain stocks or even entire sectors; accounts also provide allocation and rebalancing advice; graph compares returns of managed accounts with $100,000 and under with those of far larger accounts; drawing (M)

headline: Q & A
abstract: Q. Our computers are connected to the Internet by a cable modem and a Linksys wireless access point. I want to buy a new cordless phone, but I am worried that it may disrupt the network. Are there cordless phones that use a frequency that will not interfere with the wireless network?    A. The most common wireless networks for home users, 802.11b and g, can sometimes interfere with some cordless telephones because they use the 2.4-gigahertz frequency to broadcast signals from the base station to a computer or handset. Other devices like baby monitors or older microwave ovens can also disrupt a wireless network. Although interference from other electronic products may not block the wireless network signal entirely, it can make the network slow and balky.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bankruptcies Decline
abstract: Number of companies in Japan filing for bankruptcy drops 20 percent in May from same month year earlier; debts left by failed companies fell 33 percent from last year (S)

headline: Rome Journal; Footnote to a Royal Affair: Mr. Simpson's Teary Moment
abstract: Rome Journal on Christie's auction of Duchess of Windsor memorabilia, including 14 love letters from Edward VIII and letter from her former husband, Ernest Simpson; photos (M)

headline: 9 Palestinians Killed by Israelis In Second Day of Gaza Fighting
abstract: Israeli troops in armored vehicles kill 9 Palestinians and wound about 25 in second day of running clashes in northern Gaza Strip; Israeli operation seeks to stop Palestinian rocket fire, which intensified after Israelis killed Hamas leader Abdel Aziz Rantisi (M)

headline: Spanish Candidate for I.M.F. Director Seeks African Support
abstract: Former Spanish Finance Min Rodrigo Rato hopes to succeed Horst Kohler as new managing director of International Monetary Fund; has European and American support as well as endorsement of Latin American countries, which are largest IMF borrowers; is seeking support of African countries; there is concern in developing countries that selection process is too elitist; photo (M)

headline: Will China Buy the Giants or France Acquire the Yankees?
abstract: Market Place column on disclosure that Thailand's Prime Min Thaksin Shinawatra plans to use state money rather than his own to become part owner of Liverpool soccer club; notes criticism that disclosure has provoked in both countries (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Bush Supports Sharon's Plan to Withdraw From the Gaza Strip
abstract: President Bush, in a significant shift in American policy, said the U.S. would not object if Israel retained some West Bank settlements under a future peace accord.

headline: Sharon Says He Has Ordered a Halt to Gaza Development
abstract: Prime Min Ariel Sharon, in message Israeli officials say is intended to reassure Bush administration, says he has given orders to halt development of Jewish settlements in Gaza Strip in step toward eventual Israeli withdrawal; says he will not be deflected from his withdrawal plan by corruption inquiry that could result in his indictment; hundreds of Israeli police officers clash with thousands of Palestinians in Jerusalem in largest eruption of violence there since Palesinian uprising began in Sept 2000 (M)

headline: Chicago Agency Names New Creative Executive
abstract: Chicago Agency Names.

headline: First-Quarter Profit Rose 9.4% at SunTrust
abstract: SunTrust Banks reports that first-quarter profit rose 9.4 percent, to $358.5 million (S)

abstract: Data released by Thai governmeï

headline: Omnicom Unit Wins Top Creativity Prize
abstract: TBWA/Chiat/Day wins Grand Prize Kelly Award at annual Kelly Awards for creativity in magazine advertising (S)

headline: Banking On the Pleasure Principle
abstract: Condom makers are refocusing their ad campaigns to sell condoms as pleasure boosters, not just health necessity; are selling benefits of additives like benzocaine, mild anesthetic, to add to man's endurance; photo (M)

headline: Finally, an Old Dog That Can Learn New Tricks
abstract: German researchers working with nine-year-old border collie named Rico say he can listen and learn like human child, using 'fast mapping' reasoning to deduce name of new toy and pick it out from group of familiar objects; photo; Dr Julia Fischer explains (M)

headline: LAWMAKERS VIEW IMAGES FROM IRAQ
abstract: Lawmakers who viewed hundreds of images of mistreatment of Iraqi prisoners say photos were more graphic than they expected, and included pictures of forced sexual acts between male detainees, soldier posing with body of dead prisoner, and consensual sex between American soldiers; lawmakers emerge from viewing shaken and aghast; say they could not tell where pictures were taken, but images of mistreatment appear to be confined to Abu Ghraib prison because people in photo are ones seen in photos released to public; Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld defends interrogation techniques used in Iraq, saying Defense Dept lawyers deemed them to be consistent with Geneva Conventions; Sen Richard Durbin disputes this claim; explicit nature of photographs leaves lawmakers deeply conflicted over whether images should be made public; even some who previously favored public release, like Sen Charles E Schumer, say they changed their minds after military personnel said public release would violate prisoners' right to privacy and protection from humiliation under international law; photos (M)

headline: Pop-Up Ad Company Plans an Initial Stock Offering
abstract: Claria Corp, known for its online pop-up ads and tracking applications, plans initial public stock offering; hopes to raise up to $150 million (M)

headline: Spain Says It Has Arrested 3 More Suspects in Train Bombings
abstract: Spain's conservative government, on its last day before turning over power to Socialists, announces arrests of three more Islamic suspects in Madrid train bombings; Socialist Party leader Jose Luis Rodriguez Zapatero is officially endorsed by Parliament as next prime minister; photo (M)

headline: Organize From A to Z At the Back of a Book
abstract: Q. I am interested in creating an index for a book proposal as well as a book. Is there a program designed specifically for writers and researchers doing this sort of work?    A. There are several ways to create a book's index, depending on the level of detail needed and the program you use. Some word-processing programs let you embed index entries within the manuscript. In addition to all-around database programs, there are software programs dedicated solely to making book and periodical indexes, and there are index utility programs that you can add to your word-processing program.

headline: Cut-Rate Calling, By Way of the Net
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column on voice-over-Internet protocol, which gives users option of using Internet's wiring for telephone calls at cheaper rates than telephone company; service utilizes conventional telephone, computer does not have to be on, is exempt from line charges and certain other fees, and is portable; drawbacks include being off telephone company's grid and losing access to any services it provides; chart shows services and prices; drawing; photos (M)

headline: I.B.M. and Cisco Planning Joint Internet Phone Venture
abstract: IBM and Cisco Systems plan to joint development project to expand their reach into Internet telephone market, with Cisco providing phone and network technology and IBM contributing software and integrating systems (M)

headline: U.N. Rights Chief Says Prison Abuse May Be War Crime
abstract: Report by Bertrand Ramcharan, United Nations acting high commissioner for human rights, concludes that mistreatment of Iraqi prisoners by US soldiers could constitute war crime, and calls for immediate naming of 'international ombudsman or commissioner' to oversee situation (M)

headline: O.K., Investors, Who's Afraid of a Rate Increase?
abstract: Jonathan Fuerbringer column on impact of Federal Reserve interest rate rises on stock prices; notes Fed can contain damage to stock market by convincing investors that its rate increases will be gradual; graph comparing changes in stock prices and federal funds rate (M)

headline: White House, With Support, Vows to Finish Mission in Iraq
abstract: The White Houses statement was buoyed by support from a Democratic rival and a maverick Republican.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Debate Rises In Argentina On Museum Of Abuses
abstract: Debate is raging about content of Argentina's proposed Museum of Memory, honoring those who were persecuted, tortured and killed during country's military dictatorships; Pres Nestor Kirchner supports proposal for museum put forth by Center for Legal and Social Studies, but Mothers of the Plaza de Mayo does not; they contend it is too soon to set up museum, because historical events in question are too recent; also at issue is starting date for country's so-called dirty war (M)

headline: Bush and McCain, Together, Call Iraq War a Conflict Between Good and Evil
abstract: Sen John McCain and Pres Bush, in speeches to thousands of soldiers in Fort Lewis, Wash, present unusual joint defense of war in Iraq; call war conflict between good and evil that threatens existence of US; united front of president and his old political nemesis is striking development at time when Bush is under political siege for stating that ties between Iraq and Al Qaeda justified going to war against Saddem Hussein (M)

headline: Steady, Ready, Shoot: Making a Camera Hold Still
abstract: How It Works column on high-power telephoto lenses with built-in image-stabilization features that eliminate blurry photographs resulting from camera shake; photos; illustration shows how system works (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Citing Drop in Stock Price, Oracle Cuts PeopleSoft Bid  Oracle reduced its cash offer to acquire PeopleSoft to $7.7 billion from $9.4 billion, saying the decision reflects the decline in PeopleSoft's share price since it first announced its hostile takeover bid last June.       Oracle's decision to lower the bid to $21 a share from $26 comes as lawyers for Oracle and the Justice Department prepare to meet in court after the agency's decision to sue to block the deal. [Page C2.]

headline: Witness Says Ex-Tyco Lawyer Cooperated in S.E.C. Inquiry
abstract: Lewis Liman, lawyer who represented Tyco International, says Tyco's former general counsel Mark A Belnick cooperated with 2000 Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into company's accounting; is called by prosecutors to tell jurors about information lawyers discovered about improper financial dealings by Belnick's boss, L Dennis Kozlowski, chief executive at time; prosecutors contend Belnick received $17 million bonus for covering up for Kozlowski (M)

headline: Iraqi Ayatollah Cautiously Acknowledges New Government

abstract: Ryan Holtz letter says he is offended by characterization of Internet Relay Chat network as one primarily for pirating copyrighted material (May 6 article)

headline: Reality TV Hits (Further) Below the Belt
abstract: Producers of NBC's planned boxing reality show The Contender charge both Fox network and Endemol, production company behind planned rival show The Next Great Champ, stole idea, which Fox had access to because every network bid on The Contender; Fox show is now expected to get on air first, in apparent bid to undercut NBC show; nasty dispute pits Contender producers Mark Burnett and Jeffrey Katzenberg against Fox officials Peter Chernin and Gail Berman; other prominent reality producers cite need to change way they do business to protect their ideas; some charge Fox with setting standard for ripping off reality ideas; photos (M)

headline: Bookstores Report Profits
abstract: Barnes & Noble and Borders reported first-quarter profits, helped by sales of best sellers.

headline: Office Politics Give Liberal Radio a Rocky Start
abstract: Air America Radio's first two months of broadcasting have been convulsive; fledgling talk-radio network has replaced five top executives, been taken off air in two of its top three markets and lost several crucial producers; current and former executives agree that company is perilously close to running out of money, although it has received infusion of cash from unidentified source; Al Franken, network's best-known star, says he has agreed not to draw salary temporarily; turmoil has laid bare mismatched collection of managers and investors, including Democratic Party fund-raisers, Internet entrepreneurs and radio veterans who do not get along well; photos; map (M)

headline: Nortel Fires 3 Executives Amid Accounting Inquiry
abstract: North America's largest telecommunications equipment maker fired its chief executive chief financial officer and its controller today.

headline: Sand, Rough Roads and Insurgents' Bullets Place a Tremendous Strain on Army Equipment
abstract: Gen Paul J Kern, Army's chief logistician, warns that army is wearing out equipment in Iraq and Afghanistan ten times faster than in peacetime; crippling shortages have been avoided, but supply system is just keeping pace with demands as attacks on convoys in Iraq cut flow of supplies to 70 percent of capacity; suggests Army make permanent recent temporary increase of 30,000 soldiers if current supply levels are to be sustained; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: INDIA: New Attack On An Election Rally; CHINA: Tiananmen Leader Ill In Hunger Strike;.

headline: Small Parties Start Strong in Indonesia Vote
abstract: Indonesia's elections for new Parliament proceed smoothly, with early and unofficial counts from polling places in Jakarta showing surprising strength for two small parties, including an Islamic party (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Miners' Hunger Strike
abstract: 160 miners in Khakassia Siberia (Russia) resume hunger strike begun in April to protest unpaid wages of around $7,000 each; criminal proceedings are in progress against RIA-Novosti mine administration (S)

headline: Bosnian Jew Promotes Inquiry Into Causes of the 1990's War
abstract: Jacob Finci, leader of Sarajevo's Jews and director of Bosnian civil service agency, hopes to form commission to investigate causes of 1990's war in Bosnia that killed 200,000 and displaced more than one million people; is seen as fair arbiter between Muslims, Serbs and Croats; Finci hopes to base commission loosely on model of South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, but has met with little enthusiasm from any of involved parties (M)

headline: Russia Drops Objection to U.N. Inquiry Into Oil Program
abstract: Russia dropped its objection today to a proposed investigation of the United Nations scandal-ridden oil-for-food program.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Tax Incentives
abstract: Thailand's Finance Min Somkid Jatgusripitak says cabinet approved tax incentives that it hopes will steady Thailand's stock market by attracting longer-term investments (S)

headline: Friends and Relatives Rally as a Top Russian's Bribery Trial Inches Forward
abstract: Hearing in Moscow court moves Mikhail Khodorovsky closer to trial, eight months after oligarch was arrested at gunpoint on Siberian airfield, charged with defrauding government and evading taxes; family and friends appear in court to show support; photo (M)

headline: Treasury Bills Set For This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow. A 12-day cash management bill is also scheduled to be auctioned on Tuesday.    According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 1.07 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 1.38 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 0.92 percent.

headline: INTERPUBLIC PAYS $93 MILLION TO QUIT RACING ACCOUNT
abstract: Interpublic Group of Companies will pay $93 million to end contract to promote British Grand Prix, another step toward exiting its unprofitable auto-racing business (S)

headline: Reports of Massive Blast Emerge From Secretive North Korea
abstract: Hundreds were killed and injured when two trains loaded with fuel collided, only hours after North Korea's leader had passed by, according to reports in South Korea.

headline: Airlines Are Looking at a Long, Hot Summer
abstract: Airline industry is beginning to see what was supposed to be promising year slip away, because of rising fuel costs, brutal competition and its own lingering financial problems; Delta Air Lines says it lost $387 million in first quarter, kicking off what analysts fear will be string of poor quality results for major airlines; some industry analysts say first-quarter losses could reach $1 billion or more for carriers, even though traffic is rebounding to levels last seen before Sept 2001 terrorist attacks; Delta's chief executive Gerald A Grinstein pushes for concessions from Delta's pilots, whom he calls 'major boulder' blocking competitiveness; Continental Airlines is pulling back on its forecast of break-even year; Air Transport Association says each 1-cent increase in price of fuel, now over $1 per gallon, costs airline industry $180 million; graph; chart (M)

headline: The Times to Start Companion to Magazine
abstract: New York Times will introduce companion publication called T: The New York Times Style Magazine to its Sunday magazine this summer to concentrate on fashion, designing and entertaining; new magazine will be published eight times each year and will replace current Part 2 publications; Sophisticated Traveler magazine will continue to be published quarterly (S)

headline: EUROPEAN ELECTIONS 2004 : In France, the EU election is looking for a spark
abstract: PARIS:—  There are humbling moments in every political campaign when tedium gives way to cold clarity. So it was that Alain Lipietz confronted the brutal truth about his stature as a veteran European Parliament member from France.

headline: Caste System Binds Nepalese Prostitutes
abstract: Caste has become destiny for many communities, but few people have inherited so vexed a destiny as the Badis of Nepal, who work as prostitutes.

headline: U.S. Offers North Korea Aid if It Phases Out Nuclear Program
abstract: The North Korean delegation, which put forward its own plan at talks today, had no immediate reaction to the American offer.

headline: Annual Cancer Conference Becomes Laboratory for Stocks
abstract: Annual meeting of American Society for Clinical Oncology in New Orleans has become most important medical meeting of year for biotechnology industry and its investors; shares of ImClone Systems rise as investors respond to study of its Erbitux cancer drug that were reported over weekend at annual conference; shares of biotechnology company Telik rise 90 cents as data show its drug Telcyta had impressive effectiveness against ovarian and lung cancer when combined with chemotherapy in small, uncontrolled trials; shares of Genentech and OSI Pharmaceuticals drop, partly because results were not as good as some investors expected (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Trade Group Cancels Advertising Awards
abstract: National Television Academy of Arts and Sciences aburptly cancels plans to present new honors that would have been called Advertising Awards for Excellence; says there were too few entries (S)

headline: A.M.A. Adds Its Voice to Call For Disclosure On Drug Trials
abstract: American Medical Association adopts resolution urging Health and Human Services Department, which oversees Food and Drug Administration, to create database in which all clinical drug trials performed in US will be registered at outset of trials; AMA says it is taking action because of concerns that drug industry sponsorship of such tests is affecting quality and because companies, as well as medical journals, tend to spotlight tests with positive findings, compared with those having negative or inconclusive results (M)

headline: Banks Warn Yukos Oil Of Default
abstract: Banks W

headline: Supreme Court Declines To Extend Phone Pricing Rule
abstract: Supreme Court declines to extend rules that require four regional Bell telephone companies to lease their networks at deep discounts to rivals in local markets (M)

headline: Bond Buyers May Want To Note This Birthday
abstract: View of James Grant, publisher of Grant's Interest Rate Observer, that bear market in bonds began one year ago discussed; factors likely to influence markets this week noted; graphs (M)

abstract: EBay Inc says first-quarter earnings surged 92 percent, to $200.1 million; sales rise 59 percent, to $756.2 million (S)

headline: Talkative Chief Complicates An Offering By Salesforce
abstract: Salesforce.com says that it might be forced to buy back shares it planned to sell in initial public offering if company were found guilty of violating federal rules because of remarks by chief executive Marc Benioff quoted in article in New York Times on May 9; Salesforce, in statement filed with SEC, says that Benioff might have violated provision of Securities Act of 1933 that severely limits what a company can say publicly in months leading up to stock offering; Salesforce, which filed to go public last December, was still in so-called quiet period when Benioff spoke at length with reporter for Times article; Benioff photo (L)

headline: TV and Radio Move to Address Complaints
abstract: The National Association of Broadcasters said that it would form a task force to study how best to insure that its member stations will offer only responsible programs.
