headline: After a Violent Week, Israel to Step Up Gaza Patrols
abstract: Senior Israeli official says Israel will widen army-patrolled zone at southern end of Gaza Strip near border with Egypt, step that will involve demolishing many Palestinian buildings; says step is necessary to protect Israeli soldiers who hunt for Palestinian smuggling tunnels in area, where five soldiers were killed recently; photos (M)

headline: Day 11 Brings More Inquiries From Tyco Jury
abstract: Jurors in the trial of former Tyco International executives L Dennis Kozlowski and Mark H Swartz appear to be focusing on stock fraud charge as panel ends its 11th day of deliberations without verdict (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Petition Ruling Near
abstract: Former US President Jimmy Carter, who is acting as monitor of opposition drive to recall Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez, holds that electoral officials will rule shortly on validity of signatures needed to force recall referendum (S)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Nuclear Inspectors Arrive
abstract: Five International Atomic Energy Agency inspectors arrive in Tehran to confirm cessation of uranium enrichment activities in Iran (S)

headline: 3 Car Bombings Kill 20 People In an Iraqi City
abstract: Three car bombs explode in front of Iraqi police stations in Basra, killing about twenty people and wounding more than 60; morning blast hits school bus, burning schoolgirls inside; attacks come day after insurgents fire mortar rounds into Abu Ghraib prison near Baghdad, killing 22 prisoners and wounding 92; US marines allow fifty families to return to Falluja as step toward permanent cease-fire, although there is no sign that local civil leaders can get insurgents and foreign fighters to disarm; Lt Gen Ricardo Sanchez orders phased pullback around Najaf to avoid major firefight that would anger powerful Shiite clerics who have pressured Moktada al-Sadr to return control of city to Iraqi police (M)

headline: Economic Growth Swells Trade Deficit to Record $46 Billion
abstract: The U.S. trade deficit expanded in March as a strong economy stoked demand for foreign-made goods and oil prices surged.

headline: In Mideast Aviation, Vying to Be New Global Hub
abstract: Business and leisure travel in Middle East and South Asia has surged, heating up regional competition and spurring multibillion-dollar expansions of Persian Gulf carriers and airports; Middle East accounts for only about 5 percent of world air transport market, and most of its airlines, including Saudi Arabian Airlines, are clunky, poorly managed operations controlled by state; passenger traffic in region ended in November grew 5.4 percent, compared with worldwide traffic increase of 2.1 percent; plane takeoffs and landings grew 10.3 percent, compared with worldwide decline of 0.6 percent; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Investigating G.I.'s Killing of Iraqi
abstract: US military starts investigation into killing of Iraqi man by soldier on May 17 in Baghdad (S)

headline: In 5th Day Of Gaza Raid, A Girl, 3, Is Shot Dead
abstract: Palestinian officials say Israeli soldiers killed three-year-old girl during raid on Rafah refugee camp in Gaza; raid, in fifth day, is in response to killing of Israeli soldiers in Gaza; is designed to cut off arms smuggled through tunnels from Egypt and to hurt local militants; photo (M)

headline: Mountain Dew Double-Dose For Times Square Passers-By
abstract: PepsiCo has started advertising campaign to reinvigorate its Mountain Dew soft drink brand, which has lost momentum; has erected adjacent billboards in Times Square; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Studio Sells Shares
abstract: Pinewood Shepperton Studios, which operates movie studios, raises 75 million pounds ($134.6 million) in initial public offering (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Current Account Grows
abstract: Japan's current account surplus grew 13 percent in March from month earlier, for ninth straight increase; surplus rose to 1.83 trillion yen ($16 billion) as exports to China and other Asian countries increased; over all, Japanese exports rose 13 percent, to 5.17 trillion yen ($45.3 billion), while imports rose 11 percent, to 3.83 trillion yen (S)

headline: Deck, Den, Home Theater and Now, the Pec Room
abstract: Advice on gym equipment for exercising at home; some $4.7 billion was spent on home exercise gear in 2003; table of factors to consider; photo (M)

headline: Europeans Delay Enforcement of Order Against Microsoft
abstract: European Commission says it will not enforce June 28 deadline for ordering Microsoft to start selling version of its Windows operation system in Europe that is not bundled with Media Player (S)

headline: DDB New York Hires Executive From Gap
abstract: Flagship New York office of DDB Worldwide hires Peter Hempel, Gap Inc executive, as executive vice president and managing director (S)

headline: A Corporate Quandary Over Raising Prices
abstract: Labor Department reports Consumer Price Index rose 0.5 percent in March from February and three-month trend that would translate to annual inflation rate of 5.1 percent; numbers convince many economists that Federal Reserve will raise interest rates this summer to forestall inflationary burst; while inflation is strong in many service industries, other businesses, mainly those in manufacturing sector, have been unable to pass along rising costs for materials; graph; photo (M)

headline: 14 Afghans Are Killed for Registering to Vote
abstract: Suspected Taliban fighters carry out their most lethal attack yet in widening campaign to derail Afghan elections; 14 unarmed men in province of Uruzgan are executed after registering to vote; this follows bombing of bus carrying female election workers in Jalalabad; bombing killed two women and injured 13 others; twin attacks mark new level of brutality and may increase pressure on NATO leaders meeting in Istanbul to commit additional troops to secure elections, which are scheduled for Sept (M)

headline: CBS Bid Wins Rock Star Reality Show
abstract: CBS wins bidding war for producer Mark Burnett's latest reality show, tentatively titled Rock Star; show will feature contestants vying to be new lead singer for rock group INXS (M)

headline: U.S. Begins Transfer of a Shaky Haiti to U.N. Hands
abstract: United States military commanders begin turning over Haiti to United Nations contingent that will try to lead anarchic nation toward elections; photos (M)

headline: Starbucks Selects Wieden & Kennedy
abstract: Starbucks Selects.

headline: Executive Pay: A Special Report; For Directors, Great Expectations (and More Pay)
abstract: Article in special report on executive pay focuses on increased workload and pay of corporate directors, who also face increased risks; compensation experts expect further pay gains for directors, mostly in cash, with stock component remaining stable; see pay likely to be linked to committee work, reversing recent trend to eliminate extra pay for attending committee meetings; photo (M)

headline: Bush Supports Sharon's Plan to Withdraw From the Gaza Strip
abstract: International Herald Tribune.

headline: Diversify! Diversify! Well, Not So Fast
abstract: Mark Hulbert column on new stuÿ

headline: Volkswagen Workers on Strike in Brazil
abstract: Workers at Volkswagen plan in Sao Jose dos Pinhais, Brazil, will continue a strike that began May 19 after negotiations to reduce working hours stall (S)

headline: Click Me Up, Scotty
abstract: Tom Byrne letter comments on use of wireless keypads to answer questions posed by professor in college classes (April 29 article)

headline: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Mine Strikers Fired
abstract: Impala Platinum Holdings Ltd, South Africa, fires 1,700 workers who struck at its main mine; rock drill operators strike to protest working conditions (S)

headline: Failures on Terrorism Will Help Shape Tenet's Legacy
abstract: Notion that Osama bin Laden is still on loose while new groups arise from wreckage of his Al Qaeda organization underscores how much unfinished business remains in war on terror as George Tenet departs as director of central intelligence; his resignation serves as reminder of CIA's greatest failures: not producing specific information that might have prevented 9/11 attacks, and providing faulty evidence about weapons of mass destruction in Iraq; judgment of history on his service at CIA may ultimately be decided by how agency continues to wage fight against terrorism under his successor; his career at CIA recalled, including his rebuilding of agency after cold war; photos (M)

headline: MAKER OF TWINKIES SAYS IT MAY HAVE TO RESTATE RESULTS
abstract: Interstate Bakeries, maker of Wonder bread and Hostess Twinkies, says costs for worker compensation insurance, primarily in California, has risen so fast that it may have to restate results (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Fertilizer Concern Forecasts Gain
abstract: Potash Corp, world's largest fertilizer producer, says second-quarter earnings will be about quarter higher than expected; graph (S)

headline: 2 Outsiders to Join Board, MBNA Official Says
abstract: MBNA Corp names outsiders Mary M Boies and Laura S Unger as new directors; succeed board members Norma Lerner and Michael Rosenthal, who are resigning (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago       Prime rate   4.00   4.00   4.25       Federal Funds   1.00   1.00   1.24       3-month Libor   1.19   1.18   1.29       3-month T-bills   1.04   0.97   1.08       6-month T-bills   1.29   1.17   1.11       10-yr. T-infl.   2.23   2.10   1.92       10-yr. T-note   4.78   4.60   3.68       30-yr. T-bond   5.47   5.37   4.67       Telephone bd.   6.46   6.48   5.64       Municipal bds.   5.21   5.13   4.73          (Sources by Bloomberg News; Telerate; The Bond Buyer; British Bankers' Assoc.)

headline: Oil-for-Food Inquiry Wins Russian Backing; Volcker to Take Over
abstract: Russia drops objection to proposed investigation of scandal-ridden UN oil-for-food program in Iraq, clearing way for Paul A Volcker to lead inquiry into corruption and cover-ups; GAO report says Saddam Hussein's government pocketed more than $10 billion, and Iraq documents suggest that UN officials, notably Benon V Sevan, may have benefited personally (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: World War II Mass Grave Found
abstract: Poisk, group that locates remains of Nazi victims, reports discovery of mass grave in Crimea (Ukraine) that may contain as many as 2,000 bodies; group member Vassyl Rydka reports that finding appears to be mainly older adults and children shot in back of head (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Retailer's Sales Rise
abstract: British supermarket chain Tes

headline: Corrections; CORRECTION
abstract: Correction: picture caption with May 2 article on Marsh & McLennan Cos reversed identities of two executives and gave outdated title for one of them0

headline: Timberland Account To Arnold Worldwide
abstract: Timberland names Arnold Worldwide as global ad agency of record on creative and branding parts of its account; billings estimated at $10 million; account has been handled by Fallon Worldwide (S)

headline: Executive Life; These Career Coaches Are Learning, Too
abstract: these career coaches a

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Earnings Revision
abstract: Credit Suisse restates its 2003 earnings to 770 million Swiss francs ($593 million) from 5 billion Swis francs after switching from Swiss accounting standards to generally accepted accounting principles used by most corporations in US; graph (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Iranian Arrested In Arms Find
abstract: Marseille (France) police arrest Iranian man possessing large supply of arms in home, including 15 pounds of explosives and assault rifle (S)

headline: A Decade After Massacres, Rwanda Outlaws Ethnicity
abstract: Government of Rwanda sets up six-week re-education camps to purge former Hutu and Tutsi fighters of any ethnic ideologies that they may still harbor from 1994, when extremist Hutu massacred 800,000 Tutsi and moderate Hutu; government, now dominated by minority Tutsi, has wiped out ethnic distinctions by decree; photos (M)

headline: A Tree That Supported Sudan Becomes a War's Latest Victim
abstract: War that has ravaged Sudan's Darfur region since early 2003 has begun to disrupt collection of rare tree sap, gum arabic; it is essential ingredient in everything from soft drinks to beauty products and pharmaceuticals; US has had economic sanctions in place against Sudan since 1997 to protest its links to terrorists, but gum arabic has been exempted at urging of US business leaders; Sudan provides over two-thirds of world's supply of gum arabic; production fell about 60 percent in season just ended, and companies that rely on it for their products are paying higher prices for it; graph; map; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Platinum Producer Gains
abstract: Johnson Matthey, British platinum dstributor, says second-half profit was little changed from 2003 period (S)

headline: Center Uses Laser Method To See Cancer
abstract: Scripps-PARC Institute, partnership of Xerox Corp's Palo Alto Research Center and Scripps Research Institute, announces development of cancer detection system based on laser printer technology; technique involves tagging cancer cells with fluorescent marker and then scanning blood cells with laser looking for fluorescence (M)

headline: Market Place; Schwab tells less-affluent customers they have to pay more than richer clients to make trades.
abstract: Charles Schwab Corp announces lower commissions for online stock trades by all sorts of customers except those not-so-affluent investors on which it built its franchise; starting in June, customers with more than $1 million in their accounts will pay as little as $9.95 to buy or sell shares through Schwab, but customers with less than $100,000 will pay three times as much--$29.95 for each trade--unelss they make more than eight trades each quarter; Schwab's chief executive David Pottruck comments; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Sure You Need a Job, but You Have to Be Careful
abstract: Advice on avoiding being defrauded during online job search (S)

headline: First Loan Of Ex-Lawyer For Tyco Is Recalled
abstract: Paul Rubenstein, who was law partner at Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, testifies that Mark A Belnick received company loan when he took job as general counsel for Tyco International in 1998, Belnick's criminal trial; prosecutors contend it was first of almost $15 million in improper no-interest loans that Belnick received from Tyco; Rubenstein says Belnick negotiated loan with his future boss, L Dennis Kozlowski, chief executive at time (M)

headline: Google's Sale of Its Shares Will Defy Wall St. Tradition
abstract: The initial public offering, in the form of a five-stage auction, is expected to make the company's founders instant billionaires.

headline: MediaTalk; Reversing the Trend, an American Editor Will Join the Lads in Britain
abstract: British-owned Dennis Publishing names Greg Gutfeld, former editor of American version of its 'lad' magazine Stuff, to serve as editor of strugglng British version of Maxim; photo (M)

headline: Verizon Plans To Raise Fee Of Digital Net Service
abstract: Verizon Communications plans to add $2 to $3 monthly surcharged to cost of its high-speed Internet connections, move that could fuel further debate over taxation of online services; charges $34.95 for high-speed Internet service, but customers who use Verizon long-distance and local telephone service pay $29.95 per month for Internet line; BellSouth will add $2.97 fee to bills of 1.4 million high-speed Internet customers starting April 15; fate of federal fee--along with other state and local taxes levied on Internet access--is being debate in Congress and is subject of litigation (M)

headline: 9/11 Panel Members Debate Qaeda-Iraq 'Tie'
abstract: Thomas H Kean, chairman of 9/11 commission, reiterates that inquiry has turned up no evidence that Iraq or Saddam Hussein took part 'in any way in attacks on the United States'; says this does not put commission at odds with Bush administration's contention that links existed between Al Qaeda and Iraq; Vice Pres Cheney says evidence of relationship between Iraq and Al Qaeda is 'overwhelming,' and that he 'probably' has information that commission does not have; Kean says that if such information exists, panel needs it 'pretty fast' (M)

headline: M.P.'s Received Orders to Strip Iraqi Detainees
abstract: Col Thomas M Pappas, who was in charge of interrogations at Abu Ghraib prison, told Maj Gen Antonio M Taguba that his intelligence officers sometimes instructed military police to force Iraqi detainees to strip naked and to shackle them before questioning them, but only when there was 'some good reason'; also told Taguba, who is investigating charges of abuse, that his unit had 'no formal system in place' to monitor instructions they gave to military guards, who worked closely with interrogators to prepare detainees for interviews; Pappas's statements offer highest-level confirmation so far that military intelligence soldiers directed military guards in preparing for interrogations; they also provide first insights by senior intelligence officer at prison into relationship between his troops and military police; Taguba's report concludes that Pappas was 'directly or indirectly responsible' for actions of those who mistreated and humiliated Iraqi prisoners; photo (M)

headline: Gore Announces Acquisition of Cable TV Network
abstract: An investor group headed by former Vice President Al Gore said today it is launching a cable news network for young adults.

headline: 4 Killed in Istanbul Bus Bombing Before Bush Visit to Turkey
abstract: Four people are killed in Turkey when bomb explodes on crowded public bus in Istanbul, just hours after similar device blows up near hotel in Ankara where Pres Bush is due to stay in advance of NATO summit meeting on June 28; upcoming NATO meeting has provoked several anti-NATO and anti-American demonstrations across Turkey; Turkish security forces have been especially vigilant in recent weeks; Turkey hopes NATO meeting will showcase its modernity and aspirations to join European Union; it has invested $40 million to spurce up parks and streets of Istanbul and provide security; map (M)

headline: German Court Frees 9/11 Suspect Pending Retrial
abstract: The only person convicted in the 9/11 terror attacks was freed before he faces charges of aiding the plot in Hamburg.

headline: DDB Worldwide Tops Honors in Clio Awards
abstract: DDB Worldwide Tops.

headline: Medco to Pay $29.3 Million to Settle Complaints of Drug Switching
abstract: Medco Health Solutions agrees to start telling patients, doctors and employers about billions of dollars in annual rebates that it has received from drug manufacturers for promoting their products; agreement settles state and federal complaints that accused Medco of violating consumer protection and mail fraud laws by switching patients to drugs that were said to add costs for patients and their health plans; state and federal officials say terms of settlement would establish new rules for largely unregulated industry, providing more transparency and prohibiting actions that critics contend favor drug manufacturers at expense of patients; Steven Rowe, attorney general of Maine, says agreement will lift cloak of secrecy around Medco; Medco agrees to change some practices and pay $29.3 million to resolve legal issues; company does not admit any wrongdoing; photo (M)

headline: Court Hears How Adelphia Hid Problems From Banks
abstract: Adelphia Communications Corp's former vice president James R Brown testifies that company's former assistant treasurer Michael Mulcahey helped to prepare variety of false financial statements intended to fool banks and investors about real condition of Adelphia; says such moves were meant to hide that Adelphia was in default of borrowing restrictions in lending agreements with banks and bondholders; also says that Mulcahey and other Adelphia executives kept two sets of ledgers as part of plan to deceive lenders; Brown, who pleaded guilty to fraud in late 2002, is testifying as part of his plea agreement (M)

headline: 8 Leaders Welcome U.N. Backing for Iraq Transition
abstract: Pres Bush, surrounded by world leaders sounding eager to put bitter divisions behind them, welcomes UN resolution on Iraq; comments with Russian Pres Vladimir Putin at Group of 8 meeting on Sea Island, Georgia; Putin warns 'long time' is needed for resolution to have any real impact; unanimous resolution is diplomatic victory for Bush, putting Security Council on record approving US occupation and giving UN stake in successful outcome; Bush meeting with German Chancellor Gerhard Schroder is called warmest since Iraq invasion; Schroder photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Adecco Seeks To Delay Report
abstract: Swiss employment services company Adecco is trying to persuade its lenders to exend deadline of May 3 set for release of its audited financial statements for 2003; delayed reporting 2003 results in January after disclosing that it had uncovered accounting problems at unit (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Airport Victim Had Stolen Passport
abstract: French authorities report that one of four people killed in Charles De Gaulle International Airport terminal collapse remains unidentified because passport she was carrying was stolen; other victims are identified as Chinese man and woman and Lebanese woman (S)

headline: Iran Frees British Servicemen Seized in Boats
abstract: Iran frees eight British servicemen who spent three nights in Iranian custody after their boats strayed into Iranian waters; British diplomats meet with eight in southern Iran and fly with them to British Embassy in Tehran; photo (M)

headline: Bullet Train Remakes Map of South Korea
abstract: Sleek new French-designed bullet trains are already reworking face of South Korea, prompting airlines to cut many domestic flights and sending real estate prices soaring in backwaters suddenly seen as future suburbs of Seoul; new era for South Korea begins with start of high-speed service on first three-quarters of 253-mile distance from Seoul to Pusan; map; photo (M)

headline: Shiite Cleric Is Forming Party That May Play Role in Elections
abstract: Moktada al-Sadr, Shiite cleric whose fighters have waged 10-week insurgency against American-led occupation, is starting political party that will probably take part in Iraq's 2005 elections; Qais al-Khazali, Sadr spokesman, says Sadr cannot disband his militia because it is popular uprising, not organized force, interview; election move would defy American administrator L Paul Bremer III's edict barring people associated with illegal militias from taking part in elections in near future (M)

headline: 5 Afghans Die and 4 U.S. Soldiers Are Wounded in Clashes
abstract: Five Afghans are killed and four US soldiers are wounded in clashes in Afghanistan; Pakistani officials protest what they say was second incursion by US forces into Pakistan in month (M)

headline: In Ford's Tomorrow, Fuel-Saving Hybrids And a Luxury Lincoln
abstract: Ford Motor Co's chairman-chief executive William Clay Ford Jr says his company plans to make three hybrid vehicles, two by 2007 model year in wake of rising gas prices; also says it will redouble efforts to build more efficient vehicles; reiterates Detroit's past support for substantially higher gas taxes as well as incentives for consumers buying vehicles like hybrids; Ford Motor will become third automaker this year to sell hybrid vehicle, offering version of its Escape sport utility vehicle; photos (M)

headline: Former Cendant Executive Agrees to Pay $14 Million
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission reaches settlement with former Cendant executive Cosmo Corigliano, who as controller and later chief financial officer of CUC International, Cendant predecessor company, allegedly helped improperly inflate CUC's reported earnings; Corigliano will transfer $14 million in cash, securities, pension funds and other assets to court-appointed receiver and be barred from serving as officer of public company; is expected to be key witness in criminal trial of Cendant former chairman Walter A Forbes and former vice chairman E Kirk Shelton; pleaded guilty four years ago to criminal fraud charges in case (M)

headline: 2 Weeklies' Covers Separated By a Common Reagan Picture
abstract: Time and Newsweek use same 1980 photograph by Michael Evans to adorn their covers for commemorative issues on late former Pres Ronald Reagan; Time and Newsweek editors comment; photos (M)

headline: DOW CHEMICAL DROPS '95 LAWSUIT AGAINST MONSANTO
abstract: Dow Chemical Co's AgroSciences unit drops 1995 lawsuit that accused Monsanto Co of infringing patent for genetic technology to protect plants against insect damage; AgroSciences unit agrees to dismiss suit after US Patent and Trademark Office ruled in February that Monsanto was first to invent technology (S)

headline: A Quiet Foreign Invasion of Korea's Giants
abstract: A Quiet Foreign Inv

headline: 2 Wild and Crazy Guys (Soon to Be Billionaires), and Hoping to Keep It That Way
abstract: Profile of Google Inc founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin in light of company's upcoming initial public offering; photo (M)

headline: COEUR D'ALENE RAISES BID FOR CANADIAN MINE COMPANY
abstract: Coeur d'Alene Mines Corp doubles cash portion of its unsolicited bid for Wheaton River Minerals Ltd, valued at 2.3 billion Canadian dollars ($1.7 billion), to minimum of 1 Canadian dollar a share; urges Wheaton shareholders to reject merger with Iamgold Corp (S)

headline: In Chicago, Hometown Support for the Airline but Doubts About Government Aid
abstract: Many Chicagoans hope United Airlines, based in suburban Elk Grove Township, will become financially viable again; some back government loan guarantees, while other say airline has long been mismanaged and needs to work out its own problems (M)/

headline: Reviving the Range Finder, With Some Digital Twists
abstract: Epson R-D1 digital camera uses mechanical shutter and L-mount lenses designed for Leica cameras; photo (S)

headline: China Tries to Block News of Hong Kong's Pro-Democracy March
abstract: China is clamping down on travel by Chinese tourists to Hong Kong to prevent news of expected huge pro-democracy march in Hong Kong from spreading on mainland; march will protest China's decision not to allow general elections in Hong Kong; Hong Kong's leading democrats are split over how aggressively to challenge China (M)

headline: IT'S ALL JUST PRODUCT
abstract: it's all just product**

headline: Bremer Raising Pressure to End Iraqi Uprisings
abstract: American civil administrator L Paul Bremer III warns of military showdown in Falluja and Najaf because of rebels' refusal to submit to American demands; speaks of need to bring early end to standoffs in Najaf with followers of Moktada al-Sadr, and in Falluja with Sunni Muslim insurgents; uprisings have posed greatest challenge to Amerian authority since invasion; American troops have been held back in Falluja and Najaf to allow mediation, but American generals say they will use force if talks drag on without result; until now, Bremer has said little publicly about crisis but has reportedly been working intensively behind scenes to allay impatience within American military command over standoffs and to give Iraqi negotiators as much time as possible to find peaceful solution; photo (M)

headline: Steve Lacy, 69, Who Popularized the Soprano Saxophone
abstract: Steve Lacy, American soprano saxophonist who helped legitimize his instrument in postwar jazz, dies at 69; career reviewed; photo (L)

headline: Sharon to Face Cabinet Hard-Liners on Gaza Pullout Plan
abstract: Israeli officials say Prime Min Ariel Sharon plans cabinet debate on full Israeli withdrawal from Gaza Strip, but will probably not hold vote; he sets stage for showdown with hardliners in cabinet who oppose even scaled-down withdrawal; photo (M)

headline: 5 Longtime Executives Create New York Shop
abstract: Ad executives Carl Johnson, Ernest Lupinacci, Andrew Kibble, Justin Barocas and Jason DeLand are opening New York-based ad agency Anomaly (S)

headline: T-Mobile Gaining Spectrum By Ending Cingular Venture
abstract: T-Mobile USA, nation's fifth-largest cellular operator, reaches deal to acquire control of some much-sought-after wireless spectrum from Cingular Wireless to improve its national network; Deutsche Telekom, T-Mobile's parent, will pay Cingular $2.3 billion to dissolve their three-year joint venture that allowed them to share their networks in several crucial states; T-Mobile will take over part of Cingular's network in California and Nevada, and regain exclusive control of some of its network in New York; T-Mobile will give Cingular part of its network in New York; T-Mobile will also pay $180 million for additional parts of Cingular's spectrum in San Francisco, Sacramento and Las Vegas markets, and it will get option to buy more spectrum in California from Cingular during next two years; photo of Deutsche Telekom deputy chairman Karl-Gerhard Eick and T-Mobile chairman Rene Obermann (M)

headline: AT&T in Deal to Return to Wireless Market
abstract: AT&T, which spun off and then sold its wireless cellphone operation, has signed a five-year deal with Sprint to sell wireless service over Sprint's network.

headline: Outsourcing's Other Side
abstract: Frank Levy and Richard J Murnane letter on Apr 11 article notes jobs outsourced abroad have historically been held by high school graduates, while Americans hired by foreign companies with United States operations are mainly college graduates

headline: Where Entrepreneurs Go And the Internet Is Free; Wi-Fi Providers Rethink How to Make Money
abstract: Entrepreneurs and telecommunications companies seeking sustainable business models for selling wireless Internet connections are challenged by growth in Wi-Fi connections that are provided free at cafes, malls and downtown business districts; T-Mobile is among Wi-Fi providers that do have profitable business model, with 4,650 Wi-Fi hot spots in Kinko's, Borders Bookstores, hotels, airports and Starbucks cafes, a number that rises by 35 a day; says it is not worried about growth of free hot spots because it believes commercial networks can offer more reliable, more secure Internet access; photos (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: International Paper Co agrees to buy closely held Box USA Holdings as prices and demand for boxes rise; analysts estimate deal's worth at $300 million to $325 million (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen rises before government report that is expected to show Japan's economic growth was revised higher in first quarter; dollar settles at 109.61 yen, down from 111, in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: D-DAY / 60 years later : 60th anniversary of D-Day:Leaders stress friendship
abstract: ARROMANCHES, France:—  The boys who liberated Europe came back to the beaches of Normandy on Sunday, stooped and frail, as their leaders put aside their differences to jointly remember the deaths of so many killed here 60 years ago.

headline: With a Tap From Putin, a Leader Emerges for Chechen Presidency
abstract: Maj Gen Alu Alkhanov, Chs

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Today.

headline: Revised Plan Would Give More Control To the Iraqis
abstract: United States and Britain introduce revised UN resolution that would give new interim government in Iraq control over Iraqi military and police, and end mandate of international force by Jan 2006; new version affirms that administration will be 'fully sovereign' after June 30 transfer of power (M)

headline: Iraqi Calls for Sovereignty And for Foreign Force to Stay
abstract: Iraq's new foreign minister Hoshyar Zebari tells Security Council that resolution it is now considering must give Iraq full sovereignty, but he also seeks continued presence of foreign forces; says any premature departure of troops would lead to chaos and possibly civil war; Security Council is in its second week of debating British-American draft resolution for Iraq; China, France, Germany and Russia, all opponents of war year ago, are pressing for language in resolution that would give Iraqis mechanism to ask foreign troops to leave; photo (M)

headline: Adelphia Kept Records of Deals With Rigases, Witness Says
abstract: Adelphia Communications Corp consultant Robert DiBella testifies company kept records of all transactions it conducted with business entities operated by founder John Rigas and two of his sons; has been called by prosecution to summarize evidence that it says supports criminal charges that Rigases hid $2.3 billion in debt and stole $100 million before Adelphia sought bankruptcy protection in June 2002 (M)

headline: Some Mitsubishi Duties To Omnicom Units
abstract: Mitsubishi Motors North America names Omnicom Group agencies DavinciSelectwork, PHD USA and Pentacom Canada to handle many media duties on its account, which had been handled by Deutsch; Deutsch continues to handle rest of account (S)

headline: Sun Moving to Underscore New Strategy
abstract: Sun Microsystems will open its JavaOne software conference in San Francisco by announcing partnerships with Orange and Vodafone, two largest European cellphone companies, to develop new Java-based applications for cellphone handsets and strengthen Sun's position in rapidly growing mobile Internet business; is expected to report that there are now four million programmers who use Java language to design software and that Java has become standard tool in cellular phone, automotive and other consumer electronics markets; Jonathan Schwartz, president, says company is determined to compete effectively in high-volume, low-cost server market that is dominated by computers based on microprocessors sold by Intel and AMD; photo (M)

headline: Former Israeli Soldiers Tell of Harassment of Palestinians
abstract: Israeli military re-energizes debate surrounding exhibit by former Israeli soldiers documenting some of their own misdeeds against Palestinians while serving in tense West Bank city of Hebron; army confiscates video testimony and calls in five soldiers for questioning; military claims it took actions not to suppress exhibit but to investigate abuses described by soldiers; former soldiers claim military is trying to silence them to discourage others from speaking out; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Retailer Rejects New Bid
abstract: World Business Briefing: Britain: Retailer Rejects Nÿ

headline: High-Maintenance TV
abstract: Digital broadcasts are wave of future, but getting array of antennas and decoder boxes often proves frustrating; technical advances over next few years will improve reception; photo (M)

headline: 3 Insurers Say New York State Is Investigating Fees to Brokers
abstract: Aetna and Cigna received subpoenas as part of an investigation into whether fees that insurers pay brokers pose a conflict of interest.

headline: Pope Ends Visit to Switzerland Calling His Pilgrimages a 'Duty'
abstract: Pope John Paul II leaves Bern, Switzerland, concluding his 103rd pilgrimage and appearing stronger than in recent public appearances; tells 13,0000 Catholic youths gathered at packed hockey stadium that it is his 'duty' to keep adding pilgrimages to his record as most traveled pope; celebrates open-air Mass for abut 75,000 worshipers; photo (M)

headline: The Trans-Atlantic Divide Is Growing Ever Deeper
abstract: A few American soldiers have shaken the sense of moral solidarity that has always been at the core of the trans-Atlantic alliance.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Tiger Faction In Retreat
abstract: Vinayagamoorthy Muraleetharan, breakaway faction of Tamil Tigers leader, also called Karuna, flees into eastern jungle ending recent uprising against mainstream Tamil leadership (S)

headline: Arab Leaders Adopt Agenda Endorsing Some Change
abstract: Arab leaders sign modest if unprecedented joint commitment toward political change at end of Arab League's annual summit meeting; participants and analysts wonder if document will have any significance, because putting it into effect is being left largely up to individual countries; recall past summit meetings littered with resolutions that went nowhere; but Arab leaders are eager to come up with plan of their own before Group of Eight summit meeting in June, when Pres Bush has said he would issue blueprint to push democracy across Arab and Muslim world (M)

headline: Political Rivals Nip at Governing South African Party
abstract: African National Congress is expected to win two-thirds of vote in South Africa's third post-apartheid national election on April 14, as it did two previous elections, but Patricia De Lille's upstart Independent Democratic Party hopes to cut into landslide; De Lille's year-old party exploits combination of rising disaffection with ANC and decline of squabbling opposition parties; De Lille is former anti-apartheid activist, current member of Parliament and unsparing critic of ANC; her party hopes to win five to ten percent of vote in upcoming parliamentary elections; photo (M)

headline: Iraqi Detainees Protest as Media Tours Prison
abstract: As reporters stepped onto the prison grounds, hundreds of Iraqi detainees rushed from their tents to the razor wire fence.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Qwest Changes Rules On Some Carrier Fees
abstract: Qwest Communications International will not bill other carriers fees of about half-cent per minute to connect callers who use high-speed Internet connection to reach Qwest local-telephone customers (S)

headline: Grand Jury Subpoenas Documents From Nortel
abstract: Federal grand jury in Texas subpoenas financial documents from Nortel Networks in criminal probe of accounting irregularities at Canadian telecommunications giant; Nortel is already being probed by securities regulators; share price graph; photo (M)

headline: Venezuelan Recall Is in Dispute Even Before the Vote
abstract: Touch-screen voting machines, which have been plagued by security and reliability concerns in US, will be used in Venezuela's recall vote on Pres Hugo Chavez, prompting his foes and foreign diplomats to suspect government may use equipment to manipulate outcome (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Telstra Plans Dividend
abstract: Telstra, Australian phone operator, says it will pay shareholders 1.5 billion Australian dollars ($1.03 billion) a year for next three years through dividends or share buybacks; credit rating agencies lower Telstra's rating, while stock price rises 5 percent (S)

headline: To Side With Sharon, Peres Wants Joint Peace Plan
abstract: Israeli Labor Party leader Shimon Peres lays out for first time conditions under which his party will join government of Prime Min Ariel Sharon; says Israel's evacuation of Gaza Strip must be negotiated with Palestinians, timetable for move decided on, and future of West Bank worked out as well; Sharon's plan has not involved any of these steps; Peres photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: U.N. Halts Gaza Food Distribution
abstract: United Nations Relief and Works Agency, citing increased Israeli security restrictions, suspends food aid to 600,000 Palestinians in Gaza Strip (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Senate Works to Reach Accord on Corporate Taxes  Senate leaders struggled to reach agreement on a bill that would overhaul corporate taxes and create more than $170 billion worth of tax breaks for businesses.    The bill has been stalled for months. It was originally intended to eliminate a longstanding tax break for American exporters that has been declared illegal by the World Trade Organization. Congress and the White House are under pressure to act quickly because the European Union has started to impose retaliatory tariffs on American exports. [Page C5.]

headline: DUPONT DOW JOINT VENTURE SETTLES NEOPRENE CLAIMS
abstract: DuPont Dow Elastomers, joint venture of DuPont Co and Dow Chemical Co, will pay $36 million to settle claims by customers who say they were overcharged for neoprene (S)

headline: When Your Files Go Astray, Put a Speedy Sleuth to Work
abstract: X1 Technologies introduces software that creates its own database index of files and e-mail messages on hard drive and updates index as new files are created; uses database for keyword searching; photo (M)

headline: Shell to Release Oil Reserves Report
abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell is expected to release main conclusions of its audit committee's investgation into January reclassification of its oil and gas reserves on April 19 (S)

headline: Key Witness Tells of Deception at Adelphia
abstract: James Brown, government's star witness against members of Rigas family, which ran Adelphia Communications Corp, offers blistering testimony that implicates them in variety of financial frauds; says top company executives used accounting gimmicks and sham transactions to deceive auditors, analysts and investors about Adelphia's true financial condition because they feared company's stock price would collapse and that they would default on loans if it became known; describes himself and former best friend Timothy Rigas, company's former chief financial officer, as prime movers behind deceptions; also sayus that founder-former chief executive John J Rigas and former head of operations Michael Rigas were aware that fraudulent financial data was being given to public (M)

headline: Golf Widows Take Up the Game But Play It in a Different Spirit
abstract: Many women who move to Florida for retirement and take up golf to spend more time with their husbands find game is more enjoyable played with other women; many prefer game for companionship and social reason, while men tend to view it more competitively; photos (M)

headline: G.E. Unit Buys Financing Division of Boeing
abstract: G.E. UNIT BUYS FINANCING DIVISION OF BOEING.

headline: Madrid Bombing Warrant
abstract: Spanish high court judge issues international arrest warrant for Daoud Ouhnane, Algerian whose fingerprint was found on plastic bag containing traces of explosives and seven detonators of type used in Mar 11 train bombings in Madrid; FBI had mistakenly identified fingerprint as that of Brandon Mayfield, lawyer in Portland, Ore (S)

headline: In Tehran, the Mullahs Learn Art Is Long, Censorship Brief
abstract: An exhibition of 20th-century British sculpture in Tehran is seen as testimony that Iran's cultural life has started to flourish once again.

headline: Victoria Falls Journal; The Best of Times, and the Worst, for Two Tourist Towns
abstract: Tourism in Zimbabwe has hit skids since 2000, when squatters began occupying nation's white-owned farms in what became wholesale seizure of commercial farmland; country's reputation has grown increasingly ugly, especially among tourists from members of Commonwealth nations; Zimbabwe's loss has been Zambia's gain; tourists flocking to view majestic Victoria Falls no longer travel to town of Victoria Falls in Zimbabwe, preferring to go across river to Livingstone, Zambia; photos (M)

headline: Delayed and Scaled Back, the Postbank Offering Is Set
abstract: Deutsche Post is sell shares of Postbank, Germany's largest retail bank, having cut size and price of offering and delayed it after investors spurned shares at original price; several major investors indicate they will buy shares at reduced price range; analysts are beginning to assess deal's affect on Germany's fragile investment culture; chief executive Klaus Zumwinkel comments, news conference; photos (M)

headline: MGM Mirage Bids $4.5 Billion for a Rival, Mandalay
abstract: MGM Mirage says it has offered about $4.5 billion in cash to buy rival Mandalay Resort Group; purchase would give MGM Mirage, which is based in Las Vegas, ownership stakes in several well-known casinos on Strip, including Luxor, Excalibur and Monte Carlo, as well as properties in Mississippi, Michigan and Illinois (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: World Bank Meeting Plans To Focus on Poverty  With the global economic outlook improving, the top economists at the World Bank said the focus of their annual meetings this weekend would be further reducing poverty. They will try to persuade wealthy nations to drastically increase their aid to developing nations and bolster programs to halt the spread of AIDS and improve education in poor countries.    Officials of the bank, who are meeting at the same time as officials of the International Monetary Fund, will also wrestle with the Bush administration's desire to see the World Bank and other United Nations affiliates do more to smooth Iraq's transition to a sovereign government. [Page C2.]

headline: AMGEN SAYS PARKINSON'S TREATMENT FAILED IN STUDY
abstract: Amgen Inc says Parkinson's disease drug GDNF that it is developing failed to help patients in study (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: In Poll, Chávez Wins Recall
abstract: Alfredo Keller & Associates public opinion poll holds that if Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez is recalled he will win referendum and stay in office; opposition is still deciding whether to recheck signatures and go forward with recall (S)

headline: Rally to Demand Unearthing Of Mass Graves of Franco Era
abstract: Spaniards who resisted Franco's rise to power come forward for perhaps last time to demand action on issue that has haunted them for nearly 70 years: identification of tens of thousands of political opponents, prisoners of war, battle casualties and others who historians say were killed in early stages of Spanish Civil War and dumped in mass graves by Franco's military forces (M)

headline: Israeli Effort Fails to Halt Rocket Attacks
abstract: Israeli tanks roll into northeastern corner of Gaza Strip but fail to prevent Palestinian militants from firing rockets at nearby Israeli town of Sederot; two rockets hit town while Prime Min Ariel Sharon visits family of child killed in earlier attack; he pledges widespread action to prevent more attacks; says he remains committed to withdrawing Jewish settlers from Gaza; photos (M)

headline: Philippine election results delayed
abstract: MANILA:—  More than a month after the elections here, a new president and vice president have yet to be proclaimed as endless debates and filibustering delay the counting of the votes at the House of Representatives.

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: PeopleSoft Rejects 4th Oracle Offer
abstract: PeopleSoft rejects Oracle's fourth offer for company; settles shareholder lawsuit related to its customer assurance program, in which PeopleSoft guarantees customer refunds of up to five times sales amount in event it is acquired and new owner makes substantial changes to PeopleSoft products; program will aply only if company is acquired by Oracle (S)

headline: Butler, Shine Is Hired for Converse Account
abstract: Butler, Shine Is Hired.

headline: India-Pakistan Talks Make No Specific Gains on Kashmir
abstract: Two days of talks between foreign secretaries of India and Pakistan conclude with no progress on their dispute over Kashmir, but with announcement of new confidence-building measures between nuclear-armed neighbors; talks are first between heads of two countries' diplomatic services in six years; both sides reportedly reiterated their long-held positions on Kashmir, but agreed to proceed on basis of 1972 agreement, which commits both sides to resolve their differences through peaceful means; new talks are scheduled for Aug (M)

headline: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- New Jersey; Plans for Research Center In Area of High Vacancy Rates
abstract: Cadbury Adams, part of Cadbury Schweppes and leading maker of candy and gum, will build research building on Route 10 in Hanover, NJ, area that has highest office vacancy rate in northern part of state (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Auto Parts Maker Acquired
abstract: World Business Briefing: Germany: Auto Part M6

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Defense Dept confirms death of US soldier in Iraq (S)

headline: French Stake Seen as Part Of Rescue For Alstom
abstract: France will acquire almost third of nearly bankrupt French industrial group Alstom in proposed rescue bid, and European Commission is not expected to oppose move (M)

headline: IRAQ UPDATE
abstract: Update of latest events in Iraq (S)

headline: NASDAQ TO ACQUIRE SUNGARD'S STOCK-TRADING NETWORK
abstract: Nasdaq Stock Market Inc will pay $190 million to buy Brut LLC, which operates electronic communication network that links stock traders, from SunGard Data Systems (S).

headline: Venezuela Abused Protesters, Human Rights Groups Charge
abstract: Human Rights Watch accuses Venezuelan National Guard of using torture and excessive force to deal with recent protests against Pres Hugo Chavez (M)

headline: 11 Chinese Workers Killed in Rebel Attack in Afghanistan
abstract: Gunmen raided a desert camp housing Chinese road workers, the latest in a string of attacks on relief and construction workers.

headline: Four Killed and 148 Wounded In a Suicide Bombing in Riyadh
abstract: Suicide bomber detonates car loaded with explosives in central Riyadh, killing at least four people, wounding 148 and shattering facade of police building; blast is felt three miles away; Saudi officials and foreign embassies have been bracing for an attack since Apr 12, when shootout in poor Riyadh neighborhood led to chain of bloody skirmishes across central part of kingdom; Saudi officials say bombing and clashes preceding it represent qualitative shift in ongoing war between security services and Islamic militants believed to be either directly connected to Osama bin Laden and Al Qaeda or inspired by terrorist group; analysts say success of security services in arresting militants over past year has disrupted their ability to mount organized effort to shake ruling Saud familty, but it has also made situation more volatile as those determined to carry out suicide attacks may pick almost any random target; Deputy Secretary of State Richard L Armitage, who was in Riyadh when bombing occurred, says two governments have been sharing counterterrorism intelligence, which is why American Embassy ordered many staff members and their families to leave country; photos; map (M)

headline: Citing U.S. Inquiry, Ex-Chairman Quits Computer Associates
abstract: Sanjay Kumar, former chairman and chief executive of Computer Associates, cuts all ties to company as federal criminal investigation into Computer Associates and Kumar enters its final stages; Computer Associates says that Kumar had resigned as chief software architect; both company and Kumar say they hope Kumar's departure will help Computer Associates resolve two-year investigation into fraud and obstruction of justice at company; Kumar photo (L)

headline: Aventis Outlines Its Case For Spurning Sanofi Bid
abstract: Aventis outlines its resistance to takeover from Sanofi-Synthelabo, saying it will press its case with French and German governments and defending its use of warrants; Aventis has been fighting with Sanofi since $60 billion offer of stock and cash made in January (M)

headline: It's time for 20 questions and a look at beer, deer, soup and games that teenage boys play.
abstract: Advertising column asks 20 questions about advertising, marketing, media and popular culture (M)

headline: The Bells and the Ruling on Access Fees
abstract: Bush administration's decision to side with regional Bell companies in their legal battle over access fees they charge others to lease their phone lines sets off concerns among consumer groups, long-distance providers and state utility commissions; groups say decision to remove cap on these access fees, which goes into effect June 15, will give Bells free hand to raise prices they charge AT&T, MCI and hundreds of companies trying to get into local phone market; will also push many smaller phone companies out of business and ultimately lead to higher phone rates for consumers (M)

headline: Iran Threatens to Restart Nuclear Work
abstract: Pres Mohammad Khatami threatens Iran may resume its enrichment of uranium, prerequisite for making nuclear arms, if International Atomic Energy Agency approves expected resolution rebuking it for not cooperating; says he has not yet decided to resume work; United States Amb Kenneth C Brill charges Iran tries to intimidate IAEA board and individual states into softening criticism; Iranian aides scramble to delete resolution provision calling for cancellation of Iran's plans to build heavy-water research reactor and start operations at uranium conversion plan (M)

headline: World Briefings
abstract: AMERICAS.

headline: Leader of Small Russian Republic Escapes Assassination
abstract: The powerful explosion in Ingushetia killed at least one, apparently a suicide bomber, while wounding seven others.

headline: A Creative Director Leaving Foote Cone
abstract: Bill Cimino is leaving after less than year as executive creative director at Irvine, Calif, office of Foote Cone & Belding to return to agency he came from, Chicago office of DDB Worldwide (S)

headline: HSBC Consolidates Marketing Accounts at WPP Group
abstract: In one of the largest recent consolidations of a worldwide marketing account, HSBC, the bank based in London, decided today to unite its assignments at agencies owned by the WPP Group in London.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Aznar To Teach At Georgetown
abstract: Former Spanish Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar will teach at Georgetown University (Washington, DC) in fall 2004; photo (S)

headline: Witness Tells of Adelphia Family Dynamics
abstract: Adelphia Communications Corp's former vice president James R Brown testifies that former finance chief Timothy Rigas could not control lies that his father John J Rigas made about his pay and stock holdings; says John Rigas made deceptive remarks after Adelphia disclosed on March 27, 2002, that it backed $2.3 billion in family loans (M)

headline: MediaTalk; C-Span Is Considering A Time Delay to Counter The Vulgarity of Callers
abstract: Spike in vulgar language on live call-in programs prompts C-Span, network of Congressional debates and Book TV, to consider instituting time delay (S)

headline: OBITUARY : Alan Levy, 72, writer who chronicled Prague Spring
abstract: Alan Levy, a longtime contributor to the International Herald Tribune and founding editor in chief of The Prague Post, died Friday after a brief battle with cancer, the Prague newspaper announced. He was 72.

headline: COMMAND ERRORS AIDED IRAQ ABUSE, ARMY HAS FOUND
abstract: Internal Army investigation finds virtual collapse of command structure in Abu Ghraib prison outside Baghdad where American enlisted personnel are accused of committing acts of abuse and humiliation against Iraqi detainees; report says midlevel military intelligence officers were allowed to skirt normal chain of command to issue questionable orders to enlisted personnel from reserve military police unit handling guard duty; Maj Gen George R Fay is examining interrogation practices of military intelligence officers at all American-run prisons in Iraq, not just Abu Ghraib; second review is ordered by Lt Gen James R Helmly to assess training of all reservists, especially military police and intelligence officers, soldiers most likely to handle prisoners; lawyer for one of enlisted men charged in case requests that Army open court of inquiry into abuse at Abu Ghraib, move that would expand investigation beyond six enlisted personnel to look at broader command failures; widening prison-abuse scandal has stirred anger in Arab world and holds potential to damage efforts by American officals to meet June 30 deadline to transfer limited self-rule to Iraqi people; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Orders Halt to Falluja Operations, but Situation Unclear
abstract: A halt to Marine operations in the city was announced, but the situation on the ground was far from clear.

headline: What Pensions Offer That 401(k)'s Don't
abstract: Carol E Curtis le

headline: Aventis Plan Is Rejected
abstract: France's market regulator rejects plan by Aventis to issue warrants as part of its efforts to thwart Sanofi-Synthelabo's hostile takeover bid (S)

headline: And Now, Enter the Two Who Would Be One
abstract: Friendship between Leslie Moonves and Tom Freston, new co-presidents of Viacom Inc, could be tested as they now vie with one another to succeed Sumner M Redstone as chief executive in three years; photo (M)

headline: Testy Annual Meeting Focuses on Shell's Scandal
abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell Group shareholders express anger at annual meeting over oil reserve scandal and Aad Jacobs, supervisory board chairman of Royal Dutch Petroleum Co, may have made things worse after raising doubts about when he was first informed of reserve discrepancy; shareholders appear surprised when Jacobs says he was told of 'an issue with reserves' in November; Shell's overstatement of its reserve estimates did not become public knowledge until early January; photo (M)

headline: Patents; Trademark applications, by one theory an economic gauge, remain low in some sectors.
abstract: Intellectual-property law firm Dechert tracks trends in trademarks as informal economic indicator; reports overall trademark applications rose 5 percent in 2003 after drops in 2001 and 2002, but fell for several industries often cited as future of American business and job creation; big growth area for trademarks seems to be in food; graphs of trademark applications (M)

headline: Wary Iraqis Welcome the Handover but Ask, Now What?
abstract: There was no greater sign of the cautiousness of the Iraqi people toward today's events than the quiet in Baghdad.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Calpers to Withhold Votes For Weill of Citigroup  Calpers said it would withhold its votes to re-elect Citigroup's chairman, Sanford I. Weill, and its chief executive, Charles O. Prince, as board members.     The California Public Employees Retirement System, which has about $167 billion of assets and more than 26.5 million Citigroup shares, said the company would be ''better served'' by having an independent director replace Mr. Weill as chairman. [Page C3.]

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: MCI Posts Loss; Will Cut 7,500 Jobs
abstract: MCI posts first-quarter net loss of $388 million; sales fell 13 percent to $6.30 billion; company will cut 7,500 jobs, or about 15 percent of its work force (S)

headline: Adapting a Company's Tools And Selling Them to Others
abstract: Epitome Systems is about to introduce its first product, set of software tools that let users work on documents, and it acquired product from General Motors Acceptance Corp, whose software engineers developed it; Epitome founder Vincent J Rogusky says he was convinced that commercially valuable software could be found at established American companies; photo (M)

headline: The Click Factor
abstract: Popularity of reality television is reflected in number of visits to networks' Web sites; graph (S)

headline: The Very Big Business Of Private Equity
abstract: Donald J Gogel, chief executive of Clayton, Dubilier & Rice, one of oldest private-equity firms, explains sector's role and investment strategies, interview; also notes role of Jack Welch, who joined firm in 2001 and serves on screening committee (S)

headline: A Quitter's Dilemma: Hooked on the Cure
abstract: a quitter's dilemA

headline: Business; In Debate Over Housing Bubble, a Winner Also Loses
abstract: in deb

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil prices fall on expectations that government report will show that fuel inventories rose last week; crude oil for July delivery falls 58 cents, or 1.4 percent, to $41.41 per barrel in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Sales At Publicis Slip
abstract: Publicis Groupe says first-quarter revenue fell to 866 million euros ($1.05 billion) from 905 million euros year ago (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Suspected Mercenaries To Be Deported
abstract: Extradition agreement sends 70 men suspected of involvement in plot to overthrow Teodoro Obiang Nguema's government in Equatorial Guinea to country from Zimbabwe, where they were arrested in March (S)

headline: Consumer Spending and a Factory Index Rise
abstract: Commerce Department reports consumer spending rose 0.3 percent and personal incomes rose 0.6 percent in Apr; National Association of Purchasing Management reports measure of manufacturing in Chicago area rose in May to 68, highest level in almost 16 years; University of Michigan's final index of consumer sentiment falls to 90.2 in May from 94.2 in Apr; personal income graph (M)9

headline: MDC in Toronto Buys Stake in Hello Design
abstract: MDC in Toront

headline: He Does Get Some Respect, but the Critics Still Have His Number
abstract: Profile of Ford Motor chief executive William Clay Ford Jr, who has pulled his great-grandfather's company out of sinkhole and was able to make company profitable in 2003 after huge losses in 2001 and 2002; says William Clay Ford still have his skeptics on Wall Street and within environmental community; photos (M)

headline: Grey Global's leader is staying mum despite hints that the agency may once again be up for sale.
abstract: Grey Global Group, last independent ad agency company of substantive size, may be up for sale; chairman-president-chief executive Edward H Meyer is unavailable to discuss news reports that agency company has hired Goldman Sachs Group and J P Morgan Chase last week to explore possible sale of all or part of company (M)

headline: Iqaluit Journal; Snuffing Out a Smoky Way of Life in the Canadian Arctic
abstract: Public health officials in Canadian Arctic, where smoking is integral part of life, hope to impose ban similar to one in most of rest of Canada; antismoking measure amounts to extraordinary experiment in social engineering for people so addicted to tobacco as Inuit population is; photo of die-hard smokers braving minus-20 weather to smoke outside Resolute Bay Airport; map (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: 2 Taliban Leaders Caught
abstract: Military reports that high-level Taliban commanders Abdul Hafiz Majid, who is former Kandahar police chief, and Muhammad Daoud, provincial commander, have been captured by American-led special forces in Afghanistan (S)

headline: DUPONT REDUCES PRICE OF NYLON UNIT FOR FASTER SALE
abstract: DuPont Co reduces price of Invista synthetic fibers unit it is selling to Koch Industries by 4.5 percent, to $4.2 billion, and speeds completion of sale; companies will close transaction on April 30 instead of June 30 (S)

headline: Japan Aims to Stiffen Antitrust Penalties
abstract: Japanese government has proposed sweeping overhaul of antimonopoly act that is aimed primarily at bid rigging and price fixing; bill that would codify changes has been held up because of opposition from Japan's leading big-business lobby, Nippon Keidanren; group argues Fair Trade Commission's operations should be made more transparent before commission is given more power; commission's chairman Kazuhiko Takeshima is leading push for tougher fines; photo (M)

headline: Business; Corporate Scandal? Spenser's on the Case
abstract: Robert B Parker's latest thriller, Bad Business, will make its debut on New York Times business best-seller list, at No 2, because it uses corporate accounting scandal as plot device; novel and author discussed (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Bomb Explodes In Kandahar
abstract: Bomb explodes in Kandahar, Afghanistan, perhaps signaling growing urban bombing campaign by Taliban (S)

headline: People
abstract: Roundup of executive changes in ad industry (S)

headline: Witness Says Ex-Tyco Lawyer Failed to Disclose Problems
abstract: Former Tyco International director John F Fort III testifies that company's former top counsel Mark Belnick failed to tell board about accounting problems at company when he learned of them in 2000 (M)

headline: All Stressed Out and Everywhere to Go
abstract: Article on human stress associated with frequent business travel; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Air India Prosecutors Wrap Up Case
abstract: Vancouver (Canada) prosecutors finish case against suspected Sikh terrorists Ripudaman Singh Malik and Ajaib Singh Bagri, who are accused of 1985 bombing of Air India Flight 182, which exploded in flight over Atlantic en route from Canada to India (S)

headline: South Africa's Ruling Party Expected to Dominate Vote
abstract: When South Africans go to the polls Wednesday as many as seven in 10 will vote for the African National Congress.

headline: MEN'S FASHION : For dressing up, casual meets elegant halfway
abstract: FLORENCE—  Since men the world over are wearing a uniform of low-slung jeans, three-button jacket, sneakers and T-shirt, the natural reaction would be a radical swing toward formality: sharp suit, high-collared shirt, bright tie and brogues. But as the biannual Pitti Immagine Uomo show kicked off the new menswear season in Florence last week, there was a surprise: demi dressing up was the theme of spring/summer 2005.

headline: LEVI STRAUSS SEEKS TO SELL DOCKERS BRAND
abstract: Levi Strauss & Co is exploring sale of its Dockers casual-clothing brand as it seeks to reduce debt and focus resources on its Levi's and Levi Strauss Signature brands; retains Citigroup to help with potential sale (S)

headline: Architect Starts Study of Failure In Paris Airport
abstract: Paul Andreu, architect who designed futuristic terminal building at Charles de Gaulle International Airport that partly collapsed, visits site; meets with investigators; airport officials say terminal could remain closed for up to year; experts suggest collapse was more likely caused by construction errors than by design (M)

headline: Guerrilla campaigns are going to extremes, but will the message stick?
abstract: Mainstream marketers are increasingly turning to guerrilla tactics, broad range of advertising methods that strive to strike when people least expect it, as consumers prove harder to reach with traditional advertising; Interference agency campaign for Le Tigre clothing brand cited; marketing experts say guerrilla efforts run counter to what consumers want; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Jobless Rate Falls
abstract: Australia's economy added 66,900 jobs in March, pushing seasonally adjusted unemployment rate down to 5.6 percent (S)9

headline: Coors Chairman Quits Commercials
abstract: Coors Brewing Co has stopped broadcasts in Colorado of commercials featuring chairman, Peter Coors, who will seek Republican nomination for Senate seat being vacated by Ben Nighthorse Campbell, also Republican (S)

headline: IRAQ TAPE SHOWS THE DECAPITATION OF AN AMERICAN
abstract: Web site operated by Islamic group Muntada al-Ansar posts videotape showing decapitation of American Nicholas Berg in Iraq, in what killers call revenge for American mistreatment of Iraqi prisoners at Abu Ghraib prison; site identifies killer as Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, Jordanian militant linked to Al Qaeda; State Department confirms Berg's body was found, Baghdad; Berg's family says Berg, 26, went to Iraq twice since Dec seeking work fixing communications antennas; photos (M)

headline: British Editor Fired in Uproar Over Fake Iraq Abuse Photos
abstract: The editor of The Daily Mirror tabloid, Piers Morgan, was dismissed today by the newspaper's owner, Trinity Mirror.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stocks Rise on Signs Of Economic Growth  Stocks rose, sending benchmark indexes to six-week highs, on optimism that employment growth will bolster the economy.    The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index added 17.92 points, or 1.6 percent, to close at 1,140.42, its third-biggest gain this year. All 10 of its industry groups advanced. The Dow Jones industrial average increased 148.26 points, or 1.5 percent, to 10,391.08, as 28 of its 30 members rose. The Nasdaq composite index rose 42 points, or 2.1 percent, to 2,020.62, erasing its loss for the year. [Page C11.]

headline: Profit Falls Nearly 20% At Unilever
abstract: Unilever says first-quarter profits dropped by almost fifth; reports 515 million euros ($615 million) in net profit, down from 637 million euros year ago; worldwide sales were down 8 percent, to 9.36 billion euros; sales of company's leading brands grew 1.3 percent, below forecasts of 1.5 percent to 2.5 percent (M)

headline: Big Rise in Consumer Confidence Gives a Lift to Shares
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 56.34 points, or 0.5 percent, to 10,413.43; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index adds 2.85 points, or 0.3 percent, to 1,136.50; Nasdaq composite index gains 15.11 points, or 0.8 percent, to 2,034.93; graph; chart (M)

headline: Governing Party Lacks Majority In Sri Lanka
abstract: Pres Chandrika Kumaratunga's alliance wins most seats in Sri Lankan parliamentary elections, but it does not have simple majority needed to form government; election officials say they have rejected calls for new election despite complaints of irregularities in at least two districts (M)

headline: The Wired Library
abstract: Letter from Maurice J Freedman, Westchester Library System, says Internet has revolutionized library use

headline: U.S. Troops Shut Long Sections Of 2 Main Routes to Baghdad
abstract: United States military closes down long stretches of two strategic highways to Baghdad from Turkey in north and Kuwait in south as American troops labor against insurgent attacks that have severely cut flow of supplies to city; apparently hopes that closing roads to civilian traffic will make it harder for insurgents to ambush trucks and convoys; has already effectively lost control of long sections of highway leading west from Baghdad to Jordan; photos (M)

headline: Shares Off as Home Sales Data Stir Interest Rate Worries
abstract: Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 5.07 points, or 0.4 percent, to 1,135.53; Nasdaq composite index declines 13 points, or 0.6 percent, to 2,036.77; Dow Jones industrial average loses 28.11 points, or 0.3 percent, to 10,444.73; US Treasury prices are mostly higher; price of benchmark 10-year note rises 4/32, to 96 18/32; yield declines to 4.44 percent compared with 4.46 percent; graph; chart (M)

headline: 4 European Nations Object To Bank Accounting Shift
abstract: France, Belgium, Italy and Spain tell European Commission that they oppose imposition of accounting rule that would force European banks to disclose market value of their investments in derivative securities; opposition by large states to International Accounting Standards Board rule raises possibility that rule could be blocked (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.00   4.00   4.25       Federal Funds   1.00   1.03   1.25       3-month Libor   1.14   1.11   1.29       3-month T-bills   0.93   0.93   1.13       6-month T-bills   1.03   1.01   1.13       10-yr. T-infl.   1.67   1.60   2.11       10-yr. T-note   4.21   4.14   3.98       30-yr. headline: Shell Tells of Setbacks In Russia and Off Nigeria
abstract: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group, under intense pressure to meet or exceed market expectations after its large reserve write-down in January, is running over budget at a large Russian development and will not draw oil from its Nigerian offshore project as soon as expected.       A Shell-run liquefied natural gas project, known as Sakhalin II, in the Sakhalin Islands in Russia's Far East, is proving more expensive than Shell expected. ''There are cost pressures on the project,'' said Simon Buerk, a Shell spokesman.

headline: Spain Swears In New Premier, Who Promises Broad Change
abstract: King Juan Carlos of Spain swears in new Socialist Prime Minister Jose Luis Rodriguez Zapatero, setting country on path of sweeping foreign policy and domestic changes; Zapatero won upset victory after March 11 terrorist attacks in Madrid; conservative government of Jose Maria Aznar brought prosperity to Spain but angered Spaniards with its authoritarian style and response to March 11 attacks; Zapatero is praised for mild manner and inclusive and conciliatory approach (M)

headline: Consultant suggests building at CDG could be reparable : New theory on collapse of airport terminal
abstract: PARIS:—  Detailed photographs taken shortly after the partial collapse of a passenger terminal at Roissy-Charles de Gaulle Airport last month appear to offer an alternative to initial theories that cracks in the concrete pillars supporting the structure were to blame for the deadly accident.

headline: China's Fast-Growing Economy Cools Off Slightly
abstract: China's industrial production and money supply grew at slightly less pace in May, indications that Chinese officials may be having some success in moderating growth in economy that has shown signs of overheating; consumer price index rose 3.8 percent in 12 months through April, fastest pace in seven years; money supply was 18 percent greater than year earlier; industrial production was 17.5 percent higher in May than year ago; Hu Angang, director of Center for China Study at Tsinghua University, comments; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Automotive Unit For Sale
abstract: Centrica weighs sale of its Automotive Association, insurer and provider of roadside service for drivers; stock price graph (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: UNILEVER, Rotterdam, the Netherlands, the world's largest manufacturer of food and soap, said it is selling its approximately $46 million stake in Elizabeth Arden Inc., severing its last ties to the No.2 perfume maker in America. The stake is about 2.32 million shares. The offering's manager, Morgan Stanley, will sell an additional 231,793 shares if there is demand.

headline: More Charges in Theft of Lockheed Files
abstract: Boeing Co former manager Larry Satchell is charged in federal court with using documents stolen from Lockheed Martin Corp to help Boeing win Pentagon rocket contract in 1998; Sen John McCain delays nominations of five Pentagon officials and threatens to seek subpoena if Pentagon does not provide documents on $20 billion tanker leasing deal between Air Force and Boeing; Pentagon auditors tell Bloomberg News they are reviewing whether Boeing overcharged Air Force by 'significant amount' on $1.3 billion contract to upgrade NATO surveillance aircraft; tanker lease and NATO surveillance planes were deals negotiated by former Boeing executive Darleen A Druyun, who has been fired and pleaded guilty to federal charge of having negotiated employment contract for herself with Boeing while she was still Air Force official overseeing Boeing contracts (M)

headline: Adelphia Figure Testifies on Pay
abstract: Michael C Mulcahey, former assistant treasurer for Adelphia Communications who is on trial for fraud, testifies that John J Rigas, co-defendant, paid him more than $100,000 over last year as consultant (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Deals: Apple and BMW To Adapt iPods For Cars
abstract: Apple Computer and BMW Group agree to permit Apple's iPod digital music players to integrate more easily with certain BMW and Mini Cooper models through use of adapter designed by both companies (S)

headline: When Chiefs Decline To Serve on Other Boards
abstract: William J Holstein interï

headline: Bronx Hospital Embraces Online Technology That Others Avoid
abstract: Weiler Hospital of Montefiore Medical Center in Bronx, NY, uses online technology that other hospitals avoid; Dr Matt Berger, chief of medical services at hospital, and president Dr Spencer Foreman comment; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Religious Figures Offer Abuse Apology on Arab TV
abstract: American spiritual leaders from different faiths condemn abuse of Iraqi prisoners at Abu Ghraib in 30-second ad to be broadcast on Arabic television networks; FaithfulAmerica.org sponsors ad; photo of Rev Donald Shriver reading statement as translation appears (S)

headline: United Seeks Delay to File Bankruptcy Plan
abstract: United Airlines asks United States bankruptcy judge for three more months to file restructuring plan, saying that its exit from bankruptcy protection is not likely before fall (S)

headline: Russia Weighs Tax Shift Toward Oil Sector
abstract: Russian government proposes raising tax rates moderately on oil sector and lower payroll taxes; Prime Min Mikhail Fradkov says package would lower tax bill for other Russian businesses by 280 billion rubles ($9.8 billion); new oil industry taxes would bring in estimated $2 billion to $3.5 billion; Finance Min Aleksei Kudrin also proposes raising dividend tax to 9 percent from 6 percent, starting in 2005; photo (M)

headline: Alarm Sounds for Overheated Housing Market
abstract: As house prices in the US have surged in recent years there has been no shortage of economists warning that boom would eventually turn to bust. But as interest rate rises loom, such concerns are acquiring added urgency.

headline: Economic Scene; A study looks at what the public knows, or doesn't know, about economics and why.
abstract: Alan B Krueger Economic Scene column on studies by Alan S Blinder and Krueger and Joel Slemrod of University of Michigan on public knows, or does not know, about economics and why; graph (M)

headline: Israelis Kill 12 Palestinians as Fighting Rages in Gaza
abstract: Israelis killed 12 Palestinians today after militants destroyed an Israeli armored vehicle in the Gaza Strip on Wednesday, leaving five soldiers dead.

headline: The Masters of Jihad
abstract: A poorhouse and a nuclear power, an ally of the United States and an incubator for Islamist violence: Pakistan is a land of contradictions and poses a danger to the world. Washington is backing Musharraf, who indulges radical mullahs but allows the CIAs special forces to hunt for bin Laden.

headline: UNION PACIFIC CUTS SECOND-QUARTER EARNINGS FORECAST
abstract: Union Pacific, biggest railroad in nation, says second-quarter earnings will fall fromyear ago on higher costs to end shipping delays and buy diesel fuel (S)

headline: Humans vs. Computers, Again. But There's Help for Our Side.
abstract: James Fallows article on race to design knowledge management systems to help people find data on their own computers or networks; notes Microsoft is taking unusual two-front approach to problem, planning to build new file-retrieval features into Windows operating system and developing separate program that seeks to provide easy, elegant way to lodge bits of significant data and then get them back at right time; questions whether any of other companies tackling problem will attain enough of independent identity to co-exist with Microsoft; drawing (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Industrial Output Rises
