abstract: Malaysia's industrial production rose 11.1 percent in February from year earlier, slowest pace in five months (S)

headline: In the Besieged City, the Marines Look Ahead Uneasily to Joint Patrols With Iraqis
abstract: American marine officers in Falluja privately express concerns about prospect of joint patrols with American-trained security forces known as Iraqi Civil Defense Corps; it is unclear how many may show up for duty and what will be degree of their enthusiasm; there are worries among American troops that they could turn on Americans or lead them into ambush; timeline showing incidents of diplomacy and those of fighting in Falluja (M)

headline: SCHICK SUES GILLETTE OVER RAZOR TECHNOLOGY PATENTS
abstract: Energizer Holdings Inc, maker of Schick razors, sues rival Gillette Co in dispute over diamond coating on razors (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: What India's Upset Vote Reveals: The High Tech Is Skin Deep
abstract: Coexistence of growing middle class in India with growing frustration of those excluded from it helps explain why Prime Min Atal Bihari Vajpayee's government has been turned out of office in biggest upset since 1977, when Indira Gandhi lost after imposing state of emergency; information technology industry in India employs fewer than one million people, compared with 40 million registered unemployed; photo (M)

headline: At Summit, Police and Delegations Outnumber the Demonstrators
abstract: Protestors are scarce at Savannah, Ga, park set aside for demonstrations during Group of Eight summit meeting; organizers say protest in Brunswick, closer to conference on secluded Sea Island, drew 200 people; protest organizers cite reasons for low turnout (M)

headline: Three Are Killed in Fire at a Rome Hotel
abstract: ROME, May 1 (Agence France-Presse) — A Canadian couple and an American man were killed when fire broke out Saturday in one of Rome's most luxurious hotels.

headline: OWENS CORNING REACHES ACCORD WITH CREDITORS
abstract: Owens Corning Corp reaches agreement with asbestos claimants, bondholders and suppliers on bankruptcy recovery plan; bondholders, bank lenders and suppliers will be paid about 38.5 percent of $3.2 billion they are owed; asbestos creditors are owed estimated $16 billion (S)

headline: CHURCH & DWIGHT WILL ACQUIRE REST OF ARMKEL
abstract: Church & Dwight acquires half of Armkel LLC it does not already own from Kelso & Co for $254 million (S)

headline: Weary Serbs Try Again to Elect a Leader Acceptable to the World
abstract: Serbian voters will cast ballots for president for fourth time in 18 months; first three elections were declared void because of low voter turnout, causing government to drop law requiring 50 percent turnout; opinion polls favor Tomislav Nikolic, leader of nationalist Serbian Radical party, to win; Nikolic was partner of Slobodan Milosevic and early proponent of ethnically pure 'Greater Serbia'; closest rival is Boris Tadic of Democratic Party; post is largely symbolic, but could undermine or support current coalition government of Prime Min Vojislav Kostunica (M)

headline: Standing in the Niche, Trying to Hold Your Own
abstract: Small Business column on Velocity Micro, manufacturer of custom personal computers for computer game enthusiasts; company's founder-chief executive Randall P Copeland says he welcomes competition from Dell, Hewlett-Packard and Gateway; photo (M)

headline: Digging Up the Past at 45 R.P.M.
abstract: James Gorman Online Shopper column discusses finding old songs on music download Web sites; Web sites noted; drawing (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Loses Bid To Overturn Ruling
abstract: Microsoft loses bid to overturn judge's ruling on validity of its Windows trademark before trial begins in lawsuit against Lindows Inc; Federal appeals court declines to hear Microsoft's claim that judge incorrectly ruled validity of Windows trademark could be based on how term was used 20 years ago; Microsoft sued Lindows in 2001, saying name Lindows confuses customers (S)

headline: New Health Care Lawsuits
abstract: Uninsured patients sue over half-dozen more tax-exempt health care groups in five states, accusing them of overcharging; suits are second wave of ligitation against nonprofit hospital industry; Richard Scruggs, lawyer who coordinates suits, says suits seek to represent all patients charged more for hospital care than insured patients (S)

headline: Silicon Valley Gears Up for Another Big Thing
abstract: Computer makers, software designers and telecommunications companies are scrambling to incorporate wireless capabilities into their business strategies; roundup of plans and offerings from Apple, Intel, Cisco, and Good Technology (special section, Wireless Living) (M)

headline: MILWAUKEE SIGN MAKER TO BUY SIMILAR COMPANY IN BUFFALO
abstract: Brady Corp agrees to buy EMED Co, maker of various types of signs, from Summit Partners for about $190 million (S)

headline: France Is Struggling to Suppress Extremist Muslim Clerics
abstract: Abdelkadar Bouziane is fifth Muslim cleric expelled from France this year on charges of spreading dangerously divisive brand of radical Islam; France has one of strictest antiterrorism programs in Europe, because it was hit early by Islamist terror and because it has largest Muslim population on Continent; making its hard-line stance stick is difficult, even in country more willing than most of its neighbors to limit free speech in interest of calm and cohesive society; Bouziane has won appeal that would allow him to return to France, despite court evidence showing his links to groups supporting terrorism; his expulsion and possible return highlight thorny issue most countries across Europe face as they struggle to meet needs of growing Muslim populations; part of problem is dearth of domestically trained clerics to lead congregations of European-born Muslims; photos; map (M)

headline: Hong Kong Crowds Mark Tiananmen Square Killings
abstract: Estimated 82,000 people, including some mainland Chinese, gather in Hong Kong to mark 15th anniversary of Tiananmen Square crackdown on pro-democracy students; square itself in Beijing is largely quiet; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Embassy on a 'Sacrosanct' Hill? It's a Balkan Battle
abstract: American plan to construct $50 million United States Embassy on Gradiste hill overlooking capital of Skopje, Macedonia, runs into opposition from many Macedonians, who consider hill as one of most important historical sites in country, as well as home to recently discovered 300-year-old cemetery that may hold as many as 2,000 graves; they want Macedonian government to cancel its deal to sell land to US government and designate area as national heritage spot; it appears unlikely that would happen; US Amb Lawrence Butler denies that proposed building would damage historical remains or artifacts; photos; map (M)

headline: California Agency Opens New York Office
abstract: Colby & Partners, California unit of Dentsu agency company, is opening New York office (S)

headline: Afghan Asks NATO to Protect Officials Registering Voters
abstract: President Hamid Karzai pleaded with hesitant NATO leaders today to protect officials trying to register voters.

headline: Top Rebel, a Convicted Killer, Surrenders to Police in Haiti
abstract: Louis-Jodel Chamblain, Haitian rebel leader, gives himself up to police in elaborately choreographed surrender; proclaims his innocence of murder of supporter of Jean-Bertrand Aristide, ousted president, for which he was convicted in absentia, and predicts he will be acquitted in new trial; supporters of Aristide and his Lavalas party criticize interim government for waiting more than month to arrest Chamblain and for treating him delicately even as former Aristide ministers are thrown in jail; photo (M)

headline: Patents; Software that could let people see what TV shows their friends are watching and let them tune in.
abstract: Three America Online researchers patent software that will allow people to log on to Instant Messaging or chat rooms on Internet, call up a buddy list, see what TV shows their friends are watching and then switch their televisions to same channel (M)

headline: M&C Saatchi's plans to go public revive memories of another agency's bruising stockholder battle.
abstract: Heather Timmons column on M&C Saatchi's announcement of initial public offering that is intended to raise 10 million pounds ($18 million) and values whole company at about 75 million pounds; says announcement sets off disquieting memories of Saatchi & Saatchi's initial public offering nine years ago and its sad consequences for stockholders; David Kershaw, who left Saatchi & Saatchi with Charles and Maurice Saatchi, is now one five partners with them in M&C Saatchi and will be chief executive of public company, insists that things will be different this time around (M)

headline: For Sony, a Brief Respite in Its Recent Struggles
abstract: Sony's entertainment divisions seem to be recovering from years of bloated spending, with film division producing five profitable movies in row and Sony Music Entertainment finally turning profit in year ended March1 as it awaits approval of its merger with BMG; Sony Corp of America chairman Sir Howard Stringer discusses turnaround, interview; it is still unclear whether Sony executives will embrace Sony Pictures Entertainment chairman and chief executive Michael Lynton as he seeks even more cost savings and tries to bring stability to dysfunctional studio; market share graphs; photos (M)

headline: IRAQ UPDATE
abstract: Update of news on Iraq war; map (M)

headline: 2 U.S. Marines Killed in Afghan Attack
abstract: Two US marines are killed and one is wounded in eastern Afghanistan when they are ambushed during operation near border with Pakistan (S)

headline: Main Suspect In Spain Blasts Among Dead
abstract: Interior Min Angel Acebes of Spain says forensic experts have identified one of bodies found in Madrid apartment building raided by police as man suspected of masterminding Mar 11 train bombings, Sarhane Ben Abdelmajid Fakhet, a Tunisian; says another body has been identified as that of Abdennabi Kounjaa, a Moroccan; both men were on wanted list of six men believed to have orchestrated Mar 11 attacks; 15 suspects, mainly of Morocccan descent, have been jailed in investigation focusing on militant Moroccan Islamic Combatant Group; Acebes says third body has been identified as that of Asri Rifaat Anouar, who is not on list of key suspects but is believed to be part of same group; DNA experts are trying to identify fourth man, who was found with 4.4 pounds of explosives strapped around his body; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Balance Rises
abstract: Surplus in Japan's current account grew 46.2 percent in February from year earlier, helped by rising exports to Asia and Europe and decline in services deficit (S)

headline: U.S. Cites Scant Progress in Nuclear Talks With North Korea
abstract: Senior Bush administration official, speaking from nuclear talks in Beijing, says US and North Korea have made little headway in resolving their standoff, but intend to keep trying (M)

headline: Gruner & Jahr Appoints a Chief Executive After a Difficult Search
abstract: J Russell Denson, former chief executive of Reiman Media Group, is named chief executive of Gruner & Jahr USA Publishing; photo (M)

headline: Staying Cool When the Boss Panics
abstract: Career Couch article on dealing with boss who is constantly in crisis mode; drawing (M)

headline: Raining? Check the Phone.
abstract: When you write about technology, you get to know your FedEx guy pretty well. Sometimes the packages contain products I've requested for review. Sometimes they arrive unsolicited from companies hoping for coverage. Either way, the neighbors must think I'm operating a mail-order outfit out of the living room.

headline: Former Chief of Vivendi In French Police Custody
abstract: French financial police question and hold overnight former Vivendi Universal chief Jean-Marie Messier as part of probe into stock price manipulation; his lawyer say he sought probe to gain access to evidence against him and others; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Minister's Killer Appeals
abstract: Mijailo Mijailovic, who was sentenced to life in prison for stabbing death of Swedish Foreign Minister Anna Lindh, appeals verdict; holds that prosecutors did not prove his intention to kill her; says he should be tried for manslaughter (S)

headline: When the Leader Lags in Sales
abstract: IDC study finds sales of digital video recorders, devices that record television programs on hard drive, are finally gaining momentum; finds TiVo, company that popularized idea, is increasingly being left behind, with just 39 percent of United States market in 2003; graphs of sales and market share; photo (S)

headline: Israeli Soldiers Ambushed as Dispute Continues Over Bodies
abstract: An Israeli military vehicle reportedly exploded today in Gaza Strip, killing at least five Israeli soldiers.

headline: ABUSE OF CAPTIVES MORE WIDESPREAD, SAYS ARMY SURVEY
abstract: Army survey of deaths and mistreatment involving prisoners in American custody in Iraq and Afghanistan shows widespread pattern of abuse involving more military units than previously known; Iraqi cases date back to Apr 15, 2003 and extend up to Apr death of prisoner detained by Navy commandos; survey lists status of probes into three dozen cases, including continuing probe into abuses at Abu Ghraib; indicates Army did not conduct autopsies on may of 37 prisoners who died in custody; suggests deaths now being probed most vigorously may be Dec 2002 deaths of two prisoners in one week in Bagram, Afghanistan, where platoon from intelligence battalion oversaw interrogations; photos (M)

headline: Why Were Chinese in Iraq? Like Many Neighbors, They Needed Work
abstract: Kidnapping and release of seven Chinese laborers in Iraq defuses diplomatic crisis for China, but leaves unanswered for much of rest of world question of what Chinese laborers were doing in such a violent place; Chinese workers are from Fujian PRovince, known for exporting human beings, usually illegally; Fujianese, fleeing desperate poverty, have long been willing to go anywhere and take any risks in search of work and opportunity; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Importing Tycoon For Cabinet
abstract: Georgian President Mikhail Saakashvili appoints Russian tycoon Kakha A Bendukidze as economic minister (S)

headline: Iraqis Start to Exercise Power Even Before Date for Turnover
abstract: Much of return of sovereignty to Iraq has already happened in advance of official turnover date; new interim government has been formed, old governing council has been dissolved and majority of ministries, including some key ones, have been turned over to Iraqi management; both American advisers and Iraqi leaders say their roles have already shifted, with Iraqis running day-to-day affairs and Americans dispensing advice and money; United States will continue to steer Iraq through its control over $18.4 billion reconstruction budget and presence of 140,000 American troops, who struggle to end insurgency; builds large embassy on grounds of occupation authority, central Baghdad, essentially to serve as shadow government; transition time line; photos (M)

headline: NORTEL SELLING TELEPHONE SOFTWARE UNIT TO VOLT
abstract: Nortel Networks Corp, North America's largest maker of telephone equipment, says Volt Information Services Inc agreed to acquire its businesses that provide software and maintenance for telephone operator workstations (S)

headline: Another Side Of a Viacom Dispute
abstract: another s4

headline: Saudis Kill 2 Tied to Attack at Khobar
abstract: Security forces killed two men linked to the weekend shooting attack at the Khobar oil center in Saudi Arabia that left 22 people dead.

headline: IRAQ UPDATE
abstract: Update of events in Iraq; map (S)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Defense Department confirms death of one American service member in Iraq, bringing total to 641 dead (S)

headline: On or Off? Odd U.S. Alliance With an Ex-Hussein General
abstract: Marines drop plans for all-out attack to rid Falluja of stubborn insurgency; instead, at behest of political leaders and top commanders, they decide to enter into odd alliance with Gen Jasim Muhammad Saleh, former commander of feared Republican Guard, and his somewhat amorphous army; marines' hope is to put Iraqi face on control over city that has become Arab symbol of resistance to occupation; Saleh has claimed there are no foreign fighters in Falluja; situation becomes more confused when Gen Richard B Myers goes on television to say Saleh will not be in charge of Iraqi force; as fighters in Falluja celebrate what mosque loudspeakers hail as 'victory over the Americans,' Saleh says problem in Falluja is fault of Americans (M)

headline: Relatives of the Lost Want a Longer, More Open Book
abstract: Some family members of Sept 11 terrorist attacks victims say report of independent commission probing attacks is not comprehensive enough; many have religiously attended commission hearings; some who have been doing own investigative work cite leads they want followed; photo (M)

headline: A Trailer Becomes a Rolling Abode
abstract: Itty Atcravi, a Thai immigrant who considers himself the true inventor of the rack & pinion kitty litter, received a patent for a multistory mobile home.

headline: Ex-Executives of Symbol Technologies Charged With Fraud
abstract: Federal criminal charges were filed today against seven former senior executives of the company for an accounting fraud scheme.

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: ITALY: Weapons Bound For U.S. Are Seized; FRANCE: Imam Arrested For Wife-Beating Remarks; NORTHERN IRELAND: Party Linked To I.R.A.; BELGIUM: Sex Criminal In Clash With Victim; SWEDEN: Speedy Monarch;.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Uzbekistan: Bank Withdraws Aid
abstract: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development announces suspension of loans to Uzbekistan government, citing continued human rights violations and stalled economic reforms (S)

headline: BUFFETTEERS AHOY!
abstract: Over 50 students at University of Pennsylvanin

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Defense Dept confirms deaths of four service members in Iraq (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Telecom Profit Slips
abstract: Deutsche Telekom earned 169 million euros ($201 million) in first quarter as sales increased 3 percent, to 14 billion euros (S)

headline: Attention Wal-Mart Plaintiffs: Hurdles Ahead
abstract: Lawyers and legal scholars not directly involved in case agree women suing Wal-Mart Stores for sex discrimination must keep case simple; plaintiffs seem to have cleared key hurdle with Judge Martin J Jenkins' decision to certify suit as class-action; calculating amount women say they were underpaid would be relatively easy; calculating damages for those who claim they were unfairly denied promotion would be more difficult; photo (M)

headline: Hynix Drops Plan to Sell Assets to Citigroup
abstract: South Korea's Hynix Semiconductor ends talks to sell its nonmemory assets to Citigroup Venture Capital (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Middleton Doll Co, Pewaukee, Wis, maker of collectible dolls, will move production of most of its dolls to China to reduce costs (S)

headline: Venezuelan Leader Braces for Recall Vote
abstract: Human Rights Watch warns that Pres Hugo Chavez is poised to pack Venezuelan Supreme Court with allies if August recall referendum is as close as expected; new Chavez law expands court from 20 to 32 members; government also begins intense social spending to fend off challenge from determined opposition (M)

headline: Vanunu, Disdaining Israel, Is Freed to Chants vs. Cheers
abstract: Mordechai Vanunu, former Israeli nuclear technician who disclosed information about country's clandestine nuclear program to news media, is released from prison after serving 18-year sentence; dozens of supporters, mostly American and British, cheer him as hero of anti-nuclear cause, while several hundred Israelis denounce him as spy and traitor; he says he is proud of what he did; faces list of restrictions that bar him from leaving country for year or speaking with foreigners; photo (M)

headline: A Push to Change Buying for Television
abstract: Association of National Advertisers and American Association of Advertising Agencies are forming committee called Network Upfront Discussion Group to lobby for changes in porcess marketers use to buy billions of dollars in commercial time ahead of fall season in what is known as upfront market; complaints about process have increased as prices networks charge rise faster than inflation and selling has become more concentrated in frenzied week or two of deal making; advertisers and agencies also say they are unhappy that upfront market begins in spring, months before they complete marketing plans for year (M)

headline: Kupper Parker Acquires Rabasca Marketing
abstract: Kupper Parker Communications acquires Rabasca & Co Marketing Communications for undisclosed terms (S)

headline: Molson Says It Might Sell Stake in Brazilian Unit
abstract: Molson Cos chief executive Daniel J O'Neill says company may seek buyer for its 80 percent stake in Brazilian brewer Cervejarias Kaiser unless Kaiser's fortunes improve markedly by January, news conference after Molson annual meeting; deputy chairman R Ian Molson steps down from board after clashing with his distant cousin, chairman Eric H Molson; Ian's brother William, speaking at meeting, questions why Eric Molson, 66, has not supported Ian to succeed him; company cuts board to 10 directors from 15; Daniel W Colson is elected to board without support of several big outside shareholders; photos (M)

headline: Google Says to Investors: Don't Think of Flipping
abstract: Wall Street loves Google, but the feeling isn't mutual. That message permeates the company's public offering statement.

headline: U.S. Weighs U.N. Proposal For an Interim Iraqi Leader
abstract: Bush administration officials say they are considering United Nations proposal to appoint Iraq's current Planning Minister Dr Mahdi al-Hafidh as prime minister when American occupation is dissolved on June 30; he is thought to be secular-leaning Shiite who could win broad acceptance from Iraqi factions, including Shiite followers of Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, whose backing is considered crucial; Hafidh would be expected to step aside once elected government is formed next year; plans for interim government call for president to be largely ceremonial job and for two deputy prime ministers to help in day-to-day governing of Iraq; three jobs are expected to be shared by Shiites, Sunnis and Kurds; Hafidh has reportedly won support of Lakhdar Brahimi, special UN envoy enlisted by Bush adminstration to help select caretaker government; photo (M)

headline: Prosecutors Call Russian Tycoon And Partners a 'Criminal Group'
abstract: Russian prosecutors outline in detail government's charges against Platon Lebedev, one of Yukos Oil Co's largest shareholders, alleging that he and Yukos founder Mikhail B Khodorkovsky were part of 'organized criminal group' that sought to defraud government during 1990's privatization era; Khodorkovsky and Lebedev have denied charges; Lebedev's trial date is not yet set (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Investment Grows
abstract: China reports acceleration in foreign direct investment, suggesting government measures to slow economy are not prompting overseas companies to scale back their expansion plans; investment from abroad increased 11 percent from year ago to $25.9 billion in five months through May after rising 10 percent in first four months of year and 7.5 percent in first quarter (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: La-Z-Boy Inc., Monroe, Mich., a manufacturer and retailer of home furnishings, said it would take a pretax charge in the fourth quarter, citing import competition from China. The company said the charge would be $71.9 million, $55.9 million net of tax, or $1.04 a share.    International Steel Group Inc., Richfield, Ohio, the steel manufacturer, has agreed to buy the Georgetown Steel facility, Georgetown, S.C., for $16 million in cash plus assumed liabilities.

headline: Brazil Mining Giant Said to Seek Noranda Stake
abstract: Brazil's Companhia Vale do Rio Doce has held talks to acquire controlling stake in Noranda, big, diversified Canadian mining group, for as much as $3 billion; graph; photo (M)

headline: Philippine Militant and 5 Followers Are Killed in Firefight
abstract: A leader of the Muslim militant group Abu Sayyaf and five of his men were killed during a firefight with government troops on a southern Philippine island today, officials said.

headline: Mother Creates Ads For N.B.A Playoffs
abstract: New York office of Mother, London-based ad agency, creates campaign promoting National Basketball Association playoffs (S)

headline: Prosecutors Seek More Time in Another Tyco Case
abstract: New York prosecutors asked for more time, citing the length of the six-month trial and the publicity around its collapse in a mistrial.

headline: World Briefing | United Nations: Focus On Anti-Semitism
abstract: Secretary General Kofi Annan, speaking at first United Nations conference on anti-Semitism, calls on body to adopt measures specifically condemning anti-Semitism (S)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: 2 Palestinians Killed In Nablus
abstract: Israeli troops, searching for seven suspected militants, mostly from Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades, shoot and kill two young Palestinian men in Nablus (S)

headline: May Stores Acquiring Marshall Field's
abstract: May Department Stores Co acquires Marshall Field's for $3.24 billion in cash from Target Corp, which bought retail chain in 1990; also buys sites of nine Mervyn's stores in Midwest; May chairman-chief executive Gene S Kahn comments; deal will allow Target to more sharply focus on its discount chain (M)

headline: Big Liquor Marketers Choose Ad Agencies
abstract: Big Liquor Marketers.

headline: Ventures Aim to Cut Cost of Overseas Cell Calls to Pennies
abstract: Several entrepreneurs want to use Internet technology to cut to pennies the cost of using cellular telephones to call overseas; include i2Telecom, which plans to release modemlike device to route calls over Internet, and Skype Technologies, which offers free software that lets people turn handheld computers into mobile phones; both ventures take to new level market-disrupting potential of voice over Internet protocol technology; photo (M)

headline: Stewart Prosecution Witness Pleads Not Guilty to Perjury
abstract: Ink expert Larry F Stewart who testified for prosecution of Martha Stewart's trial pleads not guilty to two counts of perjury, and his lawyer Judith Wheat suggests that at leasst one witness who said her client lied may have wanted to make him look bad; Mr Stewart's trial is scheduled to begin Sept 20; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Fiat's Loss Narrows
abstract: Fiat's first-quarter loss narrowed to 194 million euros ($230 million) from 681 million euros year earlier; sales fell to 11.2 billion euros from 12.3 billion euros (S)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Defense Dept confirms deaths of three service members in Iraq (S)

headline: Managing Editor of Money Moves to Time
abstract: Bob Safian is leading as Money magazine managing editor to become executive editor at Time; will be succeeded by Eric Schurenberg (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Airline Drops Alliance Talks
abstract: Swiss International Air Lines ends talks on alliance with British Airways, leading to speculation that it may become affiliated with Lufthansa and setting off rally in its share price; photo (S)

headline: Reservist to Face Court-Martial for Prisoner Abuse
abstract: If convicted of all charges, Specialist Jeremy Sivits could face a combination of penalties, including as much as a year in prison.

headline: The Lights Are Not Quite On All Over Baghdad, but There Are New Hands on the Switch
abstract: Workers at Iraqi Electricity Ministry say work is same now that Iraqis are in charge, but feel return of pride; are unsure how much authority Iraqis will actually wield; photo (M)

headline: As Iraq Insurgency Spreads, U.S. Finds More Foes and Fewer Friends
abstract: Military analysis of situation in Iraq, where spreading insurgency has drastically altered strategic equation for United States military (M)

headline: Strong to Pay $60 Million in Mutual Fund Inquiry
abstract: The ex-chief executive of Strong Financial has also agreed to apologize and accept a lifetime ban from the financial industry.

headline: Escape From the Clutches Of a Counterfeit Web Site
abstract: SpoofStick software from CoreStreet places toolbar in browser window that displays domain information to help users determine if they are visiting genuine Web site or bogus one designed to 'phish' for personal information; photo (M)

headline: Combat in Iraq Dulls Appetite for Trade
abstract: Violence in Iraq is making foreign companies think twice about attending country's first trade expo since Baghdad fell; Destination Baghdad Expo was supposed to start this week but has been postponed until end of month because of security concerns (S)

headline: World Briefings
abstract: ASIA.

headline: Flotilla Is Beijing's Message To an Unsettled Hong Kong
abstract: Eight Chinese warships sail down Victoria Harbor in Hong Kong; rare show of force comes as democracy advocates in Hong Kong say they are facing growing intimidation; Chinese military has been nearly invisible presence until now; people favoring popular elections find themselves under growing pressure; city's best-known radio talk show host, Albert Cheng, is longtime supporter of greater democracy and critic of local government; he has flown to Europe, leaving behind tape recording in which he complains of growing threats of violence against himself and his family (M)

headline: Entrepreneurship Courses: It Pays to Pick the School
abstract: Small Business column on business schools that offer entrepreneurship courses geared to small owner; courses at Harvard, Sloan School of Management at Massachusetts Institute of Technology and George Washington University described; photo (M)

headline: Moving to Fuel Efficiency; Smaller S.U.V.'s Draw More Attention as Gasoline Prices Rise
abstract: At Village Ford, a dealership here in the backyard of the Ford Motor Company, one corner of the display window shows an Explorer, the sport utility vehicle that has been a stalwart of the company's sales for years.       At another corner stands the Escape, a smaller vehicle that averages about 23 miles a gallon, the government says, 5 miles a gallon better than the Explorer.

headline: Ex-Vivendi Chief Under Formal Investigation
abstract: France opens formal probe into Jean-Marie Messier, former Vivendi Universal chief executive, on suspicion of share-price manipulation, providing false data and embezzlement as part of inquiry into company's accounts for 2000 and 2001; he must post bail of 1.35 million euros ($1.63 million), but is free to travel; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Suspects In Killing Of Aid Workers
abstract: Afghan Interior Minister Ali Ahmad Jalali reports that police in Panjwai District (Kandahar) have arrested 18 suspects in killing of two Afghan aid workers and policeman; accused are found with arsenal of attack equipment and vehicles (S)

headline: Small Company Halts Deal In Light of S.E.C. Inquiry
abstract: Spectrum Sciences and Software, small military contractor whose stock soared earlier this year on extremely heavy volume, says it has suspended its consulting agreement with Robert Genovese, investor who had mounted campaign to publicize company and who company says received and exercised options for majority of outstanding shares; Spectrum, in Securities and Exchange Commission filing, it had been informed by staff of SEC in April 28 letter that it was conducting informal inquiry into company and had requested information on Spectrum's relationship with Genovese and on resignation of Spectrum's former chief executive Donal R Myrick; Myrick, in his resignation letter in March, contended Genovese controlled company, claim denied by two remaining members of Spectrum's board (M)

headline: Friendlier Skies on an Unfriendly Planet
abstract: Article on various topics discussed at two-day annual conference of World Travel and Tourism Council, which was held in Qatar and drew about 1,000 representatives from travel industry and from world governments; drawing (M)

headline: Correction
abstract: A brief report in the Suits column last Sunday about the departures of three senior executives of the DPL Corporation misidentified the executive who, according to an outside law firm, had deleted files from a computer the firm asked to see. He was Peter H. Forster, the chairman, not Stephen F. Koziar Jr., the chief executive.

headline: Business People; Another Role for Liddy, This Time as Vitamin Man
abstract: another role for lidddy, this time as vitamin man**G Gordon Liddy, 73, radio talk show host and Watergate conspirator, agrees to be spokesman for Nature's Youth, company that sells nutritional supplements; photo (M)

headline: Resolute Bay Journal; Undaunted Arctic Couriers, Coming In With the Veggies
abstract: Arctic pilots are vital to development of Arctic wilderness that makes up third of Canada; area is undergoing rapid social and economic development; dominant Inuit population has evolved in just two generations from migratory hunters to modern lifestyle in rural communities; tourism mining and transport services generate their jobs; pilots bring in fresh food and medical supplies; photos; map (M)

headline: Has the Tortoise's Time Finally Come?
abstract: Jonathan Fuerbringer column on stock market outlook in light of strong first-quarter earnings; cites study that found stocks with lower-quality earnings excel at start of economic and stock market recovery, while companies with high-quality earnings perform better later; performance graph by earnings quality (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Economic Indicators Improve
abstract: Japan's index of leading economic indicators remains above boom-bust line of 50 for eighth consecutive month in April, sign that country's economic recovery may continue (S)

headline: Magazine Advertising Finally Looks Up
abstract: Publishers Information Bureau says magazine ad pages rose 4.8 percent in May compared with year earlier (S)

headline: U.S. Military Disputed Protected Status of Prisoners Held in Iraq
abstract: International Committee of the Red Cross reported in November on abuses at Abu Ghraib prison; Brig Gen Janis Karpinski sent letter in December to Red Cross asserting that many Iraqi prisoners are not entitled to full protection of Geneva Conventions and, citing exemption in Fourth Geneva Convention, emphasized military necessity of isolating prisoners deemed security risks; Red Cross disputes interpretation of relevant article; Bush administration officials have recently publicly said Geneva Conventions are fully applicable in Iraq; photo (M)

headline: European Economic Liberalization: Often Forecast but Never Done
abstract: Floyd Norris comment on European economic liberalization that was supposed to come with formation of European Union but never occurred; graph (M)

headline: House Committee Says C.I.A. Is Courting Disaster by Mismanaging Its Human Spying
abstract: Republican-led House Intelligence Committee issues scathing report, warning that Central Intelligence Agency is heading 'over a proverbial cliff' through mismanagement of its human spying operations; report is part of intelligence authorization bill; criticism carries particular significance because it was drafted by panel headed by Rep Porter J Goss, who is considered leading candidate to succeed George J Tenet as director of central intelligence (M)

headline: Mandalay Board Approves $4.8 Billion Sale to MGM
abstract: Mandao

headline: Fees Help Lift Banks' Profits In First Quarter
abstract: Wells Fargo & Co, Bank One Corp and US Bancorp say first-quarter profits rose as fees from credit cards, bank accounts and consumer loans bolster revenue; Wells Fargo says net income increased 18 percent to $1.77 billion; Bank One records 51 percent increase in net income to $1.2 billion; US Bancorp says first-quarter income rose 14 percent to record $1 billion (S)

headline: Israeli Soldiers Search for Remains After Bomb Kills 6
abstract: Israeli troops conduct grim house-to-house search for their comrades' remains, Gaza City, after Palestinian militants blow up troop carrier and make off with body parts of soldiers; incident grows out of almost routine Israeli raid on city to destroy suspected arms factories; at least seven Palestinians are killed and dozens wounded in raid; Israel rejects Palestinian bid to trade body parts for Palestinian prisoners; pledges to continue search, raising possibility that soldiers will continue to operate in city neighborhood that is militant stronghold; asks Red Cross aid in retrieving remains; Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat says Palestinian Authority tries to end impasse according to religious and humanitarian traditions; map; photo (M)

headline: Islam and Democracy: Algerians Try to Blaze a Trail
abstract: Algeria manages to elect Pres Abdelaziz Bouteflika to second term in voting that is widely celebrated as free and fair and a monumental accomplishment after decade-long civil war with radiical Islamists; exercise comes with lesson for would-be Arab democracies: timing is important and participants must agree to secular principles needed for democracy to work; photo of Bouteflika (M)

headline: Fogbound Over Nebraska, Without a WC
abstract: Frequent Flier column on Greater Topeka Chamber of Commerce president Douglas S Kinsinger focuses on some of airline travel experiences; photo (M)

headline: Overcoming Obstacles To Sharing Your Files
abstract: Q. I tried to send a file to a friend using America Online's stand-alone Instant Messenger program, but it wouldn't work. Why not?    A. In addition to real-time text messaging, AOL Instant Messenger software can transfer files directly between two connected users, including documents that might be too large to e-mail.

headline: Oil Prices Fall on OPEC Hint of More Output
abstract: Crude oil prices fall to three-week lows as OPEC president Purnomo Yusgiantoro says cartel will consider raising production quotas by 2 million barrels a day, from current 23.5 million, when it meets in Beirut on June 3; comments by US Energy Sec Spencer Abraham that oil-producing countries will increase their production also bolster confidence among traders that some relief to tight market might be imminent (M)

headline: Prosecution's Star Could Help Defense In an Enron Trial
abstract: Defendants in first criminal fraud trial stemming from Enron Corp collapse may get help from unlikely source: Andrew S Fastow, former Enron executive who is government's star cooperator; Fastow's statements, as described in government document, do not exonerate defendants; but they contain enough equivocation about events surrounding questionable financial deal between Enron and Merrill Lynch & Co that is at center of case that defense lawyers could use his comments to cast doubt on whether their clients entered into deal with intent to commit crime; government is expected to introduce documents--including some written by defendants--and call other witnesses to argue its case against four former executives of Merrill Lynch and two former Enron officials; case involves what government contends was fake financial transaction between Merrill and Enron in Dec 1999 that enabled Enron to increase its reported profits when they otherwise would have fallen short of Wall St's expectations (M)

headline: Modest U.S. Aid for North Korea
abstract: Bush administration offers $100,000 in financial aid to North Korea as it copes with aftermath of train explosion that left as many as 8,000 people homeless; State Dept spokesman Richard Boucher says administration will rely on monitors of international relief agencies to ensure that aid goes to blast victims and is not siphoned off by central government; administration is also prepared to provide medical supplies and equipment, and to send team of experts in emergency medicine to work with North Koreans; train explosion destroyed center of Ryongchon, small, remote city of about 20,000; photo (M)

headline: Spanish Leader Pulling Troops From Iraq
abstract: Spain's new Socialist prime minister, José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero, announced that he was ordering Spanish troops to leave Iraq "as soon as possible."

headline: Back to Nature in Lawn Care
abstract: Deborah Ellis letter suggests replacing lawns with native flowers, shrubs and trees

headline: IRAQ UPDATE
abstract: Iraq update; map (S)

headline: Powell Blames C.I.A. for Error on Iraq Mobile Labs
abstract: Sec of State Colin L Powell says he had assurances from intelligence community that one of principal charges he made in United Nations speech in Feb 2003--that Iraq had mobile weapons laboratories--was solid at time; urges presidential commission examining intelligence problems in Iraq to look into what he says was failure by Central Intelligence Agency (M)

headline: Fleeing War, Refugees Met New Strife
abstract: Refugees from Afghanistan who were turned away from Australia in August 2001 endure harsh conditions and uncertain future in camp on Nauru; Australian Prime Min John Howard's tough stance on refugees was popular and helped him win re-election; he called on other countries to accept refugees, and Nauru obliged in exchange for $10 million; international refugee officials have been critical of Australia's behavior; Nauru has refused to admit journalists and has limited lawyers' access to refugees; refugees' long journey described; photos, map (M)

headline: U.S. and Iraq Spar Over Who Should Run Corruption Inquiry Into Oil-for-Food Program
abstract: Iraq's political leaders are sparring with American occupation administrator L Paul Bremer III over who should investigate possible official and corporate corruption in United Nations oil-for-food program; dispute pits Bremer against people he appointed to council last year; as June 30 date for American power transfer approaches, two sides have increasingly been at odds over future political setup (M)

headline: Google Says It Doesn't Plan To Change Search Results
abstract: Google Inc has no plans to alter its search results despite complaints that first listing on search for word 'Jew' directs people to anti-Semitic Web site; first listed site on search for 'Jew' is 'Jewwatch.com,' which promotes itself as 'Keeping a close watch on Jewish communities and organizations worldwide' and offering references to anti-Semitic research, documents and organizations; Web site calling itself 'Remove JewWatch.com from the Google search engine!' is circulating petition asking Google to remove site from its listings (M)

headline: Data, Data Everywhere, and All for Me
abstract: Times reporter Jennifer 8 Lee shares experience of having wireless access for first time (special section, Wireless Living) (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Warlord's Auction Fails
abstract: Auction of luxury goods left behind by Adzharian separatist leader Aslan Abashidze when he fled last week to Russia fails when no one comes to buy items; Georgian President Mikhail Saakashvili holds that proceeds of sale would have been spent on social programs in Adzharia province; photo (S)

headline: Shouldn't Greenspan Quit While He's Ahead?
abstract: Daniel Akst commentary on Pres Bush's nomination of Alan Greenspan for fifth term as Federal Reserve chairman; lists reasons why Greenspan is wrong choice this time; drawing (M)

headline: Abducted Marine Had Reportedly Deserted
abstract: Marine officer says Cpl Wassef Ali Hassoun, American marine kidnapped by extremists in Iraq, had deserted military because he was emotionally traumatized by seeing his sergeant blown up, and was abducted while trying to make his way home to his native Lebanon; suspects he was betrayed by Iraqis he befriended on base (M)

headline: Fiat Struggles to Steady Itself During Turmoil
abstract: Umberto Agnelli's death has once again raised the question of whether Fiat can survive without breaking up its wide portfolio of businesses.

headline: To Get Weapons Away From Iraqis, the Army Sets Up an Arms Bazaar
abstract: American-led troops in Iraq are trying new approach in year-long effort to get weapons away from Iraqis: they offer to buy them; first day of buyback program in Baghdad is so popular that it is extended for another two days; after three days, total of 56,536 items--bullets, assault rifles, mortars, etc--are turned in for total of $761,357; photo (M)

headline: German Bank Deal Off, Despite Government Effort
abstract: Deutsche Post, mail and delivery giant that owns Postbank, plans to move ahead with bank's previously announced stock offering in June, rejecting sale to Deutsche Bank and pledging to hold on to majority stake in newly public company; is setback for German officials, who had hoped that deal would kick off consolidation in banking; Postbank episode is being regarded in Germany as watershed--sign that Chancellor Gerhard Schroder has decided to emulate French policy of creating and supporting national industrial champions; failure to bring off deal illustrates difficulties Germans face in attempting to follow France's policy; photo (M)

headline: Cheney Praises Japan's Stand Against Abductors in Iraq
abstract: Vice Pres Dick Cheney, in Tokyo for first stop in Asian tour, praises Japan for not bending to demand that it remove its troops from Iraq to win freedom of three Japanese civilians abducted in Iraq; three Japanese, shown blindfolded and kneeling in shocking video, remain out of sight; their kidnappers had vowed to burn them alive if Japanese troops are not withdrawn, but deadline they set comes and goes without any news about them; Sunni religious council says hostages will be released; Japanese public opinion appears to back Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi, who has explicitly refused tearful calls by relatives of three kidnapped Japanese to withdrw troops from Iraq; photo (M)

headline: Cisco Set to Introduce Faster Internet Router
abstract: Cisco Systems will unveil its fastest-ever router, device used to direct traffic over Internet; Cisco is leader in router business, but it faces challenge from main rival Juniper Networks (M)

headline: Bangladesh Arrests Director of Major Anti-Poverty Organization
abstract: Bangladeshi authorities arrest president of Proshika, one of country's largest nongovernment organizations, on charges of corruption; accuse Qazi Faruque Ahmed and his deputy David William Biswas of embezzling money from poverty alleviation fund of Proshika and misappropriating money from fund to pay income tax for 12 consultants; Proshika supporters argue that arrests are politicaly motivated; note Ahmed's outspoken criticism of growth of fundamentalism under government that includes two Islamist parties, and government's perception that Ahmed supports opposition party; government is trying to amend 1978 ordinance so it can gain right to take over any nongovernment organization that engages in political activity (M)

headline: By a Back Door to the U.S.: A Migrant's Grim Sea Voyage
abstract: Special report: Dangerous Passage: From Ecuador by Sea describes hazardous and arduous eight-day voyage, covering 1,100 nautical miles from Ecuador to Guatemala coast, by migrants seeking to reach United States; El Tiempo reporter Sandra Ochoa made trip as client of smugglers, and sometimes as hostage, after migrant smugglers refused to take New York Times reporter; journey provides rare look inside small part of vast pipeline that carries migrants to US; map; photos (L)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Financial Concern Cuts Jobs
abstract: HSBC Group will cut 3,500 jobs in Britain as it moves some clerical and administrative work to Asia and drops some management jobs; losses will be offset by hiring of 1,000 customer relations employees in Britain (S)

headline: Deal Complete, NBC Is Planning To Cross-Market
abstract: NBC formally announces completion of its acquisition of Vivendi Universal's entertainment operations, promising new entity that will aggressively cross-market its television, movie and theme park properties to drive profits while avoiding pitfalls of previous media mergers; NBC chief Bob Wright will be chairman of new NBC Universal; some industry executives say NBC's history in network television business, with its short-term thinking, might hamper NBC Universal's ambitions; pledge to step up NBC's already intensive cross-marketing immediately draws criticism from consumer groups that have challenged growth of big media companies; Center for Digital Democracy's executive director Jeff Chester says Universal was last real independent outlet for writers; adds writers will work for NBC and will have to do what network tells them to do; Wright also announces NBC has signed long-term deals with anchor Tom Brokaw and Dick Wolf, producer behind successful Law & Order series; Brokaw will continue to produce and be anchor of documentaries for various NBC channels for 10 more years after his retirement from NBC's Nightly News on Dec 1; Wolf agrees to remain housed with NBC Universal at least until 2008; photo (M)

headline: From Shared Resources, Your Personal History
abstract: Amateur and professional genealogists use Internet to share and examine commonalties of recorded data; information originally collected and filed by hand is now available in computer databases, making task of tracing family genealogy much easier; Web sites noted; photo (M)

headline: Bremer Is Increasing Pressure for a Quick End to Iraqi Uprisings
abstract: With no sign of a breakthrough in talks with rebels, the leader of the U.S. occupation appeared to move closer to a military showdown.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: TiVo First-Quarter Loss Widens
abstract: TiVo Inc says first-quarter loss widened to $9.07 million as it spent more on research and development; sales rose 21 percent; revenue rose to $34.5million from $28.5 million (S)

headline: Administration Sides With Bells on Lease Discounts for Rivals
abstract: The Bush administration won't seek an extension of the regulations that require regional Bell companies to lease their equipment to their rivals at heavy discounts.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: 'Top To Bottom' Prisons Review
abstract: Lt Gen David Barno, commanding American general in Afghanistan, orders full review of detention practices and facilities in country (S)

headline: I.B.M. Will Collaborate Somewhat More on Chip Design
abstract: IBM plans to adopt more open strategy in its microprocessor business; will share more technical information about its Power family of microprocessors, will widely distribute free software tools for chip design and testing, and will set up series of design centers around world to help customers develop custom chips (M)

headline: British Police Make Second Terror Raid in Three Weeks
abstract: Hundreds of police officers were deployed in Britain today in what was depicted as a major sweep against terrorists.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Real Estate Acquisition
abstract: Spain's Inmobiliaria Colonial, real estate company, plans to buy French property manager Societe Fonciere Lyonnaise for 1.6 billion euros ($2 billion) (S)

headline: World Health Officials Declare End to SARS Outbreak in China
abstract: WHO declares end of SARS outbreak in China that apparently originated with safety breach in government's leading virology laboratory (S)

headline: SYNGENTA AND FOX PAINE TO BUY DUTCH SEED SUPPLIER
abstract: Syngenta and Fox Paine acquire seed company Advanta BV for 400 million euros ($475 million) (S)

headline: TIME TO DUCK, SPIN SISTER
abstract: American Society of Magazine Editors president Susan Ungar

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Janus to Lower Fees As Part of Settlement  The Janus Capital Group said that it would lower fees on its mutual funds as part of a $225 million settlement with regulators over improper trading in its funds.       The New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, demanded the fee reduction of $125 million over five years even though, according to Morningstar, fees on Janus mutual funds are already below average. [Page C5.]

headline: Court Ruling Muddies Merger Scene In Europe
abstract: Antonio Tizzano, advocate general of European Court of Justice, criticizes lower Court of First Instance for overstepping its role when it annulled European Commission's veto of $2 billion merger involving two European packaging companies Tetra Laval and Sidel in 2002; lower court cleared merger, which has since taken place (M) .

headline: Where Chess Is King and the People Are the Pawns
abstract: Pres Kirsan Ilyumzhinov of Russian republic of Kalmykia is also president of World Chess Federation; somehow found $30 million to $50 million dollars in desperately poor steppeland to build modernistic Chess City in Elista to host international tournaments; planned Chess City as heart of larger arts and sciences complex; his grandiose plans spark debate as well as puzzlement; photos; map (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Microsoft Testimony Aids U.S. in Oracle Trial  A top executive of Microsoft testified that the company has no plans to compete in the enterprise software market, bolstering the government's case that the market is far less competitive than Oracle contends.       The testimony from Douglas J. Burgum, a senior vice president at Microsoft, who was subpoenaed by the government, came in the third week of a trial in which the Justice Department is trying to block Oracle's $7.7 billion hostile takeover of PeopleSoft. [Page C5.]

headline: A Smooth Go-Between Brings Taped Movies to Disc
abstract: GoDVD digital video duplicator from Sima simplifies transfer of taped recordings to DVD; photo (S)

headline: Judge Says Racketeering Suit Can Proceed Against Block and Household International
abstract: Federal Judge Elaine E Bucklo rules class-action racketeering lawsuit that accuses H&R Block and Household International of conspiring to trick poor customers into taking out high-interest loans will proceed toward trial; dismisses most of counts against two companies but upholds two racketeering complaints; case began with loan that sole named plaintiff Lynne A Carnegie obtained in February 1995 when she had Block office prepare her taxes; Beneficial Finance, now Household International, made loan in anticipation of her income-tax refund (M)

headline: Iraq's Abu Ghraib Prison Should Be Closed Now
abstract: The decision by the U.S. military to place Iraqi prisoners in Abu Ghraib prison appears bizarre.

headline: Straight to the Heart
abstract: Now that the pact of Washington has been concluded, the political battle on the home front begins for Israeli Prime Minister Sharon. US President Bush is paying a high price for his support.

headline: ATTACKS ON BASRA EXTEND VIOLENCE TO A CALM REGION
abstract: Suicide attacks in Basra bring anger, mourning and upheaval to mostly Shiite southern city that has been spared worst of violence in year-long American occupation; death toll from attacks is said to rise to 68, including as many as 23 children in school bus; well-coordinated attacks were aimed at Iraqi police buildings during morning rush hour; British soldiers are shoved away from twisted and burning cars by mobs angry that foreign troops could not protect city; American administrator L Paul Bremer III repeats his fear that such violence is likely to get worse as June 30 deadline nears for returning sovereignty to Iraqis; in Falluja, marines engage in what is described as heavy battle; top Marine Corps general in Iraq says American attack against insurgents in Falluja is 'inevitable' within days unless militants immediately surrender their heavy weapons and ammunition; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Gain In Car Sales
abstract: European Automobile Manufacturers Association says Western European auto sales rose 1.2 percent in May, fourth consecutive monthly increase; sales rose to 1.24 million vehicles from 1.23 million units year earlier; five-month sales rose 2.8 percent, to 6.43 million vehicles; German sales were down 7.3 percent from year ago (S)

headline: Thompson California Offices United Under JWT West
abstract: Thompson Unites.

headline: Redefined Boundaries and Uneasy Transformations; Immigration Matters Raise New Concerns For Czech Republic
abstract: Third article in series The New Europe examines immigration issues facing expanded European Union; new members in Eastern Europe face demographic problem of aging populations and shrinking workforce and could become magnets for legal and illegal immigration, a marked shift for societies closed off for 40 years under Communism; International Organization for Migration identifies Poland, Czech Republic, Slovakia and Slovenia as attractive destinations; debate over immigration in Czech Republic, which has nearly 230,000 legal immigrants, described; photos; map (M)

headline: First Insiders Sold Their Shares Privately, Then Salesforce.com Filed to Go Public
abstract: Floyd Norris column urges SEC to change rules that will allow Salesforce.com to go public without telling investors about private sales of stock by insiders; says chief executive Marc Benioff has not said what he did with shares he once owned because SEC rules bar him from talking; photo (M)

headline: 8 Investment Firms Are Fined In Sales of Municipal Bonds
abstract: NASD orders UBS, Merrill Lynch and six other investment firms to pay total of $610,000 in fines and restitution after regulators find investors received below-market prices for their municipal bonds; says firms bought bonds from customers that were later resold by other dealers at 'markedly higher prices,' in violation of Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board rules (M)

headline: NATIONAL SENIOR CARE BUYS MARINER HEALTH CARE
abstract: Mariner Health Care Inc, nursing home operator, agrees to be bought by National Senior Care Inc for about $615 million (S)

headline: Chicken Little Is Ready for Medicare
abstract: Fred Brock column clarifies distorted warnings that Medicare could go broke by 2019; Medicare trustees say hospital insurance trust fund is now expected to exhaust its surplus by 2019, but will still be able to pay 80 percent of its bills from Medicare payroll tax; Medicare Part B, which pays for doctors bills and other outpatient services, would not be affected by depletion of hospital fund surplus; drawing (M)

headline: Martha Stewart's Company Nominates 4 New Directors
abstract: Four new directors are nominated for board of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia in move intended to aid troubled company and perhaps widen distance between it and its founder, Martha Stewart; they are Rick Boyko, Michael Goldstein, Susan Lyne and Wenda Harris Millard (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Services: Electronic Data Posts Loss On Navy Contract
abstract: Electronic Data Systems Corp posts first-quarter from continuing operations of $38 million compared with net loss of $1.43 billion year earlier; sales rose to $5.2 billion from $5.02 billion; graph (S)

headline: Dow Prunes AT&T in First Index Change Since 99
abstract: Along with AT&T, International Paper and Eastman Kodak will also be removed from the index of the top 30 industrial stocks.

headline: Roy Walford, 79; Linked Diet to Longevity
abstract: Dr Roy Walford, gerontologist whose pioneering research on longevity showed that low-calorie diet could prolong life and increase vigor, dies age age 79; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: MCI Suspension Ended For New Jersey Contracts
abstract: MCI, which exited biggest bankruptcy in US history in April, has almost three-month suspension from winning New Jersey government contracts lifted because of improved internal controls; company has been barred from contracts because of accounting scandal (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Insurance Unit Sold
abstract: ING sells its general insurance operations in Australia to its local partner, QBE Insurance, for 465 million Australian dollars ($527 million) (S)

headline: U.S. Forces Destroy Office of Cleric in Baghdad
abstract: BAGHDAD, Monday, May 10 — American forces destroyed the Baghdad headquarters of a rebel Shiite cleric on Monday, a day after troops killed at least 19 of his militiamen in clashes in the Sadr City slum district, the military and witnesses said Monday.

headline: For High-Definition Sets, Channels to Match
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column on satellite television service from Voom; service offers 39 high-definition channels, many more than are available from any other source; photo; drawing (M)

headline: Spanish Judge Charges 5 More for Ties to Qaeda
abstract: Spanish Judge Baltasar Garzon, who indicted Osama bin Laden and 34 others last September, charges five more people with supporting Al Qaeda cell in Spain (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Footstar, West Nyack, N.Y., the athletic-shoe retailer that filed for bankruptcy protection last month, said it had won court approval to auction its 355 Footaction stores on April 16.

headline: Disappearance of Rightist Unsettles Colombian Peace Talks
abstract: Peace talks between Colombia's paramilitaries and government are thrown into state of turmoil with disappearance of Carlos Castado, driving force of right-wing paramiltary army; United Self-Defense Forces of Colombia, anti-guerrilla movement he founded, is known for mass killings and drug trafficking and classified as terrorist organization by State Dept; days before his disappearance he was target of assassination attempt by rival faction of organization; it remains unclear if he has been killed and his body hidden or if he escaped into jungle (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Voting Software To Be Demonstrated
abstract: Open Voting Consortium that criticizes current crop of privately developed electronic voting machines as hacker prone and mysterious will demonstrate free software in San Jose, Calif, that it says will make elections more secure and accountable (S)

headline: Vancouver Journal; Chinese Prosper in Canada, and Eagerly Read About It
abstract: Chinese-language news media predominates in Vancouver, British Columbia, where ethnic Chinese population has surged to 30 percent of city's people; Chinese-language press has become influential player on Canadian political landscape; photos (M)

headline: North Korea's Top Priority Remains Secrecy After Blast
abstract: North Korea's state media reports that women in Ryongchon, site of deadly railroad explosion, ran into blazing buildings to save treasured portraits of Kim Jong Il before searching for their children; such tales of sacrifice are staple of country's propaganda mythology; speculation about explosion is swirling; Kim Jong Il has not been seen or heard from since accident; Chinese state television reports that he left Beijing for home on Apr 21, and South Korean reports say his train passed through Ryongchon about eight hours before blast; North Korea refuses to allow foreign journalists to visit site, and has even ignored Chinese offers of treatment for victims at hospitals in Dandong; South Korea is sending aid by ship after North Korea refuses to allow relief goods to arrive by truck; photos; map (M)

headline: Rice and Palestinian Leader Optimistic on Gaza
abstract: National security advisor Condoleezza Rice meets with Palestinian Prime Minister Ahmed Qurei in Berlin; both say afterward that Israeli plan to withdraw from Gaza creates new chance to move toward wider peace agreement; Rice says United States is urging Palestinians to take steps to extend its control in Gaza, particularly by creating professional security force able to combat terrorism (S)

headline: AT&T's Net and Revenue Fall As Phone Prices Head Lower
abstract: AT&T Corp says first-quarter profit fell by almost half, to $304 million; revenue plunges 11.1 percent, to $7.99 billion (M)

headline: How Frozen Pizza Got Hot
abstract: Kraft Foods' DiGiorno brand, which revolutionized frozen pizzas with 1995 introduction of pizza featuring rising crust, is set to introduce pizza with thin crispy crust; Kraft Pizza Co vice president John Boswell notes Agriculture Department rule change will allow frozen products that do not contain tomato sauce to be called pizza; photo (M)

headline: A Bridge to Sicily, or a Castle in the Air?
abstract: Promoters of long-sought bridge linking Calabria and Sicily lay out proposal for longest suspension bridge on record to be built between Messina and Reggio di Calabria; photo of ferry; map; span nearly 10,000 feet long would have 12-lane roadway and two-way railroad track, and anchoring towers taller than Eiffel Tower (M)

headline: In Jordan's Scrapyards, Signs of a Looted Iraq
abstract: Sensitive military equipment, brand-new components for oil rigs and water plants and whole complexes of older buildings are being smuggled out of Iraq on flatbed trucks, even as United States spends billions of dollars to rebuild Iraq's civil and military infrastructure; estimated 100 semitrailers loaded with what is billed as Iraqi scrap metal are streaming each day into Jordan, one of six countries sharing border with Iraq; American officials claim sensitive equipment is closely monitored and much of rest leaving country is legitimate removal; many experts disagree, saying much of what is going on amounts to vast looting operation; International Atomic Energy Agency official Jacques Baute says satellite photographs of hundreds of military-industrial sites in Iraq show that entire buildings and complexes of buildings have been vanishing from photographs in past few months; pieces of Iraqi metal bearing tags put in place by United Nations Monitoring Verification and Inspection Commission during Saddam Hussein's rule have been spotted in Jordanian scrapyards; recent examinations of Jordanian scrapyards turn up astounding quantity of scrap metal and new components from Iraq's civil infrastructure; photos; maps (L)

headline: MAKER OF ARTIFICIAL JOINTS DOUBLED SALES IN QUARTER
abstract: Zimmer Holdings Inc, world's largest maker of artificial hips and knees, says first quarter sales almost doubled, to $740 million, after purchase of Centerpulse; says earnings exceeded analysts' estimates (S)

headline: Frodo Gets a Cellphone. Think of the Ad Possibilities.
abstract: Daniel Akst humorous column on product placement possibilities in updates of classic novels, lightened for modern sensibilities; drawing (M)ÿ

headline: Larisa Bogoraz, Soviet Dissident, Dies at 74
abstract: Larisa Bogoraz, early Soviet-era dissident whose moral stubbornness helped define movement, dies at age 74; photo (M)

headline: Asia Letter : Their culture for sale, the Chinese buy it back
abstract: HONG KONG—  When Sotheby's opens the bidding on some prize Chinese antiquities at its Bond Street auction rooms next week, more than a dozen art collectors from mainland China will be there. Sotheby's is helping the collectors arrange their visas and travel plans, and the group will be squired around London by Wang Jie, the representative for the auction house in Shanghai.

headline: Wider Statoil Inquiry
abstract: Olav Fjell, who quit last year as chief of Norway's largest oil company, Statoil, said over the weekend that he was personally under investigation.

headline: U.S. Orders Further Cuts in Air Traffic at O'Hare
abstract: Federal Aviation Administration orders deeper cuts in traffic at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago; ordered cuts earlier to reduce traffic, but delays became worse at O'Hare in March (M)

headline: Turin's Olympic clock is ticking impatiently
abstract: TURIN:—  If you are searching for the appropriate spot to get a sense of the next Winter Olympics, you can head for the 19th-century heart of Turin, whose elegant arcades and facades belie this city's lingering reputation as a gray industrial center.

headline: AIDES SAY MEMO BACKED COERCION ALREADY IN USE
abstract: Current and former government officials say Aug 2002 Justice Department memo that held interrogators can use extreme techniques on terror suspects helped provide after-the-fact legal basis for harsh procedures CIA used on high-level Al Qaeda leaders; memo was prepared after internal government debate over methods used to extract data from Abu ZuBaydah, top aide to Osama bin Laden, after his Apr 2002 capture; provided legal basis for coercive techniques used later against other high-ranking detainees, like Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, suspected architect of Sept 11, 2001 attacks, who was seized in early 2003; White House recently made memo public without explanation; memo, now disavowed by senior Bush legal advisers, was addressed to White House counsel Alberto R Gonzales and signed by Jay S Bybee, then Office of Legal Counsel head; photos (M)

headline: TITAN TO GET MOST ASSETS OF ITS SPINOFF, NOW BANKRUPT
abstract: Titan Corp will take over most of assets of SureBeam Corp, maker of food irradiation systems and subsidiary it spun off in 2002, to satisfy $25 million senior secured note owed to its by SureBeam; plna is approved by US bankruptcy court; Titan, which agreed in September to be acquired by Lockheed Martin , plans to dispose of assets (S)

headline: No Role in Shrine Damage, U.S. Says; Clash Kills 13 Iraqis
abstract: One of Shia Islam's most sacred sites was slightly damaged in Najaf today as Iraqi militants attacked coalition forces.

headline: A Medley of Inspiration For the Disorganized
abstract: Paul B Brown reviews new books for executives and others on becoming more productive; photos (M)

headline: World Briefings
abstract: AFRICA.

headline: Convoy of Foreign Contractors Is Hit by Truck Bomb in Baghdad
abstract: The blast killed at least 13, including two Britons, one Frenchman, one American and another foreigner, the U.S. military said.

headline: How Trickle of AIDS Drugs Can Bring a Torrent of Hope
abstract: Free antiretroviral drugs become available to treat people in late stages of AIDS in Gauteng Province in South Africa, after years of political debate and threatened lawsuit; experts say there are as many as 1.6 million HIV-positive people in Gauteng, and that without antiretrovirals, death would be looming for about 164,000 of them; Pres Thabo Mbeki and his health minister persistently have questioned whether virus causes AIDS and whether antiretroviral drugs help; Mbeki promised to provide drugs free under enormous political and diplomatic pressure (M)

headline: As a Center for Outsourcing, India Could Be Losing Its Edge
abstract: Wages in India's major outsourcing sectors have been rising by close to 15 percent per year because of increased competition for labor.

headline: MIDWAY GAMES CHAIRMAN WILL RESIGN NEXT WEEK
abstract: Midway Games Inc, struggling video game company, says that its chairman, Neil D Nicastro, will resign next week; Midway directors approve Sumner Redstone's suggestion last month that board be cut to 8 members from 11, and accept nominations to board of Shari Redstone, Redstone's daughter, and Kenneth Cron, interim chief executive of Computers Associates International Inc; Sumner Redstone, chief executive of Viacom, owns about two-thirds of Midway (S)

headline: Alex Woodley, 71, Coach Of Philadelphia Track Club
abstract: Alex Woodley, who coached and mentored many Olympic gold-medal sprinters in 1960's and 1970's as head of Philadelphia Pioneer Club, dies at age 71 (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Tire Makers Investigated
abstract: Fair Trade Commission raids offices of more than 10 Japanese tire makers, including Bridgestone, Yokohama Rubber and Toyo Tire and Rubber, on suspicion that they rigged bids for tires for military vehicles that were purchased by Defense Agency; companies face fines of up to 6 percent of their sales to agency (S)

headline: China Hits the Brake, But Maybe Too Softly
abstract: Keith Bradsher Economic View column on China's effort to slow rapid economic growth; notes independent economists question whether limited government steps are adequate; money supply graph (M)

headline: Signposts to the Land of Nod
abstract: Joyce Cohen Online Shopper column discusses shopping on Internet for bed pillows; drawing (M)

headline: Iran Seizes 3 British Navy Boats and Detains 8 Sailors in a Territorial Dispute on Iraqi Border
abstract: Iran seizes three small British Royal Navy boats and arrests all eight sailors on board, saying boats entered Iranian waters without permission; sailors were stopped at Shatt al Arab, stretch of water marking southern boundary between Iran and Iraq; navy was delivering boats to Iraqi Riverine Patrol Service; British officials seek to play down boat incident as relatively minor; arrests come during time of strained relations between Iran and Britain, mostly over war in Iraq and Iran's nuclear capacity; map (M)

headline: Worms Like Wireless Phones, Too
abstract: Caber smartphone worm virus is thought to be first pest that spreads itself from phone to phone using Bluetooth wireless technology; most industry experts are not worried about rampant infections; say cellphones are less vulnerable than PC's because there are so many different operating systems; photo (M)

headline: Power-Hungry Chips
abstract: Evan Wilner letter on new computer central processing unit that can be regulated to minimize power consumption (May 27 article)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Retail Sales Surge
abstract: Singapore's retail sales rose 41 percent in February from year earlier, more than twice expected pace, suggesting that export-led recovery in economy is beginning to fuel domestic spending (S)

headline: D-Day / 60 YEARS LATER: Sacrifices in Normandy live on in the European memory
abstract: Whenever I think of D-Day, it is not some Normandy beach that springs to mind but a peaceful French village about 15 kilometers inland. It is a pretty place called Fontaine-Henry, its houses built of a warm golden stone, and on one side of the village green a memorial to the dead of World War I. On the other there is a picture-postcard château, and next to it, the church. Walk through the gate and up the steps, turning left at the top. Underneath the yew tree, if you look closely, you will see that the churchyard wall is pitted with scars.

headline: Maybe not the magic $1 billion, but big gains are still expected for cable TV's advance sales.
abstract: Cable television networks, nearing end of talks with advertisers and agencies for sale of commercial time ahead of 2004-5 season, are likely to take in far more than they did year ago, but are unlikely to exceed last year's total by attention-grabbing $1 billion; analysts expect cable networks to beat last year's total in unfront market by $600 million to $800 million, for gain of 10.9 percent to 14.5 percent from sales of estimated $5.5 billion last year; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Expands
abstract: Japan's merchandise surplus grew for 10th consecutive month in April, expanding 30.3 percent from year earlier to 1.08 trillion yen ($9.7 billion), as exports to Asia expanded; Japan's trade surplus with Asia rose 63 percent, to 667 billion yen; trade surplus with US fell 2.4 percent, to 553 billion yen; value of exports from Japan rose 10.8 percent in April, to 5.11 trillion yen, while imports rose 6.5 percent, to 4.03 trillion yen (S)

headline: Beyond the EKG, to a Hypersensitive Heart Monitor
abstract: What's Next column on new computer-based electrocardiography imaging that delivers more information about activity of heart; technique uses vest with electrodes woven into fabric; readings are combined with computerized X-rays and processed to map electrical impulses of heart, revealing places where cardiac rhythms go awry; drawing (M)

headline: Sidestepping Alerts For Runtime Errors
abstract: Q. When I use Internet Explorer for Windows, I often get a message that says ''Runtime Error has occurred. Do you wish to debug?'' What does this mean, and is there a way to avoid it?    A. An Internet Explorer runtime error -- one that occurs when a program is running -- can be caused by several problems. Some older versions of the Internet Explorer browser will display the message if you try to open a Web page that contains an apostrophe in the title. Runtime errors are frequently caused by a mistake in the programming for a script on a Web page.

headline: U.S. Relies on U.N. to Solve Problems of Power Transfer
abstract: State Dept dismisses idea that increased fighting in Iraq might force delay in planned transfer of power to Iraqis by June 30; senior Bush administration officials, in light of anti-US insurrection, say US is relying increasingly on United Nations to put international stamp on efforts to resolve differences among Iraqis on makeup of interim government (M)

headline: Redstone Heir Steps Deeper Into Viacom Territory
abstract: Shari Redstone, president of family-owned National Amusements, says she plans to spend third of her time at Viacom Inc, diversified media company controlled by her father, Sumner M Redstone, interview; she will not have formal title, but her presence could create tensions with president, Mel Karmazin, who blocked her role in past; she says they get along well; Mr Redstone, 80, says there will be no problems between two because his daughter will not have operating role, interview; notes she is likely to eventually control Viacom through her control of trust that owns National Amusements, which owns his Viacom stock; photo (M)

headline: A Second Life for a Scruffy Bunny
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column on search for old stuffed animal toys on Internet; Web sites noted; drawing (M)

headline: Air Canada Reaches Pact With 7th Union
abstract: Air Canada clears crucial obstacle in its restructuring by reaching agreement with last of seven unions on wage concessions and other cost cuts; deal is reached after meetings between Canadian Auto Workers union president Buzz Hargrove, Air Canada's chief executive Robert Milton and Ontario judge who has helped oversee airline's restructuring since it sought protection from creditors in April 2003 (M)

headline: Ailing Toys 'R' Us Picks Young & Rubicam
abstract: Troubled retailer Toys 'R' Us names Young & Rubicam Advertising to handle creative duties on its account, which had been handled by Leo Burnett Worldwide (M)

headline: General Motors' First-Quarter Earnings Beat Expectations
abstract: G.M.'s profits were driven by record results in its lending business, surging Asian auto sales and a shrinking tax bill in the U.S.

headline: Brutal Conflict in Sudan Brings Warnings by Bush and Annan
