abstract: Conflict raging in Sudan comes under heightened international scrutiny after Pres Bush calls on government there to rein in militias and United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan raises alarm about reported atrocities; country's latest civil war has pushed estimated 100,000 civilians west across desert border into Chad; refugees, who are black Africans, report attacks by largely Arab militants affiliated with Arab-dominated government in Khartoum (M)

headline: Security Council Resolution Highlights
abstract: Highlights of the Security Council resolution on Iraq.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Major Role For Islamist
abstract: Maulana Fazalur Rahman, Islamist political leader, is nominated leader of opposition in Pakistani Parliament (S)

headline: Investing; Creative Tinkering, To Minimize Risks
abstract: Some investment analysts suggest risk-averse individual investors not move large amounts of money out of stocks despite recent dip in stock prices; recommend they instead tinker with types of bonds and stocks in their portfolios; urge selling stocks in volatile sectors and reinvesting money in more stable, dividend-paying companies; graphs of stock prices and bond yields; photo (M)1

headline: Hot Seat Grows Lukewarm Under Capital's Fog of War
abstract: Senate Armed Services Committee questioning of three generals about Iraqi prisoner abuse scandal provokes scant drama, even during questioning by Democratic critics on panel; senators are stymied in part by six-minute limit on each questioner, also by sheer complexity of figuring out who in military bureaucracy is responsible for what; photos of Gens Ricardo S Sanchez, John P Abizaid and Geoffrey D Miller (M)

headline: IRAQ UPDATE
abstract: Update of events in Iraq on June 12; map (S)

headline: In Canada, Ottawa Sneezes and the Provinces Catch Cold
abstract: Many Canadian provinces have been suffering growing budget deficits, debt burdens and tensions with public sector unions since federal government began shifting many costs of social services their way in mid-1990's; painful choices are being made by virtually every one of country's 10 provinces, which collectively had budget shortfalls of more than $4 billion last year; this is expected to be even worse this year because of slowing economy, listless corporate tax collection and rising costs in health care system; photo (M)

headline: S.E.C. Comments To Companies To Be Put Online
abstract: SEC will publish on Web site the thousands of comment letters that it sends to public companies and mutual funds each year about their annual reports, public offerings and other filings; subsequent responses by companies and funds will also be available on same system, known as Edgar; decision will make it easier for investors and rivals of companies to understand weaknesses of disclosures and what financial issues are of concern to regulators and could also offer some insight into rigor of commission reviews; agency will continue to honor requests to keep some sensitive information confidential, such as trade secrets and confidential commercial information (M)

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: SEYCHELLES: Leader Calls It Quits; SUDAN: Cease-Fire Monitors;.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Banker To Stand Trial
abstract: Santander Central Hispano president Emilio Botin has been ordered by Judge Maria Teresa Palacio to stand trial in Spain along with former chief executive Angel Corcostegui and former co-chairman Jose Maria Amusategui; Palacio rules executives should be tried in connection with pension and bonus payments of more than 164 million euros Corcostegui and Amusategui received when they resigned in 2001; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Concern About China's Growth
abstract: Bank of Japan members expressed concern at recent meeting that China's economy might overheat and threaten Japan's economic recovery; cited importance of closely monitoring efforts by Chinese central bank to cool economy (M)

headline: Politicus : Confronting Europe:a presidential tradition
abstract: PARIS—  Ronald Reagan, who Europe now thinks may not have been such a terrible leader after all, and George W. Bush, who it persists in regarding as fairly awful, shared a problem. They asked the Europeans to do what they could not easily offer.

headline: ENRON SELLS GAS PIPELINES FOR $2.35 BILLION
abstract: Enron Corp agrees to sell its natural gas pipeline system in US to CCE Holdings, joint venture of Southern Union Co and GE Commercial Finance Energy Services, for $2.35 billion (S)

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: ZIMBABWE: 63 Die Of Hunger In Country'S Second City;.

headline: BBDO Worldwide Cuts 100 Jobs
abstract: BBDO Worldwide.

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Defense Dept confirms deaths of two service members in Iraq (S)

headline: FUND ADVISER SAID TO WEIGH IN ON BIDS FOR WHEATON
abstract: Coeur d'Alene Mines Corp, which made unsolicited bid for Wheaton River Minerals Ltd, says that adviser to institutional investors has urged Wheaton shareholders to vote against competing bid by Iamgold Corp (S)

headline: The Distributor vs. the Innovator
abstract: Competition between Hewlett-Packard Co and Dell Inc in computer printer market discussed as test case of two different models of innovation and corporate strategy; Hewlett-Packard is committed to spending heavily on research and funneling home-grown technology into new products with profit margin high enough to finance further innovation; Dell's approach is to scour world for technology, fine-tune products of corporate partner, wring costs from supply chain and sell directly to customers; Dell move into printer business seems aimed at hobbling rival by attacking its key business; Dell chief executive Michael S Dell and Hewlett-Packard chief xecutive Carleton S Fiorina comment; market share graph; photos (M)

headline: Battle for Falluja Rouses The Anger of Iraqis Weary Of the U.S. Occupation
abstract: Angry comments about American occupiers can be heard througout Iraq; gist of talk is that three-week-old uprising, and American failure to handle it, has essentially turned country back to last summer's lawlessness; no Iraqi interviewed mentions suicide car bombing in Basra, guerrilla fighters trying to undermine any national stability or ouster of Saddam Hussein and his brutal dictatorship; Falluja has become symbol around which many Iraqis rally their anticolonial sentiments, saying world's sole superpower is ready to avenge killings and mutilation of four American security contractors by sending marines to shell and invade city of 300,000 people; news reports on Al Jazeera and Al Arabiya cite hospital officials saying hundreds of people have been killed, including women and children; American military officials say reports are inaccurate; maps showing locations of Iraqi police stations that have been targets of insurgency (M)

headline: Silicon Valley (Version 2.0) Has Hopes Rising for Economic Rebound
abstract: Optimists see success of Google and modest comeback in computer sales as signs that California's Silicon Valley is rebounding and new boom is imminent; other signs are mixed; region was hardest hit of any in United States after end of bubble in 2000, losing nearly 20 percent of its jobs; graphs of economic indicators; photos (M)

headline: Bush Rejects Labor's Call to Punish China
abstract: Bush administration rejects AFL-CIO's demand that China be punished for gaining trade advantages by violating rights of workers; Commerce Sec Donald L Evans, Treas Sec John W Snow, Labor Sec Elaine L Chao and US trade representative Robert B Zoellick hold rare joint news conference where they repeated berate petition as 'economic isolationism'; decision may have political ramifications in several battleground states in presidential campaign; trade petition has been endorsed by Sen John Kerry, Democratic Party's presumptive nominee, who has spent week criticizing Pres Bush's trade policies as failing to protect American jobs and American workers; photo (M)

headline: New Audit Details Fall Of Parmalat
abstract: Report prepared by independent auditor for prosecutors in Milan finds that Parmalat falsified its earnings reports for at least 13 years, losing almost 2 billion euros ($2.4 billion) and realizing only one profitable year; finds that Calisto Tanzi, Parmalat's founder and former chairman, took at least 926 million euros ($1.1 billion) from company from 1990 to 2002, period covered by report; 2001 photo of Calisto Tanzi with Fausto Tonna, former financial director for company who is cooperating with prosecutors' investigation (M)

headline: Appeals Court Orders Judge to Step Aside in Three Asbestos Cases
abstract: Federal appeals court orders Judge Alfred M Wolin, who is overseeing five important asbestos-related bankruptcy proceedings, to withdraw from W R Grace, Owens Corning and US Gypsum cases because of appearance of bias; legal experts say decision will probably force new delays and might cause far-reaching economic repercussions in long-running litigation; three-judge panel says Wolin has not done anything wrong or unethical or biased; will decide later whether to remove Wolin from case involving Armstrong World, which had been asked to be included in any withdrawal order; legal experts say it will be up to Wolin to decide whether to continue overseeing fifth case, involving Federal-Mogul Global; ruling was requested by Kensington International Ltd, which bought $275 million in Owens Corning bank debt soon after company sought bankruptcy protection, and Springfield Associates, another holder of distressed debt; photo (M)

headline: Shell Pays a Price for Overstating Reserves
abstract: Shares of Royal Dutch Petroleum and Shell Transport and Trading, parents of Royal Dutch/Shell Group, are struggling to recover from steep fall after several managerial faux pas despite high oil prices; some analysts argue difficulties are serious but short-term problem for otherwise sound business; others worry longer decline is possible; stock price graphs; photos (M)

headline: MEMO PAD
abstract: This year's unanticipated surge in fuel costs threatens hoped-for rally in domestic airline fortunes as travel picks up through spring; chart shows market share of US airlines, 1982 and 2003; InterContinental Hotels Group says it is informing online travel booking sites that it will stop doing business with any site that fails to provide accurate rate and room availability information or engages in 'misleading market practices'; Hong Kong International Airport is chosen as top airport in world in 2004 Skytrax Airport of Year awards (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Brussels: Investigation Advances
abstract: European Commission threatens to open legal proceedings against Coca-Cola in late June if company fails to address antitrust concerns commission has been investigating for five years; settlement talks are believed to be focused on Coca-Cola's practice of paying retailers rebates in return for ensuring prominent shelf space for its weaker brands (S)

headline: Canadian Group Is Said to Seek Small but Special Israeli Daily
abstract: CanWest Global Communications is reportedly among possible suitors for Jerusalem Post as part of impending breakup of Hollinger International, Conrad M Black's newspaper empire; money-losing, English-language broadsheet's visibility abroad overshadows its circulation and limited profit potential; editor in chief Bret Stephens comments; photos (M)

headline: U.N. Refugee Chief Denies Charge He Harassed Woman
abstract: Ruud Lubbers, chief of UN refugee agency, confirms that he is under investigation following sexual harassment complaint by staff member who says Lubbers, 65, 'grabbed her behind' at meeting last December; denies charge (S)

headline: Cleric's Aide Backs New Iraq Government; Clashes Continue
abstract: A representative of Moktada al-Sadr endorsed the new Iraqi government today, marking a reversal by the rebel cleric.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Peru: Town Agrees To Halt Unrest
abstract: Ilave, southeastern Peruvian town, agrees to halt violence that has been widespread in region since April 26 hanging of Mayor Cirilo Robles if government will withdraw troops; seven politicians have been arrested for involvement in lynching (S)

headline: Sabotaged Pipeline Is Engineers' Nightmare
abstract: Army Corps of Engineers and oil company workers struggle to deal with sabotaged pipeline near Zubayr, Iraq; suspect that only someone with expert knowledge of system could have placed explosives so effectively; attacks on pipelines can be devastating because many valves meant to isolate leaks are broken or missing; two recent attacks have shut down exports from Iraq's southern fields, which are by far its most productive; repairs on other pipeline are almost complete; photo (M)

headline: At Height of Everest's Climbing Season, 4 Deaths and Record Ascent
abstract: Bodies of three South Koreans are found after they were reported missing earlier in week as they descended Mount Everest; Shiroko Ota, 63-year-old Japanese woman, dies after becoming second-oldest woman to climb to 29,035-foot summit; she slips not long after beginning her descent; Pemba Dorje, Nepali Sherpa, scales Everest in record 8 hours and 10 minutes (M)

headline: Catering to the Chinese passion for luxury timepieces
abstract: HONG KONG—  Shopkeepers in Hong Kong no longer bat an eyelid when a tourist from the mainland walks in to buy a gold Rolex watch and pays for it in cash.

headline: Americans Are Jolted By Gruesome Reminders Of the Day in Mogadishu
abstract: Many Americans are horrifed and disgusted at grisly television news images of American bodies, beaten and dragged through streets in Iraq; to some, gruesome images are immediately and painfully reminiscent of 1993 street scene in Somalia, when mob dragged body of American soldier through streets of Mogadishu; for Americans reacting to latest scenes from Iraq, there is crucial difference from their memories of 1993; by then, Somalia had largely receded from public view, while images of deaths of soldiers in Iraq have continued, week by week, for year (M)

headline: Miramax Principals Acquire Film That Disney Shunned
abstract: Bob and Harvey Weinstein, principals of Walt Disney Co's Miramax Films division, personally aquire rights to Michael Moore documentary Fahrenheit 9/11, bringing film closer to American theaters; Disney has barred unit, which financed film harshly critical of Pres Bush's decision to wage war on Iraq, from distributing it; Weinsteins will reimburse Disney for $6 million production cost; Disney is requiring Weinsteins to donate added profits arising from controversy over film to charity; Moore calls deal fair; photo (M)

headline: Scores Are Killed as Rebel Attacks Ripple Across Iraq
abstract: In what seemed to be coordinated assaults, rebels overran police posts, ambushed U.S. patrols and bombed government buildings.

headline: DELTA TO REDUCE THE NUMBER OF SEPTEMBER FLIGHTS
abstract: Delta Air Lines will reduce flights by its main airline and its low-fare subsidiary Song during September; mvoe reflects expected drop in business after busy summer travel season; plans to resume regular schedules in October (S)

headline: Celebrations of a New, Expanded Europe Are Clouded by Old Fears of Immigration
abstract: European Union welcomes eight former Communist states of Eastern Europe as new members; countries joining union are Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Czech Republic, Slovakia, Slovenia and Hungary; enlarged union is larger than US in population, with marginally stronger economic output, but lacks political cohesion or diplomatic heft of US, and celebrations are clouded by existing members' worries about flood of economic migrants from new members; leaders call for swift action to complete constitution before June summit meeting; photos; maps (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Houston Exempts Pension From Keeping All Promises  Houston residents voted decisively Saturday to exempt the city's pension plan from a state requirement that all pension promises be kept.    Houston put the matter to the voters amid growing concern about the solvency of the city's pension fund. Pension officials added an unusually generous package of benefits to the plan in 2001. The package attracted little notice at the time, but since then, the cost has spiraled. Similar problems have cropped up in a number of other cities. [Page C2.]

headline: HBO Moves to Develop and Show New Situation Comedies
abstract: HBO moves to develop and show new situation comedies; names Tracy Katsky, former head of comedy development at Fox network, to run its internal production company, HBO Independent Productions; Katsky's mission is to develop traditional half-hour videotaped comedies, which are shot with three cameras and produced like live plays on sound stages in front of studio audience; photo (M)

headline: Electronic Arts to Stop Advertising For Online Casinos on Its Web Site
abstract: Electronic Arts, video game giant, says that it had decided to stop running advertisements for Internet casinos on its Website, delivering another blow to onine gambling industry (M)

headline: Karmazin Ends a Turbulent Run at Viacom
abstract: Mel Karmazin resigns as president and chief operating officer of Viacom Inc; Tom Freston, chairman and chief executive of Viacom's MTV Networks, and Leslie Moonves, chairman of Viacom's CBS Inc, are named co-presidents; two executives find themselves in competition to succeed Sumner Redstone, who says he will step down as chief executive in three years; Karmazin, who reportedly decided to quit after learning that he had been excluded from short list of candidates to be next chief executive, will receive severance package of $30 million, about balance of his contract; his contract did not have any noncompete clauses, so he is free to work for competing companies; chart; photos (M)

headline: Wieden Is Top Winner In Awards for TV Work
abstract: Offices of Wieden & Kennedy win most honors in agency category at annual show sponsored by Association of Independent Commercial Producers, recognizing work on TV commercials; other winners noted (S)

headline: Stocks Close Below 10,000 for 1st Time Since December
abstract: The stock market fell to new 2004 year lows today as the prospect of higher interest rates, high oil prices, Iraq, and the presidential election all unnerved investors.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cellphones And Phone Lines
abstract: Poll by online cellphone retailer LetsTalk and Wirthlin Worldwide finds one in three Americans are willing to ditch their fixed phone lines and use only cellphones if cellular network coverage increases and companies offer customers more free minutes; finds 1 percent already rely on cellphones entirely (S)

headline: New Index Will Measure Online Help-Wanted Ads
abstract: Monster Worldwide, corporate parent of careers Web site Monster.com, will publish its first monthly Monster employment index of online demand for workers; indicator is compiled from data on more than 1,500 Internet job boards, including Monster's, and corporate-career Web sites (M)

headline: Auction Process: How to Get In
abstract: Following is an excerpt from Google's filing today with the Securities and Exchange Commission. It describes the unusual auction process for buying some of the companies stock in an eventual public offering.

headline: VF ADDS KIPLING BELGIUM, A MAKER OF BACKPACKS
abstract: VF Adds Kipling Belgium, A

headline: India Market Falls on Jitters After Election
abstract: Indian stock prices tumble amid widespread fears that Congress Party head Sonia Gandhi will form coalition with left-wing parties and lead government that will slow recent economic changes and halt privatization of government-run companies; photo (M)

headline: Musharraf May Not Give Up His Army Post
abstract: Pres Pervez Musharraf says he may break agreement he made with opposition parties that requires him to resign as army chief by end of year; plan was praised as step toward restoration of full democracy in Pakistan; he has faced bitter criticism over holding dual offices as president and head of army from opposition political parties and European Union (S)

headline: Marines Were Killed in the Sunni Stronghold of Ramadi
abstract: It was one of the most violent days in Iraq since the fall of Saddam Hussein, with half a dozen cities ignited.

headline: MARSHALL & ILSLEY AGREES TO BUY ADVANCED FINANCIAL
abstract: Marshall & Ilsley acquires Advanced Financial Solutions, which sells systems for converting paper checks into electronic images; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: U.S. Envoy Predicts Passage Of Revised Iraq Resolution
abstract: Amb John Negroponte believes US has UN Security Council backing for Iraq resolution intended to establish sovereignty of interim government and legitimacy of US-led forces there, and define UN role after transition; photo (M)

headline: Star Witness Against the Rigases Found Mostly Relief in Deception
abstract: James R Brown, main government witness at fraud trial of Adelphia Communications Corp founder John J Rigas, testifies he felt relief, not pride, in fooling people about finances of company before its bankruptcy; remark comes during cross-examination as defense lawyer tries to undermine his credibility as witness (M)

headline: Deadly Blight Threatening Orange Trees In Brazil
abstract: Hundreds of Brazilian farmers are badly hurt by mysterious new crop disease that began ripping through heart of country's citrus belt in 2001; disease, being called citrus sudden death, is highly contagious and can kill orange tree within weeks after first symptoms appear; oranges are one of Brazil's biggest breadwinners, providing jobs for 400,000 people and bringing in $1.3 billion a year in exports; map; photo (M)

headline: Delta Faucet Puts Account in Review
abstract: Delta Faucet Co places its ad account in review after parting ways with Campbell-Ewald; billings estimated at $12 million to $14 million (S)

headline: Executives' Stock Options Cited in Fraud Case by U.S.
abstract: Federal indictment and SEC complaint against Symbol Technologies charges that Tomo Razmilovic, former chief executive, Leonard Goldner, former general counsel, and certain other executives were given so-called look-back period of 30 days to make decision on exercising stock options; says this essentially allowed executives to announce after sharp rise in stock price that they had bought stock weeks earlier at much lower price; says it also cut their taxable income (M)

headline: Suing Wal-Mart but Still Hoping to Move Up
abstract: Betty Dukes, lead plaintiff in suit charging Wal-Mart with widespread discrimination against women workers, comments on suit and her determination to move up at company; Wal-Mart says it is continuing to review its employment practices; table and graph of job-discrimination cases; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Deutsche Bank Posts Profit
abstract: Deutsche Bank posts first-quarter profit and stronger-than-expected revenue, helped by fixed-income revenue, which grew 7 percent from 2003's first quarter; net profit rose to 941 million euros ($1.1 billion), up from loss of 219 million euros (S)

headline: BOSTON SCIENTIFIC WINS RULING ON STENT PATENTS
abstract: Boston Scientific Corp wins court ruling that finds Israel-based Medinol Ltd's patent on stents invalid and allows Boston Scientific to resume stent sales in Netherlands; European Patent Office reverses December decision that forced Boston Scientific to stop Dutch sales of Express and Taxus brand stents; ruling is final and cannot be appealed; ruling does not affect German patent infringement case that Boston Scientific is still appealing (S)

headline: New Unity On Contracts Seen in NATO
abstract: Group of six companies, led by European Aeronautic Defense and Space Co, known as EADS, and Northrop Grumman, looks set to win contract, worth $4.8 billion, to build mixed fleet of manned and unmanned surveillance aircraft for NATO by 2010 (M)

headline: Executive Quits In Biogen Inquiry
abstract: Biogen Idec Inc says Nabil Hanna has resigned as executive vice president after company coducted internal probe of Hanna's trading of another company's securities; says it is not target of Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry and declines to name other company; executive chairman William H Rastetter and senior vice president Michael Gilman will assume Hanna's duties (S)

headline: Laughter and Anxiety at the Tyco Trial
abstract: Juror number 4--79-year-old woman--in Tyco International fraud case seems to make herself focus of case, making another bizarre motion; courtroom breaks out in laughter as she gesticulates wildly before reaching doorway leading to jury room; she first appears to tug at her white collared shirt, but then made off motion touching her head with her forefinger; Justice Michael J Obus admonishes spectators; jury appears to be making increasing progress toward possible verdict (M)

headline: Indian Services Giant Hits $1 Billion Mark
abstract: Infosys Technologies, bellwether of Indian software services industry, posts more than $1 billion in annual sales for first time and celebrates news with giant party, special dividend of $2.28 a share and distribution of three shares for every one held; chief executive Nandan M Nilekani and chairman N R Narayana Murthy comment; photo (M)

headline: WHITE HOUSE SAYS IRAQ SOVEREIGNTY COULD BE LIMITED
abstract: Marc Grossman, under secretary of state for political affairs, tells Senate Foreign Relations Committee that Bush administration plans for new caretaker government in Iraq will place severe limits on its sovereignty, including only partial command over its armed forces and no authority to enact new laws; says administration is still not sure who will govern Iraq after June 30 or precisely how they will be selected; several European and United Nations diplomats say they do not think UN will approve Security Council resolution sought by US that handcuffs new Iraq government recommended by Lakhdar Brahimi, special UN envoy, in its authority over its own armed forces on its own soil; Democratic and Republican members of committee appear frustrated that so few details are known at this late stage in transition process (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Chief Executive Resigns At Computer Associates  Sanjay Kumar resigned as chairman and chief executive of Computer Associates as a criminal investigation into suspected securities fraud and obstruction of justice reached the highest level of the company.    His resignation came as directors tried to save Computer Associates from a criminal indictment that could seriously damage its business. [Page A1.]

headline: Strike at Plant In Day 10; Fiat Shuts Five Others
abstract: Strike by Fiat workers in Melfi, Italy, enters its 10th day, posing threat to Fiat's nascent recovery from its worst financial predicament; lack of parts made at plant halts production at five other Fiat car factories in Italy; lost production as result of strike so far totals 25,000 cars; striking employees are seeking shifts and pay comparable to those of other Fiat workers in Italy; map; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Group That Killed Hostage Threatens Iraqi Prime Minister
abstract: American officials said the threat had come from Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, one of the most wanted terrorists in Iraq.

headline: Your Taxes Are Filed. But Don't Turn Off the Calculator.
abstract: Advice on reviewing 2003 tax return to prepare to take better advantage of new tax law changes; cites breaks on long-term capital gains and qualified dividends (M)

headline: Resistance Builds as Hospital Prices Rise
abstract: Study by Center for Studying Health System Change says hospitals continue to have upper hand in talks with health insurers; finds hospitals raised their overall prices by 8 percent in 2004, highest of six consecutive years of increases; National Business Group on Health says hospital costs are irresponsible; hospitals defend higher prices, saying they are often result of better care; rise in hospital spending comes after long period in which hospitals were unable to force health plans to pay much more; graph (M)

headline: Shell's Report on Its Troubles Cites Discord at Top
abstract: Summary of Royal Dutch/Shell Group internal inquiry finds tense and at times hostile relationship between company's two most powerful executives caused nearly two-year delay in addressing problems with overstated oil and gas reserves; describes pressure Sir Philip Watts, chairman until last month, exerted on Walter van de Vijver, man who succeeded him, to 'leave no stone unturned' to meet goal of reporting that company was replacing every barrel pumped out of ground with new barrel of reserves; says while van de Vijver did object, he never took his doubts about reserves to company's outside directors or its audit committee; both men resigned in Mar after company disclosed it had overstated reserves by 20 percent; internal inquiry finds company's chief financial officer Judy Boynton was aware of problems for two years but did nothing to correct them; she has been relieved of her duties; company expresses confidence in its new chairman Jeroen van der Veer; he is not mentioned in internal inquiry, even though he also was advised about problems with reserves two years ago and failed to take any action; Shell revises its reserve figures downward on Apr 19 for third time, by another 300 million barrels, and Standard & Poor's strips company of its AAA credit rating; company is under investigation by regulators and prosecutors in Europe and United States; photo (L)

headline: Searing Uncertainty for Iraqis Missing Loved Ones
abstract: Abu Ghraib prison abuse scandal adds to fears of hundreds of Iraqi families, possibly thousands, searching for missing loved ones; American military is taking steps to improve access to information for families of arrested Iraqis; families of prisoners and groups that work with them see some improvement, but say problem is far from resolved; Red Cross report written last Feb to American-led occupation authorities stated that system for notifying families of prisoners effectively did not exist and that relatives often learned where prisoner was housed from other prisoners who had been released; steps to improve notification system began in Jan, after military started its own investigation of abuses at Abu Ghraib; one official says central databank now posts names of detainees within month, and that wait to see loved ones has shortened under policy begun in Apr; military has also begun thinning out population of severely overcrowded Abu Ghraib prison; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Vehicle Sales Surge
abstract: India's passenger vehicle sales rise by more than 30 percent in fiscal year ending in March and total one million for first time (S)

headline: Anti-Obesity Plan Drafted
abstract: World Health Organization, after months of negotiations with sugar-producing countries, reaches tentative agreement on set of recommendations to help millions of people avoid obesity and other chronic diseases through healthy diet (S)

headline: Saudi Security Forces Search for a Missing American
abstract: Saudi Arabian security services hunt for Paul M Johnson Jr, man Islamist Web site says was kidnapped in Riyadh during seemingly choreographed operation in which Kenneth Scroggs, another American employee of Lockheed Martin, was shot to death elsewhere in city; kidnapping, which would be first of its kind in nation, and rising toll of dead Westerners raises stakes in militants' effort to drive non-Muslims from kingdom, damaging its economy and undermining ruling family; Web site cites Johnson's ties to local company that works on Apache helicopters it says are used to kill Muslims; American Embassy says kidnapping and killing show signs of careful planning; warns Americans to be on lookout for strangers following them; State Sec Colin L Powell says situation in Saudi Arabia is dangerous, but that nation is not unraveling, television interviews; says Saudis could be doing more to fight terrorism, but lauds their efforts so far; material posted on Islamist Web sites include images that seem to show shooting death of American Robert Jacobs, apparently singled out because he worked for Vinnell Corp, American company training Saudi National Guard; photo (M)

headline: Combat Death of N.F.L. Star Is Laid to American Troops
abstract: Army Cpl Patrick Tillman, former football player with Arizona Cardinals, was probably killed by friendly fire in Afghanistan; joined army in June 2002, trained as Army Ranger and served first tour in Iraq before transfer to Afghanistan; was caught in crossfire when Afghan ally was mistaken for enemy; was posthumously promoted from specialist to corporal and awarded Purple Heart; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY NEWSBOEING RAISES DIVIDEND AND RESUMES BUYBACKS
abstract: Boeing raises its quarterly dividend to 20 cents per share from 17 cents and says it will resume stock buybacks under program that was halted afer terrorist attacks on Sept 11, 2001 (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: TDS To Restate Some Results
abstract: Telephone and Data Systems, parent of US Cellular Corp, says it will restate its financial results for 2002 and 2003 because new accounting rules value company's mobile-phone licenses higher; that will increase 2002 net loss by about $10 million and reduce 2003 net income by about $14 million (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Industrial Production Falls
abstract: World Business Brie

headline: Cuba Base Sent Its Interrogators To Iraqi Prison
abstract: Military officials say interrogation experts from Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, detention camp were sent to Iraq last fall and played major role in training American military intelligence teams at Abu Ghraib prison; say teams, which were allowed broad latitude in questioning 'enemy combatants' at Guantanamo, played key role at prison through Dec, time when worst abuses of prisoners were taking place; say Maj Gen Geoffrey D Miller, then head of Guantanamo detention operations, was sent to Iraq last summer to recommend improvements in intelligence gathering and detention, and urged teams be sent; military officials say Maj Gen George W Fay will determine whether tactics used at Guanatano and in Afghanistan were wrongly applied in Iraq (M)

headline: Ex-General Promises Democracy For Nigerians
abstract: Chris Alli, retired general assigned to stanch cycle of violence in Nigeria, pledges to fortify security and enable thousands of displaced people to return home; seeks to quell fears that appointment of ex-soldier signals return of military rule; violence that has killed many thousands of people started with Christian-Muslim riots in 2001, followed by series of retaliatory attacks; in latest incident, largely Muslim town of Yelwa was attacked by Christian militia; map (M)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Defense Dept confirms deaths of four service members in Iraq, bringing total since start of war to 840 (S)

headline: Janus Is Said to Be Near Agreement With Regulators
abstract: Janus Capital Group is in final stages of talks with regulators that could require it to pay more than $200 million to settle investigation into improper trading in its mutual funds (M)

headline: FOR WOMEN, AMONG OTHERS
abstract: iVillage Inc, which runs Internet site for women and girls,

headline: No Use Crying Over Spilled Billions
abstract: Profil

headline: Designing a Smarter Shoe
abstract: Adidas introduces running shoe with biomechanical technology; battery powered sensor, microprocessor and motor adapt shoe to changing conditions and style of runner; photos (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: TRT Holdings, Irving, Tex., which owns about 40 Omni Hotels in North America, said it had bought Gold's Gym International Inc., the fitness chain, from Brockway Moran & Partners Inc., Boca Raton, Fla., a private equity firm. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: S.E.C.'S GEEK BEAT
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission sues Geek Securities Inc, its owner, Kautilya (Tony) Sharma, and broker, Neal R Wadhwa, charging them with market timing and late trading in mutual funds on behalf of hedge funds and other big investors (M)

headline: Iran Threatens to Resume Enrichment of Uranium
abstract: The International Atomic Energy Agency passed a resolution rebuking Iran for not cooperating with the U.N. watchdog group.

headline: Picking a Jury for a Case in the Headlines
abstract: Testimony has finished in trial of former Credit Suisse First Boston banker Frank P Quattrone but publicity surrounding his and other prominent white-collar criminal cases may make life little harder for corporate defendants who follow; jury consultants, who advise defense lawyers, say that every newspaper headline and every evening newscast about executives on trial make it more difficult to find sympathetic jurors; views of potential jurors about any stock market losses in Adelphia Communications case may prove critical because those on trial are accused of fraud that effectively led bankruptcy of publicly traded cable company (M)

headline: Cheney Urges China to Press North Korea on A-Bombs
abstract: Vice Pres Cheney, in Beijing, presents Chinese leaders with new evidence about scope of North Korea's nuclear programs; emphasizes that six-nation talks under Chinese auspices must show 'real results' soon; senior Bush administration official implies that China must achieve breakthrough in coming talks to forestall sanctions against North Korea (M)

headline: Two Grey Units Picked For Rayovac Venture
abstract: Rayovac Corp names Grey Global Group units to handle Rayovac batteries account in North America; Grey Worldwide will handle creative duties, which were handled by Condon & Root, and MediaCom Worldwide will handle media planning and buying, which were handled by Mediaedge:cia (S)

headline: South Korea's Impeached President Gains Support in Vote
abstract: South Korean voters triple size of Pres Roh Moo Hyun's parliamentary delegation, in sharp political reaction against his impeachment; rout of conservatives who voted for impeachment gives pro-Roh party 152 seats, slim majority of one-chamber National Assembly; election results send clear message to nation's Constitutional Court to rule against vote to impeach him; conservatives have faulted Roh for his style as much as his politics; photo (M)

headline: Biggest Task for U.S. General Is Training Iraqis to Fight Iraqis
abstract: Lt Gen David H Petraeus, charged with rebuilding Iraqi security force that collapsed during Apr uprising, discussed how America's forces might one day extract selves from Iraq; cites importance of giving Iraqis stake in success of new Iraq to defeat insurgency; faces daunting task in getting Iraqi soldiers to fight Iraqis; photos (M)

headline: Arab Meeting Expected to Produce Mostly Criticism of U.S.
abstract: Leaders gathering for Arab League summit meeting in Tunis are expected to issue collective criticism of US for abuse of Iraqi prisoners and what they view as anemic US effort toward ending Arab-Israeli conflict; Bush administration had hoped that meeting would showcase greater political openness in Arab world stemming from overthrow of Saddam Hussein; photo (M)

headline: New Tech Surge in Ireland, And It Feels Like '99 Again
abstract: Ireland, whicl

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Bomb Threat Turns Back Ship
abstract: Superfast, Greek passenger ferry, returns to Patras port after anonymous bomb threat; no explosives are found (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: A Big Hand For Mugabe
abstract: Pre-inauguration party for South African President Thabo Mbeki is overshadowed by controversial presence of Zimbabwe's President Robert Mugabe (S)

headline: Fed's on Deck: How Hard A Swing?
abstract: Expected Federal Reserve move to raise short-term interest rates, other factors likely to affect markets this week noted; graph of new-home sales (M)

headline: 75 Die as Chechen Rebels Stage Raid Across Border
abstract: Audacious overnight raid by heavily armed militants in southern Russian republic neighboring Chechnya kills at least 75 people and wounds dozens more; photos; fighters withdraw with minimal losses and cache of captured weapons; raid aimed at police and security posts in Nazran, Ingushetia, is largest by Chechen separatists since 1999; Pres Vladimir Putin flies to region (M)

headline: Up to 12 Marines Die in Raid on Their Base As Fierce Fighting Spreads to 6 Iraqi Cities
abstract: American forces in Iraq come under fierce attack; up to 12 marines are killed in Ramadi, while Shiite militiamen loyal to rebel cleric Moktada al-Sadr step up three-day-old assault in Najaf; American warplanes fire rockets and houses in Falluja, where American security contractors were killed and their bodies mutilated last week; marines drive armored columns into heart of city, where they fight block by block to flush out insurgents, making several arrests; violence hits some six cities, with heaviest fighting raging in Sunni strongholds of Falluja and Ramadi; role of most of majority Shiites previously thought to be relatively sympathetic to American goals is uncertain; Ramadi fighting began with attack by several dozen insurgents with rocket-propelled grenades and automatic weapons on American base; Defense Department says attackers, who suffered large numbers of casualties, seemed to be well-trained; al-Sadr urges his followers to keep up fight; proclaims his solidarity with Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, Iraq's most influential religious figure, while continuing to ignore Sistani's religious decree urging Shiites to stay calm; his followers have rolled over Iraqi security forces in number of cities, including Kufa, Najaf, Nasiriya, Basra and Baghdad, and taken over government offices; string of successes seems to inflate his popularity and draw more recruits to his militia; his forces have established occupation-free zone in some cities; map; photos (M)

headline: 'Time is running out for us'
abstract: The former Minister of Human Rights, Abd al-Bassit Turki, discusses the escalation of violence and the impending failure of Project Democracy.

headline: ABC and MindShare Order a TV Drama
abstract: ABC network and MindShare North America order six episodes of TV drama called The Days, first show developed under venture companies formed in December (S)

headline: OPEC Raises Quota; Not Much More Oil May Flow
abstract: OPEC agrees to increase its production quotas by two million barrels a day, or 8.5 percent, delivering only tepid message to oil markets about its commitment to lowering prices; traders in New York bid up futures prices, but prices drop later in day when new Energy Department statistics show growing supplies of oil, gasoline and other distilled fuels in US; analysts say problem with OPEC's move is that it will not add any new oil to market because OPEC is already overproducing its declared ceiling of 23.5 million barrels a day; graph (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Software Services Stake Acquired
abstract: World Business BrA

headline: Wider Fallout From Terminal's Collapse
abstract: Deadly collapse of passenger terminal at Charles de Gaulle Airport near Paris is likely to cause wide ripples in French industrial circles, perhaps even affecting introduction of Airbus 380 jumbo jet; Air France, which has ordered 10 of 555-seat planes, had planned to use building, Terminal 2E, and adjacent satellite terminal, which is still under construction, to handle A380; future of Terminal 2E looks grim; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Exports Rise
abstract: South Korean exports rose more than third for second month in March, reaching record as consumer spending picked up in its Chinese, Japanese and American markets; shipments rose 40 percent from year earlier to $21.5 billion after climbing 45 percent in February; exports to China rose 54 percent in first 20 days of March; sales to US increased 41 percent, and shipments to Japan rose 52 percent (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Postal Agreement
abstract: Ireland's government-owned postal company An Post ends labor dispute that stopped 60 percent of Ireland's mail for two weeks after unions and management agree to hold six-week series of talks about pay increases and productivity deals (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Army Report Undercut
abstract: Colombian Internal Affairs office report, obtained by New York Times, shows that soldiers who said they accidentally killed family of five peasants from long distance mistaking them for guerillas shot at least one from less than two feet away; Colombian President Alvaro Uribe has issued public apology for events that killed baby and three teenagers (S)

headline: Regulators Reject Migraine Drug From Pozen
abstract: Pozen Inc, developer of treatments for migraine headaches, says Food and Drug Administration has rejected experimental MT 100 drug (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Charges In Muslim Family's Massacre
abstract: Indian police charge four people connected with governing Hindu nationalist party, six policemen and two doctors with obstructing investigation and destroying evidence of gang rape of pregnant Muslim woman during 2002 Gujarat religious riots; 15 of her relatives were killed during uprising (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Latvia: Russian Diplomat Expelled
abstract: Latvia expells Russian diplomat accused of trying to gather information on NATO and other issues of national security; Lithuania and Estonia expelled Russian diplomats earlier this year for suspected espionage; Russia is expected to ask Latvian envoy to leave Russia in retaliation (S)

headline: Australia Feeling Nervous as Its Dollar Soars
abstract: Volatile Australian currency has grabbed more than aesthetic attention recently after breakneck rise against its American counterpart, rise that has Australia's exporters shuddering; roller coaster currency plunged to historic lows of just under 50 American cents in April 2001, then hit seven-year high of 80 cents this February; Westpac bank forecasts Australian dollar will hit 80 again in third quarter; graph (M)

headline: People
abstract: John Jarvis, chief creative officer at Colle & McVoy, will also serve as president, succeeding Phil Johnson, who becomes chief operating officer; also assumes duties handled by chief executive Chuck Kushell, who is leaving (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Prime Minister In The Witness Box
abstract: Irish Prime Minister Bertie Ahern testifies in High Court corruption inquiry looking into alleged bribes by Dublin real estate developers in 1980's and 1990's; has not been directly implicated in wrongdoing; photo (S)

headline: Wanted: Young Voters' Cellphone Numbers
abstract: Voter registration groups and others have begun collecting cellphone numbers of 18-to-24-year-olds as new way to galvanize young voters; some are concerned about how information will be shared; photo (M)

headline: Evidence of High-Skill Work Going Abroad
abstract: Evidence of High-Skil

headline: World Briefings
abstract: AMERICAS.

headline: Judgment Against Former Hollinger Chief
abstract: Hollinger International Inc wins summary judgment against its former chief executive Conrad M Black from Delaware court; Vice Chancellor Leo E Strine Jr refuses Lord Black's request to put on more evidence in effort to upset findings he breached his fiduciary duty to Chicago newspaper conglomerate; finds Black violated pact with Hollinger International by attempting to sell control of company without telling board; also dismisses remaining claims by Black against board members Richard C Breeden and James R Thompson (M)

headline: Little Progress Made in U.S.-North Korea Nuclear Talks
abstract: Bush administration officials said today that the U.S. and North Korea had made little headway in resolving their standoff.

headline: Technology Briefing | Deals: Reuters To Sell Yankee Group
abstract: Reuters Group sells Yankee Group, Boston telecommunications research and consulting company, to private investor group led by Monitor Clipper Partners; graph (S)

headline: A Succession Plan. Well, Almost.
abstract: a succession p

headline: Gateway to Lay Off 2,500 With Closing of 188 Retail Stores
abstract: Gateway Inc will close 188 retail stores and lay off 2,500 employees next week; plans to sell products through third-party retail stores as well as directly to customers over its Web site and via telephone (M)

headline: Small Company, Giant Paycheck
abstract: Should a chief executive earn more than his company?

headline: Technology Briefing | People: Cadence Names Chief Executive
abstract: Cadence Design Systems names Michael J Fister chief executive, replacing H Raymond Bingham, who is elected chairman; former chairman Donald L Lucas will remain director; Abhijit Talwalkar will succeed Fister at Intel (S)

headline: Pressure to Go Along With Abuse Is Strong, But Some Soldiers Find Strength to Refuse
abstract: Images of prisoner abuse coming out of Iraq show side of human behavior that psychologists have sought to understand for decades; what they find even more puzzling is disobedience: reports of handful of soldiers who refused to take part; Maj Gen Antonio M Taguba, in his report on prisoner abuse, praised actions of three men who tried to stop mistreatment of Iraqi detainees; Lt David O Sutton alerted his commanders of abuse, Navy dog handler William J Kimbro refused to participate in 'improper interrogations' despite significant pressure, and Specialist Joseph M Darby gave military police evidence that sounded the alarm (M)

headline: Doubt Is Cast on Photos Said to Show Britons Abusing Iraqi
abstract: British military is investigating origins of widely published photographs that appear to show British soldiers on patrol in Basra beating and urinating on Iraqi captive; military experts have questioned authenticity of photos, noting that soldiers in photos are wearing wrong kind of hats, and that their uniforms carry no ornamental markings, as would be expected; The Daily Mirror, which published photos, defends them as genuine and says two active members of Queen's Lancashire Regiment who gave photos to paper disclosed other incidents of abuse; has been forceful opponent of Britain's role in Iraq; photo (M)

headline: Fighting Erupts Among Rebels In Sri Lanka
abstract: Fighting begins in Vakarai, Sri Lanka, between Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam and breakaway faction of group, posing new threat to country's stability and its stalled peace process; map (M)

headline: U.S. Training African Forces to Uproot Terrorists
abstract: American military has dispatched Special Operations forces to countries of Africa to train soldiers and outfit them to fight well-financed bands of Islamic militants who are recruiting, training and arming themselves for future acts of terrorism; investigators say railroad bombing in Madrid that killed 191 people may have had North African link and may presage others in Europe; American military officials say that assisting local governments to do fighting themselves will save America from becoming lightning rod for popular anger that radicals can capitalize on; say al Qaeda-linked militants, pushed out of Afghanistan and blocked by increased surveillance of traditional points of entry along Mediterranean coast, are turning to overland travel to make contact with North African Islamic terror groups; cite case of known Qaeda militant who traveled across Africa in 2002 to help plan attacks; program to shore up border controls and deny sanctuary to suspected terrorists was begun with $7 million and focused on Mali, Mauritania, Niger and Chad; it is being expanded to include Senegal and possibly other countries; photo; chart (M)

headline: MEDICINE'S DATA GAP: Selective Disclosure; Two Studies, Two Results, And a Debate Over a Drug
abstract: Federal regulators in US are scrambling to reassess effectiveness and safety of antidepressants like GlaxoSmithKline's drug Paxil; British regulators touched off controversy in 2003 by asking drug companies for unpublished data from antidepressant trials; New York State Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer has sued GlaxoSmithKline, accusing company of consumer fraud for not disclosing all of its Paxil data; two studies done by SmithKline Beecham in mid-1990's and how they were publicized discussed; GlaxoSmithKline defend its record, saying it provided all results of their Paxil clinical trials to Food and Drug Administration as required by law; chart; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Siebel Accused Again Of Selective Disclosure
abstract: Siebel Systems Inc, world's largest maker of customer-service software, is sued second time by Securities and Exchange Commission which says company's chief financial officer Kenneth A Goldman and Mark D Hanson, who heads investor relations, violated rule barring selective disclosure of news to favored investors; says two executives told institutional investors last year that company was performing better than it publicly stated (S)

headline: Dow Jumps 148 in Broad Rally Spurred by Jobs Data
abstract: Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 17.92 points, or 1.6 percent, to close at 1,140.42; Dow Jones industrial average rises 148.26 points, or 1.5 percent, to close at 10,391.08; Nasdaq composite index gains 42 points, or 2.1 percent, to 2,020.62; US Treasury prices rise slightly; price of benchmark 10-year note increases 4/32, to 99 30/32; yield drops to 4.76 percent, from 4.77 percent; graph; chart (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.00   4.00   4.25       Federal Funds   1.00   1.00   1.34       3-month Libor   1.14   1.14   1.32       3-month T-bills   0.92   0.91   1.16       6-month T-bills   1.04   1.02   1.17       10-yr.
