headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Spy Game
abstract: Vladimir Patkin, Russian Volleyball Federation Secretary, announces that Nikolai Patrushev, Russian Federal Security Service head, has been named president of federation (S)

headline: Assessing a Gruesome Toll After a Rash of Beheadings
abstract: Scholars and analysts of Middle East say violent extremists who have seemingly adopted gruesome tactic of beheading hostages from United States and its allies see such acts as ultimate symbols of power over an enemy; Richard W Murphy of Council on Foreign Relations says militants have knowingly chosen method of execution that is particularly horrible to reach widest audience (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Eastman Chemical Co., Kingsport, Tenn., the maker of plastics, agreed to sell businesses in the United States, Europe and China to the closely held Apollo Management L.P., Los Angeles, an investment company, for $215 million, reducing Eastman's work force by 14 percent.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Airbus Wins Orders
abstract: Airbus wins $2 billion order for 20 A330-200 planes from China Eastern Airlines Corp, with option to buy 10 more planes (S)

headline: Out of Prison, Executives Find a Spot At the Lectern
abstract: Executives who have spent time in jail for corporate malfeasance are in demand on lecture circuit; Walter Pavlo, former senior manager of collections at MCI, who spent more than year and half in prison after he was convicted of wire fraud and money laundering, has spoken Center for Responsible Business at Haas School of Business at University of California, Berkeley; Gary Zeune of Pros and Cons, speaker agency that specializes in former white-collar criminals, says demand has been spurred by prominent trials of executives like Martha Stewart and Tyco International's former chief executive L Dennis Kozlowski; Toby Bishop, president and chief executive of Association of Certified Fraud Examiners, says phenomenon is unlikely to last (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: First Community Corp., Lexington, S.C., a holding company, said it planned to acquire DutchFork Bancshares Inc., Newberry, S.C., for about $50 million.    Williams Cos., Tulsa, Okla., a pipeline operator, said it had agreed to sell petroleum contracts and inventories from its energy-trading business to Saracen Energy Partners, Houston, for about $23 million.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Private Schools Shut Over High Fees
abstract: Zimbabwe's Education Minister Aeneas Chigwedere closes 46 private schools claiming raises in tuition are aimed at keeping black students away (S)

headline: A New, Inclusive Europe Yawns, And Picks a Fresh Parliament
abstract: Elections for European Union's parliament, spread across 25 nations over four days, end after dismal turnout and widespread apathy over outcome; vote proves to be less referendum on Europe's future than series of local popularity tests for hundreds of parties and thousands of politicians; voters in many countries use poll to express dissatisfaction with their incumbent governments; preliminary results suggest Parliament will retain center-right political cast; photo (M)

headline: Officialdom and the Press: Too Clubby in Japan?
abstract: Cozy relationship between Japanese government and big media outlets discussed; latest illustration is light reporting of Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi's admission that he has not made mandatory pension payments for seven years; photos; big newspapers and television networks had accepted at face value his denial when two other politicians were forced to resign for not making payments (M)

headline: 3 Substitutions Made in List Of Dow 30
abstract: The Dow Jones industrial average is shedding some losers, again.      Dow Jones announced yesterday that it was dropping AT&T, Eastman Kodak and International Paper from its list of 30 industrial stocks, and adding Pfizer, the American International Group and Verizon Communications.

headline: Book by C.I.A. Officer Says U.S. Is Losing Fight Against Terror
abstract: New book by senior CIA officer who headed special office to track Osama bin Laden and Al Qaeda warns that US is losing war against radical Islam, and that Iraq invasion only played into enemy's hands; unidentified author of book Imperial Hubris is still serving in senior counterterrorism post; book includes harsh criticism of Clinton and Bush administrations and says threat is rooted not in American values but in US policies and actions (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago       Prime rate   4.00   4.00   4.25       Federal Funds   1.06   0.98   1.19       3-month Libor   1.11   1.11   1.28       3-month T-bills   0.92   0.93   1.10       6-month T-bills   0.97   0.98   1.09       10-yr. T-infl.   1.40   1.44   2.03       10-yr. T-note   3.84   3.89   3.93       30-yr. T-bond   4.77   4.81   4.92       Telephone bd.   5.92   5.93   5.81       Municipal bds.   4.59   4.62   5.02          (Sources by Bloomberg News; Telerate; The Bond Buyer; British Bankers' Assoc.)

headline: Big Employers Join Forces in Effort to Negotiate Lower Drug Prices
abstract: Fifty of country's largest employers are creating buyers' club to bargain directly with drug makers on behalf of five million active and retired employees and their families; move is major departure from current industry practice of employers paying middlemen--known as pharmacy benefit management companies--to provide drug coverage for their insured workers; those prices are supposed to be at discounted rates; but because drug pricing is notoriously opaque, employers cannot be sure if they are getting best possible deal; photos; chart (L)

headline: Camber Journal; No Itsy-Bitsy Bikinis or Suntan Lotion, Please, We're British
abstract: Britain's beaches remain popular vacation destinations despite often cold and miserable conditions; warm clothing, hot tea and portable plastic shelters are staples of beach visits; beachgoers in Camber, which has one of southeast England's largest sandy beaches, comment; map; photo (M)

headline: A Deadly Adventure
abstract: An Israeli immigration stamp in his passport apparently became a death sentence for the American who was beheaded by Al Qaeda. But his fate also raises new questions.

headline: World Briefings
abstract: EUROPE.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Alcatel Reports Profit
abstract: Alcatel reports its first profits in three years for first quarter, and raises its outlook for 2004; net income grows to 134 million euros ($161 million) for first quarter of 2004, in contrast to 461 million euro ($552 million) loss for period last year (S)

headline: 'Enthusiasm' Is Not a Candidate in Elections for European Union
abstract: Record low voter turnout is expected as elections are held in 25 nations for 732 members of European Parliament; even most of union's 10 new members are decidely listless about their first chance to vote; Parliament's power is growing, but most of its role is lost on voters because news media does not cover EU with breadth or detail given national issues (M)

headline: Bomb in Istanbul Kills 4 and Injures 14
abstract: A small bomb exploded on a crowded public bus in Istanbul today as security officials prepared to close off swaths of the city in advance of a NATO summit meeting.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Axa, Paris, the insurer, said it had increased its stake in Textron Inc., Providence, R.I., the maker of Cessna business jets, by 34 percent during the first quarter.    Center Financial Corp., Los Angeles, which owns banks in Southern California, said it had terminated its offer to buy Liberty Bank, New York.

headline: In a Soldier's Words, an Account of Concerns
abstract: Excerpts from previously secret testimony of Army Specialist Joseph M Darby to military investigators on abuse of Iraqi detainees at Abu Ghraib prison (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Shell Revising Reserves Again
abstract: World Business Briefing: S

headline: Two Securities Firms Fined by Big Board
abstract: Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc and Morgan Stanley are fined and censured by New York Stock Exchange's enforcement division; Lehman is fined $175,000 for entering more than 245 test orders in what appeared to be real trades to test its system during buisiness hours and failing to monitor testing adequately; Morgan Stanley will pay $140,000 because it had $455 million less than required as collateral for loans; both firms consent to penalties without admitting or denying guilt (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Telecom Stake
abstract: Hong Kong-bï

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Chairman Resigns
abstract: Takashi Usami resigns as chairman of Mitsubishi Fuso Truck and Bus Corp, which admitted in March that design defect may have been cause of series of truck accidents; photo (S)

headline: In Study, Most Companies Reported No Taxes
abstract: General Accounting Office study finds nearly two-thirds of companies operating in US reported owing no taxes from 1996 through 2000; says foreign companies doing business in US are more likely than American-based ones to claim they owed no taxes (M)

headline: Cost-Cutting Measures Pay Off at Merrill Lynch
abstract: Merrill Lynch reports nearly twofold increase in quarterly earnings; net earnings were $1.25 billion, up from $643 million year earlier; chief executive E Stanley O'Neal's cost-cutting measures discussed; photo (M)

headline: In Pacific, a Red Carpet For China's Rich Tourists
abstract: Guam is wooing Chinese tourist; Guam's Gov Felix P Camacho says number of Chinese tourists in Guam should match number of Japanese tourists within next few years; last year almost three-quarters of Guam's 909,506 foreign tourists were Japanese; fewer than 1 percent were Chinese; Camacho notes average Chinese tourist spend $1,500 shopping, almost triple what average Japanese visitor spends on Guam; map; graph; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Economic Data Show Continuing Momentum  Industrial production surged 1.1 percent in May, the strongest performance in nearly six years, and a nationwide survey of business activity showed widespread strength, the Federal Reserve reported.    In other economic news, the Commerce Department reported that nearly 1.97 million residential units were being built last month, at an annual pace. That represented a 0.7 percent drop from April, but still exceeded analysts' forecasts. Total housing permits, a barometer of current demand, rose a strong 3.5 percent in May. [Page C7.]

headline: Bush and Chirac Reporting Progress on Iraq Resolution
abstract: Pres George W Bush meets with French Pres Jacques Chirac in Paris to discuss differences over proposed United Nations resolution on returning sovereignty to Iraqis; Bush and Chirac agree that understanding reached between US and interim Iraqi Prime Min Iyad Allawi could help resolution pass in UN; Chirac cautions that there might still be differences between US and France over military control and expresses dismay over degree of chaos prevailing in Iraq; photo (M)

headline: Provincial Capital in Afghanistan Is Seized by a Warlord's Forces
abstract: Forces loyal to Gen Abdul Rashid Dostum, Afghan warlord, seize control of capital of Faryab Province, forcing governor to flee and drawing sharp rebuke from Pres Hamid Karzai; troops of Afghan National Army, along with their American trainers, arrive too late to prevent takeover of power; this is first time that governor appointed by central government has been forced from power by armed faction; it will be test of Karzai and his government's ability to reassert control; Dostum has often voiced support for central government, yet he has been advocate for federated state and has been reluctant to give up military and econmic control of his region (M)

headline: Wholesalers' Inventories Show Unexpected Decline for April
abstract: Commerce Department reports inventories at American wholesalers unexpectedly fell 0.1 percent in April; sales at distribution centers, warehouses and terminals rose 0.8 percent; total inventories fell by $156 million; Bureau of Labor Statistics delays scheduled release of Producer Price Index because staff is working to resolve unexpected difficulties in calculating index (M)

headline: IRAQ UPDATE
abstract: Update of latest news from Iraq; map (S)

headline: Tough Washington Insider to Face His Critics on Bank Regulation
abstract: John D Hawke Jr's regulatory efforts are under scrutiny as he nears end of his six-year tenure as comptroller of currency; Hawke and his agency have drawn criticism in Congress for failing to fix longstanding compliance problems at Riggs National Corp, favorite of diplomats and government officials that is involved in federal probes of suspected money laundering and terrorist financing through its accounts; Hawke also argued with state regulators when he issued guidelines in February saying his agency had upper hand in enforcing lending laws; action put him on collision course with state officials like New York State Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer who say Hawke's guidelines favor banks and weaken consumer protection; House Finance Services Committee is holding hearing to review how Hawke and Federal Reserve monitor suspect banking activities like those at Riggs; photo (M)

headline: IMCO RECYCLING TO BUY COMMONWEALTH INDUSTRIES
abstract: IMCO Reycling to acquire aluminum-sheet manufacturer Commonwealth Industries for about $175.6 million in stock (S)

headline: Disney Profit Increases 71%; Economy Cited
abstract: Walt Disney Co says net income increased 71 percent in quarter, to $537 million, compared with $314 million year earlier; revenue increased 11 percent, to $7.2 billion from $6.5 billion; earnings are welcome news for chief executive Michael D Eisner, who has been under pressure to improve performance or risk losing his job; chief financial officer Thomas O Staggs increases estimate for earnings per share growth to 50 percent from more than 40 percent for fiscal year ending Sept 30 and reaffirms double-digit earnings growth through 2007; Eisner comments (M)

headline: Cellular Survey Puts Verizon At Top of Corporate Market
abstract: Yankee Group survey of wireless subscribers finds Verizon Wireless, largest mobile phone provider, holds biggest share of lucrative corporate market, with 22.4 percent of all business users, compared with 20.3 percent for Nextel and 16.3 percent for AT&T Wireless; earlier studies, based on surveys of chief information officers and other executives, suggested AT&T and Nextel had better footholds with business users (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Ernst Barred From Adding Audit Clients for 6 Months  Ernst & Young was barred from accepting any new audit clients in the United States for six months after a judge found that the firm acted improperly by auditing a company with which it had a highly profitable business relationship.    The unusual order brought to an end a bitter fight in which the Securities and Exchange Commission had contended that Ernst violated rules on auditor independence by jointly marketing consulting and tax services with PeopleSoft, an audit client. [Page A1.]

headline: Bush Puts Penalties on Nuclear Suppliers
abstract: Bush administration imposes sanctions on 13 foreign companies and individuals in seven countries that it says have sold equipment or expertise that Iran could use in nuclear, chemical and biological weapons programs; sanctions, which are being imposed under Iran Nonproliferation Act of 2000, will prohibit companies and individuals from exporting goods to or receiving contracts or assistance from United States and will prevent American companies from trading with them for two years; 13 entities include five Chinese companies and companies in Russia, Macedonia, Belarus, Taiwan, North Korea and United Arab Emirates; at least five have already been given sanctions at least once before by administration; Under Secretary of State John R Bolton denies that administration is overlooking Pakistani proliferation activities in Iran because of that state's cooperation in fighting terrorism(M)

headline: Fund for Hussein Victims
abstract: American officials announced Tuesday that they would establish a special compensation fund for Iraqis who were imprisoned or executed for political reasons under Saddam Hussein. The fund, to be administered by a commission controlled by Iraqis and financed by a ''substantial'' contribution from the United States, would also look at compensating Iraqis who lost their jobs because they opposed Mr. Hussein, the officials said.

headline: Hostage Is Free; 9 G.I.'s Killed in Iraq Attacks
abstract: A U.S. contractor taken hostage last month escaped, and nine soldiers died in violence across central and northern Iraq.

headline: Unfurling on Your Dashboard, Every Ribbon of Highway
abstract: StreetPilot from Garmin is after-market Global Positioning System for automobile that comes with maps of US and parts of Canada already programmed in; photo (S)

headline: 3 U.N. Police Die in Shootout At Kosovo Jail
abstract: Two American women working as prison guards with United Nations in Mitrovica, Kosovo, are killed and 10 other Americans and Australian working at prison are wounded when Jordanian, also with UN, opens fire on them; attacker is shot and killed; UN says motive for shooting is unclear; map (M)

headline: Chief Executive Of US Airways Quits Amid Strife
abstract: David N Siegel resigns as chief executive of US Airways and is succeeded by Bruce Lakefield; Siegel vowed in March that he would not run from airline's deepening financial problems but reached logjam with its unions (M)

headline: Need ESPN but Not MTV? Some Push for That Option
abstract: Opposition is growing--especially from groups protesting violence and indecency on television--to current system where cable companies sell bundled number of services to customers but do not let them pick and choose which channels they want to pay for; FCC chairman Michael K Powell has been asked by bipartisan House group to review feasibility of a la carte pricing; large cable operators view any such restructuring as potential nightmare; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: UNITED NATIONS.

headline: Israeli Shells Hit Crowd of Palestinians, Killing at Least 9
abstract: Palestinians called it an unprovoked attack; Israeli military officials said there were gunmen in the crowd.

headline: Martha Stewart TV Plans
abstract: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia Inc will create four new shows about weddings on Style Network and will show repeats of Martha Stewart Living television program on cable channel (S)

headline: U.S. Advisers To Stay in Iraq After June 30
abstract: Bush administration planners say about 200 American and international advisers will continue to work at 26 Iraqi ministries as consultants after June 30 transfer of authority to Iraq; at same time, American reconstruction teams will set up four regional headquarters around country to continue managing billions of dollars in American aid that has not yet been spent (M)

headline: United Methodist Church Bucks the Trend on Employee Pensions
abstract: United Methodist Church has voted to start old-fashioned, defined-benefit pension plan for its 25,000 American pastors and lay employees--very type of plan that so many companies have scuttled; church appears to be first sizable employer to create such pension plan in many years; has about $12 billion in other types of retirement plans; photo (M)

headline: Struck in Side, Many Cars Fare Poorly In Safety Test
abstract: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety tests how passenger cars fare when struck in side by sports utility vehicles and pickup trucks, and 10 of 13 midsize car models tested receive lowest of four possible ratings, indicating likelihood of serious or fatal injury; tests show that women are at disproportionate risk in truck-car side-impact collisions; show that side airbags can make a difference between life and death in some cases; Toyota Camry and Honda Accord equipped with side airbags receive highest of four ratings, while standard version of both cars receive lowest rating; tests show that airbags that descend from roof to offer head protection are particularly effective; safety experts believe institute's tests better reflect impact made by light trucks than do tests conducted by National Highway Traffic Safety Administration; table shows ratings for cars made by Toyota, Honda, Chevrolet, Mitsubishi, Mazda, Suzuki Hyundai, Saturn, Nissan, Dodge and Chrysler; graphs; photos (M)

headline: In Bush's and Cheney's Words
abstract: Text of statements by Pres Bush, Vice Pres Cheney and commission probing Sept 11 terrorist attacks on relationship between Iraq and Al Qaeda; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Business Confidence Falls
abstract: Germany's Ifo Institute says business confidence index was 96.1 in May compared with 96.3 in April; companies' expectations for next six months rose to 97.8, from 97.7 (S)

headline: Joseph F. Cullman 3rd, Who Made Philip Morris a Tobacco Power, Dies at 92
abstract: Joseph F Cullman 3rd, who led Philip Morris as it became one of largest corporations in America and maker of best-selling cigarette in world, dies at age 92; photos (M)

headline: Total Nears Iran Gas Deal
abstract: Total, French oil company, says it nears $1.2 billion accord to develop part of Iran's offshore natural gas reserves (S)

headline: INTERMAGNETICS GENERAL TO PURCHASE MRI DEVICES
abstract: Intermagnetics General, which makes parts used in magnetic resonance imaging systems, will buy MRI Devices for $100 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Steel Maker's Profit Rises
abstract: World Busine

headline: United and Atlantic Coast Agree to a Split
abstract: United Airlines and Atlantic Coast Airlines, which operates as regional carrier under United Express name, agree to sever their relationship by late summer, ending long and bitter dispute; Atlantic Coast says its new low-fare subsidiary Independence Air will begin flying June 16 using Dulles airport outside Washington as its hub; airline will use gates that now handle United Express flights, and will serve many of same routes; Independence Air will buy 15 jets from Airbus and also plans to lease 10 A319 jets for total of 25 Airbus planes (M)

headline: Wild West, or Mere Conduit?
abstract: Suw Charman letter contends Internet Relay Chat is one medium for communication among many and is not simply venue for pirating copyrighted material (May 6 article)

headline: Maujempur Journal; On a Newfangled Voting Machine, the Same Old Fraud
abstract: Indian officials are trumpeting introduction of electronic voting machines as example of the new India, but old India abruptly reappears; in state of Bihar, two small bombs explode near one polling place and party workers threaten five policemen guarding booth, then brazenly take control of it; as poll workers and police avert their eyes, young party workers push button for their party on electronic voting machine over and over again, casting vote after fraudulent vote; incident suggests that like rest of India, country's political operatives are becoming more businesslike and more technologically savvy; photo; map (M)

headline: British Official Vows A Thorough Inquiry
abstract: Britain says it accepts at face value as possible evidence of crime photos that seem to show British soldiers beating and humiliating hooded Iraqi prisoner; Min Adam Ingram says military police will probe case despite suspicions that photos were faked (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Privatization Negotiations
abstract: Unions representing Thailand's public-sector workers put off decision on whether to conduct general strike in hopes of negotiating with Prime Min Thaksin Shinawatra over his plans to privatize part of government-owned utility (S)

headline: Iraqi Leader Says He'll Respect Kurd Desire for Autonomy, at Least for Now
abstract: Prime Min Iyad Allawi, responding to threat by Kurdish leaders to pull back from Iraqi state and possibly secede, says his government will adhere to interim constitution until 2005 elections; constitution recognizes autonomy of Kurdish regions and grants Kurds extraordinary powers to protect it; Kurdish leaders react cautiously (M)

headline: Intriguing the Physicists, Radio Buff Shrinks an Antenna
abstract: What's Next column on Rob Vincent, who invented radio antennas that are one-third to one-ninth conventional size; possible applications noted; drawing (M)

headline: The Real Eurotunnel Issue
abstract: Article on who will really control Eurotunnel now that shareholders threw out old management and voted in new board; says overriding issue for next two years will be whether shareholders will lose control of company to creditors; graph (M)

headline: Japan Gets a Taste of Wal-Mart
abstract: Japan Get4

headline: NBC Claims the First Interview With O.J. Simpson, but Fox Does an End Run
abstract: Fox News cable channel shows interview with O J Simpson before NBC News gets chance to air what it thought was first exclusive interview with Simpson; NBC cries foul against Fox News and Yale Galanter, lawyer representing Simpson; photos (M)

headline: Attack in Iraq: Many Versions, Obscure Truth
abstract: Iraqis and American military offer conflicting accounts of roadside bombing of American Humvee in Baghdad that killed one soldier, and its aftermath; after dead soldier is evacuated, Humvee is set on fire and children rush out to celebrate attack; American soldiers begin shooting at rooftop snipers and at least one Iraqi teen-ager is killed in cross-fire; Iraqi witnesses claim five children were killed by American soldiers, but make no mention of gunmen firing from rooftops; several Iraqis say children had been incited to jump around burning Humvee by cameraman for Al Arabiya, Arab news channel which American officials blame for stoking anti-Americanism among viewers around Arab world; station denies charge; contradictory versions of what happened are revealing about thickening fog of this war; many Western reporters are mostly ensconced in hotels and houses protected by huge concrete blast walls, because of recent wave of kidnappings and killings of foreigners; photo (M)

headline: CPI DISMISSES ITS CHIEF AND NAMES AN ACTING SUCCESSOR
abstract: CPI Corp, which operates photography studios in Sears, Roebuck & Co department stores, dismisses J David Pierson as chief executive and chairman; Jack Krings is named acting chief executive, chief operating officer and president (S)

headline: Can the Technology Industry Grow Bigger, Not Just Older?
abstract: Outlook for technology industry and tech stocks discussed in light of recent jump in earnings at big technology companies; confusing signals noted; stock price graph; photos (M)

headline: Iraqi Force In Falluja, With City Still on Brink
abstract: Falluja is balancing on brink between conflict and recovery, after weeks of battling between American marines and insurgents; which way things go may be determined in next few days, as new Iraqi security force struggles to bring order to city after fighting that killed more than 600 residents; photos (M)

headline: Microsoft Agrees to Extend Time Limit in Licensing Deal
abstract: Microsoft Corp agrees to extend provision of its antitrust settlement with Justice Dept in response to concerns that company is taking too long to put agreement into effect; agrees to offer its competitors licenses for server software code for two years beyond original expiration of agreement in 2007 (M)

headline: U.S. Military Says Shiite Rebels Seem to Have Ceded Karbala
abstract: American commanders say insurgents loyal to rebel cleric Moktada al-Sadr appear to have ceded control of central Karbala after three weeks of urban combat; large raid meets no resistance from group of buildings from which insurgents had been firing at American tanks, and civilians return to their homes in area they had abandoned during fierce fighting; Iraqis tell soldiers that insurgents fled after concluding that they were no match for American tanks; commanders intend to press Iraqi police to patrol old city over next few weeks in effort to determine how much of insurgency is left; if rebellion in city has indeed dissipated, it will show that insurgency is suffering badly; photo (M)

headline: Ford's First-Quarter Earnings Up More Than 100%
abstract: The Ford Motor Company more than doubled its first-quarter earnings, driven by cost cuts and favorable pricing trends.

headline: Israeli Rightists Support Gaza Pullout Plan
abstract: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon picked up support from right-wing leaders for his plan to withdraw from the Gaza Strip without a peace agreement.

headline: Army Conducting 20 Criminal Inquiries in Treatment of Iraqis
abstract: The criminal inquiries came as the furor over mistreatment of some Iraqi captives continued to grow.

headline: Palestinians and Police Clash at Sacred Site in Jerusalem
abstract: It was the largest eruption of violence at the Jerusalem holy site since the Palestinian uprising began in September 2000.

headline: ITT INDUSTRIES NAMES PRESIDENT AND CHIEF EXECUTIVE
abstract: ITT Industries names Steven R Loranger, former executive of Textron Inc, to succeed Louis J Giuliano as president and chief executive (S)

headline: ARMY DISCLOSES CRIMINAL INQUIRY ON PRISON ABUSE
abstract: Gen George W Casey Jr says Army in last 16 months has conducted over 30 criminal probes into misconduct by American captors in Iraq and Afghanistan, including 10 cases of suspicious death, 10 cases of abuse and two deaths already determined to have been criminal homicides; disclosure is strongest indication yet of wider pattern of abuse at American prisons; military officials say most severe penalties in any of cases to date were less-than-honorable discharges for five soldiers; Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld scores Nov abuses at Iraq's Abu Ghraib prison, news conference; seeks to minimize significance of incidents elsewhere and insists military responds swiftly to abuse charges; Senate Armed Services Committee members, including Sens Carl Levin and John McCain, express anger after being briefed on details and potential scope of misconduct; Senate Intelligence Committee sets closed hearing to determine whether intelligence officers were involved; Bush administration dispatches State Sec Colin L Powell, national security adviser Condoleezza Rice and other top officials to contain fallout over widening story of abuse at prisons; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Highway Privatization Advances
abstract: Japan's Parliament passes laws that pave way for privatization of public highways (S)

headline: Pentagon Official Says Asking Army to Help Iraq Interrogators Did Not Lead to Prison Abuse
abstract: Stephen A Cambone, under secretary of defense for intelligence, says he urged last summer that Army general be sent to Iraq to review how American military interrogators could gain more intelligence from Iraqi prisoners at Abu Ghraib prison, but he never advocated policy of having military guards at prison soften up prisoners for interrogators; Cambone's role in sending Maj Gen Geoffrey D Miller and team of experts to Abu Ghraib last Aug and Sept, and in pushing from highest levels of Pentagon for more and better intelligence to help fight insurgents, will be focus of hearings Senate Armed Services Committee will hold May 11; Miller claims his recommendation that prison guards prepare detainees for interrogations played no role in later abuse and humiliation of prisoners by some guards; photo; chart of scheduled witnesses at abuse hearings (M)

headline: Huge Basque Arsenal Found in Southwestern France
abstract: Interior Min Angel Acebes of Spain announces that police have discovered large arsenal of Basque separatist group ETA in southwestern France; says site contained grenades, other weapons and explosives, and may also have been arms factory; says French police raid also resulted in arrests of two people suspected of being ETA members (S)

headline: Israel Says Children Enlist Children as Suicide Bombers
abstract: Israel contends Palestinian factions have used teenagers to recruit other teenagers as suicide bombers; some Palestinian leaders have condemned use of teenagers, and opposition to practice is widespread among ordinary Palestinians, but it is clear practice has not stopped; Israel has arrested 15-year-old Nasser Awartani of Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades, accusing him of recruiting youths in Nablus as suicide bombers; arrest comes after 16-year-old Hussam Abdo fails to detonate bomb at Israeli checkpoint and is taken into custody and questioned; Awartani is specifically accused of recruiting friend Sabih Abu Saud, who blew himself up in West Bank on Nov 3; photos (M)

headline: Tax Day Is Here Again
abstract: More than 131 million tax returns are expected to be filed this year, and last-minute filers are streaming into post offices countrywide.

headline: Saying Grasso Duped Big Board, Suit Seeks Return of $100 Million
abstract: New York Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer files long-awaited civil suit against former New York Stock Exchange chairman Richard A Grasso, demanding that he repay more than $100 million of his 'excessive' $139.5 million pay package; powerful heads of Wall St firms who served on exchange's board will be put in uncomfortable position of having to testify publicly about how they came to approve compensation package that some of them later disavowed; Spitzer's suit cites new evidence for contending that Grasso inflated his pay and deliberately misled his high-powered board about many details of his package to enhance his pay above and beyond benchmark of comparable chief executives; suit names only one other defendant, Kenneth G Langone, Grasso's friend and chairman of compensation committee in years when Grasso's annual pay peaked, 1999 to 2003; Spitzer discloses that Frank Z Ashen, internal compensation expert at NYSE, will cooperate with authorities and pay back $1.3 million of compensation he received; says Ashen has said that Grasso did not disclose to board $18 million of bonus payments he received; Grasso issues statement saying he looks forward to 'complete vindication'; photos; chart (L)

headline: Rumsfeld Chastised by President For His Handling of Iraq Scandal
abstract: White House officials say Pres Bush chastised Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld for his handling of scandal over American abuse of Iraqis held at Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq; say he expressed displeasure over Rumsfeld's failure to tell him about photographs of abuse, which have enraged Arab world; disclosure of Bush's dressing-down of combative Rumsfeld is first time president has allowed his displeasure with senior member of his adminstration to be made public; Republicans note strong public relations aspect to disclosure about Oval Office scolding, which makes Rumsfeld scapegoat in scandal; Bush's chief political adviser Karl Rove says one of dangers of basing re-election campaign on national security and foreign policy is that events can be beyond president's control (M)

headline: Israeli Platoon Leaders Fired Over Death
abstract: Israeli Army dismisses commander and deputy commander of platoon whose gunfire killed Arafat Ibrahim Yaakub, Palestinian in wheelchair, on June 6 near Ramallah (S)

headline: Leo O'Neill, 64, Executive Who Helped Expand S.&P.
abstract: Leo C O'Neill, chief executive who guided Standard & Poor's as it expanded from American bond rating firm into international concern, dies at age 64; photo (M)

headline: Chairwoman Pulls Lucent Back From the Brink, But Not Out of the Woods
abstract: Lucent Technologies' chairwoman-chief executive Patricia F Russo has returned telecommunications giant to modest profitability by eliminating tens of thousands of jobs, slashing billions of dollars in debt and settling major lawsuits with investors; Russo is now in race against time to develop new products and services that will allow Lucent to survive as entire industry changes around it; Russo comments; photo (M)

headline: Treasury Offerings Set for the Week
abstract: This week's schedule of Treasury auctions includes the sale of new three- and six-month bills today and four-week bills tomorrow. At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 0.95 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 1.15 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 0.84 percent. The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week:    TAX EXEMPT  TODAY      Spring Branch Independent School District, Tex., $50 million of general obligation bonds. Competitive.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: BCE To Buy Assets From 360networks
abstract: Canada's BCE Inc will buy assets from 360networks Corp for 275 million Canadian dollars ($201 million) to help it win customers from rivals like Telus in Western Canada (S)

headline: After Ending Arms Program, Libya Receives a Surprise
abstract: International Atomic Energy Agency, in new report on Libya's nuclear disarmament, discloses American-led team that originally seized five containers of centrifuge parts bound for Libya from ship in Oct missed another container from different source full of components for most advanced centrifuge available from network set up by Abdul Qadeer Khan; Libyans quietly reported arrival of shipment to agency and American intelligence when parts arrived at Tripoli port in Mar; American official denies team missed container; suggests Libya got container in Jan (M)

headline: Chinese People's Republic Is Unfair to Its Short People
abstract: Chinese government denies government jobs to those who do not meet often unwritten code of fitness--height, looks and robust good health--that many say has nothing to do with their ability to perform task in question; standards are sign of how far China has drifted from Communist Party's stated socialist values; officials are no longer selected on basis of ideological fervor or working-class background, but rather in ways that seem more reminiscent of China's imperial history; rigorous requirements for height and physique have long been used to screen people who want to work in China's most internationally visible jobs; new effort to extend those standards to all government jobs is traced to China's effort to put best face forward since joining World Trade Orgn and interacting more with outside world; photo; map (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of table with Apr 4 special report on chief executives' payÿ

headline: U.S. Officer in Critical Condition After Shooting at Kosovo Jail
abstract: American serving as correctional officer with United Nations mission in Kosovo is in critical condition after attack on mostly-American group of prison guards by Jordanian policeman also serving with UN mission there; two American women die in shooting and another nine American officers are wounded, as is Austrian prison guard; Jordanian officer is killed when guards return fire; police investigators say they could not comment as to whether Jordanian officer deliberately chose Americans as his target; photo (M)

headline: 3 Firms Are Fined by NASD
abstract: Morgan Stanley, Bear Stearns and Deutsche Bank are fined total of $15 million and censured by NASD for collecting outsize commissions for allocating shares of initial public offerings to favored clients; NASD says firms violated regulatory rules by accepting commissions 'far in excess of typical rate of 6 cents a share' from customers one day after selling them shares in initial offerings (M)

headline: Ex-Executives At Symbol Are Indicted
abstract: Seven former senior executives of Symbol Technologies are indicted in accounting fraud scheme that US Atty Roslynn R Mauskopf describes as breathtaking in scope and a veritable playbook of corporate fraud; she says deception ran from 1999 to 2002, inflated company's reported revenues by more than $200 million and involved nearly its entire former management team; says Symbol's own investigation into matter was slowed by interference of company executives, notably Michael DeGennaro, former senior vice president for finance; others named in indictment are Tomo Razmilovic, former chief executive, Kenneth Jaeggi, former chief financial officer, Brian Burke, Frank Borghese, Christopher DeSantis and James Heuschneider; criminal charge against eighth executive, Leonard Goldner, former general counsel, accuses him of orchestrating securities fraud in which he and other Symbol executives manipulated stock options program to enrich themselves and avoid taxes; SEC files civil lawsuit accusing Symbol and 11 former executives of securities fraud in accounting scheme; new management team at Symbol is cooperating with prosecutors (M)

headline: Israeli Crowd Supports Pullout From Gaza
abstract: Crowd of 120,000 people in Tel Aviv rallies to support Israeli Prime Min Ariel Sharon's plan for unilateral withdrawal from Gaza in rare display of support for conservative government from marginalized left; Sharon's own Likud Party rejected plan in referendum two weeks ago; Shimon Perez of center-left Labor Party says 80 percent of Israelis support plan and will not allow one percent of population represented by Likud dissenters to derail it; photo (M)

headline: As College Plans Proliferate, It Pays to Shop Around
abstract: Concern is growing that brokers and investment company fees for state-sponsored 529 college savings plans are so high they often outweigh tax benefits; experts advise investors to look first at own state's plan, which may offer special tax advantages; investment options vary, with many offering funds that shift gradually from stocks to bonds as child nears college age; graph (M)

headline: Testing 1, 2, 3; Critics Agree: Good Things Come in Small, Powerful Packages
abstract: Roundup of laptop computers designed for gaming; photos (M)

abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.00   4.00   4.25       Federal Funds   1.13   1.09   1.11       3-month Libor   1.60   1.59   1.11       3-month T-bills   1.37   1.35   0.86       6-month T-bills   1.75   1.67   0.93       10-yr. headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Jewish Military Memorial Defaced
abstract: French Veterans Ministry reports that Douaumont National Necropolis worker has discovered 1916 Battle of Verdun memorial dedicated to Jewish soldiers defaced with Nazi graffiti (S)

headline: Iraqi With Close U.S. Ties Chosen to Be Prime Minister
abstract: Dr. Iyad Allawi, a member of the Iraqi Governing Council, has been chosen to be prime minister of Iraq's interim government.

headline: Court Orders F.C.C. to Rethink New Rules on Growth of Media
abstract: Federal appeals court orders Federal Communications Commission to reconsider rules it issued last summer that would ease way for largest media companies to grow and enter new markets; 2-to-1 decision will prevent big broadcasting and publishing companies from any attempts for now to expand; they have lobbied and litigated for years in effort to ease rules; decision is also setback for Bush administration, which supports easing ownership limitations, and for FCC Chmn Michael K Powell, main architect of new rules; rules would have lifted restriction on company's owning both newspaper and television or radio station in same market, and would have allowed companies in largest cities to own as many as three television stations, eight radio stations, cable operator and newspaper; ruling does not dispute FCC's right to ease ownership limitations, but says regulators must do so in way that is not 'arbitrary and capricious,' which court says had occurred in this case; ruling is victory for smaller broadcasters and coalition of labor, consumer, religious, artistic and civil rights organizations; they fear rules would result in reduction in diversity of voices on airwaves and declining standards in television and radio programming; photo (M)

headline: People
abstract: Michael Hudes is named executive vice president for corporate development at Clear Channel Outdoor; Robin Steinberg is named vice president and director for print services at MediaVest (S)

headline: Two More U.S. Soldiers to Face Courts-Martial for Iraq Abuse
abstract: Eight other Americans have been charged in the abuse scandal; one is set to face court-martial on May 19.

headline: S.E.C. Acts on Corporate Shells
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission for first time suspends trading in shares of companies because they failed to file financial disclosure reports; takes action against 26 shell companies, which have few assets or sales; officials are concerned that absence of financial reports could leave investors vulnerable to 'pump and dump' manipulation, in which misleading or incomplete information inflates price of stock (M)

headline: Justice Elusive in 1994 Attack on Argentine Jews
abstract: Argentine government blames Iran for 1994 bombing of Jewish community center in Buenos Aires that killed 85 people and wounded 300, but it has been unable to extradite suspects; has instead focused on provincial police officers and car thieves alleged to have supplied vehicle used in bombing, but case has been compromised by witness-tampering scandal that has resulted in removal of investigating magistrate and two prosecutors; Jewish groups question police role and suspect involvement of state intelligence apparatus; case has lately stagnated while replacement judge wades through backlog of work; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.00   4.00   4.25       Federal Funds   1.00   1.03   1.24       3-month Libor   1.15   1.15   1.32       3-month T-bills   0.91   0.92   1.15       6-month T-bills   1.05   1.09   1.16       10-yr. T-infl.   1.77   1.85   2.15       10-yr. T-note   4.34   4.40   3.96       30-yr. T-bond   5.17   5.21   4.89       Telephone bd.   6.23   6.28   5.85       Municipal bds.   5.00   5.02   4.95          (Sources by Bloomberg News; Telerate; The Bond Buyer; British Bankers' Assoc.)

headline: Nanotech Memory Chips Might Soon Be a Reality
abstract: Nantero, which is developing memory chips using cylindrical molecules of carbon known as nanotubes, and LSI Logic, leading maker of specialty microchips, are set to announce that they have transferred Nanotero's technology to LSI's standard semiconductor production line in Gresham, Ore; say considerable work remains to improve chips; carbon nanotubes have extraordinary strength, but also extraordinary electrical and magnetic characteristics that have helped make them powerful symbol of nanotechnology's potential; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Brazil: Inflation Rises
abstract: Brazil's consumer price index rose 0.51 percent in May, up from 0.37 percent increase in April (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Pepsi Bottling Ventures, Raleigh, N.C., the third-largest bottler of Pepsi-Cola in the United States, plans to buy closely held Pepsi-Cola Bottling Co., Salisbury, Md., to expand into Maryland, Virginia and Delaware. Terms were not disclosed.    Spiegel Inc., Downers Grove, Ill., the bankrupt clothing retailer, won court approval to sell its flagship catalog business to Pangea Holdings Ltd., Bermuda, a private equity firm, for $53.4 million.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Berlin Bans Scarves For Public Servants
abstract: Berlin become sixth of Germany's 10 states to ban wearing of visible religious symbols by civil servants (S)

headline: $9 Million in Pay for US Airways Chief
abstract: US Airways Group pays chief executive David N Siegel $9 million in 2003, mainly in restricted stock, after his previously granted awards were canceled in airline's bankruptcy (S)

headline: Ruling on Yukos Taxes Draws Nearer
abstract: Russian court lifts injuction that barred tax authorities from seizing Yukos assets; decision is procedural move in Tax Ministry's bid for $3.4 billion in back taxes; removes obstacle to judgment on actual substance of case; criminal trial of Mikhail B Khodorkovsky, who built Yukos into oil giant, on fraud and tax evasion charges is adjourned again to give defense more time to review evidence; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Airline Adds Fuel Fee
abstract: British Airways will add surcharge of 5 pounds ($8.89) to every round-trip fare on its British flights as result of rising price of oil; fares will increase by $4 per flight sector outside of Britain (S)

headline: Rumsfeld Preserves Bearing, But Weighs Ability to Serve
abstract: Confidants say that Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld, man at center of furor over American soldiers' abuse of Iraqis at Abu Ghraib prison, is maintaining his normal workaholic schedule, but as scandal widens and deepens he is weighing every day whether he can continue to effectively run world's largest military; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Meat Ban Challenged
abstract: European Union regulators demand that Russia immediately lift ban on meat imports from Europe, warning that ban may hold up Russia's effort to join World Trade Organization (S)

headline: Glaxo Plans Public Listing Of Drug Trials on Web Site
abstract: GlaxoSmithKline, reacting to complaints that it selectively disclosed results from pediatric trials of its antidepressant drug Paxil, plans to create Web site that will publicly list all clinical trials on its marketed drugs; says site will include results of all tests run on drug before its approval for marketing and subsequent tests of same drug for new uses or on new types of patients; medical director Dr Alastair Benbow calls plan major step in transparency, phone interview; New York Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer lauds plan (M)

headline: Beijing Journal; China Warms Up and Practices for a Future in Baseball
abstract: Chinese Baseball League All-Stars, China's first professional baseball league, is in its second season; few fans turn out and players lack skills, but promoters are optimistic; country is gearing up to host 2008 Olympics in Beijing, where it will compete in sport for first time; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Airlines Brace for a Huge New Battle
abstract: Major airline executives at industry conference in San Francisco discuss how they plan to compete with growing number of low-fare carriers; drawing (M)

headline: EXIDE'S PLAN TO CUT $1.3 BILLION IN DEBT IS APPROVED
abstract: Exide Technologies, world's biggest maker of car batteries, wins approval for its plan to eliminate $1.3 billion in debt and exit bankruptcy protection by end of April (S)

headline: Outpatient Services Are Making Medical Offices Hot
abstract: Article on rising market for medical offices; Real Capital Analytics says $1.3 billion worth of medical office buildings individually valued at $5 million or more changed hands in 2003, up from $954.6 million in 2002 and $787.8 million in 2001; says $330 million in sales have closed so far this year, with another $401 million under contract; some specific deals discussed; graph; photo (M)

headline: Israeli Army Pushes Sweep In Gaza, Killing 7
abstract: Israel presses its campaign against Palestinian uprising; in Gaza Strip, it broadens its offensive, sending tanks and armored bulldozers into four of six major neighborhoods in Rafah and killing at least seven Palestinians, most or all of them militants; in Tel Aviv, Israeli court convicts Palestinian leader Marwan Barghouti of murder in attacks that killed five Israeli civilians; he is acquitted of charges relating to 21 other slayings; Barghouti remains defiant, saying uprising will continue as long as occupation continues; is most prominent representative of pragmatic secular Palestinian leadership that is losing ground during conflict to Muslim extremists calling for Israel's destruction; although Barghouti defends current Palestinian uprising, he was once eloquent proponent of 1993 Oslo accords; photos (M)

headline: U-HAUL PARENT SETTLES WITH I.R.S. FOR BIG TAX REFUND
abstract: Amerco Inc, parent of U-Haul International truck-rental business, says it avoided paying as much as $93 million in additional tax by settling dispute with Internal Revenue Service; will get net refund of $6.5 million as result of settlement (S)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Howard G. Belk was named chief creative officer at Siegel & Gale, New York, succeeding Kenneth Cooke , who left, the agency said. Mr. Belk had been a group director at Interbrand, New York, part of the Omnicom Group.

headline: North Korean Performers Adapt to Life on a New Stage
abstract: North Korean performers who defect to South Korea confront cultural divide; typically perform traditional songs and dances that are popular with older people but no longer comprehensible to younger South Koreans raised on latest pop music; North Korean performers typically work together in large groups according to rigid artistic system of North Korea, while South Korea rewards individualism and originality; photo; map (M)

headline: The Latest High-Tech Legal Issue: Rooting Out the Spy in Your Computer
abstract: Battle against spyware, software that shows up on computer unannounced, often because owner has signed up for free service, and usually delivers pop-up ads, is entering new phase; Utah has become first state to enact antispyware law, barring software installed without user's consent and programs that send personal data; industry, facing threat of patchwork of possibly conflicting state laws, is asking Congress for uniform, but less stringent, federal law; WhenU.com challenges Utah law; drawing (M)

headline: Broadcast networks join forces against their cable rivals in a battle for commercials.
abstract: Broadcast networks join forces against their cable rivals in battle for commercials; agencies and marketers have been upset over rising cost of advertising on broadcast networks at time when viewers are steadily gravitating to cable; networks will strike back with campaign that sticks up for broadcast and belittles cable's reach; photo (M)

headline: Draped in advertising, Rome curbs a monumental coverup
abstract: ROME:—  It was when Romans woke up late last month to find a colossal, glossy-lipped woman's face towering over one the city's most prominent landmarks that City Hall said "basta" to the practice of putting advertisements on the scaffolding of monuments under restoration.

abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.00   4.00   4.25       Federal Funds   1.00   1.00   1.21       3-month Libor   1.28   1.28   1.28       3-month T-bills   1.02   1.00   1.05       6-month T-bills   1.36   1.32   1.05       10-yr.
