headline: Résumé Buffing, the Wall Street Way
abstract: Andrew Ross Sorkin Dealbook column on increasingly widespread, and potentially misleading, form of backscratching in which corporations credit their biggest lenders for strategic advisory work, even when they do little or nothing; notes corporations do so in hopes of getting better loan terms, while investment banks do so as way to puff up own deal lists; holds quarterly rankings of investment banking activity are now too skewed by fanciful representations to be trusted; drawing (M)h

headline: More Angry Than Ever at the U.S., the Iraqis Crave Security
abstract: In Baghdad, most Iraqis seem to be waiting, uncertain and with less tolerance than before violence of last weeks; they say they want to see how much power they will actually receive in transfer of some sovereignty on June 30 and whether fighting will flare again in Falluja or, worse, in holy Shiite Muslim city of Najaf; most important to them is whether American soldiers can contain any new burst of fighting without killing innocent Iraqis; most Iraqis interviewed speak of losing their sense of security; photo (M)

headline: Helping People on the Move Keep Addresses Up to Date
abstract: Profile of Plaxo, online peer-to-peer service that helps computer users keep their address books updated with latest postal addresses and phone numbers of everybody in their circle; service is free, but company plans to make money by selling premium version to business users; sees its rapidly expanding network giving it edge over Microsoft and others aiming to incorporate wide array of business and personal services into their software; graph of Plaxo users; photo (M)

headline: GENERAL DYNAMICS WILL HIRE 210 FOR MARINE CORPS PROJECT
abstract: General Dynamics Corp to hire

headline: EUROPE ASKS GLAXOSMITHKLINE TO STRENGTHEN WARNINGS
abstract: European Union advisory panel says that GlaxoSmithKline should strengthen warnings about severe withdrawal symptoms when patients stop taking its depression medicine Paxil (S)

headline: The Pleasures and Pitfalls of Second Homes
abstract: Benefits and costs, sometimes unanticipated, of owning vacation home discussed, with advice to be realistic about home's likely use (M)

headline: FNB AGREES TO ACQUIRE SLIPPERY ROCK FINANCIAL
abstract: FNB Corp acquires Slippery Rock Financial for $78.5 million in cash and stock, adding nine banks in western Pennsylvania (S)

headline: Najaf Talks Stall; Soldier Is Killed
abstract: Negotiations to settle stand-off in Najaf between American forces and fighters loyal to Iraqi cleric Moktada al-Sadr have broken off for reasons that are unclear; one American soldier is killed in outskirts of Najaf when Iraqi forces open fire on patrol (S)

headline: General Took Guantánamo Rules To Iraq for Handling of Prisoners
abstract: Maj Gen Geoffrey Miller's recommendations last August for interrogation and detention procedures in Abu Ghraib included giving military intelligence officers greater authority and asking military police guards to help gather information about detainees; some officers who met Miller in Iraq claim current Abu Ghraib crisis is partly rooted in what they describe as his determination to apply his experience at Guantanamo Bay, where he won praise from Pentagon for improving flow of intelligence from terrorist suspects and prisoners of Afghanistan war; Miller dismisses notion that his visit to Iraq helped unleash abuses there; says his prescriptions may have been misinterpreted by ineffective commanders in chaotic environment; Maj Gen Antonio M Taguba's report on Iraqi prison abuses says Miller's recommendations violate Army doctrine; hints that they might also have contributed to abuses; photo (M)

headline: Palestinians Say Israeli Troops Killed 2, One of Them a Child
abstract: Palestinian security officials say Israelis killed child when tanks raided Khan Yunis refugee camp in Gaza; Israeli military denies raid occurred; says it returned fire when nearby army posts came under attack by antitank weapons and Molotov cocktails; in separate incident, Israeli soldiers in West Bank shoot and kill armed man who approaches them (M)

headline: U.S. Forces Push Fight in Najaf, and Clashes Erupt in Karbala
abstract: American forces stepped up their fight against militants loyal to the rebel cleric Moktada al-Sadr today.

headline: Technology Briefing | Deals: I.B.M. Buys Schlumberger Unit
abstract: IBM acquires disaster recovery subsidiary of Schlumberger for undisclosed sum; deal will add 40 business backup centers in Europe and North America to 120 IBM Global Services already operates (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Softbank Posts a Loss
abstract: Softbank Corp says net loss grew to 107 billion yen ($953 million) for year ended March 31 from loss of 100 billion yen year earlier as revenue grew 27 percent, to 517.39 billion yen (S)

headline: Coke Names a New Head of Marketing
abstract: Coca-Cola Co chief executive E Neville Isdell names Charles B Fruit chief marketing officer, succeeding Daniel P Palumbo, who is leaving Coke; Fruit comments, interview (M)

headline: Adelphia Witness Defends Big Cash Advances
abstract: Adelphia Communications Corp's former assistant treasurer Michael Mulcahey testifies he never doubted that company's founder John Rigas could repay cash advances of $1 million per month for expenses; Mulcahey, who is on trial on fraud charges, tries to explain in earlier testimony about cash advances that he authorized (S)

headline: A Broker's Empty Promise, a Retiree's Shattered Dream
abstract: Case of Norman Huff, who won arbitration case against Prudential Securities and broker Michael G Dobbins, who convinced him to accept early retirement deal, for improperly investing his pension funds noted; some securities lawyers say circumstances surrounding his losses are becoming disturbingly common as brokers find people considering retirement to be receptive and trusting targets; brokers have incentive to recommend that workers accept early retirement offers to gain access to pension money; photos (M)

headline: OPEC Agrees to Increase Output in July to Ease Oil Prices
abstract: The increase in oil output, 2 million barrels a day, was the biggest in six years but it failed to meet oil traders' expectations.

headline: Reality Intrudes On a Spring Rite Of Network TV
abstract: Audience taste for reality shows puts pressure on Hollywood studios that produce sitcoms and dramas as well as on television writers, directors, actors and their agents; 12 of top 20 shows in current television season are reality shows, and many of remainder are either about to end their runs, like Friends, or are part of multipart crime franchise, like NBC's Law and Order and CBS's CSI; trend upsets annual spring 'upfront presentations' of new shows to advertisers; Fox, which can anchor its lineup on baseball in fall and American Idol in winter, plans to begin introducing roster of new shows in June; CBS and NBC, which have stable schedules, plan minimal changes for next season; ABC struggles to find shows to turn its dismal performance around; photos (M)

headline: Sharon's Gaza Pullout Plan May Face His Party's Rebuff
abstract: Three separate polls show members of Prime Min Ariel Sharon's s own party are likely to vote down his proposal for pulling Israel out of Gaza Strip, which would be major political setback for him; he has said that party's referendum on Gaza withdrawal plan would amount to vote of confidence in his leadership; referendum is not legally binding, but Sharon has warned that defeat would have wide-ranging repercussions, jeopardizing assurances he got from Pres Bush during White House visit; settlers and right-wing Israelis have been waging campaign to defeat his proposal (M)

headline: Britain Extends Its Detention of 8 Bomb Suspects
abstract: Scotland Yard antiterrorism branch says it has extended to Apr 3 the detention of eight men arrested in connection with seizure of 1,000 pounds of bomb-making compound near central London; says arrests in Canada and Saudi Arabia of father and son from Pakistan may be connected to investigation into suspected bomb-making activities in London; police say no detonators, timing devices or other paraphernalia was discovered in raid (M)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Defense Dept confirms deaths of 11 service members in Iraq, bringing total to 734 since war began (S)

headline: Disney Seeks to Counter Analysts' Poor Reviews
abstract: Wall Street analysts are beginning to worry that Walt Disney Co's movie division may have less-than-steller year because of cool reception to early films like The Alamo and Home on the Range; Smith Barney media analyst Jill S Krutick says last weekend's poor showing of The Alamo, which earned only $9.1 million at box office, despite its $100 million price tag, could reduce Disney's earnings by as much as 3 cents for year; adds Home on the Range, which opened two weeks ago, has brought in only $27 million so far (M)

headline: Selling the Chill Factor (and the Vodka)
abstract: Absolut Spirits Co, which recently introduced Danzka vodka brand in United States, say metal bottle shaped like cocktail shaker allows vodka to chill faster than vodka in glass bottle; is using marketing strategy geared toward young urbanites; photo (M)0

headline: Merrill Is Accused Of Sex Bias In London
abstract: Merrill Lynch former senior manager Stephanie Villalba says she was 'bullied and belittled' by her boss Ausaf Abbas and then unfairly forced out of her job, in what could become London's highest profile sexual discrimination case; is asking $15 million in compensation for unfair dismissal and sexual discrimination; Merrill Lynch denies Viillalba's claims, saying her sex had no effect on how she was treated on job; photo (M)

headline: BBDO Worldwide Cuts 100 Jobs
abstract: Jenny Craig Puts.

headline: With Killer's Execution, Karzai Signals Move on Warlords
abstract: Abdullah Shah, notorious mujahedeen commander, is first man to be executed in two years since Pres Hamid Karzai established new Afghan government; Afghans welcome execution as sign that government is finally moving against criminal warlords, but it raises concerns among human rights groups and reveals shortcomings in judicial system under Karzai's Transitional Administration; rights groups say Shah was not given fair trial and was falsely accused of being notorious killer; there is some speculation that more powerful warlords orchestrated case against Shah; photos (M)

headline: S.E.C. Adopts Rule on Fund Market Timing
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission orders mutual funds to disclose what they do to deter rapid trades, first rule developed to address trading scandals that erupted last year in industry; rules requires funds to explain in prospectuses their policies for thwarting 'market-timing' trades (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Energy Secretary Quits
abstract: Mexican Energy Secretary Felipe Caldereon Hinojosa resigns in wake of dispute with President Vicente Fox; Calderon plans to run for president in 2006 (S)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Advertising spending in major media for the first quarter rose more than forecast, by 9.6 percent, to $31.5 billion, compared with the period in 2003, according to TNS Media Intelligence/CMR, part of Taylor Nelson Sofres. The sharpest increase came in Internet ad spending, which rose 28.1 percent, to $1.9 billion. National spot radio spending fell the most, 2.2 percent, to $515.1 million.

headline: White House Reconsiders Its Policy on Crisis in Sudan
abstract: Bush administration is considering toughening its policy toward Sudan over events in Darfur, where thousands of people have been killed and over million driven from their homes by Arab militias that many in region say are linked to Sudanese Army; Bush officials are considering whether what is happening in Darfur amounts to genocide; Sec of State Colin L Powell says link between militias and government is strong, and that many people are still at risk of dying in Darfur and across bor der in Chad; map; photo (M)

headline: Deadlock Seen On Presidency In Iraqi Talks
abstract: American, Iraqi and United Nations officials deadlock over selection of Iraqi president, even as they appear to strike deal over most important cabinet ministers for new government that is to take over on July 1; on one side of deadlock are United Nations envoy, Lakdar Brahimi, and chief American administrator, L Paul Bremer III, who are backing former foreign minister, Adnan Pachachi; leaders of Iraqi Governing Council support rival, Sheik Ghazi Ajil al-Yawar; both men are Sunnis (M)

headline: Spitzer's Claims Aren't as Clear Cut As They May Seem
abstract: Some of New York State Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer's claims in suing former New York Stock Exchange chairman Richard A Grasso to force him to return upwards of $100 million in pay will be difficult to provide; Spitzer appears to back away from one of most explosive accusations against Grasso--that as chairman and chief executive of NYSE he knew of fraud by research analysts and failed to act on it; complaint includes accusations that Grasso intervened in exchange's regulatory processes and in those of other regulators to get favorable treatment for companies run by directors of exchange; contends that those directors, mostly top executives at major Wall Street firms, rewarded Grasso with compensation that Spitzer views as outrageously high; charts; photos (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Switching Smoothly From PocketPC to Palm
abstract: Q. I use a PocketPC organizer and would like to switch to a Palm. How can I get my data from one to the other without having to re-enter it?    A. Pocket PC organizers use a version of Microsoft Outlook to manage calendar and contact information and to synchronize the data between hand-held and desktop computers. Palm organizers come with the Palm Desktop program instead, but you do not have to use it; you can continue to use Outlook.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Level 3 Communications Inc., Broomfield, Colo., the telecommunications company, said it had acquired a business that provides dial-up Internet access from ICG Communications Inc., Englewood, Colo., a data and voice communications provider, for about $35 million.

headline: HealthSouth Reaches an Agreement With Its Bondholders
abstract: HealthSouth Corp reaches broad agreement with bondholders to withdraw threats that might have pushed it into bankruptcy; will pay bondholders $73 million to $80 million and give them opportunity to redeem some of bonds early in restructuring of $2.6 billion of debt (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon Rivals Offered Higher Rate-Leasing Plans
abstract: Verizon Communications introduces contractual framework for leasing its lines to competing telephone companies (S)

headline: Powell Offers Abuse Apology and Israeli Rebuke
abstract: There was little evidence that the twin gestures had mollified Arabs mistrustful of the U.S. in both Iraq and the Mideast.

headline: Bush Welcomes Gaza Plan, Without Backing It Fully
abstract: Pres Bush stops short of endorsing Israeli Prime Min Ariel Sharon's plan for unilateral pullback from Gaza and parts of West Bank; says plan should not replace White House's stalled proposal for negotiations that would lead to creation of Palestinian state; is silent on Israel's hopes of securing administration's approval for its plan to hold on to contested portions of West Bank; Israel also wants US to recognize its right to send military forces back into Gaza if necessary to deal with terrorists there; Egyptian Pres Hosni Mubarak, visiting Bush in Texas, says Egypt is willing to help somewhat by using its influence to rein in some Palestinian factions in Gaza and to help maintain security there after Israeli forces leave; photo (M)

headline: Honors
abstract: Jack Griffin, president of Meredith Publishing Group, is named chairman of American Advertising Federation (S)

headline: A Guilty Plea Over Insider Trading at Enron
abstract: Paula Rieker, former corporate secretary of Enron, pleads guilty to insider trading and agrees to cooperate with Federal government's investigation of company; Justice Department says Rieker made insider trades in July 2001 to avoid significant losses in Enron Broadband Services; Rieker also agrees to pay $499,333 to settle Securities and Exchange Commission accusations that included claim she provided 'substantial assistance to Enron executives and senior managers' in misleading public about company's finances; neither admits nor denies wrongdoing (M)

headline: IRAQ UPDATE
abstract: Update of events in Iraq; map (M)

headline: At Alitalia, a Case Study in Boss vs. Worker Dynamics
abstract: In the airline business, it often seems like a basic rule of employment is turned on its head: The bosses cannot fire the workers, but the workers can get rid of the bosses.

headline: Trade Theory vs. Used Clothes in Africa
abstract: Local clothing makers in Africa want their countries to ban imports of used clothing from Europe and US so they can sell more apparel and make more money; shoppers can buy secondhand American clothing for much less than new African goods; International Trade Commission says declared value of American secondhand clothing exported to Africa was $59.3 million in 2002; about $2.3 milion of that went to Uganda; photo (M)

headline: Havas Plans to Sell Two-Thirds of WCRS
abstract: French agency Havas will sell back to management 75 percent of London agency WCRS; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Ready for the Admiral
abstract: Amgen

headline: Israeli Official Offers Empathy but Hits a Nerve
abstract: Israel's Justice Minister Yosef Lapid, who opposes Israeli plan to demolish Palestinian homes in Gaza, starts political uproar by saying that suffering Palestinian woman he saw on television news program reminded him of his grandmother, who died in Holocaust; Danny Naveh, another cabinet minister who lost relatives in Holocaust, rejects any comparison to Holocaust, even implied; Lapid says he is not comparing Israeli Army to Nazis, but his remarks feed Israeli debate about continuing Israeli military campaign in Palestinian neighborhoods of southern Gaza Strip; Lapid says army is considering demolishing as many as 2,000 Palestinian homes in Rafah refugee camp to expand Israeli-patrolled zone; says Israelis look like 'monsters' in eyes of the world; photo (M)

headline: Witness Tells of Dual Accounting at Adelphia
abstract: Adelphia Communications Corp's former vice president James R Brown testifies top executives at company knew that its published financial results were misleading because they regularly received reports that compared those figures with company's real financial conditions; says real results were needed to make operating decisions; describes public disclosures as filled with 'accounting magic'; reiterates in second day of testimony that Rigas family members who ran company knew that investors were being misled (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar gains against euro after consumer confidence rises to two-year high; euro settles at $1.2083, down from $1.291, in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: Delta Pilots to Seek Talks
abstract: Air Line Pilots Association at Delta Air Luines seeks resumption of contract talks with company, using updated objectives (S)

headline: In Focus; Shoot Close-Ups From Your Keyboard, by Remote Control
abstract: Remote control software for digital cameras discussed; programs let user store photos on computer hard drive, giving equivalent of super-size memory card (M)

headline: Apple Putting More Focus On Simplifying Searching
abstract: Apple Computer chief executive Steven P Jobs demonstrates coming feature for Apple computers, called Spotlight, that will allow users to search quickly for words and concepts stored on hard drive by using search technology borrowed from company's iTunes online music service at software conference in San Francisco; search feature, part of next version of Macintosh operating system called Tiger, is scheduled for release in first half of 2005; photo (M)

headline: Work Restarts On Projects Hurt by Strife, Officials Say
abstract: American officials say work on rebuilding Iraq's infrastructure is recovering from near halt at height of violence earlier in April even though 10 percent of foreign workers remain out of country for safety and little is being done at 10 percent of projects; acknowledge that reconstruction could be hindered if more violence erupts in weeks leading up to transfer of some sovereignty to Iraqis on June 30 (M)

headline: KEYSPAN PROFIT UP ON HIGHER NATURAL GAS SALES
abstract: KeySpan Corp says first-quarter profit rose 1.8 percent from year earlier, to $246.2 million (S)

headline: President of Electronic Arts Steps Down
abstract: Electronic Arts says president-chief operating officer John Riccitiello has resigned effective immediately; chief executive Lawrence F Probst III will assume Riccitiello's responsibilities while company evaluates candidates and names successor (M)

headline: Roof Collapses at Paris Airport, Killing 5
abstract: A 120-foot section of new terminal at Charles de Gaulle international airport in Paris collapses, killing at least five people and burying unknown number of others; terminal, concrete and glass elliptical tube, was opened less than year ago after several construction delays; if accident is determined to have been caused by structural failure, as suspected, terminal's strikingly unconventional design is likely to stir debate about how far architects can push new materials and construction theories in pursuit of beauty without endangering lives; photo (M)

headline: Chiquita Will Sell Colombian Unit
abstract: Chiquita Brands International Inc. agreed to sell its Colombian banana business to Invesmar Ltd. for about $51.5 million to reduce costs.

headline: Pollenzo Journal; A New Italian Campus, Where the Thought Is for Food
abstract: First Univ of Gastronomic Sciences will open in fall in 19th-century palace in Pollenzo, Italy; university director Vittorio Manganelli says students will study sociology of consuming, history of gastronomy and iconography, from first scratching of image of food on wall to how it is depicted today on Internet; photos; map (M)

headline: 9 Iraqi Militias Said to Approve Deal to Disband
abstract: About 100,000 paramilitary soldiers have agreed to demobilize and re-enter civilian life or join the country's security forces.

headline: Way Clears for Spaniard to Lead I.M.F.
abstract: Rodrigo Rato, former finance minister of Spain, is poised to become Europe's choice to head International Monetary Fund, after France drops its support of rival candidate, Jean Lemierre, president of European Bank for Reconstruction and Development; photo of Rato (M)

headline: Citing `Crunch Point,' Blair Plans Review of Immigration Rules
abstract: The announcement by British Prime Minister Tony Blair came just four days before the enlargement of the European Union removes obstacles to continental migration.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Oracle's Bid for Competitor To Be Tested in Court  Lawyers for the Justice Department will call their first witnesses today in the government's lawsuit to block Oracle's proposed hostile takeover of PeopleSoft, after opening statements by both sides.     The trial in federal court in San Francisco comes a year after Oracle surprised PeopleSoft with its initial $5.1 billion bid for the company, the first in a series of offers that PeopleSoft's board has rejected. In its most recent bid, Oracle is offering $7.7 billion to acquire the rival software company. [Page C4.]

headline: Hotels Go to the Mattresses In the War for Customers
abstract: Growing number of four-star and five-star hotels are replacing standard guest-room bed with luxury ones to attract customers; drawing (M)

headline: Former Soviet Central Banker Emerges as Yukos Chairman
abstract: Fora

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank May Sell Unit
abstract: World

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Sammy To Acquire Sega For $1.45 Billion
abstract: Japan's Sammy Corp acquires Sega Corp for $1.45 billion in stock; graph (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar falls against euro after US jobless claims are higher than expected; euro settles at $1.2268, up from $1.2117, in New York; graph; chart (S)

headline: Chechen's Death Dashes Hope for a Return to Normal
abstract: May 9 assassination of Chechen Pres Akhmad Kadyrov dashes hopes that life might return to normal; Kadyrov was seen as Moscow's puppet but had begun to win grudging respect of people for heartfelt manner, small improvements and hints of defiance toward Moscow; vignettes of Chechnya and capital city Grozny; photo; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Nauru: Help For A Neighbor
abstract: Pacific island nation of Nauru, which is threatened with bankruptcy by financing company GE Capital, seeks help from Australia, which promises to have senior finance officials help Nauru devise plan to stave off financial ruin (S)

headline: Bush Meets Pope, Who Voices His Displeasure Over Iraq
abstract: Pope John Paul II, in meeting with Pres Bush at Vatican, reiterates his unhappiness over invasion of Iraq and urges him to speed restoration of sovereignty to Iraqi people; urges US to work toward new United Nations resolution, and suggests that mistreatment of Iraqi prisoners has undermined battle against terrorism; thousands of people in Rome demonstrate against war and US foreign policy; photo (M)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Defense Dept confirms deaths of five service members in Iraq, bringing total to 764 since war began (S)

headline: South of Baghdad, a Road of Recurring Death Claims Two More Victims
abstract: Two Japanese freelance journalists driving to Baghdad from south are killed by insurgents on particularly dangerous stretch of road between Mahmudiya and Iskandariya, towns filled with Sunni Arabs seething at occupation; numerous journalists, soldiers and contractors have been ambushed, robbed, and, often, killed there; Brig Gen Mark Kimmitt says area is spillover zone for fighters from Baghdad and Falluja; map (M)

headline: Mutual Funds Report; Some Funds Win Big by Buying Small
abstract: Mutual funds that focused on small-capitalization

headline: 2 U.N. Peacekeepers Killed in Eastern Congo
abstract: Crisis deepens in Eastern Congo with fatal shooting of two United Nations peacekeepers in city of Goma and tensions with neighboring Rwanda; Congolese Pres Joseph Kabila has accused Rwandan government of helping former rebel soldiers who laid siege to Bukavu in recent days, which Rwanda denies; siege set off riots in which thousands of demonstrators stormed UN headquarters in capital, Kinshasa; rebel commander Gen Laurent Nkundu now says he is pulling his troops out of Bukava (M)

headline: U.S. Protests Broadcasts by Arab Channels
abstract: Bush administration is frustrated by what it calls 'inflammatory' reports by Arabic television channels about war in Iraq; it is protesting to foreign government officials, confronting Arab news executives and putting together list of supposed abuses; Secretary of State Colin Powell voices American concern about Al Jazeera, channel based in Qator and financed by government, to Qatar Foreign Min Sheik Hamad bin Jassim bin Jabir al-Thani; State Dept refuses to say what action Powell seeks from Qatar; he and other administration officials claim their efforts in Iraq are being undercut by politically motivated or erroneous reports by both Al Jazeera and Saudi-based Al Arabiya; American generals in Iraq claim Al Jazeera broadcasts are inflaming anti-American sentiment; photo (M)

headline: Europe's Loss of Focus
abstract: The prevailing tone today in trans-Atlantic relations is one of conciliation. But the divergence in outlook between America and Europe suggests that tensions are likely to recur.

headline: Stephen M. Peck, 69, Investor And Mount Sinai Philanthropist
abstract: Stephen M Peck, Wall Street investment banker and philanthropist, dies at age 59 (S)

headline: A.N.C. Again Sweeps South Africa Vote
abstract: African National Congress, as expected, scores runaway victory in South Africa's general election; voter turnout, however, falls sharply from last election, raising questions about voters' satisfaction with electoral process; Democratic Alliance, party with historic ties to country's white minority, establishes itself in comparatively strong second place; photo (M)

headline: French Pedophilia Case Falls Apart When Main Suspect Recants
abstract: Pedophilia case that has captivated France, and destroyed lives of dozen people, collapses when main suspect, Myriam Delay, suddenly admits that she made up much of story; on 10th day of her trial, she tells stunned courtroom that her tale of gang rapes and child prostitution ring based in her home in Outreau was elaborate lie; points out several of accused, saying they are innocent; trial has shattered lives of 18 people accused in case, with one committing suicide and others losing custody of their children; Delay could face up to 2 years in jail for her false accusations, in addition to possible sentence of 20 years for sexual abuse of minors (M)

headline: Facing the Consequences of Not Going
abstract: Article on consequences workers face when refusing to go on business trips; says sometimes, refusing to travel means finding different job; some executives and workers comment (M)

headline: Promoter of U.S. Image Quits for Wall St. Job
abstract: Margaret D Tutwiler, State Dept veteran with mandate to overhaul public diplomacy effort, resigns to take position at New York Stock Exchange; move is blow to Bush administration's hopes to improve America's image abroad and better articulate its policy goals; Tutwiler had embraced conclusions of report released in Oct, painting dire picture of American efforts to reach out to foreign countries and build support for Washington's actions; will be executive vice president for communications and government relations at stock exchange; photo (M)

headline: Who Got the Message? There's a Way to Know
abstract: E-mail service from DidTheyReadIt.com offers return-receipt for every e-mail sent; privacy groups are concerned because receipt includes information about recipients; photo (M)

headline: Blair Stands Firm With Bush in Face of New Iraq Fighting
abstract: Prime Minister Tony Blair committed himself anew today to the war in Iraq, calling it a "historic struggle" against dictatorship, terrorism and fanaticism across the globe.

headline: After a hiatus and a decline in sales, Jim Beam is reaching out to ask consumers to take a look inside.
abstract: Jim Beam Brands Worldwide ends yearlong hiatus from advertising and will have its first campaign for its bourbon by its new agency BBDO Worldwide; advertising budget estimated at $8 million to $12 million (M)

headline: Addenda
abstract: Foote Cone Loses.

headline: Ad Links Politics And Higher Gas Prices
abstract: Detroit Project Action Fund and Campaign for America's Future introduce TV commercial that blames politics for rising gasoline prices; ad argues that federal energy policy favors large oil companies over consumers (S)

headline: Confusion with Slovakia prompts new flag : Slovenia's identity crisis
abstract: LJUBLJANA, Slovenia:—  CORRECTION PUBLISHED IN THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE DATED Monday, April 19, 2004:

headline: U.N. Distances Itself From an Envoy's Rebuke of Israel and the U.S.
abstract: United Nations officials move to disassociate organization from damning remarks about Israel and US policy in Middle East made by Lakhdar Brahimi, its special envoy to Iraq (M)

headline: VERIZON WIRELESS TO MOVE 1,700 CUSTOMER-SERVICE JOBS
abstract: Verizon Wireless plans to move 1,700 customer-service jobs in Orangeburg, NY, and Morristown, NJ, to bigger call centers in Wilmington, NC, and unannounced location; is offering workers $10,000 incentive to move; size of new centers will allow Verizon Wireless to add about 500 customer-service jobs and reduce need to hire outside contractors to handle call overflow (S)

headline: KFC Settles Charges Over Commercials
abstract: KFC settles FTC charges that television campaign in November 2003 made false claims about healthiness of its fried chicken (S)

headline: Turks Free 4 Kurds Whose Jailing Irked European Union
abstract: Turkish appeals court frees Leyla Zana and three other Kurdish former members of Parliament convicted 10 years ago of belonging to outlawed separatist movement; sets hearing on their appeal; Amnesty International urges Turkey to drop case altogether, holding they were prosecuted only for their political beliefs; Min Abdullah Gul predicts four will not return to jail; four, who have already served most of their sentences, are mobbed by supporters as they leave Ankara prison; European Union Comr Gunter Verheugen hails move as sign political reforms are gaining ground (M)

headline: AOL Rebounding From Subscriber Losses
abstract: Time Warner chief executive Richard D Parsons says he is pleased by performance of company's businesses, including its Warner Brothers and New Line film studios, annual meeting, Burbank, Calif; says America Online is 'stabilizing' after losing subscribers for six consecutive quarters; America Online lost 237,000 subscribers in United States in first quarter and ended period with 24 million, down from 26.2 million in period year earlier; unit cut costs and increased earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization by 21 percent in first quarter; Parsons says it is 'most powerful and most profitable business in the Internet sector' (M)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Defense Dept confirms death of US soldier killed in Iraq

abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.00   4.00   4.25       Federal Funds   1.06   1.01   1.28       3-month Libor   1.15   1.14   1.32       3-month T-bills   0.92   0.93   1.15       6-month T-bills   1.09   1.08   1.16       10-yr. headline: U.S. Preparing for Influx of Compensation Claims by Abused Iraqis
abstract: Defense Dept officials are preparing for influx of compensation claims stemming from charges of abuse at Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq (M)

headline: NextWave Pact With F.C.C. Ends Airwave Dispute
abstract: Government forges agreement with NextWave Telecom Inc that will free valuable airwave licenses vital to improving nation's cellphone system and provide windfall potentially worth billions of dollars to NextWave, which has been in bankruptcy protection since 1998; NextWave will return to FCC 75 percent of licenses it won in 1996 auction but never paid for, but will be allowed to keep some of the most valuable of disputed licenses in largest cities; government will also receive $1.1 billion on top of $500 million down payment it received years ago from NextWave; licenses returned to FCC, which have never been used, will be reauctioned (M)

headline: Making the Grade
abstract: making t

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: ASIA.

headline: The trick:Getting consumers to pay : Digital music wars play out in Europe
abstract: LONDON:—  The guitar strains of Buddy Holly's "It's So Easy to Fall in Love" jangled through a London auditorium last week as Steve Jobs, chief executive of Apple Computer, introduced the company's iTunes online music service to Europe.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Cuts At Schering
abstract: German pharmaceutical group Schering will cut jobs and close some research and development projects to raise profit; chief executive Hubertus Erlen comments; photo (S)

headline: Spain Labels as Credible a Letter Threatening New Attacks
abstract: Spanish authorities are giving credence to a letter received from a self-described Al Qaeda spokesman threatening more attacks.

headline: NORTHROP, OPTIMISTIC ABOUT 2005, PLANS STOCK SPLIT
abstract: Northrop Grumman expects sales to climb 7.1 percent in 2005 as military spending rises; raises its dividend and will split its stock 2-for-1 for first time since 1984 (S)

headline: Butler, Shine Is Hired For Converse Account
abstract: Converse, athletic-shoe company, names Butler, Shine, Stern & Partners to handle its advertising account, which has been handled by Modernista (S)

headline: Deal Reached on Enron Pensions
abstract: Some former directors of Enron Corp agree to pay as much as $86.5 million to settle part of $3 billion in employee pension-fund claims linked to company's collapse in 2001 (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Drug Rights Sold
abstract: Irish drug maker Elan sells North American rights to its migraine treatment Frova to British biotechnology company Vernalis for $55 million over next two years; Japanese drug maker Eisai will buy epilepsy drug Zonegran for $130 million; Elan chief executive Kelly Martin comments; photo (S)

headline: E-Commerce Report; Online competitors are crowding the flower vendors for a piece of the Mother's Day market.
abstract: Online merchants have begun competing more aggressively for gift shoppers over last year, making major battlegrounds of second-tier gift-giving occasions like Mother's Day; Web sites that had carved niches in gift-giving category have been forced to redouble their efforts, particularly flower retailers who rely heavily on Mother's Day for revenues; photo (M)

headline: Sabotage Cuts Power to More Than 100 Key Electrical Lines
abstract: Internal Iraqi government report obtained by New York Times shows that sabotage attacks have cut power flowing through more than 100 of lines that form backbone of Iraq's electrical grid since US invasion last year; nearly 1,200 of huge support towers have been toppled; most of damage has been repaired, but far more attacks have occurred this year than were publicly reported; map; table (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Knocking On Europe's Door, In Greece
abstract: Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan makes first state visit to Greece in 16 years and urges that both nations rise above long-held rivalry; asks Greece, which joined European Union on May 1, to help with Turkey's admission into union; photo (S)

headline: ANADARKO'S PLAN TO SELL ASSETS LEADS TO A RISE IN SHARES
abstract: Shares of Anadarko Petroleum Corp rise after company announces it plans to sell more than $2.5 billion in assets and buy back up to $2 billion of its stock (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: DUANE READE INC., New York, the drugstore chain, said it had agreed to accept 2.9 percent less cash from Oak Hill Capital Partners, Menlo Park, Calif., the buyout firm controlled by billionaire investor Robert M. Bass, to speed completion of Oak Hill's takeover. The cash portion of the price was cut to $16.50 a share, or $404 million, from $17, or $416 million.

headline: A Human Tidal Wave, or a Ripple of Hysteria?
abstract: Many in Western Europe fear expansion of European Union will bring deluge of legal immigrants from East; fears, especially of Gypsies, persist despite tightened access to welfare benefits, temporary immigration curbs and recent studies showing flood of migrants to Germany and Britain is unlikely; map; photo (M)

headline: Big Board Considers Move Into Derivatives Trading
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange intends to expand its product range, including a possible move into derivatives trading, as part of a broad review to boost revenues and growth.

headline: In Shiite Enclave, Cheers Have Turned to Fury
abstract: Shiites of Sadr City grieve for kin and neighbors killed in firefight with American soldiers, as American armored forces patrol their impoverished neighborhood; eight American soldiers and about two dozen Iraqis die in firefight; battle is blow to hopes of Shiites who had welcomed American troops last year; now they are angry about continued military occupation, lack of jobs and instability; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: As Profit Rises, Wal-Mart Offers Note of Caution  Wal-Mart Stores reported that its profits for the first quarter rose 16 percent and that overall sales, bolstered by growing interest in apparel, increased at the fastest pace in more than two years.    But H. Lee Scott, the company's chief executive, warned that soaring gasoline prices could put a crimp in consumer spending in the months ahead, potentially slowing the gains the world's largest retailer previously forecast. [Page C3.]

headline: 4 Leading London Hotels Sell for $1.3 Billion
abstract: Quinlan Private, Dublin-based group of real estate investors, acquires four London hotels called Savoy Group for 750 million pounds ($1.37 billion) from American-based private equity firms Blackstone Group and Colony Capital; photo (M)

headline: Gauging the Worth Of the Chief Executive
abstract: gauging the worth of t

headline: Man in the News; A Guide for Hard Times -- Iyad Alawi
abstract: Profile of Dr Iyad Alawi, named to become interim Iraqi prime minister; photo (M)

headline: Hide-and-Seek Among the Coca Leaves
abstract: Bush administration reports gains in drug crop eradication program in Colombia, after setbacks that saw coca crop expanding threefold, to more than 400,000 acres in 2001; overall coca production has declined in Andes, but cocaine trade has shifted tactics, abandoning coca plantations in favor of numerous tiny plots in isolated gullies and valleys, such as national park east of Santa Marta; photo; map (M)

headline: Los Angeles Times Wins 5 Pulitzer Prizes
abstract: The five awards were the second highest number of awards won by a single newspaper in the history of the awards.

headline: U.S. Congress moves to clarify the rules : Just how 'American' must a president be?
abstract: WASHINGTON:—  The U.S. Constitution specifies that only a "natural born citizen" can become president of the United States, and after more than two centuries of uncertainty about the phrase, Congress is taking steps to clarify its meaning.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cablevision Offers $90 Monthly Package
abstract: Cablevision Systems Corp begins offering $90-a-month package of TV, phone and Web-access service (S)

headline: Arafat Shrugs Off Warning He May Be Israeli Target
abstract: Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat says he is not troubled by warnings from Israel that it could act against him; Israeli Prime Min Ariel Sharon earlier said Arafat has 'no insurance policy' against Israeli action; Arafat has been confined to compound in West Bank for two years (M)

headline: In Israel, a New Highway Leads to an Ancient Christian Past
abstract: Archaeologists of Israel Antiquities Authority announce they have unearthed fifth or sixth century Christian community in path of planned highway improvement project in seaside town of Netanya; site seems significant, but archaeologists have explored only in path of proposed interchange; dig has been suspended while authority considers how to proceed; difficulties of engineering in small country that is essentially one big archaeological site, where modern needs conflict with preserving cultural heritage, discussed; map, photo (M)

headline: Kangerlussuaq Journal; Golf Under a Handicap: Icy Cold Is Par for the Course
abstract: Sondie Arctic Desert Golf Course is said by Greenlanders to be northernmost 18-hole golf course in world, 35 miles above Arctic Circle; course is essentially unmodified terrain that has been defined either as fairway, tee, green or rough by markers and flags; it is low-budget labor of love, created with scraped-together donations of equipment and scraps of material; clubhouse is pair of brown trailers; photos; maps (M)

headline: MCKESSON IN TALKS WITH BRITAIN'S HEALTH SERVICE
abstract: McKesson Corp says it is trying to renegotiate 10-year, $500 million contract with National Health Service of Britain and that profits might be reduced if talks fail (S)

headline: 4 Rivals Near Agreement on Ways to Fight Spam
abstract: America Online, Earthlink and Microsoft, which have merged their technical standards for identifying and discarding e-mail messages with fake return addresses, near accord with Yahoo, which develops more technically powerful approach to fighting spam, to give limited support to each other's technology; proponents say two approaches could be complementary; drawings (M)

headline: Hussein to Be in Iraqi Custody 'Very Soon,' New Premier Says
abstract: Iraq's interim Prime Min Iyad Allawi says Saddam Hussein will be physically transferred to custody of Iraqis within few days after Iraqis officially take power on June 30; says Hussein will receive 'a just trial,' unlike those he gave Iraqi people while in power; Allawi's comments are corroborated by Muwafak al-Rubaie, new interim government's national security adviser, who says American soldiers will escort handcuffed Hussein from his cell and turn him over to four Iraqi policemen for formal arrest before Iraqi judge on July 2 or 3; these are most specific public statements yet on Hussein's future; they seem to give Allawi and new interim government symbolic shot of credibility among Iraqis eager to see that they will have real power over their fate; Allawi acknowledges that foreign soldiers--most likely Americans--will probably guard building where Hussein is imprisoned; Allawi has won early support among Iraqis for promising tough action against insurgents who have killed hundreds of Iraqis and Americans; his authority to govern strongly will be limited sharply by desires of Americans who continue to have great military and financial sway, and by competing Iraqi political interests able to exercise power in ways that were not allowed under Hussein; photo (M)

headline: Shares Fall as a Jobs Report Fuels Interest-Rate Worries
abstract: Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 7.54 points, or 0.7 percent, to 1,113.99; Nasdaq composite index declines 19.52 points, or 1 percent, to 1,937.74; Dow Jones industrial average declines 69.69 points, or 0.7 percent, to 10,241.26; US Treasury prices decline; 10-year note falls 5/32, to 95 9/32; yield rises to 4.60 percent from 4.58 percent; graphs; charts (M)

headline: At Iraqi Prison, Rumsfeld Says Abuse Will Be Dealt With Openly
abstract: During an unannounced trip to Iraq, the defense secretary promised that America will punish any soldier guilty of abuse.

headline: A Fad's Father Seeks a Sequel
abstract: Gary Dahl, who created most popular novelty product of 1975, the Pet Rock, has not been able to repeat his success with other products he has dreamed up over years; he is writing book The Pet Rock Saga, and looking for publisher; photos (M)

headline: Attacks in Mideast Raise Fear of More At Oil Installations
abstract: Recent killing of five Western contractors at Yanbu, Saudi Arabia, oil hub and attempted suicide bombing of Iraq's main oil export terminals have raised market-rattling fears that oil workers and facilities may be Al Qaeda's new targets and made security central preoccupation of Mideast oil producers; attacks did not do great damage, but traders worry about possibility of more serious disruptions of already strained oil market, sending prices up; photo (M)a

headline: General Says Sanchez Rejected Her Offer to Give Address to Iraqis About Abuses
abstract: Brig Gen Janis Karpinski, former head of military police at Abu Ghraib, says Lt Gen Ricardo S Sanchez, top American general in Iraq, rejected her recommendation in Jan that military make public Arabic-language radio or television address to Iraqi people to confront accusations of abuse at prison; says Sanchez visited military intelligence unit at Abu Ghraib at least three times in Oct, when first of worst of abuses were taking place; Sanchez has said he did not learn of abuses until Jan 14, but Karpinski says that in late Nov, Sanchez's top deputy Maj Gen Walter Wojdakowski was present at meeting at which there was extensive discussion of Red Cross report that cited specific cases of abuse; two Defense Dept offiicals acknowledge that command in Baghdad was reluctant to say too much at outset because of continuing criminal investigation; photos (M)

headline: United Nations Journal; At East River Landmark, Creaking Old Bones Are Bared
abstract: John M Clarkson, program director for United Nations' master plan to renovate aging interior of UN headquarters building, offers 'dirty tour' of landmark marble and glass tower, focusing on its eyesores and decay; master plan to gut and refurbish emptied headquarters complex--subject to approval of $1.2 billion loan proopsed in Pres Bush's 2005 budget--is to finish in time for staff members to return in 2011; they will be relocatted temporarily in 2007 to 35-story building under construction nearby; photos (M)

headline: White Knuckles On the Timing Of a Rate Rise
abstract: Chmn Alan Greenspan, set to testify before Congress, is likely to face questions about timing of first Federal Reserve interest rate rise in four years; graph of Treasury yields; photo (M)

headline: IRAQ UPDATE
abstract: Update on recent events in Iraq; map (S)

headline: Patents; Inventors of a virtual music machine try to overcome objections by giving it musicality.
abstract: Computerized, virtual orchestra that has been at heart of dispute between theater producers and musicians on and off Broadway is defended by three scholars who won patent for it; they claim their system will keep musical theater alive by cutting costs without sacrificing orchestra; debate has led musicians' union in New York City to demand ban on invention; after two years of battling musicians' union, inventors are focusing on using their idea to enhance smaller orchestra, rather than fully replace live orchestra; system described; inventors are three professors: David B Smith, Frederick Bianchi and Kojiro Umezaki; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Machinery Orders Fall
abstract: Orders for new machinery in Japan fall 3.2 percent in March from February, tempering some of recent optimism about strength of Japan's economic recovery; government still expects orders to rise over long term (S)

headline: Russia Seeks Balance in Drug-Use Sentencing
abstract: Russia liberalizes penalties for possession of small amounts of illegal drugs; makes possession of small amounts for personal use punishable by fine, though possession of larger amounts or trafficking is punishable by prison term; laws were already similar to those in West in theory, but actual sentences have been harsh even for possession of small amounts of drugs; special commission has redefined table of weights and penalties, bringing them closer to those accepted by world community (M)

headline: Brazil's Big Stake in Cotton Likely to Become Bigger
abstract: World Trade Organization's ruling in early June that American cotton subsidies violated international trade rules could eventually drive up world prices and give cotton growers from Brazil to West African incentive to increase production; graph; photo (M)9

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Drug Maker Posts Profit
abstract: Serono says profit is up 76 percent in first quarter, to $106 million (S)

headline: For Japanese Hostages, Release Only Adds to Stress
abstract: The young Japanese taken hostage in Iraq returned home this week, not to the warmth of a yellow ribbon embrace but to a disapproving nation's cold stare.

headline: Under the Falluja Sun, Gunfire and a Grim Task: Wait It Out
abstract: Marines of Company L, waiting in 'fighting holes' 400 yards north of Falluja, say they were greeted with nearly constant rocket and mortar barrages from Falluja insurgents when they first arrived eight days ago, but that last two days have been relatively quiet (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Four marketers named Addis, Berkeley, Calif., to handle brand strategy and design assignments. They are: Bally Gaming and Systems, Las Vegas, part of Alliance Gaming; Cutters Gloves, Phoenix, a sports-glove marketer; Delta Technical Coating, Whittier, Calif., which sells arts and crafts supplies; and PepsiCo, Purchase, N.Y.

headline: As Bush Confers With NATO, U.S. Is Seen Losing Its Edge
abstract: Pres Bush, in Istanbul to press NATO allies to play greater role in Iraq, faces resistance from critics of his administration's previously unilateral stances who worry that Iraq mission may be on brink of failure; normally friendly countries like Germany, France and Japan, as well as international organizations long dominated by US, are forcing administration to rethink its plans for security in Iraq; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: RCN Files For Bankruptcy Protection
abstract: RCN Corp files for bankruptcy protection after failing to attract enough customers to pay debts it incurred in expanding its networks; service will not be interrupted as result of bankruptcy (S)

headline: 5 Big Networks To Attend Ad Meeting
abstract: Executives from ABC, CBS, Fox Broadcasting, UPN and WB will attend initial meeting of committee called Network Upfront Discussion Group formed by advertisers and agencies, seeking to improve process by which they buy billions of dollars of TV commercial time each spring; NBC is not scheduled to attend; also attending will be executives from Turner cable networks and Court TV, as well as Warner Brothers division that sells spots during syndicated series (M)

abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.00   4.00   4.25       Federal Funds   1.00   1.00   1.23       3-month Libor   1.27   1.26   1.27       3-month T-bills   1.01   1.02   1.06       6-month T-bills   1.34   1.32   1.06       10-yr. headline: Witness Says Tyco's Ex-Chief Had Authority to Give Bonus
abstract: Tyco International Ltd former director Frank E Walsh Jr testifies that former chief executive L Dennis Kozlowski had authority to pay bonus to company's top lawyer Mark A Belnick; Walsh has pleaded guilty to stock fraud in connection with secret $20 million finder's fee he received from company (M)

headline: Testimony From Abu Ghraib Prisoners Describes a Center of Violence and Fear
abstract: Testimony of Iraqi detainees at Abu Ghraib prison provides graphic and gruesome details of behavior by guards that included intimidation, violence and sexual assault that has so far gone beyond criminal charges filed in affair; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Prison For Bombings Investigator
abstract: Former Russian State Security agent Mikhail Trepashkin is sentenced to four years hard labor in prison for revealing state secrets surrounding 1999 apartment bombings in Moscow and Volgodansk that killed 243 people; reported link between bombings and FSB security service, which sparked renewed Chechan conflict (S)

headline: CYCLING : Book details suspicions about Lance Armstrong and drug use
abstract: PARIS:—  A book scheduled to be published this week in France charges that Lance Armstrong used illegal performance-enhancing drugs before and during the first of his five successive victories in the Tour de France in 1999.

headline: A Great Fund (For Them, Not You)
abstract: Retirement plan of federal employees, including members of Congress, is very model of how mutual funds should be run for benefit of shareholders, in sharp contrast to unethical practices that victimize many investors in private realm; federal Thrift Savings Plan offers five index funds operating at modest cost far below fees paid by many private investors; disparity noted in light of Congess's apparent lack of interest in tightening regulation (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Advertising Speciality Institute, Trevose, Pa., reported that spending by marketers on promotional products — giveaway items like pens or paperweights bearing company logos — increased 3.2 percent last year to $16.1 billion from $15.6 billion a year earlier.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AT&T Testing Voice-Over-Internet Service Overseas
abstract: AT&T begins trials on its over-the-Internet phone service in Asia and Europe for its business customers; low-cost phone service, which uses high-speed Internet lines to connect calls, has already been rolled out in US (S)

headline: Video of President Bush's Speech
abstract: Following are video excerpts of the president's speech on Monday night.

headline: With Eye on Europe, Turkey Backs Bid to Reunite Cyprus
abstract: Turkey, intent on winning points with European Union, throws full weight behind UN proposal to reunite Cyprus, despite domestic charges of betraying island's Turkish population; US and European officials praise decision; Greek and Turkish Cypriotes still have to decide in separate referendums whether to live under loose federation after thirty years of strict, bitter division (M)

headline: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Westchester; From Canyons of Manhattan To Serene Old Haunt of I.B.M.
abstract: New York

headline: SOUTHWEST BANCORP TO PAY $165 MILLION FOR TEXAS BANK
abstract: Southwest Bancorp of Texas plans to buy Klein Bancshares for $165 million, adding branches in two Texas counties (S)

headline: Addressing Cadets, Bush Sees Parallel to World War II
abstract: Pres Bush delivers grim commencement speech at United States Air Force Academy, telling 1,000 cadets that they would soon be part of struggle against terrorism that he likens to World War II as historic challenge of the time; outlines in most detail yet what he sees as continuing threat of terrorism; emphatically affirms his belief in striking enemies before they can strike first to protect Americans against Al Qaeda and other terrorist threats; Bush's remarks appear to try to strike balance between frightening Americans and offering himself as only choice to lead nation out of danger and to shore up his credentials as commander in chief in election year; photo (M)

headline: A Change in Destination, A Sense of Direction
abstract: Sean Donohue The Boss article on his life, airl

headline: Add 'Cut' and 'Bleep' To a DVD's Options
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column on DVD player from RCA with ClearPlay software that uses filters to 'sanitize' movies; Directors Guild of America has sued ClearPlay and similar companies; drawing; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Analogic Profit Falls 74%
abstract: Shares of Analogic Corp fall sharply after company says earnings declined 74 percent in third quarter ended April 30; reports earnings of 13 cents a share, down from 51 cents year earlier; revenue fell to $92.3 million from $100.1 million a year earlier (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Hearing Set On Music Merger
abstract: European Commission schedules hearing on proposed merger of music units of Sony and Bertelsmann for June 14-15 (S)6

headline: Balancing A Three-Martini Career
abstract: Simon Ford My Job article on his work promoting Plymouth Gin brand, work that involves both extensive after-hours entertaining and drinking and regular office hours; photo (M)

headline: A Surge of Juice From Dashboard to Laptop
abstract: Xantrex XPower Micro Inverter plugs into car power outlet and lets user access household power from vehicle; photo (S)

headline: Arroyo Said to Win Bitter Philippines Race
abstract: Philippine Congress concludes that Pres Gloria Macapagal Arroyo has won re-election by more than million votes; counting votes from May 11 election took weeks that were marked by acrimonious debates; supporters of closest rival Fernando Poe Jr accuse administration of election fraud and threaten to contest results before Supreme Court (M)

headline: Plea in Movie Piracy Case
abstract: Russell W Sprague pleads guilty to federal charges related to Internet posting of copies of first-run movies supplied by Academy Award voter; admits to pirating promotional copies of videos, known as screeners, that are sent to Oscar voters and film critics (S)

headline: Kabul Orders Troops to Quell Latest Violence
abstract: Pres Hamid Karzai is sending newly trained Afghan National Army troops from capital to quell fighting in outlying regions for second time in two weeks; local governor in Maimana, in northern part of country, appealed for support from central government after heavy fighting broke out as Uzbek warlord's militia advanced to fight forces loyal to general who has declared his allegiance to central government in Kabul; fighting is fresh blow for Karzai government, which is preparing for elections amid Taliban insurgency (M)

headline: Factory Orders Were Up 4.3% in March
abstract: Commerce Department reports new orders at factories rose 4.3 percent in March, biggest increase since July 2002; increase, to $360.7 billion, was third in fourth months and follows rise of 1.1 percent in February that was higher than previously reported; shipments were up 3.8 percent in March; factory inventories rose 0.3 percent after 0.6 percent rise in February; orders for durable goods rose 5 percent, revised from 3.4 percent increase reported on April 23 (M)

headline: Big Board's Interim Leader Extends Stay
abstract: New York Stock Exchange's interim chairman John S Reed agrees to reamin until April 2005; decision underscores extent to which unresolved matter of controversial pay package of former chairman Richard A Grasso continues to tie Reed to exchange; Securities and Exchange Commission questions Kenneth G Langone, chairman of compensation committee during years that Grasso received his highest pay deals, about his role in setting Grasso's pay (M)

headline: Bank Money Accounts
abstract: Annual percentage yields, in percent, on money market accounts, three-month certificates of deposit and six-month C.D.'s expected at selected institutions on Wednesday, June 16, 2004. Yields are based on the method of compounding the interest rate stated for the lowest minimum to open an account, but minimums may vary. Higher yields may be offered for larger deposits. C.D. figures are for fixed rates only. Rates subject to change without notice.

headline: Top European Praises Spain on Pullout
abstract: The European Commission president today praised the new Spanish prime minister's decision to withdraw troops from Iraq.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Nissan Raises Thai Stakes
abstract: Worldo

headline: A Philippine Movie Star Hopes to Land a New Role: President
abstract: Farnando Poe Jr, one of Philippines' most popular actors, is running for president and is thought to have chance to defeat incumbent Pres Gloria Macapagal Arroyo; in 2001, she replaced another actor-turned-president Joseph Estrada, who was forced out of office in kickback scandal; latest polls show Poe and Arroyo virtually tied; vote is on May 10; photo (M)

headline: Ex-C.I.A. Aides Say Iraq Leader Helped Agency in 90's Attacks
abstract: Former intelligence officials say Iyad Allawi, Iraq's designated prime minister, ran exile group that sent agents into Baghdad in early 1990's to plant bombs and sabotage Saddam Hussein's government, under CIA direction; say Allawi's Iraqi National Accord used explosive devices smuggled from northern Iraq; generally agree that efforts did not seriously threaten Hussein's rule; no public records exist and recollections are sketchy and contradictory, including truth of Iraq's claims of civilian casualties; former officials like Kenneth Pollack note irony of Allawi's promise now to stop bombings; Sandy Berger recalls that Allawi, unlike Ahmad Chalabi, was trusted by regional governments (M)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Test Your Theater Speakers.

headline: U.S., Seeking to Stabilize Iraq, Casts Baathists in Lead Roles
abstract: Iraqi Gen Jasim Muhammad Saleh leads force that will take over for marines in Falluja to avoid stirring deeper anger against occupation; use of Iraqis is meant to help restabilize country by inviting some if its most educated and qualified professionals to reclaim their old jobs, and ultimately help rebuild Iraq; it is also intended to reverse precipitous erosion of American popularity by gaining backing of constituency--stalwarts of Saddam Hussein's old bureaucracy--who have been embittered by their outcast status since American-led invasion; shift risks alienating Iraq's majority population of Shiite Muslims; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Napster And Best Buy In Deal
abstract: Napster, digital music provider, and Best Buy, electronics retailer, enter deal to promote each other (S)

headline: One Journal Of Oil Industry Covers More Than Just Rigs
abstract: Upstream, irreverent weekly, has become must-read for oil and gas industry executives; Upstream is popular not only for its extensive news coverage of oil and gas developments and trends, but has made point of upending stereotype of eye-glazing trade journal; some of its appeal comes from its offbeat humor, cheeky headlines and photographs that sometimes seem to have only most tenuous connection to accompanying articles; photo of Erik Means, editor in chief; photo of Upstream cover that was banned by censors in Iran (L)

headline: Cuba Denounces Mexico as the Diplomatic Break Worsens
abstract: Cuban government strongly denounces Mexico for accusing leaders of Cuba's Communist Party of engaging in spying and posing threat to Mexican security; Cuban Foreign Min Felipe Perez Roque holds emotional press conference to say relations between two countries are close to breaking point; Mexico's recent recall of its ambassador from Cuba and expulsion of Cuba's ambassador from Mexico further isolates Pres Fidel Castro (M)

headline: U.N. Moves to Disassociate Itself From Remarks by Envoy to Iraq
abstract: Officials moved today to disassociate the U.N. from remarks about Israel and U.S. policy in the Middle East made by Lakhdar Brahimi.

headline: 2 Giants Hire Agencies To Reach Minorities
abstract: Home Depot names Vidal Partnership as agency of record for advertising and marketing to Hispanics, assignment that had been handled by Casanova Pendrill Publicidad; billings undisclosed; Alltel Corp expands its relationship with DDB Worldwide by naming units of DDB to create campaigns aimed at minority consumers (S)

headline: Executive Pay: A Special Report; What Pays a Legend Most? In Many Cases, It's the Options
abstract: Article in special report on executive pay focuses on total compensation collected over 10 years by prominent, longtime chief executives; former Citigroup chief Sanford I Weill tops group with $979 million, bulk of it from exercising stock options; excluding gains from options, largest total compensation went to Bear Stearns chief James E Cayne, who collected $247 million over 10 years, less than $1 million from options; Warren E Buffett, who owns $40 billion stake in his Berkshire Hathaway, gets just $100,000 a year in salary, no bonus and no options; graph of prominent executives' wealth; photos (M)

headline: How to Tip a Guide Who Has a Slow Camel and a Fast Horse
abstract: EBay International vice president Kip Knight writes Frequent Flier column, sharing some of his airline travel experiences; photo (M)

headline: China's Economy Soars Despite Beijing's curbs
abstract: China's economy continued to surge in the first quarter as local authorities went on an investment binge and banks continued to lend despite Beijing's orders to rein in credit.

headline: Japan Leader Calls on North Korea to Dismantle Nuclear Program
abstract: Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi says North Korea must dismantle nuclear weapons program and account for kidnapped Japanese before getting aid and diplomatic ties; gives account of his message in meeting with North Korean leader Kim Jong Il (S)

headline: QLT to Acquire Atrix Labs for $885 Million
abstract: QLT, maker of eye disease drug Visudyne, acquires Atrix Laboratories, which makes drugs for prostate cancer and skin conditions, for $885 million in cash and stock (M)

headline: Details; With a Tweak Here and There, a Custom Machine
abstract: Guide to ordering personal computer from manufacturer's Web site; notes manufacturers that do not allow choice of options (M)

headline: Card Seem at Risk? Try a Stunt Double
abstract: Citibank, MBNA and Discover offer credit cardholders option of using temporary account number to make online purchases from sellers whose database security might be questionable; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Internet Dissident Goes On Trial
abstract: Trial of Chinese civil servant Du Daobin, who is accused of writing online about politics and human rights issues, begins; Du's lawyer was apparently given too short notice to attend proceeding (S)

headline: Lights Left On? A Virtual Valet Can Check
abstract: Several services allow users of Internet-capable mobile devices, like cellphones or organizers, to monitor household systems; photo (M)

headline: Bush Nominee to Lead F.T.C. Is Questioned Intensely About Gasoline Prices
abstract: Deborah P Majoras, Pres Bush's choice to head Federal Trade Commission, comes under sharp questioning at confirmation hearing by Sens Ron Wyden and Barbara Boxer, Democrats who say agency has not done enough to prevent steep rise in gas prices; senators say Majoras has failed to propose any meaningful change in way commission reviews oil company mergers and industry practices; say this has contributed significantly to recent run-up in prices at pump, particularly on West Coast; also express frustrations that agency has not acted to stop shutdown of large refinery in Bakersfield, Calif, owned by Royal Dutch/Shell Group; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Asks Sheiks to Help Rebuild Iraqi Corps in South
abstract: American military is beginning to recruit Iraqi fighters from prominent Shiite political parties and tribal sheiks to rebuild national security forces in south that have been decimated by uprising led by Moktada al-Sadr; Iraqi security forces crumbled when uprising began; many Iraqi security officers refused to fight insurgents, and some even joined them; new recruitment policy is intended to place part of responsibility for security in south, where most Iraqi Shiites live, in hands of political and tribal leaders; there is no guarantee that fighters from rival political parties and tribes will work together should civil war break out; map (M)

headline: Lawmakers Oppose Plan To Ease Sales Of U.S. Arms
abstract: House Republican leaders are blocking Bush administration plan to waive licensing rules so Britain and Australia, close American allies in fight against terrorism, can buy 'low sensitivity' military items from United States; House committee warned plan would play into hands of terrorists seeking to acquire vital American technology; administration says safeguards are in place to keep arms from being diverted; says Bush seeks to confer special status on two nations for their support in Iraq (M)

headline: Credit Suisse Offerings Are Examined at Retrial
abstract: Frank Quattrone's retrial has first full day of testimony; banker at Credit Suisse First Boston testifies that Quattrone's investment banker at Credit Suisse sometimes suggested which investors should receive shares in lucrative stock offerings (S)

headline: Police in Jordan Kill 4 It Says Plotted Against It and the U.S.
abstract: At least four militants are killed in firefight as Jordanian police continue rounding up suspects in what is described as major plot to bomb US and Jordanian targets; photo; Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, Jordanian terrorist linked to Al Qaeda, is suspect (S)

headline: Israeli Corruption Case Against Sharon Is Dropped
abstract: Israel's attorney general decided against indicting the prime minister on charges of accepting bribes from a developer.

headline: Forced to Act, Disney's Board Considers Its Next Steps
abstract: Walt Disney Co board is expected to debate how much power to wrest from chief executive Michael D Eisner in wake of shareholder revolt that forced him to cede chairmanship to George J Mitchell; directors loyal to Eisner are betting projected company turnaround will show push to oust him is mistake; others want Mitchell to expand his office and take more activist role in defining Disney's priorities and strategic vision; photos (M)

headline: BBC Appoints a New Director, Seeking to Overcome Scandal of Unfounded Iraq War Report
abstract: British Broadcasting Corp names Mark Thompson its director general; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Predicting Kodak's Future As Cameras Go Digital  After years of downplaying the digital threat, Kodak has changed its strategy. It has introduced digital cameras and has put self-service kiosks into drug and discount stores, where consumers are encouraged to print out their own digital photos. It has also fortified its medical imaging business and plunged into commercial printing. And it has recruited respected digital experts.    Can Kodak become a giant in a newly digital world? Experts say yes -- but it will take a lot more work. Six Kodak watchers suggest what the company can do. [Page C4.]

headline: Reject Terror's 'Logic of Death,' Pope Urges
abstract: Pope John Paul II uses his Easter message to plead for world to unite to overcome terrorism and 'the logic of death'; security around Vatican is heightened for his appearance, although Italy's top terrorism prosecutor says he knows of no specific threats against Italy (M)

headline: Chad Rebel Group Says It Holds Qaeda-Linked Terrorist
abstract: Rebel group in Chad says it seized one of North Africa's most powerful terrorists and wants to turn him over to United States or any of its allies, but US and other countries are unwilling to offend government of Chad by negotiating with rebels; man group is holding, Amari Saifi, is Islamic militant with ties to Al Qaeda; he is wanted in Algeria for many crimes, including kidnapping of 32 European hostages last year; Germany paid $6 million in ransom for hostages' release; for years he has operated with impunity in sparsely populated zone stretching from Mauritania to Chad; his presence in region was catalyst for expanding American program to rally regional governments into loose alliance to fight terrorism; rebels say one of men captured with Saifi identified himself as Abu Abdallah, raising possibility he could be bombmaker of that name who was trained by Al Qaeda and is known follower of Saifi (M)

headline: IRAQ UPDATE
abstract: Update of latest events in Iraq (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Move To Export Cheap Drugs
abstract: Canadian Parliament approves legislation allowing drug companies to produce and export generic drugs to poor countries battling health crises, including AIDS (S)

headline: A Cross-Border Battle of Auto Unions Heats Up
abstract: Intensifying competition between American states and Canadian provinces for automotive jobs is helping to stoke two decades of discord between unions that represent workers on each side of border; Ontario government discloses package of incentives valued at 500 million Canadian dollars ($371 million); incentives will be available to companies that invest at least 300 million Canadian dollars in new project in Ontario, or create or protect more than 300 jobs; several US states have similar programs; there is rising competition for members between United Auto Workers, based in Detroit, and its counterpart, Canadian Auto Workers; photos (M)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Defense Dept confirms deaths of five service members in Iraq (S)

headline: World Briefings
abstract: EUROPE.

headline: In Few Words, Many Clues To C.I.A.'s Working Method
abstract: Aug 6, 2001, intelligence briefing to Pres Bush represented what intelligence officials call boiled-down version of all CIA had learned, guessed or been told since 1997 about Osama bin Laden's intentions for American strike; declassifed version is blacked out in three places to hide names of foreign governments that provided crucial reports; nowhere in document does CIA assess veracity of sources (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Globalstar Emerges From Bankruptcy
abstract: Globalstar emerges from bankruptcy; Thermo Capital Corp pays $43 million for 81.25 percent of its stock, with remainder being divided among former bondholders Qualcomm and Loral (S)

headline: Major Terrorist in Algeria Is Reportedly Killed
abstract: The death of Nabil Sahrawi, the leader of the Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat, follows earlier reports that the group's founder is dead.

headline: Oil and Gasoline Futures Soar On U.S. Report on Inventory
abstract: Crude oil prices rise and gasoline futures surge to records after Energy Department says US stockpiles of gasoline increased less than expected; gasoline supplies gained 1.2 million barrels, to 203.7 million; analysts had expected increase of about 1.5 million barrels; crude oil reserves fell 1.1 million barrels, to 298.9 million barrels; crude oil for June delivery rises 96 cents, or 2.4 percent, to $41.50 per barrel in New York trading; gasoline for June delivery increases 6.34 cents, or 4.6 percent, to record $1.4503 per gallon; Pres Bush says he opposes tapping reserve to address rising gasoline prices; graphs; charts (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: ASIA.

headline: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: Regional Market -- New Jersey; BMW Spreads To Nearby Office Space
abstract: BMW is expanding in Woodcliff Lakes, NJ, adding to its offices to create 85-acre headquarters campus to accommodate company's growth as it continues to expand in US; map; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: No Time For Food Envoy
abstract: Hames Morris, United Nations World Food Program Executive Director, cancels visit to Zimbabwe, in which he had hoped to persuade President Robert G Mugabe to change his mind and accept deliveries of food aid; Zimbabwe government said no one was available to meet with Morris (S)

headline: SONIC INNOVATIONS SHARES FALL ON REDUCED OUTLOOK
abstract: Stock of Sonic Innovations Inc, maker of hearing aids, drops 38 percent after company lowers its second-quarter earnings forecast, citing cutbacks in health care benefits in Germany (S)

headline: World Briefings
abstract: AFRICA.

headline: G.I.'s Are Accused of Abusing Iraqi Captives
abstract: American soldiers at Abu Ghraib prison outside Baghdad have been accused of forcing Iraqi prisoners into acts of sexual humiliation and other abuses in order to make them talk; charges, first announced by military in Mar, have been documented by photographs taken by guards inside prison; some of these photographs, and descriptions of others, are broadcast by CBS News program 60 Minutes II; Pentagon says charges against soldiers include assault, cruelty, indecent acts and maltreatment of detainees; say top officers at prison, including brigadier general, face administrative review; accused men are all from Army Reserve military police unit; lawyer for one of them says they had been told to soften up prisoners by more senior American interrogators; three of six soldiers charged have alrady been recommended for court martial trials (M)

headline: Russia to Run 2,500-Mile Oil Pipeline In East Asia
