abstract: Russian government says it and not private oil companies will build pipeline between Tayshet in Irkutsk region, former gulag hub in Siberia, and to Nakhodka, port on Sea of Japan, bringing much-needed oil to countries in East Asia; pipeline represents far more than $10 billion deal between Russia and Japan, which could take until end of decade to complete pipeline of 2,500 miles; Kremlin is reasserting its control over Russia's oil exports; decision to build pipeline to Japan instead of China is seen as largely political; photo; map (M)

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: BRAZIL: Diamond Hunters Killed In Amazon; COLOMBIA: Paramilitary Chief Missing After Attack;.

headline: JUDGE GIVES UAL MORE TIME TO FILE A RECOVERY PLAN
abstract: UAL Corp is given another extension to file bankruptcy recovery plan (S)

headline: A Reason to Switch?
abstract: Gartner survey finds that many people are willing to switch Internet service providers to rid themselves of spam and pop-up ads; says most subscribers believe that ISP's should be responsible for curbing problem; photo; graph (S)

headline: In Indonesia, Unions Hit a Roadblock: Contract Labor
abstract: Indonesia's fledgling labor movement is backfiring on workers; growing number of Indonesian companies, frustrated by proliferation of unions and confusing laws on employment, are replacing employees with contract laborers who cannot bargain, or are moving their jobs to nonunion countries; map; graph; photo (M)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: List of American service members newly confirmed dead in Iraq; 826 have died since start of war

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: BOSNIA: 2 Officials Dismissed For Obstructing Srebrenica Inquiry; ITALY: Berlusconi Trial Resumes; ITALY: Aviation Officials Sentenced In Country'S Worst Crash; FRANCE: Bandannas Not Ruled Out; BRITAIN: Cyclist Sentenced In Tire-Slashings;.

headline: Europe-Russia Pact to Cover New Union Nations
abstract: European Union and Russia agree to extend their economic and political relationship to union's ten new members, most of them former Soviet satellites (S)

headline: Murdochs Share (Some) Power
abstract: British Sky Broadcasting adds two independent directors, Nicholas Ferguson and Andrew Higginson, in wake of shareholder grumbling over chairman Rupert Murdoch's appointment of son, James, 31, chief executive and big 'noncompete' fee he offered departing chief, Tony Ball; Murdoch also quits committee that sets son's salary (S)

headline: Trump Takes a Meeting, Now Backs a Resort in Brazil
abstract: Trump Takes a Meeting Now Backs a Reso

headline: A Hamstrung Market Fights Global Warming
abstract: Bush administration opposition to mandatory caps on emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases may be undermining trading of pollution allowances, viewed by all sides as effective tool for curbing pollution; such trading was strongly advocated by United States during Kyoto Protocol talks and embodied in accord; some trading in emissions allowances for greenhouse gases has begun despite US refusal to set caps; graph of trading in emissions credits (M)

headline: Hitched to a Star, With a Go-To Gadget
abstract: How It Works column on telescopes that incorporate computer and GPS controls to locate celestial objects; advances in telescope technology from Meade and Celestron noted; photo (L)

headline: S.E.C. REVIEWS TRADES MADE BY CHIEF EXECUTIVE OF SWIFT
abstract: Swift Transportation Co says Securities and Exchange Commission is reviewing stock trades made by chairman and chief executive Jerry Moyes, who is said to have made $622,000 trading 187,000 shares in May (S)

headline: Bush Firm on Iraq Policy as Senators Question the Costs
abstract: President Bush said today that the latest carnage in Iraq would not lessen the United States' commitment to bring peace and freedom to that country. But some lawmakers questioned whether he had been forthright about the costs of that mission.

headline: Defense at Adelphia Trial Portrays Witness as a Liar
abstract: Paul Grand, lawyer for Adelphia Communications' former chief financial officer Timothy Rigas, begins sharp attack on James R Brown, government's star witness in fraud trial of John Rigas and two of his sons; depicts Brown as self-described skilled liar whose testimony was self-serving and tainted; photo (M)

headline: Tunisian Named as Leader Behind Madrid Bombings
abstract: A Spanish judge issued a warrant for a Tunisian man who is labeled as the "leader and coordinator" of the bombings.

headline: Antitrust Office In Japan Raids Intel Branch, Seeking Files
abstract: Fair Trade Commission raids Japanese office of Intel in probe into whether company unfairly kept computer makers from buying rival chips; investigators are looking into whether Intel violated Japan's antimonopoly law by excessively pressuring computer manufacturers to refrain from using chips in personal computers made by competitors like Advanced Micro Devices; commission officials question people at Toshiba, Sony and other companies that use Intel chips about Intel's sales tactics; none of those companies are suspected of violations (M)

headline: Ex-C.E.O. of Computer Associates Makes Departure Complete
abstract: Sanjay Kumar, who stepped down in April as chief executive of the Long Island company, has decided to leave the company altogether.

headline: Intel Considers Options Change
abstract: Intel Corp is proposing measure that would overhaul its existing stock-option plan without having to record options as expense (S)

headline: A Young Radical's Anti-U.S. Wrath Is Unleashed
abstract: American occupation forces have been focusing on moderate Shiite leader Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani while radical young Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr has been threatening widespread insurrection against American-led occupation; Sadr is heir apparent to his father, revered Shiite cleric who was assassinated in 1999 by Saddam Hussein, as were his two brothers and an uncle; Sadr has been issuing statements denouncing Americans and any Iraqis who work with them; he is one of many powerful Shiite clerics calling for Islamic government; his following seems especially devoted; he has reputation for vengefulness; one of his henchmen is accused of hacking to death rival Shiite cleric last Apr; militia Sadr formed is estimated to number in tens of thousands and has its own religious courts and prisons; photo (M)

headline: New Technology Loosens Controls Over Images of War
abstract: Military, government and mainstream media are losing countrol of images of war; digital technology is forcing major shift in expectation of what can be kept private, and it may ultimately hold everyone more accountable for their actions (M)

headline: U.S. and Britain Propose Outline for June 30 Transfer of Power in Iraq
abstract: United States and Britain introduce draft Security Council resolution that pledges transfer of power to interim government in Iraq on June 30 but leaves open to further negotiation authority and duration of American-led multinational force remaining in country; resolution, aimed at gaining international support for political transition in Iraq, backs current efforts of United Nations envoy Lakhdar Brahimi to appoint caretaker government, and endorses timetable of UN-planned direct elections for national assemby by end of Jan; photo; chart with highlights of draft resolution (M)

headline: Army Discovers Old Iraqi Shell Holding Sarin, Illicit Weapon
abstract: American commanders say they discoverd Iraqi artillery shell in Baghdad last week containing sarin, one of deadly nerve agents Saddam Hussein said he had destroyed before war began last year; say shell had been fashioned into homemade bomb; say two American weapons experts suffered minor exposure to nerve agent when they tried to defuse shell; say shell appeared to have been manufactured before Persian Gulf war, and offers some of most substantial evidence that Hussein did not destroy all of banned chemical agent, as he claimed he did; say it is not clear that insurgents who planted it knew it contained sarin (M)

headline: Click One for the Gipper
abstract: Nielsen/NetRatings reports that 54 percent of American office workers visited news and current affairs Web sites during week of Pres Ronald Reagan's funeral; analyst says that Reagan's death had relatively little impact on Web traffic and that figure reflects tendency among Web users to visit news and current affairs sites when they are on the job

headline: DEMAND FOR COSTLY SHOES BOLSTERS NIKE PROFIT
abstract: Nike Inc reports 23 percent rise in fourth-quarter net income, to $305 million; sales climb 17 percent, to $3.5 billion (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: 605 Kidnapped In Chechnya In 2003
abstract: Russian Interior Ministry reports that 605 people were kidnapped during 2003 in Chechnya and another 249 people kidnapped in surrounding regions; holds that 253 people have been freed (S)

headline: Good Marks for Rank and File Who Responded to Attacks
abstract: Staff of Sept 11 commission reports that, despite major lapses in command, lower-level aviation and military personnel rose to challenge on day of hijackings, taking creative and decisive actions in crisis for which they were not trained; credits rank and file with bypassing chains of command to engage each other and with safely carrying out unprecedented grounding of some 4,000 airplanes in short time; implicit is criticism of senior officials who stuck to protocol (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Telecom Profit
abstract: World Business

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: On The Noisy Road To Ruin
abstract: Archbishop Sean Brady, Roman Catholic Church leader for Ireland and Northern Ireland, preaches concern over rapid modernization contributing to loss of Irish spirit (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Move Seen As Leader's Power Ploy Fails
abstract: Ukrainian Parliament defeats proposed constitutional ammendment that would strengthen Parliament, but weaken future Presidents; President Leonid Kuchma supported measure that would cement his influence even without re-election this fall; photo (S)

headline: A Tool That Puts All Your Passwords At Your Fingertip
abstract: American Power Corp BioPod fingerprint scanner includes software that matches passwords with associated user fingerprint; photo (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Bank Regulators Urged To Address Embassy Issue  The State Department is pressing federal bank regulators to address the inability of some foreign embassies to find banking services in the United States, according to several people briefed on the matter. An investigation into suspicious transactions in embassy accounts at the Riggs National Corporation has made banks wary of engaging in such business.       The government's move was primarily driven by the needs of Saudi Arabia, a key American ally whose embassy accounts are at the center of the Riggs investigation, these people said. [Page C14.]

headline: Staples Narrows List For Television Account
abstract: Staples narrows review for its television creative account, with spending estimated at $60 million to $70 million, to six agencies; Staples parted ways with Martin/Williams in early May (S)

headline: Well-Timed Traveling Music At the Ready on Your Wrist
abstract: LAKS and BMW partner to offer MP3 wristwatch that stores music or data files; photo (S)

headline: Where's the Beef? Heading For the Supreme Court
abstract: Supreme Court agrees to decide constitutionality of 1985 federal law that requires beef producers to pay into fund that supports generic promotion campaigns to encourage more beef consumption; case ins appeal by Bush administration and group of Nebraska cattle producers from ruling last July by federal appeals court in St Louis that declared that program amounted to compelled speech, unconstitutional under First Amendment; $50 million program, paid for by assessment of $1 for each head of cattle, was challenged by smaller group of cattle producers who maintained that generic campaign hurt their interests by making no distinction for consumers between domestic and imported beef (M)

headline: U.S. Exploring Corruption Case for Aristide, Powell Says
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that American judicial authorities are looking into prosecuting the former Haitian president, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, on corruption charges.

headline: Time Warner's Profit More Than Doubles in Quarter
abstract: Time Warner says first-quarter profit more than doubled; net income was $961 million compared with $396 million year earlier; revenue rose 9 percent, to $10.1 billion from $9.24 billion, beating analysts estimates of $9.51 billion; operating income rose to $427 million compared with $251 million year ago (M)

headline: Chief Warns Of Rapid Rise In Rates if Fed Sees the Need
abstract: Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan warns financial markets to prepare for sharper rise in interest rates in months ahead if inflation turns out to be more serious problem than Fed's policy makers now expect; tells investors not to count on 'measured' increases in short-term rates that Fed described as its preferred strategy in communique issued after its most recent monetary policy meeting, in early May; photo (M)

headline: Cleaning Up In Aisle 4
abstract: Safeway chief executive Steven A Burd, whose salary was steady at $1 million while workers agreed after long strike and lockout to lower pay for new workers and no pay increase for current ones, gave up $181,000 'capital performance bonus;' netted $13 million exercising stock options (S)

headline: Constitutional Court Reinstates South Korea's Impeached President
abstract: South Korea's nine-member Constitutional Court issues ruling dismissing impeachment case against Pres Roh Moo Hyun, restoring full powers to him; case has tested nation's fledgling democracy; Roh was impeached for minor election law violations; during his two months of political limbo, presidential powers were exercised by Prime Min Goh Kun (M)

headline: White House Undermined Chemical Tests, Report Says
abstract: House committee report describes how Bush administration worked with US chemical industry to undermine European plan that would require all manufacturers to test industrial chemicals for their effect on public health before they were sold in Europe; administration had said publicly that proposal last year would threaten $20 billion in chemicals that US exports to Europe each year because cost of testing would be prohibitive; proposal would shift burden to prove safety of chemicals onto manufacturers instead of governments; Bush administration says proposal is unsound science and abuse of regulatory authority; European officials say testing plan is necessary because of increase in health problems (M)

headline: Atmos Buying Gas Operation Of TXU to Expand in Texas
abstract: Atmos Energy Corp acquires natural gas operations of TXU Corp for $1.93 billion; deal would create one of nation's largest distributors of natural gas; Atmos Energy chief executive Robert W Best comments; photo of Best with TXU Gas president Mike McCall (M)

headline: Blair to Visit Bush Next Week For Talks Dominated by Iraq
abstract: British officials say Prime Min Tony Blair will fly to Washington next week for meeting with Pres Bush; trip was scheduled for some time, but sudden spike in violence and instability in Sunni heartland and in Shiite neighborhoods and towns is expected to transform meeting into strategic review of policies toward Iraq; diplomats who have served in Iraq voice concern that occupation authority has not done enough to reach out to Shiite leaders, or to include Iraqis more broadly in critical areas of security and national reconstruction strategy; Sir Jeremy Greenstock, departing British envoy in Baghdad, has reportedly expressed concerns about American administrator L Paul Bremer III's style in running postwar Iraq, particularly in closely controlling decision-making with minimal input from Iraqis or others, including Greenstock; photo (M)

headline: Forest Asked to Supply Information on Marketing of Some Drugs
abstract: Forest Laboratories receives wide-ranging request from New York State Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer asking for information about how company tested and promoted drugs like its antidepressant Celexa for so-called off-label, or as yet-unapproved, uses (M)

headline: ARMY PUNISHES 7 WITH REPRIMANDS FOR PRISON ABUSE
abstract: Senior American commander in Iraq Lt Gen Ricardo S Sanchez issues severe reprimands to six American soldiers who served in supervisory positions at Abu Ghraib prison and milder 'letter of admonishment' to seventh for abuse of Iraqi prisoners; they are not demoted or discharged, but action will likely end their military careers; six of their subordinates accused of actually carrying out abuse of Iraqi prisoners already face criminal charges; more details are emerging of widespread problems in detention system in Iraq; investigative report by Maj Gen Antonio M Taguba says pervasive flaws in leadership, training and morale of military police at Abu Ghraib and elsewhere may have contributed to abuse even after earlier instances were reported and punished; report cites 'riots, escapes and shootings' of prisoners over many months, and says 'little to nothing was done'; key recommendation of Taguba report is to send to Iraq team of specialists to train soldiers assigned to run prisons; chart showing chain of command at Abu Ghraib at time of abuses from Oct to Dec 2003; photos (M)

headline: OFFICER SUGGESTS IRAQI JAIL ABUSE WAS ENCOURAGED
abstract: Army Reserve Gen Janis Karpinski, whose soldiers were photographed as they abused Iraqi prisoners at Abu Ghraib, says she knew nothing about abuse until after it occurred and that she is 'sickened' by photos; says cellblock where abuse occurred was under tight control of Army military intelligence officers who may have encouraged abuse, and suggestion appears largely supported in still-classified Army report; New Yorker magazine article by Seymour M Hersh says report by Maj Gen Antonio M Taguba found that reservist military police at prison were urged to prepare prisoners for interrogation; indicates far more wide-ranging and systematic pattern of abuse than previously reported and reveals litany of cruelties on part of soldiers; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen gains after Japanese imports climb to record, adding to signs growth is accelerating in country's economy; dollar settles 111.75 yen, down from 111.77, in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: Neighbors Cling to Hope for Missing Soldier
abstract: Friends and neighbors of Maupin family in Glen Este, Ohio, cling to hope for Specialist Keith Matthew Maupin, American soldier who disappeared in Apr after his convy was ambushed outside Baghdad; students have erected something of shrine to him at high school; photo (M)

headline: U. S. Taiwan Expert Quits; Reason Is Disputed
abstract: Therese Shaheen abruptly resigns as top diplomat in United States office responsible for relations with Taiwan; was Washington director of American Institute in Taiwan, which acts as de facto embassy; State Dept spokesman denies report that Chinese officials asked for her to be replaced because they think she is overly sympathetic to Taiwan government (S)

headline: INAMED AND GENZYME WIN APPROVAL FOR WRINKLE FILLER
abstract: Inamed Corp and its partner, Genzyme Corp, win FDA approval of Hylaform gel to treat wrinkles around eyes and mouth (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: 17 Years For Bosnian Serb Policeman
abstract: Former Bosnian Serb policeman Darko Mrdja is sentenced by Hague war crimes tribunal to 17 years in prison for his participation in killing of more than 200 prisoners of war in 1992 in Bosnia (S)

headline: Patents; A technique to help combat the online piracy of music uses decoy files that deliver noise and 'gotcha' scoldings.
abstract: Prof John Hale and Gavin Manes patent software that analyzes and monitors illegal music swapping on file-sharing networks, and then systematically inserts decoy files into mix; decoys seem real but contain either poor-quality recordings, buzzing or ads; Hale commments; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.00   4.00   4.25       Federal Funds   1.00   0.99   1.31       3-month Libor   1.17   1.17   1.31       3-month T-bills   0.96   0.95   1.09       6-month T-bills   1.15   1.14   1.11       10-yr. T-infl.   2.05   1.92   2.17       10-yr. T-note   4.50   4.39   3.84       30-yr. T-bond   5.28   5.20   4.76       Telephone bd.   6.29   6.34   5.73       Municipal bds.   5.06   5.05   4.84          (Sources by Bloomberg News; Telerate; The Bond Buyer; British Bankers' Assoc.)

headline: Share Prices Rise on Higher Forecasts for 2004 Earnings
abstract: Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 15.84 points, to 1,139.93; Dow Jones industrial average increases 143.93 points, to 10,461.20; Nasdaq composite index adds 37.28 points, to 2,032.91; graph; table (M)

headline: Many Iraqis Are Skeptical of Bush TV Appeal
abstract: Many Arab watchers say Pres Bush's effort to repair damage from growing uproar over Abu Ghraib prison adds up to only more hollow words (S)

headline: IRAQ UPDATE
abstract: SOLDIER KILLED -- A soldier with the First Cavalry Division was killed and a contractor working for the American firm Kellogg Brown & Root was wounded in a mortar attack in Baghdad. In Baquba, five Iraqi gunmen were killed, and one American soldier was wounded in fighting between American soldiers and Shiite and Sunni insurgents. [Page A7]    GOOD VS. EVIL -- President Bush and Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, appeared together at a campaign rally in Reno, Nev., and defended the American-led effort in Iraq, calling it a struggle between good and evil. [A7]

headline: E-Commerce Report; As Google considers going public, some of its online colleagues say they are happy to remain privately held.
abstract: Executives at some online companies that missed out on Wall Street's dot.com bubble say they are choosing not to take part in new round of initial public offerings; note interest from investment bankers is on rise and conditions for making offering are getting easier; graphs of number and value of Internet IPO's (M)

headline: China Bristles At Criticism Of Hong Kong Restrictions
abstract: Chinese Foreign Min Li Zhaoxing responds angrily to US and British criticisms of China's latest restrictions on democracy in Hong Kong, charging double standard by two countries that showed little such concern during more than century of British rule (M)

headline: Russia Seems Open to Deal With Yukos On Tax Bill
abstract: Finance Min Aleksei L Kudrin says Russia and Yukos Oil Co may try to negotiate settlement of $3.4 billion tax claim; says Yukos has enough funds to pay its liabilities; tax charge is seen as part of wider Kremlin-backed drive to diminish influence of Yukos founder Mikhail B Khodorkovsky, held since Oct on tax evasion charges; Kudrin's remarks seem to confirm that government will not bankrupt Yukos; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: European Court Backs Ban On Muslim Scarves
abstract: European Court of Human Rights rejects appeal by Turkish student barred from attending Istanbul university wearing head scarf; holds ban is not discriminatory (S)

headline: Suutarila Journal; Educators Flocking to Finland, Land of Literate Children
abstract: Educators from all over world are flocking to Finland to deconstruct its school system ever since Finnish schools topped respected international survey, coming in first in literacy and placing in top five in math and science; survey was conducted by Orgn of Economic Cooperation and Development; photo (M)

headline: Thai Troops Kill 107 in Repelling Muslim Attackers
abstract: Thailand's Muslim southern provinces are scene of worst outbreak of violence in years; 112 people are killed when scores of armed men raid as many as 15 police stations and security outposts; officials say dead include 30 attackers who were killed at most revered mosque in region, whose loudspeakers were used to call for local uprising; no group claims responsibility; government officials variously blame bandits and drug addicts, or Muslim separatists who received training abroad; analysts say violence is result of same grievances that led to separatist rebellions in past in impoverished southern provinces; say residents there feel neglected and repressed in largely Buddhist nation; say long-simmering rebellion offers opportunities for militant recruitment and hard-line mosques have begin to appear; photo; map (M)

headline: With Bid, Continental Looks To Expand in South America
abstract: Continental Airlines and Copa Airlines, Continental's Panama partner, offer to buy Colombia's Avianca Airlines (M)

headline: Exchange Ready To Battle Grasso Over Bonus Pay
abstract: Dan K Webb, lawyer who prepared extensive report on pay of former New York Stock Exchange chairman Richard A Grasso, says exchange will vigorously fight Grasso's claim he is owed $48 million in bonus payments; comments suggest that NYSE, after months of silence on matter of Grasso's pay, is ready to assume more combative posture; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: With a Digital Slide Show, You May Upstage the Bride
abstract: Basics column on devices, software and hardware for producing digital image slide shows for display on screen or projected onto wall; drawing (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Bank Profit Rises ABN
abstract: ABN Amro Holding re

headline: Gladiators For Hire
abstract: Private military contractors are becoming involved in civil wars and crises worldwide, and are earning princely sums in the process.

headline: ALBERTSON'S TO EXIT OMAHA, SHEDDING 21 STORES
abstract: Albertson's plans to sell or close 21 grocery and drugstores, cutting 180 jobs, as it leaves Omaha market; financial terms undisclosed; Walgreen Co to buy prescription files of nine Osco drugstores in Omaha that are closing; No Frills Supermarkets and Bag 'n Save will buy 11 Albertson's grocery stores in Bellevue and Grand Island, Neb, as well as Omaha; Hy-Vee will buy one Osco drugstore in Council Bluffs, Iowa (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; New York State Fund to Join Californians in Dissent at Citigroup
abstract: New York State Common Retirement Fund joins California Public Employees' Retirement System in planning withhold vote for re-election of Sanford I Weill and Charles O Prince as directors of Citigroup; says 'their status as company insiders raises questions about independence and objectivity of Citigroup's board of directors' (M)

headline: A Techno-Geeks New Car
abstract: March 9 was my 41st birthday. It was also doomsday for our nine-year-old Honda Civic, whose last gasp included, among other problems, a transmission that requires a $3500 replacement. What better opportunity, then, to treat myself, like millions before me, to a Midlife Crisis Mobile?

headline: U.S. Investor Acquires 60% Of Wireless Provider in Japan
abstract: Carlyle Group will acquire 60 percent of DDI Pocket, Japanese provider of cellphone and wireless Internet service, from KDDI Corp for 220 billion yen ($2.02 billion); Kyocera Corp will increase its stake in DDI to 30 percent from 13 percent; KDDI will keep 10 percent stake; deal is one of largest leveraged buyouts ever in Japan (M)

headline: No Evidence Of Meeting With Iraqi
abstract: Staff of panel probing Sept 11, 2001 attacks discloses for first time that FBI evidence strongly suggests that terrorist pilot Mohammed Atta was in United States at time when reports that surfaced shortly after attack placed him at secret Apr 9, 2001 Prague meeting with Iraqi intelligence officer; some in Bush administration repeatedly cited alleged meeting as evidence of link between Al Qaeda and Iraq despite serious doubts cast on report; staff cites photo taken by surveillance camera and cellphone records; dismisses broader notion that there was terrorist alliance between Iraq and Al Qaeda; effectively rebukes Pentagon's civilian leadership, which set up small intelligence unit after Sept 11 attacks to hunt for link; unit told senior Pentagon and White House officials that CIA ignored evidence of link; staff notes Osama bin Laden explored possibility of cooperation with Iraq in early and mid-1990's but that Iraq did not respond to his bids for aid (M)

headline: Britain Extends Detention of 8 Muslims Held After Raids
abstract: The police said the arrests of two men in Canada and Saudi Arabia are connected to possible bomb-making activities in London.

headline: Qantas Airways Discloses Plan For Low-Cost Singapore Carrier
abstract: Qantas Airways will set up low-cost carrier in Singapore with group of local investors that includes government agency that owns majority stake in rival Singapore Airlines; Qantas's chief executive Geoff Dixon says new airline is seeking approval from local authorities to start operations by end of year; Qantas will invest about 50 million Singapore dollars ($30 million) for 49.9 percent stake in new airline, while Temasek Holdings, investment arm of Singapore government, will own 19 percent; two local businessmen will hold remainder; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Economic Growth Revised Upward for First Quarter  The economy grew slightly faster than previously thought in the first quarter of this year, the Commerce Department reported, providing fresh evidence of momentum heading into the summer.     Gross domestic product from January through March increased at a 4.4 percent annual rate, the department said. That was an improvement from both the 4.2 percent pace first estimated for the quarter a month ago and the 4.1 percent growth rate in the final quarter of 2003. [Page C5.]

headline: United Airlines Is Turned Down In Bid for Loans
abstract: Federal loan board rejects United Airlines' application for $1.6 billion in loan guarantees, citing belief that airline can emerge from bankruptcy and survive on its own; United was last US airline to apply under $10-billion program set up to help industry after Sept 11 terrorist attacks, and its plans for emerging from bankruptcy depended heavily on getting loan guarantees; Air Transportation Stabilization Board turned down bigger request in Dec 2002; chief executive Glenn F Tilton and other executives have said they believe United can emerge with or without federal help; photo (M)

headline: REMODELING AND TRACTOR SALES LIFT HOME DEPOT
abstract: Home Depot says earnings rose 21 percent in first quarter ended May 2; net income increased to $1.1 billion from $907 million year earlier; revenue rose 16 percent, to $17.6 billion (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LOWE'S COS., Mooresville, N.C., the home-improvement retailer, said that its chairman and chief executive, Robert L. Tillman, would retire in January, to be succeeded by Robert A. Niblock, the company's president.    L-3 COMMUNICATIONS HOLDINGS INC., New York, a maker of military electronics, said it had won contracts worth more than $84 million to provide the United States Army with software engineering support for ground and satellite communications.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Yellow Pages Offer
abstract: France Telecom begins initial public offering of its directory unit PagesJaunes, aiming to sell 30 to 43 percent of company (S)

headline: Hoping for Free Saris, 21 Indian Women Die in Stampede
abstract: Thousands of poor women in northern Indian city of Lucknow respond to offer of free saris, setting off stampede that kills 21 women; offer was made at public birthday celebration for close aide to Prime Min Atal Bihari Vajpayee; members of oppositon party call sari distribution an illegal effort by Vajpayee's party to win favor with voters; photo (M)

headline: Forecast on Spending Is Revised Upward
abstract: TNS Media Intelligence/CMR increases its forecast for advertising spending in major media to gain of 9.3 percent this year from 2003, compared with its earlier estimate of 7.8 percent increase (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Ivory Coast: U.N. Inquiry Into Abidjan Violence
abstract: United Nations spokesman Jean Victor Nkolo announces that UN will appoint special commission to look into recent opposition protest in Abidjan (Ivory Coast) against President Laurent Ghagbo government in which undetermined number of people died (S)

headline: 4 FROM U.S. KILLED IN AMBUSH IN IRAQ; MOB DRAGS BODIES
abstract: Four American workers for security company are ambushed and killed in Falluja, and enraged mob jubilantly drags their burned bodies through downtown streets, hanging at least two corpses from bridge; 15 miles away, in same area of violent Sunni Triangle, five American soldiers are killed when roadside bomb rips through their armored personnel carrier; anti-American rage in Falluja is so great that no American or Iraqi forces respond to attack against civilians, although several news crews film mayhem; images of frenzied crowd mutilating bodies is reminiscent of scene from Somalia in 1993, when mob dragged body of American soldier through streets of Mogadishu in incident that led to American pullout; White House blames terrorists and remnants of Saddam Hussein's former government for attack; it is not clear what four American civilians were doing in Falluja, but many residents there insist four were spies working for Central Intelligence Agency; photos (M)

headline: U.N. Atomic Energy Chief Faults Iran on Disclosures
abstract: Iran was accused of "less than satisfactory" cooperation with an investigation of its nuclear activities.

headline: Warnaco Reports Profit in Quarter
abstract: Warnaco Group says net income was $20.2 million in first quarter ended April 3 compared with $22.3 million year earlier, when it reported results for two-month period after exiting Chapter 11 protection; sales were $393.3 million (S)

headline: 4 Afghan Soldiers Killed in Taliban Attack on Government Offices
abstract: Taliban fighters kill four Afghan soldiers in attack on government ofices in Helmand; four US soldiers killed earlier by bomb in Zabul Province (S)

headline: In the Sensitive Sedan, a Microclimate for Every Passenger
abstract: What's Next column discusses heating and cooling systems in Volkswagon Phaeton; computerized system is most complex offered in production car; drawing (M)

headline: North Korean Leader in Beijing? No One's Talking
abstract: The Chinese are pretending that a certain dictator with nuclear ambitions is not really in town.

headline: EMI to Cut Artist Roster And Close 2 CD Plants
abstract: EMI Group, which has been under pressure as music sales decline globally, will reduce its roster of artists by 20 percent and cut 1,500 jobs; cuts will result in 25 million pounds ($45.66 million) of savings in fiscal year ending March 2005, and 50 million pounds ($91.31 million) in years following; bulk of EMI job losses stem from outsourcing of compact disc and DVD manufacturing; EMI will close its manufacturing plants in Jacksonville, Ill, and Uden, Netherlands, cutting 900 jobs; photo (M)

headline: Fed Officials Seek to Ease Fears of a Surge in Inflation
abstract: Federal Reserve's top officials are trying to reassure investors that inflation will not surge; officials, in series of recent speeches and comments, have argued that neither new rise in employment nor recent jumps in consumer prices mean economy is in danger of overheating; Fed governor Donald L Kohn, who is advisor to Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan, said in speech on June 4 that recent pickup in price increases probably does not represent leading edge of steadily worsening inflation; photo (M)

headline: Prime Minister José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero's Interview
abstract: Following is a transcript from Prime Minister José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero's interview with The New York Times.

headline: Suit Expected to Be Filed Soon Over Pay Package for Grasso
abstract: Regulators are expected to file civil suit against New York Stock Exchange's former chairman Richard A Grasso, seeking return of part of his controversial pay package; suit could also name former directors who played crucial role in deciding Grasso's pay; court action would cap four-month probe, carried out by New York State Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer and Securities and Exchange Commission (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: General Motors, Detroit, the major automaker, said it would spend $160 million to prepare for new truck models at an Arlington, Tex., factory that builds sport-utility vehicles.    Sears, Roebuck & Co., Hoffman Estates, Ill., the department-store giant, agreed to buy Standards of Excellence, San Diego, an appliance dealer, to bolster sales in the luxury home market. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Can beer ads extol great taste in good taste? A chastened Anheuser-Busch is thinking about it.
abstract: Anheuser-Busch is rethinking tone and content of its advertising campaigns for beer brands; president August A Busch IV attributes reassessment to intense backlash against risque content generated by Janet Jackson risque performance during Super Bowl XXXVIII halftime show on Feb 1 (M)

headline: Ford's Sales Fell 4.4% Last Month
abstract: Ford Motor Co reports sales fell 4.4 percent from year earlier, even though it relied more heavily on discounted deals with rental care companies than previous months (M)

headline: Investors Are Taking Long, Hard Look at Nortel's Board
abstract: Investors are starting to quesiton whether Nortel Networks' blue-chip board should be changed in light of company's decision to tear up its financial statements for last three years and has fired top management; company has been under investigation by regulators in US and Canada for accounting practices; faces two-dozen class-action lawsuits filed since mid-March on behalf of investors who say they lost money because Nortel intentionally misled them; new chief executive William Owens says he is waiting for review before commenting on some corporate bonuses; photo (M)

headline: China Takes Another Step To Tighten Monetary Policy
abstract: China's central bank tightens monetary policy for second time in less than three weeks, trying to put brakes on bank lending and property speculation as top Chinese officials voice concern that economy may be overheating; latest tightening takes form of higher reserve requirements for bank; action comes after release of figures showing that China ran trade deficit in March for third consecutive month; deficit, though modest at $540 million, makes it more likely that China will continue resisting pressure from US, Europe and Japan to let its currency rise, even as Vice Pres Dick Cheney vists Beijing; China's State Council, nation's cabinet, calls for strict curbs on new construction after meeting led by Prime Min Wen Jiabao; graph; photos (M)

headline: U.S. General in Afghanistan Says Pakistan Has Hurt Al Qaeda
abstract: General Barno commended the Pakistani military for its "bold moves" against foreign fighters in the Pakistani tribal area of Waziristan in March.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Power Cuts As Protest
abstract: French electricity workers, staging protest over privatization plan for Electricite de France, cut power to several regions and country houses of Prime Minister Jean-Pierre Raffarin and other politicians (S)

headline: Distinct Views Of Iraq Speech Follow Lines Of Loyalty
abstract: Pres Bush's address on his strategy for Iraq fails to change minds of Democrats or Republicans in Congress; Democrats say administration is mishandling conflict and looming transfer of power there; Republicans say he presented coherent plan for weeks and months ahead; outside Congress, former NATO commander Gen George A Joulwan says speech lacked clarity and failed to answer important logistical questions; Brookings Institution military expert Michael O'Hanlon disagrees with how Bush tied Iraq to global battlefield on terror (M)

headline: Pakistan Says It Killed a Tribesman Who Aided Militants
abstract: Pakistani officials said on Friday that they had killed a former Taliban fighter whose defiance of Pakistan's military had made him a folk hero among Islamic militants.

headline: Coast to Coast With Laptop and Diaper Bag
abstract: Stephanie Dickey writes Frequent Flier column, describing her adventures traveling with her six-month-old daughter; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Government Budget Surplus
abstract: Brazil posts primary budget surplus of 5.8 bllion reais ($1.87 billion) in May, putting country on track to meet fiscal targets of $14 billion loan agreement with IMF (S)

headline: Rice Says She and Bush 'Strongly' Support Rumsfeld
abstract: National security adviser Condoleezza Rice says she agrees with Pres Bush's support of Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld, who has come under attack over abuse of Iraqi prisoners; Rice says responsibility lies not just with Pentagon and Rumsfeld but with Bush's entire national security team; says United States public response to this serious matter will show world US takes abuse seriously and freely encourages investigation of wrongdoing (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Attack On Governor Was A Hoax
abstract: Mexican federal prosecutor Gilberto Higuera holds that assassination attempt on Oaxaca Governor Jose Murat was hoax and that shots, which slightly wounded Murat, were fired from inside vehicle, not by assailant; investigation will be mounted; photo (S)

headline: Mitsubishi To Accelerate Recovery Plan
abstract: Mitsubishi Motors will cut employee salaries and speed up layoffs as it expands recovery plan announced May 21 to deal with sharp drop in vehicle sales in Japan; will over next two years cut executive pay packages by 25 percent to 50 percent, trim salaries of middle managers by 10 percent and lower paychecks of rank-and-file workers by 5 percent; expects cutbacks to reduce costs by $660 million over next two years; chief executive Yoichiro Okazaki comments; photo (M)

headline: With Its Gas Prices Already High, Europe Is Less Rattled by Jump
abstract: Europeans seem less concerned about gas prices than Americans are; gas is so heavily taxed in most European countries that rise in market price is less noticeable, and recent strength of euro versus dollar has insulated customers; Europe, after three decades of seeking alternatives to oil, is somewhat less vulnerable to effects of higher crude prices; Europe does not view $40-a-barrel oil with same alarm as America for variety of reasons, ranging from smaller cars and shorter commutes to windmills used for energy that dot many European nations; photo (M)

headline: BRADLEY TO PAY $183 MILLION FOR UNIT OF PHARMA SERVICES
abstract: Bradley Pharmaceuticals, which makes skin medicines, acquires Bioglan Pharmaceuticals for $183 million (S)

headline: Key Energy Services Gets Default Notice
abstract: Key Energy Services, oilfield services company being investigated by federal securities regulators, receives notice of default on most of its debt, setting off 10 percent decline in its share price (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: TIAA-CREF Moves to Make MBNA Board Independent  TIAA-CREF is trying to round up support for its push to make the board of MBNA more independent from management and the family of Alfred Lerner, the company's former chairman and chief executive.     TIAA-CREF, which owns 17.9 million shares of the MBNA Corporation, a credit card company, plans to send letters to other institutional investors, asking them to vote for its proposal at the company's annual meeting on May 2. [Page C3.]

headline: Japan Arrests 5 Who Knew Man Possibly Tied to Qaeda
abstract: Japanese authorities announce arrests of five foreigners who had been in contact with Frenchman with possible ties to Al Qaeda; three men come from Bangladesh, one from Mali and another from India; four of them are charged with violating Japanese immigration laws, while fifth is charged with falsifying document; Frenchman is Lionel Dumont, whom Interpol has linked to members of Al Qaeda; he lived in Japan for parts of 2002 and 2003, selling cars and making frequent bank transfers; it is unclear whether he contacted men arrested as part of his car business or, as Japanese authorities are investigating, to set up terrorist cell in Japan; he was extradited to France from Germany last week (M)

headline: Saying 'economic expectations are much brighter,' a longtime forecaster raises his spending estimates.
abstract: Universal McCann forecaster Robert J Coen predicts national and local advertising spending in United States will grow combined 7.3 percent in 2004, up from his earlier forecast of 6.9 percent; expects spending to grow 6.5 percent in 2005 over 2004; reduces his prediction for ad spending growth in local media across country, citing softnes in categories like retail and classifieds (M)

headline: World Briefings
abstract: ASIA.

headline: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Genentech Profit Rises On Cancer Drug Sales
abstract: Genentech says first-quarter net profit rose 17 percent; net income climbed to $176.6 million from $151.5 million year earlier; revenue increased 30 percent, to $975.1 million (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Stake Sold
abstract: South Korean government sells its 22 percent stake in Hana Bank for 1.07 trillion won ($920 million), removing concern that bank, nation's fourth-largest lender, would have to purchase shares with its own capital; graph shows stock price (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Unemployment Rises
abstract: Unemployment in Brazil rose for fourth consecutive month in April to 13.1 percent; survey also shows number of people looking for work rose 8.5 percent from April year earlier and 3.2 percent from previous month; real wages fell 0.9 percent while number of people working remained stable (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Deals: Ametek Acquires Precision Tool Maker
abstract: Ametek acquires Taylor Hobson Holdings Ltd, British-based maker of precision tools for computer-chip market and other industries, for about $93.4 million in cash from Permira (S)

headline: Greenhill Public Offering
abstract: Greenhill & Co, investment bank and asset management company of Robert Greenhill, raises $87.5 million in initial public offering; company sells five million shares at $17.50 each (S)

headline: Powell, on Trip to Mideast, Vows Justice on Iraq Abuse
abstract: Sec of State Colin L Powell, in Shuneh, Jordan, addresses members of Arab world's business and political elite at meeting of World Economic Forum; promises that justice will be done in matter of prisoner abuses at Iraq's Abu Ghraib prison; renews commitments to progress in Middle East peace efforts and to working with United Nations in establishing new independent Iraqi administration; asks Arabs not to lose sight of good work of Americans in rebuilding Iraq; receives polite applause; photo (M)

headline: Bush Plays Down Dispute With France Over Iraq War
abstract: Pres Bush calls Pres Jacques Chirac a friend and says he was never angry with French for opposing American-led war and occupation in Iraq, interview with Paris Match magazine before his arrival in France, with wife Laura, to commemorate 60th anniversary of D-Day and dine with Chirac and his wife; Bush's warm words contrast with his anger last year, when he said that Chirac would not be guest at his ranch and Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld called France part of 'old Europe' that does not count any longer; Laura Bush, in prime-time interview on French television station, joins her husband in lavishing praise on France; photo (M)

headline: IRAQ UPDATE
abstract: Update of events in Iraq; map (M)

headline: Regulators Fine Riggs $25 Million
abstract: Federal regulators fine Riggs National Corp, parent of Riggs Bank, $25 million for failing to report suspicious activity; fine, largest ever assessed against domestic bank in connection with money laundering, stems from Rigg's failure over at least last two years to actively monitor suspect financial transfers through Saudi Arabian and Equatorial Guinean accounts held by bank; accounts are still being scrutinized as possible conduits for terrorist funds or for proceeds of graft; Saudi Arabian Embassy spokesman denies any involvement by Saudi officials in terrorist financing activities through Riggs; Equatorial Guinean Embassy does not return calls seeking comment; Financial Crimes Enforcement Network, investigative arm of Treasury Department, and Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, regulatory arm of same agency, each impose $25 million penalties against Riggs, but bank will be allowed to pay them concurrently (M)

headline: Multipurpose Maverick Takes On the Game Boy
abstract: Gizmondo from Tiger Telematics is hand-held game console designed to compete with Nintendo Game Boy, and can be used for other functions; photo (S)

headline: Cash vs. Benefits: Efficiency, or Assault on Russia's Soul?
abstract: Pres Vladimir Putin's government moves to dismantle array of social benefits, robust vestige of Soviet times, that many Russians consider essential; proposed bill would replace subsidized transportation and electricity, free medicine and rent-free apartments for government workers with cash stipends, which would affect millions of veterans, invalids and retirees; photo (M)

headline: Latin America Graft and Poverty Trying Patience With Democracy
abstract: Toxic impatience with democratic process across Latin America has resulted in lynching of one mayor, ousting of six elected heads of state in face of violent unrest and polls showing majority of Latin Americans would choose dictator over elected leader if provided economic benefits; analysts trace discontent to corruption and widespread feeling that elected governments have done little or nothing to help 220 million people in region, 43 percent of population, who still live in poverty; at-risk governments stretch thousands of miles from Caribbean and Central America through spine of Andes to continent's southern zone; increasingly, problems associated with weak governments are spilling beyond Latin America and affecting United States interests in region; among weakest states is Guatemala, followed by Haiti and Bolivia; Venezuela remains deeply polarized; even in Argentina, once Latin America's most developed country, Pres Nestor Kirchner has warned of threats against his government and his life as he struggles to root out corruption, repair democratic instititutions and improve economy; photos; map (L)

headline: Israel Considers Trench in Gaza To Stop Tunnels
abstract: Israeli military seeks bids to build 80-foot-deep trench along part of Gaza border with Egypt, to block digging of tunnels used to smuggle in weapons (S)

headline: Shell Weighs Modifying Dual Setup
abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell Group will consider changing its century-old two-company structure to create unified board; British-Dutch company has been cool to calls for simplified structure in past; Shell is taking more conciliatory tone as it grapples with fallout from scandal surrounding its overstatement of proven oil and natural gas preserves; says review will be led by chairman Jeroen van der Veer and four members of two component companies' boards; review results will be made public in November; photo (M)

headline: JONES APPAREL EXTENDS BID FOR MAXWELL SHOE COMPANY
abstract: Jones Apparel Group extends its $20-a-share tender offer for Maxwell Shoe Co until May 17 (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Lawmaker Loses Post For Smoking
abstract: John Deasy, Fine Gael Party's justice spokesman and member of Parliament, is dismissed from party post after smoking in Parliament bar; action violates Ireland's new ban on smoking (S)

headline: Afghan Route To Prosperity: Grow Poppies
abstract: Opium cultivation is surging in Afghanistan, defying all efforts of Afghan government and international officials to stop it; officials predict that land under poppy cultivation will rise by 30 percent or more in 2004, possibly yielding record crop; country produced almost 4,000 tons in 2003, three-fourths of world's opium; trade generated $1 billion for farmers and $1.3 billion for traffickers, more than half of Afghanistan's national income; US officials, reluctant to open new front in campaign against terror or engage in antidrug war in Afghanistan, are conflicted about how to combat it; graph; map; photo (M)

headline: Roof Collapses at Paris Airport, Killing 5
abstract: A 120-foot section of a new terminal at Paris' Charles de Gaulle airport collapsed early Sunday, killing at least five people.

headline: Pakistani Politician Is Jailed for Treason
abstract: Pakistani judge sentences leader of country's main opposition political alliance to prison after he is convicted of treason and inciting mutiny in armed forces; Makhdoom Javed Hasmi was arrested in Oct after releasing letter purportedly written by military officers critical of Pres Pervez Musharraf (S)

headline: For White House, Reversed Iraq Tactics Are Billed as Bumps on Road to Peace
abstract: Bush administration tries new tactics as deadline for handover of sovereignty to Iraqis approaches, portraying policy reversals as mere bumps on road to stable Iraq, rather than abrupt course changes; changes are most notable in handling of insurgents in Falluja and Najaf and in growing reliance on UN to help set up new government; critics see changes as evidence of floundering and say basic pre-war assumptions have been called into question; photos (M)

headline: Putin Accuses Critics of Working for Foreign Powers
abstract: Pres Vladimir V Putin, in televised state of nation speech, says that foreign 'political, economic and media pressure' is being used in attempt to weaken Russia's chances of competing globally; singles out private groups in Russia that he says claim to support welfare of people but are in fact serving other foreign and domestic masters for pay; his words, which hark back to Soviet times, catch human rights advocates off guard and seem to provide rationale for future restrictions on their activities; Putin has made stability watchword for his administration, and that appears to involve centralization of power and tightened control over independent organizations, including civic groups and press (M)

headline: Art Directors Name Winners of Awards
abstract: Art Directors Club in New York names winners of its annual awards; TBWA Worldwide wins most awards (S)

headline: Greater Urgency on Prison Interrogation Led to Use of Untrained Workers
abstract: Interrogation effort at Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq took on such urgency last fall that untrained personnel were pressed into service as analysts and even interrogators; documents and interviews note that number of two-person 'Tiger Teams' assigned to interrogation center at Abu Ghraib doubled after capture of Saddam Hussein; center was operated under control of Lt Gen Ricardo S Sanchez's top deputy for intelligence, Lt Col Steve Jordan; some accounts claim Jordan gave military intelligence officers and military police great deal of latitude; he is identified in Maj Gen Antonio M Taguba's Army report as among two officers and two civilian contractors who were directly or indirectly responsible for abuses at prison (M)

headline: Patent on Test For Cancer Is Revoked By Europe
abstract: European Patent Office revokes US-based Myriad Genetics' European patent on breast cancer genetic test, providing victory to scientists who oppose patenting of human genes; patent covers test to predict if woman is at high risk of developing breast cancer by looking for mutations in gene called BRCAL; patent office says work mentioned in patent is not inventive enough to qualify for patent protection; Myriad has met with resistance in some parts of world because it charges about $3,000 for complete breast cancer predisposition test and does not allow other laboratories to perform it; Institut Curie in France and some other research institutes and scientific societies in Europe challenged European patent, which was issued to University of Utah and US government in addition to Myriad; Province of Ontario is ignoring Myriad's patents and performing test itself, at fraction of cost (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Rate Increase
abstract: Swiss National Bank raises target range for its reference rate, three-month Swiss franc Libor, by quarter-point, to 0.5 percent; bank president Jean-Pierre Roth expects Swiss economy to grow 2 percent this year, reversing contraction of 0.5 percent last year; photo (S)

headline: AOL to Buy Advertising.com, an Online Direct Marketer
abstract: America Online agrees to pay $435 million in cash for Advertising.com, which specializes in online direct marketing for mortgage companies, correspondence courses and the like and which has been associated with spam, spyware and pop-up ads; AOL, which is trying to promote its technology to block spam, spyware and pop-ups, says any Advertising.com practices that do not conform to AOL's standards will be dropped (M)

headline: World Briefing | United Nations: Volcker Begins Inquiry
abstract: United Nations Security Council unanimously approves investigation into oil-for-food program to be headed by former Federal Reserve Chairman Paul A Volcker; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bayer Subpoenaed
abstract: Germany's Bayer AG says inspector general of US Defense Department has subpoenaed documents relating to company's withdrawal from market of cholesterol drug Baycol; preliminary conversations indicate subpoena is related to joint Defense Department and Food and Drug Administration inquiry; Bayer says it has not been informed of any charges or complaints in connection with inquiry, and that it will cooperate with German government (S)

headline: W.H. Smith Discusses Bid
abstract: WH Smith, Britain's biggest bookseller, holds talks with private equity company, Permira Advisers, that may lead to takeover offer worth 940 million pounds ($1.7 billion) (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Displaytech Files For Stock Offering
abstract: Displaytech, which makes display screens that are used in digital cameras and camcorders, registers with SEC for initial public offering of up to $57.5 million of common stock (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.00   4.00   4.25       Federal Funds   1.00   1.00   1.21       3-month Libor   1.56   1.55   1.01       3-month T-bills   1.31   1.27   0.81       6-month T-bills   1.67   1.67   0.84       10-yr. T-infl.   2.10   2.11   1.61       10-yr. T-note   4.68   4.71   3.32       30-yr. T-bond   5.37   5.38   4.40       Telephone bd.   6.51   6.49   5.72       Municipal bds.   5.23   5.23   4.58          (Sources by Bloomberg News; Telerate; The Bond Buyer; British Bankers' Assoc.)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nokia Market Share Drops
abstract: Nokia's market share fell in first quarter to lowest level in about five years as consumers picked clamshell phones with cameras made by Motorola and Samsung Electronics; global market share of Nokia dropped to 28.9 percent from 34.6 percent year earlier; Motorola's market share rose to 16.4 percent from 14.7 percent, and Samsung's share reached 12.5 percent from 10.8 percent (S)

headline: After Enron, a Sunless Year in a Tiny Cell
abstract: Conditions former Enron Corp assistant treasurer Lea Fastow will face at Federal Detention Center, where she will serve one-year sentence after pleading guilty to tax evasion, described; highly secure Houston prison is nothing like kind of pastoral prison camp many people still associate with white-collar criminals; former convicts say her time will be more difficult because she is woman, white and wealthy; photos (M)

headline: Drivers Getting Break as Many Insurers Cut Rates
abstract: Cost of auto insurance is starting to fall; State Farm, USAA and Farmers Insurance Group are cutting prices in many states, and dozens of other insurers are following their lead; giants like Allstate, Progressive and Geico are more aggressively offering lower prices to customers with good driving records and significantly raising prices for those who have been involved in crashes or have received tickets for speeding and other violations (M)

headline: Chairman of Faltering British Store Chain to Step Down
abstract: Chairman of Faltering British Store Chain to S

headline: Violence in Iraq Curbs Work of 2 Big Contractors
abstract: Insurgency in Iraq drives General Electric and Siemens AG, two major contractors, to suspend most of their operations there, raising new doubts about American-led effort to rebuild country as hostilities continue; suspensions and travel restrictions are delaying work on two dozen power plants as occupying forces press to meet expected surge in demand for electricity before summer; electricity is thought to be most important sector for Iraqis after security; GE and most other companies working in Iraq refuse to say how many employees they have in country, citing security concerns; Bechtel and Halliburton, with much larger contracts in Iraq, say they have curtailed travel by their employees but are not considering halting their work or pulling out of country (M)

headline: New York State Official Sues Drug Maker Over Test Data
abstract: The civil lawsuit contends that GlaxoSmithKline engaged in fraud by failing to tell doctors that some studies of Paxil showed the drug did not work in adolescents.

headline: Sad Adieu to College, And to Good Old .edu
abstract: College graduates that have to give up their college e-mail addresses are scrambling to set up new accounts and sending mass change of address messages; some describe it as tantamount to losing identity; photo (M)

headline: Top U.S. General Tries to Calm Furor Over Prisoner Abuse
abstract: Gen. Richard B. Myers insisted that only "a handful" of U.S. troops were to blame, but said he could not rule out that this was part of a wider pattern.

headline: Manila arrests 4 Turkish suspects
abstract: MANILA:—  Four Turkish nationals working as teachers were arrested in a southern Philippine city on suspicion that they were involved in terrorist activities, officials said Thursday.

headline: Jurors Begin Deliberations In Adelphia Fraud Trial
abstract: Jurors begin deliberations at fraud and conpiracy trial of Adelphia Communications Corp's founder John J Rigas, his sons Timothy and Michael and former assistant treasurer Michael C Mulcahey by asking for 17 documents and dozen excerpts of testimony (M)

headline: Beyoncé, From the Mouths of Babes
abstract: Razor & Tie rerecords Top 40 hits, using singers 5 to 12

headline: Walgreen Drops Havas For DDB in Chicago
abstract: Walgreen Co moves its advertising account from Euro RSCG Chicago, unit of Havas, to new Chicago office of Downtown Partners DDB, part of DDB Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group; billings estimated at $125 million (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Mining Acquisition
abstract: Canadian copper mining company Inmet Mining acquires Aur Resources for 600 million Canadian dollars ($438 million); combined group will be knowwn as Aur Mining Corp (S)

headline: How the Short-Sellers Choose Their Targets
abstract: Many financial advisers discourage short-selling entirely because it is so risky; shorting stocks--selling borrowed shares in hope of buying them back more cheaply later--should be done only after considerable research; individual investors loath to trust their own judgment but still wanting to short stocks can invest in hedge funds, or in mutual funds that short stocks; some professional short-sellers describe their strategies; photo (M)

headline: Health Care Leads Other Issues in Canadian Vote
abstract: Canada's publicly financed health insurance system emerges as dominant issue of imminent national election campaign; although majority of Canadians still view their universal coverage system with patriotic pride, satisfaction with medical services has declined in last decade as population ages, waiting lines for care grow and doctors and nurses become sparse, especially in rural areas; Prime Min Paul Martin promises to 'provide a fix' that will last for generation; he is being challenged on right by Stephen Harper, who contends that provinces should be given leeway to experiment with private sector delivery of vital health serivces (M)

headline: Energy Providers Seek Grant As Step to Build Nuclear Plant
abstract: NuStart Energy Development, consortium of companies, plans to ask Energy Department for $400 million grant to help prepare bid to build nuclear power plant; Tennessee Valley Authority and Duke Power have joined consortium since group announced interest in building plant; separately, six companies have applied for department help with $4 million project to explore building reactor in northern Alabama at site of Tennessee Valley Authority's abandoned Bellefont project (M)

headline: U.S. to Lower Duties on Canadian Lumber
abstract: The Commerce Department said that it planned to cut duties on $4.6 billion in Canadian lumber imports to as low as 13 percent from about 27 percent.

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Defense Dept confirms deaths of 11 service members in Iraq, bringing total to 652 American service members who have died in Iraq since start of war (S)

headline: Ford's Hybrid S.U.V. to Cost 15% More Than Gas Versions
abstract: Ford Motor Co says prices for its new gasoline-electric Escape, first sport utility vehicle to run on hybrid technology, will start at $26,380, about 15 percent more than models powered solely by gasoline (S)

headline: UNION PACIFIC IS PLANNING TO HIRE 5,000 WORKERS
abstract: Union Pacific Corp intends to hire 5,000 train crew workers, 800 more than its earlier plan, to help end delays that forced company to turn away shipments and reduced profit (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Advertising account changes noted (S)

headline: Seoul Journal; A Crash Course in Tradition for Modern Korean Brides
abstract: Institute of Decorum and Wisdom's bridal course has been right of passage for nearly 25 years for young women in upper reaches of South Korean society; it is finishing school where women learn manners and customs; some see it as anachronistic place that holds back very women who could lead South Korea; others say it teaches timeless traditions and customs that are necessary now, more than ever; institute is unchanging corner of fast-changing society where gap between generations grows wider every day; photos (M)

headline: Sharon Says His Pledge Not to Harm Arafat No Longer Holds
abstract: Prime Min Ariel Sharon says he told Pres Bush during their White House meeting that he no longer considers himself bound by his pledge not to harm Yasir Arafat (M)

headline: BUSH, ON ARAB TV, DENOUNCES ABUSE OF IRAQI CAPTIVES
abstract: Pres Bush goes on Arab television in effort to limit diplomatic damage from abuse of Iraqi prisoners by American soldiers, saying mistreatment 'does not represent the America that I know'; offers no apology, but pledges to bring all facts into open and says guilty would be held accountable; abuse case has left Bush administration on defensive; State Dept officials acknowledge that they put off release of annual report on human rights abuses around world because they did not want to face awkward questions about how United States could point fingers at time when its own record has been sullied; in Congress, senior members of both parties express anger at failure of Pentagon to keep Congress fully informed about case; Sen John W Warner, Republican chairman of Armed Services Committee, summons Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld to public hearing on May 7; national security advisor Condoleezza Rice and deputy secretary of state Richard L Armitage apologize in their interviews with Arab broadcasters; new commandant of Abu Ghraib prison, Maj Gen Geoffrey Miller, also apologizes to Iraqi people; Bush's interviews are broadcast on Al Hurra, US government-sponsored network, and Al Arabiya, Dubai-based broadcaster; photo (M)

headline: Angering Big Business, Donaldson Vows to Change Voting Rules
abstract: Floyd Norris comment on Securities and Exchange Commission chairman William H Donaldson's proposal to allow institutional investors to nominate one or more director candidates to run on company's own ballot if at least 35 percent of votes were withheld from candidate in previous elections; says meaningful reform to corporate board elections would be significant achievement for Donaldson; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.00   4.00   4.25       Federal Funds   1.00   1.00   1.18       3-month Libor   1.57   1.56   1.00       3-month T-bills   1.28   1.30   0.90       6-month T-bills   1.68   1.69   0.92       10-yr. T-infl.   2.13   2.23   1.56       10-yr. T-note   4.70   4.72   3.41       30-yr. T-bond   5.38   5.40   4.46       Telephone bd.   6.57   6.54   5.35       Municipal bds.   5.24   5.23   4.59          (Sources by Bloomberg News; Telerate; The Bond Buyer; British Bankers' Assoc.)

headline: Sticking to Their Scripts
abstract: Analysis: Condoleezza Rice, testifying before 9/11 commission, vigorously defends Pres Bush against accusations that he was inattentive to terrorism before attacks, but she fails to defuse debate that threatens his re-election campaign; in three hours of often contentious testimony Rice sticks to White House script, that everything that could have been done to prevent attacks had been done; she does not acknowledge any failings, apart from longtime tensions between CIA and FBI; she leaves open question of whether anyone in White House is capable of admitting error--step many of Rice's current and former colleagues say would help calm political waters (M)

headline: Afghan Deaths Linked to Unit At Iraq Prison
abstract: Military intelligence unit that oversaw interrogations at Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq had earlier been in charge of questioning at Bagram detention center in Afghanistan where two prisoners died in Dec 2002 in incidents that are being investigated as homicides; unit's work at Bagram center at time of deaths has emerged in interviews with former prisoners, military officials and from documents; two men arrested with one of prisoners who died in Bagram tell of being tortured and sexually humiliated by American jailers; their account is consistent with those of other former Afghan prisoners and cited in reports by human rights officials; environment at Bagram that men describe is similar in some ways to that of Abu Ghraib, whose outlines are depicted in photographs and testimony; in Iraq, at least three members of intelligence unit assigned to Abu Ghraib have been quietly disciplined for conduct involving abuse of female Iraqi prisoner; photo (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.  TODAY  Balance of Trade -- April  Retail Sales -- May    TOMORROW  Consumer Price Index -- May  Inventory-Sales Ratio -- April

headline: Eric Mower Group Buys Price McNabb
abstract: Eric Mower & Associates acquires Price McNabb for undisclosed terms; Price McNabb is being renamed Eric Mower & Associates/Price McNabb (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Tribesmen Get Extension
abstract: Pakistani officials agree to extension requested by 2,000-strong militia of tribesmen hunting for Al Qaeda in rugged South Waziristan near Afghan border; hold that tribal militia must show concrete results in dealing with terrorists or face tough measures by Pakistani military (S)

headline: Editors' Note
abstract: An article last Thursday about tools for digitally displaying and editing sheet music included favorable comments about the technology from Fred Anton, chief executive of Warner Brothers Publications, a leading publisher of sheet music. He cited the potential of Sunhawk.com, a sheet-music library that sells works from his company's catalog, and of the MusicPad Pro, a tablet computer for sheet music.

headline: Kinshasa Journal; The Gentlest of Beasts, Making Love, Ravaged by War
abstract: War, mining, logging and sustained trade in bush meat are putting squeeze on habitats of one of most endangered primates on earth: the bonobo; genetically, humans and bonobos, species of chimpanzee, are more than 98 percent similar; socially, they are not; they are mostly matriarchal and eschew conflict; peace-loving bonobos' jungle habitat falls on front lines between fighting factions in Congo, causing further risk to them; Claudine Andre has created sanctuary for orhan bonomos on fringes of Kinshasa; photos; map (M)

headline: Law Clients Given Choice: A Big Payout Or Privacy
abstract: Law firm Jenkens & Gilchrist agreed in March to pay $75 million in class-action lawsuit brought on behalf of 1,100 clietns of firm who had bought disputed tax shelters; settlement included some provisions for veiling clients' identities in court records that would be available to general public, though some lawyers expressed concern that confidentiality might be breached later; Jenkens & Gilchrist in May 28 letter to clients offered opportunity to stay completely out of public record of case--by accepting $100 from firm, instead of share in $75 million settlement; Judge Shira A Scheindlin, who is overseeing class-action settlement, sends letter to 1,100 clients telling them to ignore May 28 letter (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Profit At Alcan
abstract: Alcan Ltd reports $106 million profit in first quarter as prices rose and sales almost doubled after purchase of Pechiney; net income was 28 cents per share, in contrast to net loss of $27 million, or 9 cents per share, year earlier; sales rose 93 percent, to $6.2 billion; chief executive Travis Engen expects worldwide aluminum demand this year to increase 8 percent; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Bandannas Not Ruled Out
abstract: French Education Minister Francois Fillon, attending meeting of Union of Islamic Organizations of France, suggests Muslim girls could wear bandanas to replace head scarf now banned in public schools (S)

headline: New-Home Sales and Durable Goods Orders Fell in April
abstract: Commerce Department says sales of new homes fell 11.8 percent in April, largest decline in decade, after mortgage rates reached five-month high; drop in single-family home purchases was greater than expected, to 1.093 million at annual pace, after record 1.239 million pace in March; National Association of Realtors says sales of previously owned houses rose 2.5 percent, to 6.64 milion annual pace; median price of new homes increased 8.8 percent, to $221,200 from $203,300 in March; inventories of new homes for sale rose to 4.3-month supply in April from 3.7 months; Freddie Mac reports averge rate of 30-year fixed-rate mortgage increased in April to 5.83 percent, up from 5.45 percent in March; Commerce Department reports orders for durable goods declined 2.9 percent in April; graphs; photo (M)

headline: Some Analysts Salute Markets For Already Raising Rates
abstract: Growing number of analysts worry that Federal Reserve, which is expected to raise interest rates at late June meeting, may have already waited too long; senior Fed officials are quietly pleased that bond market investors have already anticipated rate increases by pushing up yields; hope advance rise in long-term rates will help cool economy even before they act (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Civil Lawsuit Challenges Big Board Pay Package  The New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, filed a civil suit demanding that Richard A. Grasso, the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, repay more than $100 million of his $139.5 million pay package.    The long-awaited suit sets the stage for what could be a dramatic trial, with heads of Wall Street firms who served on the exchange's board likely to be put in the uncomfortable position of having to publicly testify about how they came to approve a compensation package that they later disavowed. [Page A1.]

headline: JEANS MAKER TO PAY $396 MILLION FOR CLOTHING COMPANY
abstract: VF Corp acquires Vans Inc for $396 million to add sneakers and apparel that appeal to teenagers; also reports higher first-quarter results (S)

headline: TARGET CITES WEAK SALES IN LOWERING JUNE OUTLOOK
abstract: Target Corp says June sales will be well below expectations, setting off 4 percent decline in its share price (S)

headline: Europe Looks More Closely at Plan for Uranium Venture
abstract: European Commission's competition division ramps up its inquiry into planned joint venture between Areva and Urenco in which Areva would buy half of Urenco's uranium enrichment research division, Enrichment Technology Co; cites concern that deal might result in rise in price of enriched uranium used to fuel nuclear power stations and slow uranium enrichment research and development; two companies together have 80 percent of European Union enriched uranium sales; France's complaint on deal that would bolster French government-controlled Areva struck some as odd; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Aristide Files Suit Contending Kidnapping
abstract: Exiled Haitian President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, represented by lawyer Gilbert Collard, files lawsuit in Paris accusing French officials of death threats, kidnapping and sequestration; similar suit is expected to be filed against US (S)

headline: PANEL FINDS NO QAEDA-IRAQ TIE; DESCRIBES A WIDER PLOT FOR 9/11
abstract: Staff of commission probing Sept 11, 2001 attacks, in reports offering chilling, richly detailed chronology of plot, finds no apparent 'collaborative relationship' between Al Qaeda and Saddam Hussein, contradicting one of Pres Bush's justifications for Iraq war; chronology, based on panel's review of highly classified accounts of interrogations of captured Qaeda leaders, shows Osama bin Laden was far more intimately involved in planning than previously known and approved selection of each of 19 hijackers; shows original plot called for even larger and more deadly attacks; reports hold bin Laden ordered attacks over opposition of many of his advisers and of Afghan Taliban leader Mullah Muhammad Omar, believing Al Qaeda would reap recruiting and fund-raising bonanza; say Capitol was apparent target of hijacked plane that crashed in Pennsylvania; say Hussein's government rebuffed or ignored requests from Qaeda leaders for help in 1990's, directly contradicting series of public statements Pres Bush and Vice Pres Dick Cheney made before and after Iraq invasion; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Tank Builder Acquisition
abstract: BAE Systems agrees to buy Alvis, British maker of Challenger II battle tank, for 355 million pounds ($652 million), topping offer from General Dynamics; graph of BAE Systems shares (S)

headline: Corrections
