abstract: Correction: New York Stock Exchange oversaw Norman Huff's arbitration case against his broker4

headline: Water Everywhere, but Is It Good for Fish?
abstract: Manitoba, Canada, fears invasion of alien species and micro-organisms will ruin fishing on Lake Winnipeg if North Dakota drains Devils Lake water through Red River of the North system; two water systems have not been connected for 1,000 years; Devils Lake has risen 27 feet since 1993 because of rain, causing floods and $400 million in damage; North Dakota has been frustrated by lack of progress between US and Canada and has forced issued by beginning work on unfiltered drainage system, to be ready by May 2005; case may set precedent for handling growing number of cases affecting boundary waters; photos; map (M)

headline: Blair's Shift In Agenda Puts Euro In Question
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair about-face decision to hold referendum on new European constitution seems to put off any decision on whether Britain should join euro single currency, leaving question of British membership more than ever hostage to vagaries of emotional and broader debate about Europe Blair photo (M)

headline: Adelphia Founder Begins Defense in Fraud Trial
abstract: Lawyers for Adelphia Communications Corp founder John J Rigas begin presenting Rigas's defense in 14th week of his fraud and conspiracy trial; call hospital administrator David Acker to testify to Rigas's character (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Stagecoach Payout
abstract: Stagecoach Group, British bus and rail operator, says that it will return as much $451 million to shareholders and that fiscal 2004 earnings will be higher than analysts' forecasts (S)

headline: Baghdad Camp Houses Those Fleeing Falluja
abstract: Tents for hundreds of Iraqis who fled fierce fighting between insurgents and American marines in Falluja are springing up in one neighborhood of Baghdad; shaky cease-fire between Americans and Iraqi fighters has allowed some families back into Falluja, but many families have been stranded as American military keeps up its siege to force guerrillas to hand over their weapons; most of those who fled Falluja did so with few or no belongings; photo (M)

headline: The 'Last Civil War Widow' Has a Successor, It Would Seem
abstract: The 'Last Civil War Widow' Has a Successor, It Would Seem**

headline: Canada Rate Is Lowered For 5th Time In Last Year
abstract: Bank of Canada drops its overnight lending rate to 2 percent from 2.25 percent, fifth rate decrease in year; sharp rise in Canadian dollar in last year has dampened exports, and consumers, previously driving force behind economic growth, have turned more cautious; graph (M)

headline: Back in Argentina, Priest Faces 'Dirty War' Charges
abstract: Rev Christian von Wernich, Argentine priest accused of 19 counts of murder and 33 of abduction and torture, has emerged as potent symbol of institutional atrocities during country's 'Dirty War,' when military junta chased down leftist opponents, sometimes winning support of Roman Catholic Church's hierarchy for its goals; has attracted particular attention because he combines both elements: he was priest who also worked for government as chaplain for feared Buenos Aires provincial police; case is provoking protest in Argentina and in Chile, where he fled and which suffered under its own dictatorship, over past role of church and whether religious leaders conspired to hide priest accused of taking part in abuses of Dirty War; photo; map (M)

headline: Discounters Grow as Cheap Makes a Comeback
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores reports net income reached $2.17 billion in its first quarter ended April 30, compared with $1.86 billion year earlier; Target says earnings rose 26 percent, to $438 million; revenue increased 12 percent, to $11.59 billion, for quarter ended May 1; Kohl's reports modest 2.5 percent increase in profit, to $113.8 million from $111 million year ago; sales rose 12 percent, to $2.38 billion (M)

headline: An Industry That Dares Not Meet in the Country of Its Best Customers
abstract: Internet gambling executives are set to meet in Toronto; fear possible prosecution in United States, where they have millions of customers; federal government holds Internet sports wagering is illegal, and many states bar all online gambling; graph of Internet gamblers, by region, and of Internet gambling revenue (M)

headline: Guarded U.S. Statement Urges Israeli Restraint
abstract: Bush administration denies giving Israel approval for killing of Hamas leader Dr Abdel Aziz Rantisi and expresses dismay at timing of killing, shortly after Prime Min Ariel Sharon met with Pres Bush in Washington; reiterates view that Israel has right to defend itself, but urges Israel to consider more carefully consequences of its actions (M)

headline: Witness at Tyco Trial Testifies She Received No-Interest Loan
abstract: Gina Spencer, human resources administrator at Tyco International who helped run employee relocation program that lent former general counsel Mark A Belnick $15 million, testifies at Belnick's trial that she also received no-interest loan; says former finance chief Mark H Swartz telephoned her in 2001 to offer her no-interest mortgage on her house in Boca Raton, Fla (M)

headline: Divided Mission In Iraq Tempers Views of G.I.'s
abstract: American soldiers who six weeks ago were renovating schools in Karbala are now raiding them for hidden munitions, caught up in fiercest and deadliest fighting now under way in Iraq; soldiers involved in that fighting agree that war is at crucial juncture, but few can say with certainty how to achieve victory--or even what might constitute victory; insurgency has tempered their idealism, and they are concerned that abuse of prisoners at Abu Ghraib will irrevocably tarnish their work in minds of Americans and Iraqis; many soldiers are tired; their tour was extended four months when it became clear that troop numbers were too low; many soldiers say allegiance of Iraqi people is still up in the air, and whichever way it swings will determine outcome of war; say insurgents are crushing Americans in propaganda campaign right now; photos (L)

headline: Frank A. Sieverts, 70, Specialist In Refugee Issues at State Dept.
abstract: Frank A. Sieverts, 70, Specialist in Refugee Issues at State Deï

headline: Adelphia Witness Denies Secret-Books Accusation
abstract: Michael Mulcahey, former assistant treasuer at Adelphia Communications, denies claims by prosecution witness James R Brown, former vice president for finance who has pleaded guilty to fraud and conspiracy, that company kept secret books that hid true financial results from bank lenders; Brown says Adelphia lied to banks to avoid loan defaults and to cut borrowing costs, keeping actual results in second set of books (M)

headline: Spain Forms Panel to Review Intelligence Before Bombings
abstract: Spanish Parliament forms commission to investigate handling of intelligence before Mar 11 train bombings and national elections three days later; panel will explore to what extent lack of coordination among Spain's law enforcement agencies hampered collection and analysis of intelligence on Islamic militants, and whether Spain's obsession with fight against Basque separatists blinded investigators to increasing threat of Moroccan extremists (M)

headline: Israeli Military Says It Regrets Killing of a Palestinian Lecturer
abstract: Israeli military says Palestinian academic Yaser Abmed Abu-Laymoun, who was shot dead last week in West Bank village, was not involved in terrorism, as army initially claimed; says he was civilian accidentially caught in crossfire between army and Palestinian gunmen, and it regrets his death; Palestinians say army's admission of guilt is incomplete; Palestinians often complain that many of those killed and wounded by Israeli forces are not involved in militant activities, as Israeli military says; claims and counterclaims are often difficult to reconcile (M)

headline: After 2 Months, Bush's Iraq Panel Starts to Stir
abstract: Bipartisan commission Pres Bush created two months ago to look into intelligence failures in Iraq and weapons proliferation is only now beginning its work; its newly designated executive director John S Redd is currently posted in Iraq as deputy to civilian administrator L Paul Bremer III; 10-member commission, headed by Judge Laurence H Silberman and former Sen Charles S Robb, holds its first organizational meeting, with plans to appoint staff of 60 to 75 members next month; Bush, who reluctantly created panel in response to bipartisan calls for inquiry, noted at time that commission will not deliver its findings until next Mar, well after presidential elections; photos of Robb, Silberman and Lord Butler, who heads similar British panel (M)

headline: Defense Dept. Delays Action On Boeing Jets Till November
abstract: Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld postpones until November decision on $20 billion contract to lease aerial refueling tankers from Boeing Co, move that delays action until after presidential election; decision puts controversial project outside election-year politics and gives Pentagon more time to come up with alternatives to proposed deal, which critics say is overpriced and unnecessary; Rumsfeld orders analysis of alternatives to arrangement in which Air Force would lease up to 100 Boeing 767 jet for use as refueling tankers; tankers were to be used as replacements for Air Force airborne refueling fleet that dates to Eisenhower administration (M)

headline: Chief Executive Quits Havas Unit in Chicago
abstract: Euro RSCG Tatham Partners' chief executive Gary Epstein resigns, effective in June (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: 6 Bosnian Croats Surrender
abstract: Jadranko Prlic, Bruno Stojic, Gen Slobodan Praljak, Gen Milivoij Petkovic, Valentin Coric and Berislav Pusic, former participants in 1993 Croatian-Bosnian conflict accused of war crimes against Muslims, turn themselves in to Hague tribunal (S)

headline: Insurgency and Able Government Prompted Transfer Decision
abstract: Several top Bush administration officials and their Iraqi allies in Baghdad began seriously considering speeding up transfer of sovereignty more than week ago; story of how transfer that critics once said could never be done by June 30 was accomplished even earlier offers peek into administration's secretive decision making and its desire to bolster crucial ally and keep ruthless insurgency off balance; planning detailed (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: A Mistrial Declared in Trial Of 2 Ex-Tyco Executives  The judge in the six-month trial of two former Tyco International executives declared a mistrial because one juror said she had received a letter.     The Manhattan district attorney's office said that it would retry the case, in which the former chief executive of Tyco, L. Dennis Kozlowski, and the former chief financial officer, Mark H. Swartz, were accused of taking $600 million from the company. [Page A1.]

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: INTERNATIONAL RECTIFIER CORPORATION, El Segundo, Calif., a maker of chips for appliances, said it had agreed to buy a unit of ATMI Inc., Danbury, Conn., for as much as $41 million to gain control of a crucial supplier. The cash transaction includes the operations and assets of ATMI's epitaxial services business and is to be completed by the end of September.

headline: S.E.C. Feels Pressure To Weaken Some Rules
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission is under intense pressure from business and some in Bush administration to weaken proposed rules changes stemming from scandals in mutual fund industry and at some of nation's largest corporations in way corporate boards are elected, mutual funds are governed and hedge funds are regulated; two Democrats on SEC back proposals; two Republicans are skeptical; William H Donaldson, chairman, backs proposals in general; is reportedly willing to temper proposals in response to industry criticism; SEC plans to vote on final rule to let big shareholders in limited cases propose their own candidates for board seats at troubled companies; will weigh proposal to require that mutual fund chairmen not be involved in fund management; intends to propose rule to give regulators greater access to books and investment strategies of largely secretive hedge funds, requiring for first time that such funds register with SEC; table of proposals (M)

headline: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Midtown South; A Hotel That Says 'Stay a While'
abstract: Construction has begun on unusual 43-story hotel and rental apartment building on Avenue of Americas between 38th and 39th Streets; project, to be known as Bryant Park Tower, will house extended-stay hotel, 357-suite Marriott Residence Inn, with 96 studio and one-bedroom rental apartments on top 10 floors; hotel will be first Residence Inn in Manhattan; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sprint To Cut 1,100 Jobs
abstract: Sprint Corp plans to eliminate 1,100 jobs, or 1.7 percent of its work force, to reduce costs amid intensifying competition in long-distance phone market (S)

headline: In a Lawsuit, U.S. Accuses A Tax Adviser Of Fraud
abstract: Justice Department asks federal judge to effectively shut down National Audit Defense Network that it says promotes income tax fraud and has bilked government and 100,000 customers out of $500 million or more; says it has lost at least $324 million in taxes in last three years because of company, which has 470 employees; company's founder Robert Bennington refuses to comment; Federal Trade Commission and state of Nevada have taken action because of thousands of complaints from people who said they paid for advice in audits but were unable to obtain services they had paid for in advance; company charged $1,495 and up for its services, indicating it took in at least $150 million since it was founded in 1996 and perhaps much more; photo (M)

headline: 3 Nominees at I.M.F.
abstract: International Monetary Fund executive director A Shakhour Shaalan nominates Stanley Fischer, Mohamed El-Erian and Andrew Crockett to be fund's next managing director, succeeding Horst Kohler, who resigned (S)

headline: Microsoft Files an Appeal In European Antitrust Case
abstract: Microsoft files appeal of European antitrust ruling against it, saying regulators' remedies would undermine innovation; also says it will seek suspension of changes demanded by European Commission (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Beef Talks Set
abstract: Vice Pres Dick Cheney says Japanese government has invited US experts to consultations in Tokyo aimed at finding way for Japan to lift its ban on beef imports from US; Japan has blocked imports since December, when case of mad cow disease was discovered in Washington State (S)

headline: On Arab TV, Gaza Strife Dims Trial
abstract: Arab satellite television images out of Gaza, where Israeli soldiers had fired on demonstration of Palestinians, are so violent that there is only secondary coverage of court-martial and sentencing in Baghdad of Specialist Jeremy C Sivits in Iraqi prisoner abuse scandal; American officials in Iraq hoped public court-martial would show American justice in action and help blunt anger at abuses at Abu Ghraib prison (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: 2 Citigroup Executives Suspended
abstract: Robert Morse, chief executive of Citigroup's corporate and investment banking operations in Asia, says company has suspended two investment bankers in China for presentation of false information to company and its regulators; says company immediately informed appropriate authorities and will cooperate fully with them (S)

headline: Consumer Prices Surge at Fastest Rate in 3 Years
abstract: The consumer price index rose 0.6 percent in May, the Labor Department said. Energy prices fueled much of the increase.

headline: LEHMAN BROTHERS FILLS LONG-VACANT PRESIDENT POST
abstract: Lehman Brothers Holdings names Joseph Gregory president and sole chief operating officer (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | People: Computer Associates Names New Financial Officer
abstract: Computer Associates International hires Jeffrey J Clarke, former top executive at Hewlett-Packard Co, as its chief financial officer (S)

headline: MTV in Deal On Royalties With Labels In Europe
abstract: MTV Networks Europe capitulates to threat of boycott by European independent record labels, and agrees to new three-year deal that drops proposed 55 percent cut in royalties for playing rock videos; MTV has been locked in fierce battle with hundreds of European record producers over royalties for months; terms of deal undisclosed (M)

headline: Google Mail and Prying Eyes
abstract: Letter from California State Sen Liz Figueroa who is drafting legislation that will force Google to notify senders of e-mail to users of its new Gmail that their communications are subject to analysis (May 13 article)

headline: COURT APPROVES NATIONAL CENTURY'S LIQUIDATION PLAN
abstract: National Century Financial Enterprises, defunct health care finance company with $3.5 billion in debt, wins court approval to liquidate and distribute its remaining assets to creditors after 17 months in bankruptcy (S)

headline: Ex-Officers and Board at Odds Over Investigation at Shell
abstract: Early conclusions of internal probe into Shell's reserve write-down earlier this year have created warring factions of board and former executives, and have some investors and legal experts questioning whether audit committee conducting inquiry has gone far enough; Walter van de Vijver, former head of exploration and production, says he had informed company's managing directors in 2001 that some of Shell's reserves might need to be reclassified, indirectly implicating company's new chairman Jeroen van der Veer; Shell is being investigated by US Securities and Exchange Commission and Justice Department and by European regulators after company said in January that it was subtracting 20 percent from its estimate of proven reserves, most valuable assets for any oil company; company's audit committee has been conducting its own probe since reserve change; Shell's board will vote April 16 on preliminary results of internal investigation, after reviewing report of several hundred pages; report lays much of responsibility on van de Vijver and former chairman Sir Philip Watts (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: U.S. Lease of Boeing 767's Is Still Alive, Chief Says  The chief executive of Boeing, Harry C. Stonecipher, said the $20 billion deal with the Air Force to lease 767's as aerial refueling tankers ''is not dead'' and that the Air Force remains committed to the proposal.    At the moment, a decision on the tanker deal is before Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, Mr. Stonecipher said. [Page C4.]

headline: World Briefings
abstract: ASIA.

headline: Pentagon Weighs Transferring 4,000 G.I.'s in Korea to Iraq
abstract: Defense Dept draws up plans to move a brigade, 4,000 troops, from South Korea to Iraq; plan would fulfill twin goals of reshaping American military's deployment on Korean peninsula and relieving pressure on Army stretched thin by heavy commitments in Iraq; plan, if it goes forward, would be first movement of American troops from South Korea to front lines of Iraq; 37,000 American troops are stationed in South Korea under 50-year-old security treaty (M)

headline: A Design Epiphany: Keep It Simple
abstract: Simplicity Design Workshop at MIT Media Lab is set up for working designers to collaborate with researchers on simplification of technology in increasingly complex world; helps researchers focus less on technology and more on user's vital needs; photo (M)

headline: Tabloid King Seeks Makeover From Sassy to Stable
abstract: David J Pecker, chief executive of American Media Inc, has put off initial public offering as he searches for new acquisitions to make American Media a more attractive investment; is undeterred by lack of interest shown by two potential targets--Gruner & Jahr USA Publishing and Dennis Publishing; seeks to turn back competition from US Weekly and In Touch that has cut into sales of American Media's three celebrity-focused tabloids, National Equirer, Star and Globe; is banking on success of redesign of Star as larger, glossier magazine, which has been costlier than expected, and Thalia, new magazine based on Latina recording star Thalia Sodi; photos (M)

headline: Hostage Is Free; 9 G.I.'s Killed In Iraq Attacks
abstract: American contractor Thomas Hamill, taken hostage by militants last month, escapes from his captors and runs to group of passing American troops near Samarra; officers say he is suffering from infected gunshot wound but is otherwise in good condition; Hamill, fuel-truck driver working for Halliburton subsidiary Kellogg Brown & Root, was one of several foreign civilians kidnapped or killed in early Apr, as American forces faced uprisings in Sunni Arab stronghold of Falluja and among followers of Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr; eight other Americans were taken from same fuel convoy as Hamill; four were killed, as was one American soldier, and another soldier was captured; he is still missing, as are two other civilian contractors; fate of three Italian contractors taken hostage, as well as two Canadian businessmen, is unknown; photos; map (M)

headline: U.S. Says It Has Arms From Site of Attack
abstract: Coalition Provisional Authority easily fills available positions through Defense Dept web page; has about 1,160 military, civilian and foreign employees; many Americans are motivated to work in Iraq by ideals, and also by desire for prestigious resumes; many are talented individuals with careers in public service, but others lack proper experience for difficult and dangerous assignments; work in Iraq is unique means of gaining that experience and offers opportunities that would never be available back home; photos (M)

headline: European Body Said to Drop Objections to Music Merger
abstract: European antitrust regulators are expected to approve merger of music divisions of Sony Corp and Bertelsmann AG despite earlier objections (M)

headline: Private Firms Use Closed-End Funds To Tap the Market
abstract: Apollo Advisers, Blackstone Group, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and other private equity firms are reaching out to small investors through closed-end mutual funds; Apollo has raised $930 million to start a fund that will lend money to companies with revenue of $50 million to $500 million; vehicle is being promoted to investors looking for high yield in current low-rate environment, and it carries high fees; closed-end format allows private equity firms to raise money quickly and gives them permanent capital; photo (M)

headline: Once, He Might Have Capitalized This Venture. Now, He Works for It.
abstract: Steve Harmon, once prominent as venture capital fund manager, will join LiveDeal, e-Bay-like service, as vice president for business development; photo (M)

headline: Spain's Sunny Coasts Look For Water From the North
abstract: Chronic water shortages pit dry southern Spain against wet north; new Prime Min Jose Luis Rodriguez Zapatero has suspended $15 billion national water plan that calls for diverting water from Ebro River to south, saying entire concept needs to be rethought; Spain must decide what sort of development is realistic for semiarid regions; driest country in Western Europe is second-largest per capita consumer of water; new government plans to focus on better use of available resources; photo; map (M)

headline: That Mirage in Foreign Harbors
abstract: Mark Hulbert column cites growing evidence that adding foreign stocks to domestic stock portfolio does little to cut risk and could make bad situation worse; notes studies show performance of foreign and domestic stocks tends to be more closely linked when domestic stocks are declining than when they are rising; graph compares drops in domestic and foreign stocks during periods of market decline (M)

headline: BUSH MAY ACCEPT WEST BANK PLAN
abstract: Pres Bush plans to issue declaration that his aides say will recognize Israel's right to retain some Jewish settlements in West Bank as part of any peace accord with Palestinians; declaration, to be made when Prime Min Ariel Sharon visits White House on April 14, would represent subtle but substantial shift in American policy, which has viewed settlements as obstacles to peace and asserted that final borders must be arrived at through negotiations solely between Israel and Palestinians; administration officials say that Bush will also assert that Palestinian refugee families that once lived in Israel should live in a future Palestinian state in West Bank and Gaza Strip, rather than in Israeli lands they continue to claim; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Optimistic Outlook
abstract: US Treasury Under Sec John B Taylor says Japan's two-year recovery appears to be on solid ground as result of government efforts to tackle some of worst of country's economic problems; praises Japan's progress in dealing with deflation and bad bank loans; photo (S)

headline: Large-Company Funds Looking for a Revival
abstract: Outlook for inve

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Retail Stake Purchased
abstract: Nomura Holdings will invest 50 billion yen ($463 million) for majority stake in holding company of Seibu Department Store group, which is undergoing major turnaround (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of May 23 article on departures of three senior executives of DPL Inc regarding circumstances behind leaving of two of them

headline: Attack in Saudi Arabia Raises Market Concerns
abstract: The latest attack on foreign residential and office complexes in Saudi Arabia has ratcheted up concerns over that nation's ability to press forward with increases in oil production at a time when global petroleum supplies are becoming increasingly sensitive to such disruptions.

headline: U.S. May Delay Departure Of Some Troops in Iraq
abstract: Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld signals that Pentagon might delay bringing home as many as 25,000 soldiers as scheduled from Iraq, even as new troops meant to replace them are arriving; cites need for 'seasoned troops' after days of intense combat in both Shiite and Sunni cities; military officials say some reinforced American troops in Baghdad area will probably be sent to cities in southern Iraq to help other occupation forces put down insurrection by forces loyal to Moktada al-Sadr; military moves reflect deep sense of concern by Bush administration and American commanders about deteriorating situation in Iraq, where Sadr's militant Shiite followers have added second front to anti-American campaign previously limited to Sunni insurgents (M)

headline: New Suitors Emerge in Gold Deal
abstract: Idaho-based Coeur d'Alene expresses interest in buying Toronto-based gold mining company Iamgold for about $1.8 billion; Gold Star Resources says it may want to buy Iamgold for $926 million in stock, as long as Wheaton River Minerals Ltd, which has made $2.2 billion stock offer, is not part of deal (M)

headline: China Fuels Brazil's Dream of Being a Steel Power
abstract: Brazil is looking to become major player in global steel industry with help of foreign investors; Brazil's steel industry is trying to keep up with demand in China, investing billions of dollars to increase its production capacity by more than 30 percent in next few years; China's Baosteel Shanghai Group and Luxembourg's Arcelor are still planning to build blast furnaces to churn out steel in Brazil; Dongkuk Steel Mill Co of South Africa and Italian metals group Danieli are also helping to finance construction of $700 million steel slab plant in northeastern Brazilian state of Ceara; photo (M)

headline: Debating Wi-Fi Security
abstract: Last week, I attempted to throw a little water on the hot-button issue of wireless insecurity, which has been heavily hyped in the popular press. My specific beef was that so many articles are shrill about all the security steps you should take, without ever specifying what, exactly, the danger might be.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.00   4.00   4.25       Federal Funds   1.00   0.99   1.27       3-month Libor   1.18   1.18   1.28       3-month T-bills   0.97   0.96   1.07       6-month T-bills   1.17   1.14   1.11       10-yr. T-infl.   2.10   2.05   1.92       10-yr. T-note   4.60   4.58   3.70       30-yr. T-bond   5.37   5.36   4.68       Telephone bd.   6.48   6.48   5.58       Municipal bds.   5.13   5.10   4.73          (Sources by Bloomberg News; Telerate; The Bond Buyer; British Bankers' Assoc.)

headline: MediaTalk; No Shots of a Cheap Shot, and Some Wonder Why
abstract: Getty Images' deal for exclusive marketing rights with National Hockey League is called into question when Getty wire service fails to offer photo of Todd Bertuzzi punching Steve Moore at Vancouver Canucks-Colorado Avalanche game in March; photo (M)

headline: SUMITOMO AGREES TO BUY HARTZ MOUNTAIN
abstract: Japan's Sumitomo Corp agrees to purchase pet-supplies maker Hartz Mountain for $365 million; Sumitomo and its US unit agree to purchase all outstanding shares in JWC Hartz Holdings from J W Child Associates (S)

headline: INVESTOR OPPOSITION THREATENS MONY SALE TO AXA
abstract: More than 15 percent of Mony Group's shareholders say they will oppose in Delaware court insurer's sale to France's AXA, enough to give AXA right to walk away from $1.5 billion purchase (S)

headline: BANK OF AMERICA BUYS CHRYSLER'S CREDIT-CARD ACCOUNTS
abstract: Bank of America Corp acquires 160,000 DaimlerChrysler credit-card accounts for undisclosed price (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Profit For Isuzu
abstract: Japanese truck maker Isuzu Motors earned 54.7 billion yen ($478 million) for year ended March 31 compared with net loss of 144.3 billion yen year earlier (S)1

headline: Devonshire, Peerless Homeowner, Dies at 84
abstract: Andrew Robert Buxton Cavendish, 11th Duke of Devonshire, who maintained his family's historically grand way of life by selling art masterpieces and converting his Chatsworth estate into one of Britain's most visited attractions, dies at age 84; photo (M)

headline: Suspected Bomb Blast Hurts 17 in Germany
abstract: A bomb filled with nails exploded in a Turkish neighborhood in the city of Cologne today, German police said.

headline: G.M. JOINS RIVALS IN INCREASING REBATES ON SPORT UTILITIES
abstract: General Motors adds $1,000 to rebates on midsize sport utility vehicles like Chevrolet TrailBlazer, one day after Ford Motor and DaimlerChrysler raise their incentives for sport utilities; increase doubles, to $2,000, rebates consumers can use with existing no-interest loan offers of up to five years; offers end June 1 (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Transit Proposal
abstract: Thailand asks main creditors of Bangkok Mass Transit System to forgo half of their 38.8 billion baht debt ($974 million) as part of government's move to take system over (S)

headline: Take Your Music Files To a New Computer
abstract: Q. I have several gigabytes of music files in iTunes. How can I move my collection into the iTunes program on a new computer?    A. You can move your music library from one computer to another in several ways, with the steps varying slightly depending on whether it's from a Macintosh to a Windows PC, PC to Mac, Mac to Mac or PC to PC.

headline: New Jersey Town Awaits Word Of Man Held in Saudi Arabia
abstract: Little Egg Township, New Jersey, awaits word of Paul Johnson, kidnapped by Islamic terrorists in Saudi Arabia; photo (S)

headline: Investor Suit Is Dismissed
abstract: Judge Loretta Preska dismisses lawsuit accusing Bristol-Myers Squibb of misleading investors about its optimism for ImClone Systems' cancer drug Erbitux; Bristol-Myers paid $2 billion for stake in ImClone in September 2001 (S)

headline: Venezuelan President Closer to Facing a Recall Vote
abstract: Pres Hugo Chavez of Venezuela says he is ready to face referendum, hours after electoral authorities announce that his foes collected enough signatures to mount recall that could end his tumultuous five-and-a-half-year rule; country is divided between those who blame him for wrecking country and masses of poor who believe he is first leader to make serious effort to ease their hardscrabble lives; it is unclear if referendum would take place quickly enough for Chavez's foes to end his government; Venezuelan law says that any referendum held after Aug 19 would succeed only in removing president, not replacing him; Chavez's vice president would take over, effectively giving Chavez chance to rule from behind scenes and run again in 2006; photo (M)

headline: Colombians Urged to Drink More and Better Coffee (Their Own)
abstract: Federation of Colombian coffee growers seeks to spur domestic consumption in face of low prices and supply glut; good cup of coffee has been hard to find in Colombia, where premium beans have tradionally been exported and few practice best brewing methods; Brazil's success in 1990's in doubling internal consumption noted; photo (M)

headline: Russian TV Newsman Fired in Media Crackdown
abstract: Leonid Parfyonov, one of Russia's most outspoken television broadcasters, is fired after airing program against wishes of government and then objecting angrily when broadcast is abruptly halted; his firing seen as latest step by Pres Vladimir V Putin in tightening control over news media as well as other areas of public life; some of Parfyonov's colleagues accuse Putin of Soviet-style censorship; offending program was interview with widow of Chechen separatist leader who was killed in Qatar, where he had taken refuge; Putin suggested further government control last week when he said some human rights groups and other civic groups were working against national interest (M)

headline: Cool Hands, No Cables: A Gamer Roams Untethered
abstract: Air Flo Wireless Controller from Nyko for Playstation 2 has internal fans to cool hands and power game controller for 50 hours; photo (S)

headline: MEMO PAD
abstract: GENERAL AVIATION SAGGED IN 2003***General Aviation Manufacturers Association says shipments of general aviation aircraft of all types fell 3.2 percent in 2003; Federal Aviation Administration says in its annual forecast that overall flight operations fell 4.9 percent last year at top 10 general aviation airports and overseas departures rose 10.9 percent; corporate travel managers are opposing proposal being considered by federal authorities to relax security rules to allow people without tickets inside secured areas of terminal at Pittsburgh International Airport; PricewaterhouseCoopers says average hotel occupancy rates will be highest this summer, at 69.1 percent, since summer of 2000, when rate was 72.1 percent; British Airways is promoting sleep time in its Club World business-class cabins on four daily overnight flights from New York's Kennedy Airport to London's Heathrow; Californians are studying proposal for 700-mile high-speed rail system that could carry projected 68 million passengers per year by 2020 on trains using dedicated tracks and traveling faster than 200 miles per hour; chart (Memo Pad column) (M)

headline: Short on Priests, U.S. Catholics Outsource Prayers to Indian Clergy
abstract: Roman Catholic Church, faced with shortage of priests in United States, Canada and Europe, is outsourcing Mass for special intentions, such as services for remembrance of dead or thanksgiving prayers, to Indian clergy; about 2 percent of India's population is Christian, mostly Catholic; prayers in Kerala cost equivalent of 90 cents as opposed to $5 in US; priests welcome supplementary income; one diocese receives about 350 requests per month (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Denmark: Prince Marries Australian
abstract: Denmark's Crown Prince Frederik marries Australian Mary Elizabeth Donaldson in Copenhagen; photo (S)

headline: Ex-Adelphia Executive Recalls Fake Payments
abstract: James Brown, government's star witness at fraud trial of Adelphia Communications Corp's founder John Rigas and his sons Michael and Timothy, testifies Michael Rigas knew about fake circular transactions with two suppliers and did nothing to prevent them; describes 'wash' transactions involving Motorola and Scientific-Atlanta; says those transactions helped Adelphia mask eroding financial performance that led to its bankruptcy in June 2002 (M)

headline: Whose Data Is It, Anyway?
abstract: Article discusses accessing password protected computer files once the owner dies; some corporations now archive employee passwords, and experts suggest the same be done for home computers; many people just erase hard drive rather than discover embarrassing personal information; photo (L)

headline: How to Break a Code, Ever Since the Days of the Sphinx
abstract: Allegations that Ahmad Chalabi, Iraqi leader and former Bush administration ally, disclosed to Iranian official that United States had cracked code used by its intelligence service is only most recent example of code making and code breaking throughout recorded history (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.00   4.00   4.25       Federal Funds   1.00   1.01   1.27       3-month Libor   1.17   1.17   1.31       3-month T-bills   0.95   0.97   1.12       6-month T-bills   1.14   1.16   1.15       10-yr. T-infl.   1.92   1.96   2.16       10-yr. T-note   4.39   4.44   3.93       30-yr. T-bond   5.20   5.23   4.84       Telephone bd.   6.34   6.33   5.79       Municipal bds.   5.05   5.05   4.86          (Sources by Bloomberg News; Telerate; The Bond Buyer; British Bankers' Assoc.)

headline: Final Boarding Call for Your Flight to the Ends of the Earth
abstract: USA Networks founder-Reality Central chairwoman Kay Koplovitz, in Frequent Flier column, comments on some of her airline travel experiences; photo (M)

headline: Ahold Reports Loss From Efforts To Pull Back From Acquisitions
abstract: Royal Ahold lost 405

headline: Judge in Abuse Case Will Allow Questioning of Top Officers
abstract: Three American soldiers accused in the Abu Ghraib prisoner abuse scandal faced initial hearings in Baghdad today.

headline: COEUR D'ALENE MINES AGAIN INCREASES BID FOR WHEATON
abstract: Coeur d'Alene Mines of Idaho raises its bid for Wheaton River Minerals to 2.6 billion Canadian dollars ($1.9 billion) in cash and stock from 2.4 billion Canadian dollars (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Cable Venture Bailout
abstract: cableo

headline: Documents Are Said to Show Earlier Abuse at Iraq Prison
abstract: US military officials in Baghdad say that military lawyers and some colonels received internal documents that reportedly cited complaints of abuse at Abu Ghraib prison starting in Nov 2003 about two months before top military officials say they were alerted to abuse (M)

headline: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- NoHo; A Neighborhood Rarity: New Offices
abstract: Macklowe Properties is putting up first large speculative office building to be built near Manhattan's Houston Street in decades; has already leased over two-thirds of office space, even though occupancy is months away; drawing (M)

headline: Paris Memo; Since 1066, It Hasn't Always Been Cordial
abstract: Queen Elizabeth II of Britain makes state visit to France to mark 100th anniversary of Entente Cordiale, agreement that led to easing of relations between two countries; current relations between Pres Jacques Chirac and Prime Min Tony Blair are frosty; photo (M)

headline: Treasury Offerings Scheduled for Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.    According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 1.20 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 1.49 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 0.94 percent.

headline: Seven Arrested Over False Mitsubishi Reports
abstract: Japanese police arrest seven former Mitsubishi Motors Corp executives suspected of falsifying reports about commercial truck defect linked to fatal accident two years ago; those arrested include Takashi Usami, former chairman of Mitsubishi Fuso Truck and Bus and former vice president of Mitsubishi Motors; all seven were executives of Mitsubishi Motors when accident occurred in January 2002; Ministry of Land, Infrastructure and Transport files criminal complaint against Mitsubishi Motors over reports in question; Mitsubishi truck affiliate admitted in March that faulty wheel hubs might have been cause of dozens of accidents, including one in which 29-year-old woman was killed by tire that flew off truck in Kanagawa Prefecture; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: ATI Posts 2nd-Quarter Profit
abstract: ATI Technologies Inc reports profit of $47.6 million in second quarter ended Feb 29; net income was 19 cents per share, compared with restated net loss of $9.4 million year earlier; sales rose 48 percent, to $463.3 million, from restated $313.5 million; founder Kwok Yuen Ho will step down as chief executive (S)

headline: Downloading Again
abstract: Pew Internet and American Life Project survey finds online music downloading and file sharing is on rise again; finds shift in users' downloading preferences since music industry began legal drive; estimates paid music services now account for 17 percent of downloads; graph and table of music downloads; photo (S)

headline: Fiat Names Director as Chief And Vows to Remain in Autos
abstract: Fiat SpA's board names Sergio Marchionne chief executive and says he will run daily operations; reaffirms Fiat's commitment to its money-losing car unit and says it will accelerate restructuring plan that aims for return to profit in 2006; photo (M)

headline: Discovery Pushes Back Date of 'Classic' Maya
abstract: National Geographic Society reports excavation of 2,000-year-old ruins of city in Guatemala is raising serious questions about chronology of enigmatic Mayan civilization; Dr Francisco Estrada-Belli, who leads dig, says city, Cival, seems to have been one of earliest and largest in what is generally regarded as preclassic period, but had all of hallmarks of classic Mayan city, phone interview; archaeologists have long dated start of classic period at AD 250; Cival reached its prime about 150 BC and was abandoned shortly before AD 100; map; photo (M)

headline: Hong Kong Vigil Remembers Tiananmen Square Killings
abstract: Tens of thousands of people gathered to mark the 15th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square killings in Beijing.

headline: PRESIDENT SORRY FOR IRAQ ABUSE; BACKS RUMSFELD
abstract: Pres Bush says he is sorry for abuse of Iraqi prisoners by American soldiers, but vows that Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld will remain in his job; appears to direct his words to visiting King Abdullah II of Jordan as leader of Arab nation; stopped short of apology in Arab television interviews day earlier; voices faith in Rumsfeld while also saying that he chastised him 24 hours earlier for his failure to inform him about graphic photographs showing American abuse of Iraqi captives; Washington is rampant with speculation over whether Rumsfeld will survive; many Democrats, including Sen John Kerry, are calling for his resignation, while most Republicans say they are behind him for now; Rumsfeld, said to be embarrassed and angry, spends day with aides, preparing for testimony before Senate and House that is likely to be among most important of his tenure; meets with four Republicans on Senate Armed Services Committee in effort to defuse what both parties say will be contentious hearing; photo (M)

headline: SEMPRA ENERGY PROMOTES EXECUTIVE TO PRESIDENT
abstract: Sempra Energy promotes Donald E Felsinger to president and chief operating officer; will succeed Stephen L Baum as chief executive when Baum retires in 2006; chief financial officer Neal E Schmale will succeed Felsinger (S)

headline: So Close, Jurors See Long Effort End in Nothing
abstract: Jurors in six-month trial of former Tyco International executives L Dennis Kozlowski and Mark H Swartz are disappointed and frustrated after New York State Supreme Court Justice Michael J Obus declares mistrial; Obus acts after juror Ruth B Jordan is identified by name in news media and she receives threatening letter from stranger; jurors say they were close to verdict after 12 days of sometimes acrimonious deliberations, and probably would have found defendants guilty of some of 32 charges against them (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Anti-Terror Police Arrest 12
abstract: Twelve people are arrested in nine different locations north of Paris (France) for alleged involvement in terrorist activities; Islamic cleric is among those detained (S)

headline: European Approval Said to Be Near for Sony and BMG Merger
abstract: The European Commission is poised to approve a merger between Sony Music and BMG, the music division of the German publisher Bertelsmann, people familiar with the case said today.

headline: 2 Senior Executives Leave Air America Radio
abstract: Air America Radio says chief executive-founder Mark Walsh and executive vice president Dave Logan are leaving; Walsh will become senior adviser (M)

headline: Limited Price Controls Among Steps by China to Curb Inflation
abstract: China took four more steps Sunday and today to slow inflation, including limited price controls in provinces where the cost of living is rising fastest.

headline: Philippe Jutras, 87, Keeper of D-Day Museum in Normandy
abstract: Philippe Jutras, US Amry veteran of Normandy invasion and curator of Airborne Museum in Ste-Mere-Eglise, France, dies at age 87; photo (M)

headline: 99 CENTS ONLY STORES WARNS ABOUT PROFIT DECLINE
abstract: 99 Cents Only Stores says quarterly profit will fall more than expected because of disruptions in distribution as competition from supermarkets increased; second-quarter profit will decline to 4 cents to 7 cents a share, compared with earlier forecast of 19 cents to 20 cents (S)

headline: Surprising Choice Reflects U.S. Influence
abstract: Dr Iyad Alawi, chosen by United Nations envoy Lakhdar Brahimi's to be Iraq's interim prime minister, is likely to be seen as more American candidate than that of of UN or Iraqis in light of his Central Intelligence Agency ties and closeness to United States; State Department suggests Iraqi Governing Council merely ratified Brahimi's choice after fact; UN statements seem to indicate Brahami was bowing to wishes of others; he refuses to discuss choice, phone interview; diagrams (M)

headline: Strong European Sales Lift Topps's Results
abstract: Topps Co says net nicome for fiscal quarter ended Feb 28 increased 47 percent; net income rose to $2.9 million from $2 million year earlier; sales increased 6.2 percent, to $69.8 million from $65.7 million (S)

headline: Dow Jones Sees Some Good News Amid the Shadows
abstract: Dow Jones shareholders will hear good news about company for first time in years at company's annual meeting on April 21; advertising linage has grown for three consecutive quarters after declines in previous 11, thanks to nascent recovery in financial advertising and increasing consumer advertising at flagship Wall Street Journal; representatives of restive union plan to be on hand to complain about their protracted and heated labor dispute with company; photo (M)

headline: Melvin J. Lasky, Cultural Cold Warrior, Is Dead at 84
abstract: Melvin J. Lasky, the editor of two major intellectual journals and a man at the vortex of the debates and controversies thrown up by the cold war, died Wednesday at his home in Berlin. He was 84.    The cause was heart failure, Marc Svetov, his secretary, said.

headline: Google Mail: Virtue Lies In the In-Box
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column on Gmail, free electronic mail being tested by Google; Gmail offers embedded links relevant to e-mail subject and one gigabyte of storage; photo; drawing (M)

headline: Deliberations Begin in Retrial of Former Banker
abstract: Closing arguments are made in retrial of Frank P Quattrone, former Credit Suisse First Boston executive, and jury begins deliberating whether he obstructed federal securities investigation; jury sends notes and questions to Judge Richard Owen that legal experts say indicate that at least some jurors might have doubts about prosecution's case; Quattrone photo (M)

headline: Judge Refuses to Halt Agents' Suit Against Allstate Insurance
abstract: Federal Judge John P Fullam rejects request by Allstate Insurance Co to dismiss lawsuit by more than 6,000 agents; action clears way for trial on company's attempt to convert agents to independent contractors and remove their benefits (M)

headline: Global Trade Body Rules Against U.S. On Cotton Subsidies
abstract: Brazil wins preliminary ruling at World Trade Organization that could force United States to lower subsidies it pays farmers to grow cotton and, eventually, most subsidized crops; decision supports Brazil's contention that subsidies to cotton farmers violate international trade rules; final ruling against US could lead to stiff penalties if it fails to change its practices; ruling puts Bush administration in tight bind in election year, when Republicans are counting on support from Farm Belt; largest American farmers have grown dependent on $19 billion they receive in annual subsidies; if final decision in June goes against US, administration is expected to appeal, if for no other reason than to delay action until after election; Brazilian case is first successful challenge of a wealthy nation's domestic agriculture subsidies; it could force US, European countries and other well-to-do nations to act this summer and offer new compromises at global trade talks that have been blocked over this issue for more than year (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
After the Battle, Mourning and Anger in an Iraqi Slum
abstract: Almost one year ago, the Shiites of Sadr City were throwing flowers at the American tanks. But today, the Iraqis were filling plain wood coffins with the corpses of their kin.

headline: DELTA IS PRESSING PILOTS' UNION FOR 30% CUT IN PAY
abstract: Delta Air Lines chief Gerald Grinstein says that concessions from pilots' union are inadequate and that company is still seeking pay cut of 30 percent from group; pilots have offered to accept 9 percent reduction and forgo 4.5 percent increase scheduled to take effect in May (S)

headline: Human Crematory Finds Home With the Holsteins
abstract: Jim Curley leases property from neighboring dairy farm in Guilford, Vt, to operate his crematory, Vermont Blessings; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Jihad Against Drugs
abstract: Afghanistan's President Hamid Karzai urges leaders to wage holy war against drugs, particularly poppy cultivation; Afghanistan is top producer of opium in world (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: New Parliament Sworn In
abstract: First session of newly elected Indian Parliament begins and Communist Somnath Chatterjee is sworn in as speaker (S)

headline: BELLSOUTH CUTS JOBS AS WHOLESALE OPERATION FALTERS
abstract: BellSouth Corp plans to cut 349 jobs in third quarter because its wholesale business is losing customers; says most of cuts are in Atlanta in wholesale unit (S)

headline: Bush and Cheney Talk Strongly of Qaeda Links With Hussein
abstract: President Bush and Vice President Cheney said that they remain convinced that Saddam Hussein's government had a long history of ties to Al Qaeda.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Soldiers Open Fire On Each Other
abstract: Colombian Army, recently plagued with fatal accidents involving both military and civilians, has three more soldiers killed when two army patrols mistakenly fire on each other; some in Congress blame errors on President Alvaro Uribe's hard-line doctrine (S)

headline: Putting a Price on Service
abstract: George Price letter on issues in tipping (April 25 article)

headline: Senate Panel Asked to Give S.E.C. Proposals a Chance
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission chairman William H Donaldson tells Senate Banking Committee that Congress should not pass any laws to correct abuses in mutual fund industry until his agency's proposal to fix improper trading can take hold; banking committee chairman Richard C Shelby agrees with Donaldson and says mutual fund legislation is unlikely now (M)

headline: @ Issue: Long Code for a Small Symbol
abstract: At sign will become newest character in Morse Code, introduced so ham radio operators can send each other e-mail addresses and Web sites; it is first change to code in 60 years; photo (M)

headline: A Seat of Honor Lost to Open Political Warfare
abstract: Ahmad Chalabi was already losing influence in Washington four months ago, when he had seat of honor behind Laura Bush at president's State of Union address; intelligence about unconventional weapons that his Iraqi National Congress fed to senior Bush administration officials, that helped fuel push for war, was already crumbling; intelligence officials now say some of it was fabricated; reported effort by Pentagon officials to install him as Iraq's leader had faded; Pentagon has terminated his group's $335,000-a-month contract with Defense Intelligence Agency; he broke with Bush administration when it became clear he might be frozen out of interim government United Nations is expected to create for Iraq, plan he has denounced; raid on his offices is remarkable reversal for man who worked furiously to plot Saddam Hussein's fall; in recent months he has veered between tepid defenses of case he made against Hussein and increasingly vitriolic descriptions of American occupation; photo (M)

headline: Violence Jolts the Still Fragile Democracy in Nigeria
abstract: Nigeria is in one of most serious political crises since restoration of democracy five years ago; rash of sectarian clashes has left dead bodies and prompted tens of thousands of Muslims and Christians to flee in opposite directions; latest carnage was carried out in early May, when Christian militia stormed Muslim market town of Yelwa and crushed it; town is totally destroyed and town's people are huddled miles away in makeshift camps; death toll is put at 67 by government and figure ten times higher by residents; consequences are echoing across country, as towns and villages become Christian-only or Muslim-only enclaves; attack in Yelwa was fueled less by religious passions than by deep-seated rivalries over land and power; Pres Olusegun Obasanjo's election ended military rule but also revealed country's deep fissures; photo; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Profit In Software Services
abstract: Wipro, India's third-largest software services company, says fourth-quarter profit rose 42 percent, beating expectations, as outsourcing of software and back-office work by global corporations lifted its revenue by 44 percent, to $1.2 billion (S)

headline: Business; Having Their S.U.V.'s and Converting Them, Too
abstract: Former entertainment industry executives David Youth and Seth Seaberg have build their Evo Transportation into bustling business in Los Angeles with limo service that features environmentally friendly SUV's powered by compressed natural gas; Evo is now ramping up to convert SUV's for Hollywood's elite and others, as well as to convert smaller vehicles for corporate and municipal fleets; photos (M)

headline: Mutual Funds Report; Just Relax, Put Your Feet Up and Make Money
abstract: Paul B Brown reviews investment advice in book The Lazy Person's Guide to Investing by Paul B Farrell; drawing (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: New Attack On An Election Rally
abstract: Suspected Islamic militants attack political rally in Banihal (Kashmir, India) just hours before planned campaign visit to region by Indian Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee; one person is killed and 22 others are wounded (S)

headline: U.S. Says Gasoline Prices Won't Fall Anytime Soon
abstract: Energy Department predicts average price of gasoline this summer will be near record levels; crude oil prices rise 2.8 percent, to more than $37 per barrel; department says average retail price of gasoline will be around $1.76 per gallon, about what it is now and 20 cents higher than average last summer (M)

headline: U.S. to Quit A Mosque; Border Raid Still Defended
abstract: American commanders in Iraq say they are withdrawing their troops from besieged center of holy city of Karbala after week of intense combat and amid intensifying scrutiny of military actions throughout country; defend missile strike near Syrian border that reportedly killed 41 people, saying they believed they hit hideaway for foreign fighters and not wedding party as claimed by Iraqis there; note American soldiers confiscated rifles, pistols, machine guns, foreign passports and satellite communications equipment; say they will investigate why military's account does not appear to square with television film reported to be from scene that shows at least one child dead; witnesses claim strike hit several tents after wedding; photos; map (M)

headline: War and Abuse Do Little Harm To U.S. Brands
abstract: American companies that sell globally say they have so far experienced little or no disruption from discontent over Iraq war and abuse of Iraqi prisoners; many people abroad, influenced by growing sophistication in marketing big American brands, see United States products as rooted in own home nations; even Muslims in Mideast and Southeast Asia are not boycotting American products; photo (M)

headline: NOBODY DOESN'T LIKE CORPORATE SUITES
abstract: Brenda C Barnes, former Pepsi-Cola North America chi

headline: Aiming for Hit Games, Films Come Up Short
abstract: Video games based on movies or books are almost never big hits; reasons for poor crossover between audiences discussed; list of top-selling games in 2003 includes only one game--Enter the Matrix--based on movie; photos (M)

headline: A Lonely Bear Resists Increasing Optimism on Jobs
abstract: Argus Research chief economist Richard Yamarone is one of few economists that is resisting increasing optimism on jobs; Yamarone is sticking with his prediction of slim gain of 95,000 jobs for April as investors await Labor Department's release of month's figures on May 7; says it does not feel like economy created another 100,000 or 200,000 or 300,000 new payroll jobs in April; Citigroup economist Brian Jones expects April data of 250,000 new jobs; graphs; photos (M)

headline: The Ever More Graspable, And Risky, American Dream
abstract: Array of mortgages for people with little cash or overstretched budgets has enabled families of modest income to take on debt once beyond their reach to buy homes, spurred by low interest rates and confidence that house prices will continue to rise; some experts worry that recent first-time buyers will be squeezed by rising interest rates on adjustable-rate mortgages, possibly causing housing prices to wobble in some high-price markets on East and West Coasts; graphs of housing prices and mortgages; photos (M)

headline: FEDEX RAISES PROFIT ESTIMATES FOR ITS 4TH QUARTER
abstract: FedEx Corp raises profit estimates for fiscal fourth quarter ended May 5 (S)

headline: An Incendiary Cleric Braces His Militia for an Invasion
abstract: Hundreds of supporters of radical Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr are busy fortifying Grand Mosque of Kufa, where he has barricaded himself, after American authorities issue arrest warrant for him; he has refused to surrender; streets of Kufa are full of militiamen, in open disregard of occupation laws calling for private armies to be disbanded; militia prowling streets point rocket-propelled grenades at highway heading north--road they expect to see American forces come down; many Kufa residents are dreading showdown; photo (M)

headline: Sharon Coup: U.S. Go-Ahead
abstract: Analysis: Pres Bush's support of Israeli plan to withdraw from Gaza Strip is victory for Prime Min Ariel Sharon; Sharon sought and got two other commitments from Bush: American recognition that Israel would hold on to parts of West Bank, and American rejection of right of millions of Palestinian refugees from Arab-Israeli war of 1948 and their descendants to return to their lands in what is now Israel; in return, Sharon promised to trade something Israelis overwhelmingly do not want anymore: Gaza settlements and handful of settlements in West Bank; innovative, though risky, element in Sharon's strategy was to trade his concessions in Gaza and West Bank not to Palestinians as part of negotiated agreement, but to Americans; outraged Palestinian officials, who know of Israel's strong opposition to yielding whole West Bank or accepting 'right of return,' had relied on both demands as formidable negotiating levers (M)

headline: China Cools Lending, and Markets Shiver
abstract: Asian stock markets and currencies dip and prices for oil and other commodities slip as world markets respond to news that Chinese authorities ordered banks to stop their rapid increase in lending at least until weeklong May Day holiday begins May 1; crude oil prices fall in London morning trading by 30 cents, to $34.01 per barrel for Brent crude for June settlement, but recover to close at $34.31; South Korean won drops 1.3 percent against American dollar; Thai baht drops nine-tenths of one percent; New Taiwan dollar falls seven-tenths of one percent and Phlippines peso, Indonesian rupiah and Indian rupee each decrease by five-tenths of one percent; photo (M)

headline: EX-RIVALS UNITING
abstract: Growing uprising against occupation in Iraq is forging new and previously unheard of level of cooperation between Sunni Muslims and Shiite Muslims--and common cause is killing Americans; many Shiite fighters are said to be streaming into Falluja to help Sunni insurgents repel punishing assault by US marines, and Shiite families in Baghdad with little to spare are donating food to besieged residents of Falluja; Brig Gen Mark Hertling says military intelligence indicates loose coordination between renegade Shia movement of Moktada al-Sadr and Sunni extremist group called Mohammed's Army in Baghdad; Falluja, 35 miles from Baghdad, becomes rallying cry of resistance; marines are trying to root out insurgents there after four American security guards were ambushed, killed and their bodies mutilated by mob (M)

headline: HEALTHSOUTH BONDHOLDERS REJECT DELAYED PAYMENTS
abstract: Group of 13 HealthSouth bondholders rejects company offer to delay some payments and filings as company tries to restructure $3.34 billion of debt (S)

headline: BEST BUY TO SELL LIMITED QUANTITY OF GATEWAY PRODUCTS
abstract: Best Buy Co will sell limited amount of Gateway brand consumer electronics that were left over from Gateway's retail stores, which closed in April (S)

headline: Symbol Expected to Settle S.E.C. Inquiry and Lawsuits
abstract: Symbol Technologies is expected to announce settlement with Securities and Exchange Commission after long-running probe of its accounting practices and settlement of class-action lawsuits against company; has been focus of investigations by SEC and US attorney's office for Eastern District of New York (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Debt Delinquencies Rise
abstract: World Business BrA

headline: Prosecutors Sought a Scapegoat, Adelphia Defense Lawyer Says
abstract: Lawyer for former Adelphia Communications executive Michael Mulcahey, who is on trial with company founder John J Rigas and two of Rigas's sons on charges of conspiracy, bank fraud, securities fraud and wire fraud, holds in closing argument that four are scapegoats in Adelphia bankruptcy; prosecution begins rebuttal (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro rises after Bundesbank president says Germany's economy will sustain recovery even after drop in business confidence; euro settles at $1.2115, up from $1.2016, in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: A Family Feud at Molson as Profit Falls
abstract: Molson Cos and chairman Eric H Molson are under unusually intense public scrutiny in wake of earnings drop; deputy chairman R Ian Molson, who controls 10 percent of votes, is challenging his cousin, Eric, who controls 45 percent; several of company's biggest outside shareholders plan to vote against slate of three directors nominated to represent holders of nonvoting stock; photos (M)

headline: Radical Iraqi Cleric Orders His Fighters To Put Down Their Arms and Go Home
abstract: Moktada al-Sadr, Shiite cleric whose militiamen have tormented American soldiers in Iraq with ambushes and rocket attacks for nearly three months, orders his fighters to put down their arms and go home; daily violence continues across Iraq, even as his loyalists in Najaf seem to be heeding order; two American soldiers are killed and nearly two dozen wounded in rocket attack, Balad; Iraqi policeman is killed and five civilians wounded in bomb attack, Ramadi; senior Oil Ministry official is assassinated, Kirkuk; insurgents blast hole in key oil pipeline, near Basra, further crippling oil exports; poll ordered by American-led coalition finds majority of Iraqis believe they would be safer without United States forces in nation and that all Americans behave way guards did in photos of abuses at Abu Ghraib prison; Deputy Defense Sec Paul D Wolfowitz meets with Prime Min Iyad Allawi and other interim government officials, Baghdad; occupation officials say they will turn over civil aviation operations at Baghdad airport to interim government after June 30 and move virtually all American soldiers from airport; say airport security will be provided by foreign private contractor working with Iraqi forces; United States Army reportedly charges American soldier with murder of Iraqi civilian wounded in high-speed chase near Kufa in May and then shot at close range by Army officer; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Airline Warns Loss Possible
abstract: Swiss International Air Lines shares fall 5.3 percent to six-week low after carrier says it might post operating loss this year because of sharp rise in fuel prices; stock price graph (S)

headline: Actuaries Under Scrutiny On Pension Fund Pacts
abstract: Justice Department asks four actuarial firms -- Towers Perrin, Milliman USA, Watson Wyatt Worldwide and Hewitt Associates -- for information about terms of their client agreements, in what appars to be effort to learn whether certain provisions violate antitrust laws; seeks documents and other information related to firms' decisions, about two years ago, to ask their pension fund clients to sign clauses limiting their ability to sue firms (M)

headline: Iraq Self-Rule Becomes a Test of Nerves As Leaders Face Threats and Violence
abstract: Program run by RTI International in Iraq has set up hundreds of local councils to educate people in democratic processes, but council members have been branded American collaborators and face constant attacks, forcing them to call on military for protection; council members have been specifically targeted by insurgents; most international staff members of Baghdad-area councils have been evacuated; many Iraqis are skeptical about American intentions, but others are encouraged by seeing that councils can be openly critical of occupation; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Lucent Wins Contract From BellSouth
abstract: Lucent Technologies wins three-year contract from BellSouth Corp for equipment that will provide Internet calling services for businesses (S)

headline: Documents Build a Case for Working Outside the Laws on Interrogating Prisoners
abstract: Chronology and summary of responses to Justice Department memos, many written by Prof John C Yoo, providing arguments to keep US officials from being charged with war crimes for treatment of detainees from war against Taliban and Al Qaeda; responses, from Jan 2002 through Dec 2003, were from White House counsel Alberto Gonzales, Sec Colin Powell, Sec Donald Rumsfeld and others in State, Justice and Defense Departments (M)

headline: Mutual Funds Report; Unleashing Directors and Urging Them to Bark
abstract: Regulators are scutinizing mutual fund directors for possible culpability in improper market timing and late trading and writing new rules to ensure that independent directors are not rubber stamps for management; most controversial proposal would bar executives of fund's adviser from serving as board chairman; critics say fact that many funds pay advisory fees that exceed fees paid by similar pension funds suggests directors are putting managers ahead of shareholders; photo (M)d

headline: Motor-Vehicle-Related Deaths Will Increase, Study Predicts
abstract: World Health Organization and World Bank study finds motor vehicle crashes kill about 1.2 million people a year worldwide; predicts number will rise to over 2 million in 2020, making road-traffic-injuries third largest cause of death and disability, unless new steps are taken; predicts such deaths will fall by 30 percent in high-income nations by 2020 but rise 80 percent in poor ones; WHO official Dr Etienne Krug notes developing world has 20 percent of cars but 80 percent of dead, interview (M)

headline: Investing; Russia's Big Rally Fattening Portfolios
abstract: Mutual fund managers who invest in Russia comment on latest Russian stock market boom; cite factors fueling gains; photos (M)4

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: ARGENTINA: Judge Orders Arrest Of Ex-President; HAITI: Annan Proposes 8,300-Strong Force;.

headline: General Will Trim Inmate Numbers at Iraq Prison
abstract: Maj Gen Geoffrey D Miller, American commander in charge of military jails in Iraq, says he will cut by nearly half number of prisoners at Abu Ghraib prison after probe into prisoner mistreatment identified overcrowding as contributing to abusive and chaotic atmosphere, interview; says he will end hooding of prisoners, largely because it is too humiliating; defends other 'stress' tactics as legitimate means of interrogation; says goal is to extract as much intelligence as possible to help war effort; says breakdown in leadership made abuse possible; holds errors have been corrected; photo (M)

headline: World Briefings
abstract: AFRICA.

headline: Camcorder With Plenty Of Extras
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column on new camcorder from Panasonic that uses three charged coupled devices to deliver sharp images and more vivid color; device is smaller and cheaper than one-chip models and has plenty of extras to deliver enhanced video; photos; drawing (M)

headline: Europe Seems Dismayed By Iraq Turn
abstract: Fighting in Iraq causes dismay throughout Europe, with some commentators predicting that United States is now fully bogged down in Vietnam-like quagmire; but few if any European governments, even those like France and Germany that opposed war, are calling for United States withdrawal; major contributors to Iraq occupation force vow to continue their missions (M)

headline: General Blames Command and Training Lapses for Prison Abuse
abstract: The hearing took place as the administration tried to manage a scandal that has sparked outrage at home and abroad.

headline: Powell Plans to Travel to Sudan In Effort to Stop Militia Attacks
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L Powell will travel to Sudan, including western Darfur region where government-backed militias have killed thousands of people and driven more than million people from their homes; he has been outspoken critic of Sudanese government headed by Pres Omar Hassan Ahmed al-Bashir, accusing it of ethnic cleansing for having supported attacks against black Africans in region; United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan will be in Sudan at same time as Powell (M)

headline: Dancing, Or Not, To the Dollar's Fall
abstract: Daniel Gross column on reasons weakening United States dollar has not yet translated into big jump in exports needed to spur job creation; graph of dollar vs euro (M)4

headline: U.S. Hostage Is Free After Escaping; 9 G.I.'s Die in Iraq
abstract: A U.S. contractor taken hostage last month escaped from his captors on a day when nine more U.S. soldiers died in Iraq.

headline: As Household Debt Rises, New Risk in Higher Rates
abstract: Prospect of interest rate rise by Federal Reserve sometime this year or next poses new risk for consumers; Americans have become far more willing to load up on debt and banks have become far more willing to let them; household debt climbed at twice pace of household income from beginning of 2000 through 2003; Americans, enticed by low interest rates, took on $2.3 trillion in new mortgage debt during period, increase of nearly 50 percent; consumer credit rose 33 percent, rising to $2 trillion in 2003 from $1.5 trillion in 2003; economists predict significant rise in interest rates will come as jolt to many people; those with home equity loans will see their monthly payments climb almost immediately; adjustable mortgages will increase more slowly, because many borrowers locked in rates for several years; but monthly debt burdens will eventually rise; housing prices could drop significantly in some overheated markets like New York and Southern California, where many homes have doubled in price over last five years; people who bought their homes with no money down could find themselves unable to sell without owing money to their lenders; graph; photo (M)

headline: Israel to Add to Barrier
abstract: Israel is preparing to build new segments of its barrier around Ariel and other Jewish settlements that are more than 10 miles inside the West Bank. The move has drawn criticism from the Palestinians, and American officials have objected.    Article, Page A11.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: New Prime Minister
abstract: Sri Lankan President Chandrika Kumaratunga swears in new Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapakse; is still trying to win alliances to secure parliamentary majority; her United People's Freedom Alliance party recently won 105 out of 225 seats in Legislature; photo (S)

headline: Interrogation Methods in Iraq Aren't All Found in Manual
abstract: Military intelligence experts say direct questioning of prisoners without resorting to coercion of any kind has often been met with immovable resistance in Iraq, leaving interrogaters to depend on other means of eliciting response that cannot be found among acceptable interrogation tactics listed in Army Field Manual; several prisoners' rights advocates and former Army interrogators agree that interrogation techniques have grown more aggressive since 9/11, and now include some of coercive techniques depicted in photographs of hooded and nude prisoners in Abu Ghraib prison (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Deals: Broadcom To Buy Zyray
abstract: Broadcom Corp, maker of computer chips, acquires Zyray Wireless for about $97.7 million in stock (S)

headline: Maine Takes A Cautious Path On Its Pensions
abstract: Maine's pension fund puts portion of its money into bonds that pay low interest rate but whose values will rise or fall in tandem with value of pensions state must pay its retirees, no matter what markets do; bonds' durations match scheduled payouts to retirees; it is contrarian approach, but one that Maine thinks best serves its retirees and taxpayers; state is first in US to embrace concept of pension matching (M)

headline: Getting the Big Picture
abstract: Consumer Electronics Association reports telvision makers shipped 533,797 digital sets to dealers in March, up 79 percent from Mar 2003; cites drastic drop in prices and increased promotion of HDTV services; sales graphs; photo (S)

headline: Want to Charge It? You'll Have to Talk to Your Credit Card
abstract: What's Next column on prototype credit card from Beepcard; device embedded in card allows transaction to be completed after recognizing voice of owner; drawing (M)

headline: Bombardier Considering a New Line of Jets
abstract: Bombardier expects to decide by early 2005 whether to add family of passenger jets to directly compete with Boeing Co and Airbus Industrie (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Consumer Spending Rises As Economy Gains Strength  Consumer spending rose in April and a measure of business in the Chicago area increased to the highest level in almost 16 years, adding to evidence that economic growth is strengthening.    Personal spending rose 0.3 percent in April after a March increase of 0.5 percent, which was larger than previously estimated, the Commerce Department reported. The National Association of Purchasing Management-Chicago said its index of area businesses rose to 68, the highest since July 1988. [Page C4.]

headline: Latest Tyco Trial Starts as Lawyers' Showcase
abstract: Larceny and fraud Trial opens against Tyco International Ltd's former general counsel Mark A Belnick; both sides deliver opening statements; photo (M)

headline: Archer Daniels Settles Suit Accusing It of Price Fixing
abstract: Archer Daniels Midland Co agrees to pay $400 million to settle civil class-action lawsuit accusing company of fixing prices in huge market for corn sweeteners; money will go to array of corporate purchasers of sweetener known as high-fructose corn syrup; chart (M)

headline: Retailer Doubles Earnings
abstract: Pacific Sunwear of California earned $15 million in its first quarter ended May 1 on revenue of $245.1 million compared with earnings of $8 million on revenue of $198.3 million year ago (S)
