headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Jabil Shares Drop As Forecast Is Cut
abstract: Jabil Circuit's shares drop after company cuts its 2004 profit forecast; graph (S)

headline: Let Freedom Ring? Not So Fast. China's Still China.
abstract: Leadership team in China, headed by president and party chief Hu Jintao, has slapped new restrictions on free speech and press, reminding some of repressive years after 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown; most conspicuous sign of tension is in media, which in recent years flourished in more market-driven environment; people in industry claim pressure to conform to political norms, which never went away, has been strongly reasserted in recent months; propaganda officials have increased their presence inside news, culture and entertainment organizations and have refined system for pre-censorship that leaves less discretion in hands of editors; one close scholar of political scene says efforts to tighten screws on expression are signs of weakness; says authorities are annoyed about being increasingly forced to react to public opinion, and are resorting to old methods to defend themselves; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Seesawing Testimony In Pedophilia Trial
abstract: Myriam Delay reverses early testimony in northern France pedophile case and directly accuses more than dozen individuals of raping her four children and 14 others; last week Delay said she made up testimony and that accused were innocent; photo (S)

headline: 'A Mission to Fulfill'
abstract: Iraqi Governing Council member Adnan Pachachi discusses the tasks of the new transitional government, the relationship with the Americans, and an end to the occupation.

headline: Sikh Who Saved India's Economy Is Named Premier
abstract: Manmohan Singh, Oxford-educated economist who saved India from economic collapse in 1991 and began liberalization of its economy, is appointed prime minister, ending week of high political drama; Parliament members from Indian National Congress select him after Sonia Gandhi reiterates her decision not to accept post; Singh faces challenge of reforming India's economy further in order to ensure higher growth rates, and to deliver benefits of reform beyond growing middle class; Singh, a Sikh, will be country's first non-Hindu prime minister (M)

headline: OPEC Meeting May Increase Quotas for Oil
abstract: Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, scrambling to control high oil prices, plans to meet in advance of its official conference and may pursue plan to raise quotas sharply or drop them entirely; spokesman Dr Abdulrahman al-Kheraigi says raising quotas by 2.5 million barrels a day would be most realistic option, phone interview; Energy Sec Spencer Abraham, in Moscow, lauds Russia's plans to increase oil exports to United States; says record oil prices are being eased by promises of greater supplies from Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, United Arab Emirates and Nigeria (M)

headline: June 30 Goal Is Questioned By 2 Senators
abstract: Sens Richard G Lugar and Joseph R Biden, ranking members of Senate Foreign Relations committee, say American administrator L Paul Bremer III is scheduled to hold closed-door briefing on Capitol Hill this week; they warn that June 30 date for transferring sovereignty to Iraqis might be premature; two senators voice their concerns about transition date in series of telephone interviews and television appearances; concerns focus on political and security issues that have bedeviled Bremer and Coalition Provisional Authority, which he directs; White House statement reiterates that deadline is June 30 (M),

headline: Meeting on TV Ads Makes Little Progress
abstract: First meeting of Network Upfront Discussion Group, committee formed by advertisers and agencies, seeking to overhaul way they buy billions of dollars of television commercial time each spring, makes little progress and looks as if it may be last meeting (M)

headline: A Team Makes a City A High-Rent District
abstract: a team mak

headline: ACTING ON THREAT, SAUDI GROUP KILLS CAPTIVE AMERICAN
abstract: Saudi Arabian militant group executes kidnapped American engineer Paul M Johnson Jr and posts pictures of his beheaded corpse on Web site; Saudi security forces kill Abdelaziz al-Muqrin, leader of group, during gunfight shortly after Johnson's photos are posted; group is offshoot of Al Qaeda that claims responsibility for kidnapping and recent attacks on Saudi expatriates; Johnson was employee of Lockheed Martin; recent terrorist attacks in Saudi Arabia noted; map; photos (M)

headline: Where in the World Are You? Check a Hand-Held Navigator
abstract: GPS Navigator package from Tom-Tom and PalmOne includes small receiver for dashboard that helps keep drivers on course; photo (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Suspense; 'I do want to meet you sometime, but . '
abstract: Excerpt from 'Intimacies,' digital epistolary novel by Eric Brown; photo (S)

headline: U.S. Urges Israel to Begin Dismantling Outposts in the West Bank
abstract: Amb Daniel C Kurtzer says US wants Israel to follow through on plan to dismantle settlement outposts in West Bank, interview with Israeli Army Radio (M)

headline: AETNA SAYS PROFIT ROSE 11%, AIDED BY NEW CUSTOMERS
abstract: Aetna says first-quarter profit rose 11 percent; net income rose to $365.8 million from $330 million year earlier (S)

headline: Turning The Tables On E-Mail Swindlers
abstract: Individuals are using e-mail and the Internet to counterscam Internet con artists; these fraud-baiters attempt to monopolize time and resources of con artists and collect information for law enforcement officials; photo; drawing (L)

headline: Siberian Dam Generates Political Wrangle Over Power
abstract: Russia's largest hydroelectric dam, generating power for vast region in Siberia, is subject of legal struggle stemming from Russia's decision more than decade ago to sell off dam; Khakassia, impoverished region facing increase in electricity prices, is challenging decision to privatize, and federal arbitration court in Siberia has agreed with region's Governor Aleksei I Lebed that country had no legal basis for selling system to Unified Energy Systems, private company; under pressure from court, Pres Vladimir Putin ordered Deputy Prime Min Aleksandr D Zhukov to renationalize dam, returning its shares to national coffers, but Zhukov backed off; outcome now depends on appeal by Unified Energy Systems to country's highest arbitration court; photo of disputed Sayano-Shushenskaya hydroelectric dam; map (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: KB TOYS INC., Pittsfield, Mass., the toy retailer, is seeking approval from a bankruptcy court on rules governing the sale and auction of its Web sites, according to court papers.    ABIOMED INC., Danvers, Mass., a biomedical company that is developing the first self-contained artificial heart, said its founder, Dr. David Lederman, would appoint Michael Minogue, a former executive with GE Medical Systems, as chief executive and president.

headline: Bush, With Mubarak, Links Progress in Iraq to Mideast Peace
abstract: The visit by Egypt's leader came at a delicate time, and at a confluence of several thorny issues.

headline: Keep Telling Yourself: Above All, It's a Phone
abstract: Advice on shopping for cellular phone plan and on choosing phones, which now offer array of features; table of factors to consider; photos (M)

headline: GUIDANT TO DOUBLE SIZE OF ITS OPERATIONS IN IRELAND
abstract: Guidant Corp plans to open plant in Ireland and hire 1,000 more workers there to make drug-coated stents to prevent arteries from becoming reblocked after surgery (S)

headline: SYNGENTA AGREES TO BUY A 90% STAKE IN GOLDEN HARVEST
abstract: Syngenta, major maker of crop chemicals, agrees to buy 90 percent of Golden Harvest of United States for $180 million to expand its share of North American corn and soybean seed markets (S)

headline: Teaching Outsourcing As a Trend, Not a Fad
abstract: Dean Denis Fred Simon letter on Mar

headline: Israelis and Hezbollah Clash at Lebanon Line
abstract: Israeli troops and Hezbollah guerrillas from Lebanon trade artillery fire along border region in their most intense shooting exchange in months; map (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: No To Sexist Slurs
abstract: French government submits draft legislation for Parliamentary approval that would make sexist or homophobic defamation punishable offense (S)

headline: Excerpts From Statement By Sept. 11 Commission Staff
abstract: Excerpts from staff report of commission probing Sept 11, 2001 terrorist attacks; time line; photos (L)

headline: See Who's No. 1 (Quietly) in Pay
abstract: How does a chief executive quietly pocket $155 million in one year? For Barry Diller, who runs InterActiveCorp, it was all in the timing.

headline: If Oil Supplies Were Disrupted, Then ...
abstract: Simon Romero analysis of what would happen to oil prices if supplies were disrupted because of act of terrorism or other threats; industry experts say current crude oil carries 'risk premium' of 12 to 25 percent; Oppenheimer & Co energy strategist Fadel Gheit estimates that worries about Nigeria have contributed about $1 a barrel, Venezuela another $3, situation in Iraq $4 more, and concerns about new troubles in Saudia Arabia $5 a barrel; many analysts say crude might trade for $30 or $35 today instead of nearly $40 with out black cloud of vulnerability to market; chart; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Aide Quits Over Chávez Comments
abstract: Venezuelan Information Minister Jesse Chacon resigns after giving President Hugo Chavez incorrect information about fire in military barracks; Chavez, presenting incorrect facts in radio address, was later accused by opponents of involvement in blaze that killed one soldier and injured several others (S)

headline: I.B.M. Plans to Build Servers That Act Like Mainframes
abstract: IBM plans to announce new server computers that behave more like mainframes and are priced as low as $1,500; servers will be able to run as many as 10 operating system on single machine; first of server computers will begin shipping in May, and prices of some models will range up to $1 million (M)

headline: Company Isn't Afraid To Take Copycats to Court
abstract: Sporting goods maker 180's has filed at least 30 patent-infringement lawsuits; company's founders Brian Le Gette and Ron L Wilson II say not only do patent-infringement lawsuits keep competition at bay, but they can provide tidy revenue stream; photo (M)

headline: Uprooted Sudanese Balk at Invitation to Return Home
abstract: Geneina, Sudan, Gov Sulieman Abdallah Adam says Darfur is safe again and orders million refugees amassed in makeshift camps across western Sudan to head back to their villages; hundreds of black Africans chased off their land by Arab militias and government troops say they do not believe Adam and will flout his order; map; photo (M)

headline: For McDonald's, the 'I'm lovin' it' phrase of its new campaign has crossed over into the mainstream.
abstract: McDonald's Corp introduces 13 new commercials from agencies around world with 'I'm lovin' it,' theme, which it began eight months ago; executive vice president Larry Light says phrase 'I'm lovin' it' has become part of language; photo (M)

headline: FORMER T.W.A. EXECUTIVE IS HIRED BY DELTA AIR LINES
abstract: Delta Air Lines names Michael Palumbo, former Trans World Airlines Inc executive, as chief financial officer; he succeeds M Michele Burns, who has resigned (S)

headline: ERRORS ARE SEEN IN EARLY ATTACKS ON IRAQI LEADERS
abstract: Senior military and intelligence officials say United States launched 50 failed airstrikes, far more than previously disclosed, and targeted broader array of Iraqi leaders during early days of war last year than has previously been admitted; say some strikes caused significant civilian casualties; say raids targeted 13 Iraqi leaders and were seemingly undercut by poor intelligence; targets included Gen Izzat Ibrahim and Maj Gen Rafi Abd al-Latif Tilfah, who now play leadership role in anti-American insurgency; photos (M)

headline: Demonstrators Skirmish With Police in Taiwan
abstract: Riot police fought with demonstrators and used water cannon mounted on armored cars as a large rally turned unexpectedly violent today.

headline: Fox Seeks to Allow Mexicans Living Abroad to Vote in 2006
abstract: Pres Vicente Fox to propose bill to let millions of Mexican citizens living abroad vote for president in 2006; most of Mexicans affected live in United States and Fox, who cannot run again, is courting them; plans visits this week to several cities where many Mexican-Americans and Mexican migrants live; all three major political factions back voting by Mexicans abroad; photo (M)

headline: Britain Says Photos Showing Abuse Are Fake
abstract: British government says its investigation into series of published photographs purporting to show brutal treatment of Iraqi prisoner by British soldiers has concluded that photos were not taken in Iraq and had been faked; images of reported abuse were emblazoned on pages of British newspaper at same time similar photos emerged of American soldiers abusing prisoners at Abu Ghraib; authenticity of image in British photo was immediately called into question by British Army officials who pointed out that army truck in photo was never in Iraq, among other things that were wrong with picture; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Ratings Raised
abstract: Standard & Poor's raises its ratings on many of Japan's top banks, citing better business climate and progress in reducing bad loans; raises ratings on debt of Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, Mizuho Bank and six others (S)

headline: Deutsche Bank to Consider Bid for Postal Savings Group
abstract: Top executives of Deutsche Bank will convene in Frankfurt to discuss whether to bid for Postbank, Germany's huge postal banking system; Postbank is in play because its state-controlled parent company Deutsche Post plans to take bank public in June, selling up to 49.9 percent of its stock in inital public offering (M)

headline: Jordan Sentences 8 for U.S. Diplomats Killing
abstract: Six of the sentences for the October 2002 assassination of an American diplomat in the front yard of his Amman home were in abstentia.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa:
abstract: Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, former wife of leader Nelson Mandela, appeals five-year prison term for stealing $150,000 through bank-fraud scheme involving loans to fictitious employees of African National Congress Women's League; holds she was getting loans to help people in need; photo (S)

headline: Paramilitary Chief's Disappearance Clouds Colombian Talks
abstract: The recent disappearance of Carlos Castaño has thrown delicate peace talks between the organization and President Álvaro Uribe's government into uncertainty.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Growth in Japan's Economy Surpasses All Expectations  The growth in the Japanese economy exceeded all expectations for the first quarter as a largely export-driven recovery broadened to include a pickup in consumer spending.    Japan's gross domestic product rose at an annual rate of 5.6 percent, after vigorous growth in the fourth quarter of 2003, when the economy increased at a 6.4 percent annual pace, the fastest expansion in 13 years. The most-recent figures show that Japanese consumers are also contributing to the recovery, which is nearly two years old. [Page C4.]

headline: The Price of Rice Soars, and Haiti's Hunger Deepens
abstract: Haitians say they have less money, less food and less hope since Feb revolt that toppled Pres Jean-Betrand Aristide; cite soaring price of rice, a staple; price was driven up by global, national, political and economic forces; 80 percent of rice imported by Haiti comes from United States; American and global stocks of rice are down, driving prices up; photo (M)

headline: Dissident Chief Of Force Killed In Colombia
abstract: Assassins in Colombia kill Carlos Mauricio Garcia, dissident leader of right-wing paramilitary force who has harshly criticized drug trafficking (S)

headline: In Mexico, Anger Over Gas Terminals
abstract: Fierce opposition to proposed liquefied natural gas terminals in Baja California has thrown into doubt Mexican government's plan to end country's dependence on US gas imports; Petroleos Mexicanos is heavily taxed to finance government's budget and is starved for cash to develop country's abundant natural gas reserves; Mexican government estimates demand for natural gas will grow 6.8 percent per year through 2012; building of natural gas terminals would enable Mexico to import gas from distant new sources, like South America, Russia and Indonesia; photo (M)

headline: NBC Names Head of Entertainment Unit
abstract: NBC names Kevin Reilly president of its entertainment division to succeed Jeff Zucker, who was promoted last December to oversee network's entertainment, news and cable group (S)

headline: When a Job Calls And No One Answers
abstract: Eduardo Porter column on debate over lifting limit of foreign workers who can be allowed into US for seasonal jobs under program called H-2B; Department of Homeland Security has announced that this year's limit of 66,000 H-2B visas has been reached early, and employers are pressing Congress to relax limit; three bills have been introduced to that effect, but they have been kept from vote by opposition of a few senators (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Mediation In Colombian Conflict
abstract: Mexican President Vicente Fox, attending Organization of American States meeting in Ecuador, announces Mexico's willingness to act as mediator between Colombian government and guerrillas in hopes of ending four-decade-long conflict (S)

headline: Makers of Drug-Coated Stents Fight For the Hearts of Cardiologists
abstract: Johnson & Johnson, which introduced in US promosing new drug-coated stent to treat heart disease nearly year before anyone else, has already lost its lead; Boston Scientific Corp, which introduced rival device two months ago, says it has captured about 70 percent of new orders; says its US revenue for device was $163 million in April, with additional $42 million overseas; Johnson & Johnson declines to discuss its sales for March and April, but contends doctors are still deciding which device they prefer; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: An Oil Enigma: Production Falls Even as Reserves Rise
abstract: Chevron Texaco says its proven oil and natural gas reserves have risen 14 percent, over one billion barrels, in last six years, but its annual output during that time has fallen by almost 15 percent; Chevron Texaco is not only big oil company whose production is falling despite rising reserves, though it has largest gap; consumers, economists and governments around world are wondering if oil supplies can keep pace with rising demand; production trends at industry's publicly traded co mpanies are not promising; fears about supply shortfalls and rising demand have caused prices to climb about 20 percent in 2004; proven reserves and output usually move in tandem; industry experts disagree why relationship has broken down; production trends at Exxon Mobil, BP PLC and Royal Dutch/Shell noted; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: Migrants Freed From Sealed Truck
abstract: Mexican government spokeswoman Gabriela Coutino reports that Chiapas authorities have rescued 190 migrants from Guatemala, El Salvador and Honduras, who were being transported to United States in sealed tractor-trailer (S)

headline: Pakistan Opposition Figure Is Given 23-Year Jail Sentence
abstract: A Pakistani judge sentenced the leader of the country's main opposition political alliance to prison today on charges of treason and inciting mutiny in the armed forces, state-run news organizations reported.

headline: 41 Iraqis Killed in Two Car-Bomb Attacks; at Least 142 Others Are Wounded
abstract: Powerful suicide car bomb rips through throng of men waiting outside army recruiting station in Baghdad, killing at least 35 Iraqis and wounding at least 138; photos; second car bomb at city council building in village north of capital kills six Iraqi security officers and wounds four others; Iraqi officials says they are ready to crack down hard on insurgency after June 30 US handover (M)

headline: Next Job a Question Mark
abstract: Professional future of Mel Karmazin is in doubt now that he has resigned as chief executive of Viacom Inc; he has said he wants to be chief executive of entertainment company, but many of top management jobs at those companies are already taken and could be for some time (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sprint And AT&T Wireless Start Wi-Fi Venture
abstract: Sprint and AT&T Wireless announce agreement to allow their respective customers to share wireless Internet access points at several major airports (S)

headline: A Washington Bank In a Global Mess
abstract: Controversies surrounding Joe L Allbritton, powerful Washington, DC, figure, and his Riggs National Bank noted; wide-ranging probes by federal investigators, Congress and banking regulators revolve around netherworld of terrorist financing, money laundering and seamier geopolitics of Big Oil; Allbritton, chairman, former chief executive and controlling shareholder, has long held reins of bank that is highly personal, extraordinarily quirky institution deeply rooted in history of Washington; bank, despite anemic profits and tiny size, has maintained its stature by catering to city's elite political and diplomatic corps; graphs of stock price and income; photos (M)

headline: A Blogger's Recompense
abstract: Naava Katz letter relates how blogging has become unifying force in her family (May 27 article)

headline: I.B.M. Joins Stanford to Find Uses for Electron Spin
abstract: IBM and Stanford University will open joint research program to focus on field of spintronics, designing products based on how electrons spin instead of how they transmit electrical charges; plan underscores reliance of IBM and other big businesses on ties with major universities; effort could lead to far smaller devices with much lower power requirements and fewer problems with heat buildup; photo (M)

headline: Rise and Fight: Morning News Wars
abstract: Review of rivalry between early morning television shows produced by major networks: ABC's Good Morning America, CBS's Early Show, and NBC's Today, long-time morning leader; photos (L)

headline: Driving in Kenya Can Be Hazardous to Your Health
abstract: Kenya estimates 2,000 people are killed in road accidents each year; fatality rate is about 55 deaths per 10,000 motor vehicles, while US rate is two deaths per 10,000 vehicles; Kenya spends $76 million each year to care for accident victims; leading advocate of new safer driving program is Mary Mwangangi, traffic commandant of Kenya's Police Department; Mwangangi broke both arms and both legs in collision with speeding truck in 2003; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Chemicals Unit Sold
abstract: Rhodia, French maker of specialty chemicals, agrees to sell its North American phosphates unit to Bain Capital for $550 million (S)

headline: Procter & Gamble Reviewing Account
abstract: Procter & Gamble.

headline: Going Public Without Profits Or a Product? Yes, in 2004
abstract: Some analysts say stock offering by Nanosys Inc, company with no products or profits, could spur similar offerings by other nanotechnology startups; excitement over nanotechnology, broad term for technical advances in handling materials at molecular level, differs in some key respects from earlier dot-com mania; field has garnered billions of dollars in federal research support; Nanosys has over 200 patents and patent applications as well as product development ventures with big companies (M)

headline: In Italy, a new approach to tackling prostitution
abstract: PERUGIA, Italy:—  CORRECTION PUBLISHED IN THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE DATED Saturday, May 29, 2004:

headline: Struggling to Draw Workers Sending Money Back Home
abstract: Pew Hispanic Center reports that America's big banks have captured only trifling share of immigrants' remittances of money back home from conventional cash-based players like Western Union; says price of remitting money has leveled off after falling sharply in late 1990's; banks were supposed to provide poor Latin American immigrants an easier and cheaper way of sending money back home, and this in turn was supposed to draw immigrants into formal financial sector; banks remain hampered by many less-educated immigrants' lack of familiarity with formal banks and financial services; another obstacle is that ATM's and bank branch systems in Latin America seldom extend into rural areas (M)

headline: Judge Dismisses Deceit Charges In Investment Suit by Connecticut
abstract: Judge Samuel J Sferrazza throws out charges that Forstmann Little & Co buyout firm misled Connecticut's state pension fund, which is suing for breach of contract over money-losing telecommunications investments totaling $2.5 billion; lets stand state's major charge that firm bought stakes in McLeod USA and XO Communications that did not conform with investment contract (M)

headline: Get Outside, or at Least Play as if You Are
abstract: Charles Herold Game Theory column reviews RC Cars, NFL Street and Winning Eleven 7; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Maserati Executive Named
abstract: World

headline: Fighting Crime One Computer at a Time
abstract: Article on growth of small businesses that deal with Internet fraud; ICG founder-chief executive Michael Allison says company has grown to 35 employees and revenue of projected $7 million this year from 8 employees and $1.5 million four years ago; computer security firm Mi2g says online identity theft cost businesses and consumers more than $5 billion last year worldwide, while spamming drained $3.5 billion from corporations; Kroll has seven crime laboratories around world and is opening two more in US; photo (M)

headline: MediaTalk; Rosie Issue Fades Away, Copyright Issue Rises
abstract: Gruner & Jahr pledges quick resolution of dispute with Playboy Enterprises, which pressed criminal charges against international unit president Axel Ganz after its French unit, Prisma Presse, printed small photographs of Playboy magazine pages in its women's weekly; photo (M)

headline: Used Cellphones Find a Market Among Bare-Bones Users
abstract: Recycling of cellular phones discussed; environmentalists applaud refurbishment programs; majority of phones are resold to raise money for charity; photos (M)

headline: Tales of Night of Terror in Russian Region
abstract: Officials in Ingushetia, Russia, say 97 people died in attacks around region on June 21; authorities and survivors in Nazran, capital of Ingushetia, reconstruct grim tale of night in which tiny region briefly ceded control to Islamic guerrilla force; officials say they were attacked from Chechnya by mixed force of Chechen, Ingush and Russian fighters, perhaps with Arab jihadists among them; map; photo (M)

headline: For Chip Rivals, Slugfest Worthy Of Video Game
abstract: Nvidia is counting on new generation of its GeForce computer chips to regain lead in chips that enable personal computers to show more vivid three-dimensional graphics images; company, which dominated market for graphics chips, has slipped lately, allowing ATI Technologies to catch up; Nvidia lost its Xbox contract to ATI when it refused to meet Microsoft Corp's stringent pricing demands; revenue fell to $1.82 billion in 2003 from $1.91 billion in 2002; graph; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Real Estate Merger
abstract: Westfield Holdings, Australia's largest listed retail property group, says it plans to acquire two associated trusts to create global real estate company, Westfield Group; photo of Frank Lowy, who controls Westfield (S)

headline: Five Aid Workers Shot to Death In an Ambush in Afghanistan
abstract: Five aid workers from Dutch branch of Doctors Without Borders are shot dead in ambush in northwest Afghanistan; killings are latest blow to embattled aid workers in country, who have seen 32 of their colleagues killed since Mar 2003, often by Taliban and other militants intent on stalling aid and reconstruction efforts (M)

headline: Ashcroft, Deft at Taking Political Heat, Hits a Rocky Patch
abstract: Atty Gen John Ashcroft, long criticized by liberals for his definition of proper balance between civil liberties and security needs, has recently experienced series of defeats and missteps that have put him under even more intense scrutiny; some Republicans say he has become so polarizing a figure that he can no longer be effective advocate for administration initiatives, like drive to renew expiring antiterrorism law; his allies say he is not wilting under pressure; photo (M)

headline: D-DAY / 60 years later : For Britain, D-Day redeemed the shame of Dunkirk debacle
abstract: LONDON—  In one of several new studies, Samuel Newland, an American historian, concludes that, of all the defining moments of World War II — from Pearl Harbor to the fall of Paris — none provided the same sense of common purpose among the allies as the Normandy landings 60 years ago.

headline: North Korean and Chinese Leaders Meet
abstract: North Korean leader Kim Jong Il and Pres Hu Jintao of China discuss international crisis over North Korea's nuclear program; their meeting in Beijing comes less than week after Vice Pres Dick Cheney's visit to Beijing, during which he made North Korean crisis central focus and told Hu that six-nation talks sponsored by China to deal with matter must begin to show 'real results' (M)

headline: Business; Energy Drinks Charm the Young and Caffeinated
abstract: So-called energy drinks, which consist mostly of sugar, water and caffeine, with variety of vitamins, herbs and supposedly energy-enhancing extracts, have emerged as fastest-growing segment of beverage industry; beverage companies are rushing into $1 billion market to grab share from pioneer, Red Bull, lured by willingness of young men to pay twice as much for 8-ounce can of energy drink as for 12-ounce cola; Red Bull says its worldwide sales rose 10 percent in 2003; says it still has global market share of 70 to 90 percent, despite slipping to 50 percent in United States; uses little national television advertising, focusing its marketing on sponsoring extreme sports and lobbying outlets to sell its products; market share graph; tables; photo (M)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: List of Americans newly confirmed dead in Iraq

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Co, which sponsors ABC series Extreme Makeover: Home Edition, signs multiyear pact with Ty Pennington, woodworker who appears on series, to appear in Sears advertising and collaborate on merchandising and product development; William C Schumacher acquires Barnhart/CMI; becomes president, succeeding Terry Barnhart, who beomes adviser; is renaming agency Barnhart (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Banker Moves Up Resignation
abstract: World Business Briefing:

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Copper prices rise on speculation that China's economy is growing fast enough to stimulate more industrial demand; copper for July delivery rises 3.4 cents, or 2.8 percent, to $1.2655 a pound in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: MediaTalk; EarthLink Bundles Subscription-Only Sports Features From Popular Web Sites
abstract: EarthLink to sell service that will give users access to subscription-only parts of nine popular sports Web sites for about quarter of cost of buying subscriptions separately; other online services offer similar premium packages (M)

headline: Disney Board To Get Advice From Funds
abstract: Board members of Walt Disney Co agree to involve pension funds from five states in search for new independent director and to consider creating advisory committee to receive further suggestions from funds; six of Disney's 11 directors meet in New York with representatives of six funds from New York, Connecticut, North Carolina, California and Ohio; photo of George J Mitchell, nonexecutive chairman of Disney (M)

headline: Amid Violence, Powell Braces Iraqis and Saudis
abstract: After a weekend of violence in both Iraq and Saudi Arabia, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell warned today that Iraqis could face a long, bloody summer.

headline: U.S. Forces Keep Pressure on Rebels in Falluja and Najaf
abstract: The U.S. military made an aggressive push in its two-front war in Iraq as the country remained in the grip of a three-week revolt.

headline: With Potential for a Harsh Summer, Basic City Services Become the Priority
abstract: Maj Gen Peter W Chiarelli, American commander responsible for Baghdad security and reconstruction, warns of long and violent summer but sees signs of progress; says one goal is to show residents how to conduct free and fair election; wants to test process with Oct vote for district advisory councils across city; has begun pushing projects to improve basic services; photo (M)

headline: Despite an Act of Leniency, China Has Its Eye on the Web
abstract: China gives Internet democracy advocate Du Daobin suspended sentence; some applaud show of leniency, but others warn that magnanimity conceals push for tighter controls; estimated 30,000 Internet police monitor users, blocking sites and killing discussion threads on bulletin boards; provincial governments are adding their own controls; Internet bar users in Shanghai must now swipe cards with their national identity number to track use; analysts believe China is deeply concerned about blogging as medium of expression; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Broadcom To Settle Microtune Lawsuits
abstract: Microtune says Broadcom Corp has agreed to pay $22.5 million to end all patent and antitrust litigation; one-time payment to Microtune is part of accord that also binds companies to license each other's technology (S)

headline: Europe and Russia Extend Ties to 10 New Members
abstract: The agreement, the subject of sometimes contentious debate, averted what could have become a diplomatic and economic conflict.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: A Rothschild Declines Bank Position
abstract: Edouard de Rothschild will not run Rothschild & Cie Banque, French arm of banking group bearing his name; will instead become nonexecutive chairman of bank's supervisory board while undertaking projects unrelated to finance; was named to run French business last July (S)

headline: Moscow Court Keeps Ban on Jehovah's Witnesses
abstract: Moscow appellate court upholds ban on Jehovah's Witnesses in city; group's leaders say ruling reflects mounting pressure on some faiths in Russia; cite fear it could presage similar efforts in other cities, where adherents face harassment; Witnesses are registered on national level and in nearly 400 Russian cities; plan appeal to European Court of Human Rights (M)

headline: Views Mixed On U.S. Shift On Drugs For AIDS
abstract: AIDS activists and doctors who treat patients in poor countries greet Bush administration's shift in its policy on procuring AIDS drugs with mixed reviews; many are delighted, but some express frustration that White House has set up new approval process overseen by Food and Drug Administration when one overseen by World Health Orgn already exists; they consider this another roadblock (M)

headline: MediaTalk; Environmental Web Site Removes an Ad It Deems At Philosophical Odds
abstract: E/The Environmental Magazine quickly drops banner advertisement from Pacific Research Institute from its Web site because institute gets funds from Sarah Scaife Foundation and John M Olin Foundation, conservatives groups at odds with many environmental groups; online ad, and now-canceled print ad, promote report sponsored by institute and American Enterprise Institute, another conservative group; editor Jim Motavalli says ad's imagery and title gave impression group was fri

headline: Psst. Why Insider Trading Keeps Going.
abstract: Wall Street insiders, despite intense public scrutiny of recent celebrity insider-trading cases, continue to violate securities laws by misusing nonpublic information; federal prosecutors aggressively go after wrongdoers; are unsure why some of smartest people on Wall Street continue to run afoul of insider-trading laws; suspect they believe their information is so privileged that no one will know they use it; case of broker Robert Bewkes, who sold Interstate Bakeries shares on advice of his father, E Garrett Bewkes Jr, Interstate director, cited; photos (M)

headline: Things Go Better With Bingooo, Qoo And Many Megapixels
abstract: Coca-Cola Co's many product names around world noted in light of company's plan to unveil complex and costly Times Square sign; photos (M)ï

headline: U.S. OPEN TO PLAN THAT SUPPLANTS COUNCIL IN IRAQ
abstract: Bush administration accepts outlines of proposal by United Nations envoy Lakhdar Brahimi to dissolve American-appointed Iraqi Governing Council and replace it with caretaker government of prominent Iraqis when sovereignty is restored on July 1; under Brahimi plan, transition government's leaders would be appointed by UN, after consultations with US, governing council and other Iraqis; it is unclear how it would balance religious and regional rivalries within Iraq; by endorsing Brahimi plan, administration seems to accept diminished American influence over Iraqi political process as self-rule approaches; administration officials say, however, that American influence on process will be considerable, because US is to remain in charge of military and security matters and will be country's main source of economic aid; in addition, Brahimi's plan is result of his close work with Robert Blackwill, chief deputy of national security adviser Condoleezza Rice; administration officials acknowledge that any new plan has to be proposed by UN and bear no obvious stamp of American influence (M)

headline: Stewart Should Be Denied New Trial, Prosecutors Say
abstract: Prosecutors ask court to deny requests for new trial for Martha Stewart and Peter E Baconovic, her former stockbroker, who were convicted in March of lying to government investigators about Stewart's reasons for selling ImClone Systems shares in December 2001; say they had no idea that Larry F Stewart, expert witness on ink analysis, was lying on stand and that Stewart's and Baconovic's convictions were independent of his testimony (M)

headline: Chip Stocks Fall Overseas On Worry About U.S. Growth
abstract: Semiconductor-related shares slide worldwide amid expectations that rising interest rates in United States would slow economic growth (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Greece: High Price For Oil Tanker
abstract: Metrostar Management Corp pays $95n

headline: Ashcroft Says the White House Never Authorized Tactics Breaking Laws on Torture
abstract: Atty Gen John Ashcroft, whose subordinates have written confidential memos saying Bush administration is not bound by bans on torture, tells Senate Judiciary Committee that Pres Bush did not require or direct violation of either international treaties or US law; says, in heated exchanges with Edward Kennedy and other Democrats, that he will not provide memos because they are confidential legal advice to president, but says he is not invoking executive privilege; photos; Sen Joseph Biden notes that US signs treaties to protect American soldiers like his own son (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Inuit Vote For Autonomy
abstract: Nunatsiavut, Inuit region in northern Labrador (Canada), citizens vote in favor of land claim agreement giving them governing rights for 28,000 square miles territory; was last outstanding Inuit land claim in Canada (S)

headline: Behind Trans-Atlantic Cordiality: A Little Give and Take
abstract: Moves toward 'balance and moderation' in German and French relations with US is partly response to Bush administration's modest move toward multilateralism in seeking new UN Security Council resolution on Iraq; Pres Jacques Chirac and Chancellor Helmut Schroder continue to oppose US on many Iraq details, including use of NATO troops, and are not eager to bail US out of very dangerous situation there; Schroder has more urgent political need to reconcile, and seems warmer personally to Bush and more cooperative (M)

headline: 'The Next Slide, Please,' Accomplished Wirelessly
abstract: RemotePoint Global Presenter from Interlink Electronics controls PowerPoint presentation from 100 feet away; photo (S)

headline: Siebel Chief Steps Down; I.B.M. Executive Moves In
abstract: Thomas M Siebel announces his resignation as chief executive of Siebel Systems, business software company he founded and has led since 1993; Siebel will remain as chairman; Michael J Lawrie, longtime executive at IBM, will take over as chief executive and president (M)

headline: A Tight Circle Of Friends
abstract: Article on benefits-consulting firm Liden, Morton, Nestle & Soled in Westlake Village, Calif, focuses on how friends and partners helped one of partners, Linda Nestle, combat alcoholism and at same time ran the firm; photo (M)

headline: In Falluja, Ceasefire Doesn't Reduce Tension, or Danger
abstract: It has been 4 days since the U.S. declared a "cessation of offensive operations," but in Falluja, that doesn't seem to matter.

headline: Competition Is Heating Up As Projectors Go Digital
abstract: Sony Electronics will demonstrate its digital projector at Digital Cinema Laboratory, as movie theaters gradually shift from film to digital projection; motion picture industry analysts have long predicted shift to digital projection because using hard disk produces image superior to that of film projector; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Blast At McDonald's, But No Injuries
abstract: Bomb explodes in Istanbul (Turkey) McDonald's parking lot causing damage, but no injuries (S)

headline: The Army and Torture: What the Rule Book Says
abstract: A scandal could have been avoided by adhering to the 1992 field manual that outlines the army's doctrine for conducting interrogations.

headline: Subway and Google Try to Split the Screen
abstract: Subway Restaurants and Yahoo are both introducing commercials that tell stories by splitting television screen in half vertically; commercials described (S)

headline: Google Moves Toward Clash With Microsoft
abstract: Google, edging closer to direct confrontation with Microsoft, is preparing to introduce powerful file and text software search tool for locating information stored on personal computers; Google's software is clearest indication that company hopes to extend its search business to compete directly with Microsoft's control of desktop computing; improved technology for searching information stored on personal computer will also be crucial feature of Microsoft's long-delayed version of its Windows operating system called Longhorn, which is not expected before 2006 at earliest (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Seagate To Cut Jobs
abstract: Seagate Technology expects $50 million in restructuring costs this quarter and will cut 2,940 jobs because of shrinking market share and price declines (S)

headline: ABER DIAMOND OF CANADA BUYS CONTROL OF HARRY WINSTON
abstract: Aber Diamond Corp of Toronto buys 51 percent stake in Harry Winston Inc, jewelry retailer based in New York, for $85 million; has option to buy remaining 49 percent, which is owned by Fenway Partners (S)

headline: U.S. Rights Report Is Released After Delay
abstract: The abuse of prisoners by American troops in Iraq is the sort of behavior routinely denounced in these reports.

headline: Yahoo Reports a Surge In Quarterly Earnings And Plans a Stock Split
abstract: Yahoo Inc announces first-quarter financial results that are far stronger than expected; earned $101 million, more than double $47 million it earned year earlier; total revenue was $758 million; expects revenue of $2.4 billion to $2.5 billion for 2004, up from previous estimate of $2.1 billion to $2.2 billion; predicts operating cash flow to rise to $890 million to $970 million, up from previous forecast of $710 million to $800 million; announces two-for-one stock split, payable May 11 to shareholders of record as of April 28; chief executive Terry S Semel comments (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Mitsubishi Sales Chief Ousted in Start of Expected Shake-Up
abstract: A top executive at the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation resigned Friday in what is expected to be the first in a series of top management changes in response to a steep drop in sales in the United States, ballooning losses and recalls at an affiliate in Japan.      Mitsubishi Motors said that Steven Torok, its head of international sales and marketing, left the company Friday to return to the Chrysler division of DaimlerChrysler, which also controls Mitsubishi. Mr. Torok's departure will probably be followed by that of the chief executive of Mitsubishi Motors, Rolf Eckrodt, and other members of his executive team as soon as next month, according to an executive close to the restructuring planning. Mr. Eckrodt would be succeeded by Andreas Renschler, the head of DaimlerChrysler's Smart car subsidiary, which is not yet selling cars in the United States. Mr. Renschler was also the leader of the team sent to Tokyo to draft an overhaul plan for Mitsubishi, said this executive, who insisted on anonymity.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Electronics Concerns Post Profits
abstract: Sharp Corp says net profit rose 86 percent for fiscal year ended March 31, to 60.7 billion yen ($558.5 million); earned 84.3 billion yen for three months ended March 31, up 18 percent from year earlier (S)

headline: DDB Worldwide Tops Honors in Clio Awards
abstract: DDB Worldwide wins top honors at annual Clio Awards ceremonies (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Maker Names Executive
abstract: Infineon Technologies appoints Thomas Seifert as head of its main memory-chip business to succeed Harald Eggers, who is leaving after more than 25 years (S)

headline: Overhaul of Side-Impact Crash Tests Proposed
abstract: The new test procedures will reinforce the industry's voluntary commitment to equip almost all new vehicles with inflatable curtains and other side airbags.

headline: When Your Signal Needs a Lift, Quickly Attach A Portable Antenna
abstract: Freedom Antenna from ARC Wireless Solutions attaches to cellphone antenna to boost signal strength; photo (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: DaimlerChrysler To Install Sirius Radios
abstract: Sirius Satellite Radio says its radio will be installed in 11 DaimlerChrysler vehicle lines for 2005 model year; expects about 550,000 new subscribers by 2006 from agreement (S)

headline: Blaming U.S., Iran Says Truce Effort in Iraq Fails
abstract: Iran said today that the United States' "iron fist policy" in Iraq and a lack of security had foiled Tehran's efforts to end a stand-off in Iraq between American troops and Iraqi rebels.

headline: The Spitzer File: 'Dear Sandy . . .'
abstract: Former Securities and Exchange Commission chairman Arthur Levitt jokes about New York Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer's probes of Wall Street wrongdoing, journalists gathering (S)/

headline: Grilled Flight Attendant, Anyone?
abstract: Article on readers' reactions to April 20 article that focused on memo from American Airlines executive scolding flight attendants for poor service and bad attitudes; drawing (M)

abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.00   4.00   4.25       Federal Funds   1.00   1.00   1.26       3-month Libor   1.15   1.14   1.32       3-month T-bills   0.96   0.93   1.15       6-month T-bills   1.13   1.08   1.17       10-yr.
