headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Court Upholds Yukos Tax
abstract: Moscow court upholds tax ministry order that Yukos Oil pay 99.4 billion rubles ($3.4 billion) in back taxes and fines for year 2000; Yukos is expected to appeal ruling (S)

headline: To Study History, Pupils Can Rewrite It
abstract: Muzzy Lane Software has developed a multiplayer computer game custom-designed to help students study history; challenge is to design game acceptable for educational purposes that includes support material; photo (M)

headline: Jangling on Your Key Ring, 200 Stills and a Home Movie
abstract: Key019 from Philips Consumer Electronics is tiny camcorder that can store digital video or still photos; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Sale Of Airline Stake
abstract: Brazilian airline TAM plans to sell 20 percent stake in Brazil and United States within a year in bid to raise as much as $150 million to increase working capital (S)

headline: OMAN'S OIL YIELD LONG IN DECLINE, SHELL DATA SHOW
abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell Group's oil production in Oman has been declining for years, belying company's optimistic reports and raising doubts about whether new technology can extend life of huge but mature oil fields in Middle East; internal Shell documents suggest that figure for proven oil reserves in Oman was mistakenly increased in 2000, resulting in 40 percent overstatement, and that senior executives were told calculations of reserves were too high in 2002, two years before company downgraded its estimate; oil industry experts say company's experience in Oman highlights broader questions about future role of Western oil companies and their technology in Persian Gulf; official with National Iranian Oil Co says failure of Shell's horizontal drilling technology in Oman suggests that even advanced extraction techniques may not be answer to declining production rates in mature fields of Middle East; regulators in Europe and Washington as well as prosecutors at US Justice Dept are investigating whether Shell's disclosures about its reserves complied with securities laws; map (M)

headline: Nielsen Media's Revised Ratings System Is Denied Accreditation by Industry Group
abstract: Media Rating Council, leading industry association that audits rating services, declines to accredit Nielsen Media Research's planned changes in way it measures television ratings in New York City until Nielsen addresses unspecified 'noncompliance and performance issues' that turned up in Ernst & Young audit; Nielsen says it will proceed with change, which it says will provide local stations more accurate rating figures; had delayed change, to electronic meters from combination of meters and paper diaries, after critics complained it would undercount black and Hispanic viewers; council lauds new technology in general as superior to current system and sides with Nielsen, urging media critics of new system to stop supporting advertising and public relations drives against it (M)

headline: I.B.M. Plans to Buy An Indian Owner Of Call Centers
abstract: IBM will acquire Daksh eServices, third-largest outsourcing company in India with call centers providing technical support and customer care services; center employs 6,000 workers and recently opened call center in Philippines, where it expects to employ 1,000 workers; financial terms of merger transaction undisclosed (M)

headline: A top creative executive at an agency in Detroit is moving on, and changing car brands.
abstract: Gary Topolewski is leaving Chemistri in Troy, Mich, where he had been chairman and chief creative officer, working on General Motors Corp brands, for Troy office of BBDO Worldwide as one of two creative officers; Topolewski will collaborate with Bill Morden on campaigns for all brands sold by Chrysler Group division of DaimlerChrysler; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Saudi Arabia Attack Raises Concerns About Oil Output  The latest attack on foreign residential and office complexes in Saudi Arabia has heightened concerns over its ability to press forward with increases in oil production at a time when global petroleum supplies are becoming increasingly sensitive to any disruptions.     The timing of the attack in Khobar, a city on the Persian Gulf, also appear to have been intended to inflict damage on the credibility of Saudi officials traveling to Beirut this week for a meeting of OPEC. [Section A.]

headline: Shares of Oxford Health Plans Rise In Anticipation of WellChoice Merger
abstract: Investors bid up stock of Oxford Health Plans in anticipation of takeover by WellChoice health insurance company; Oxford's shares rise $7.65, or 15 percent, to $57.97; shares of WellChoice, parent of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, decline 36 cents, to $37.09, indication that its investors would not be vehemently opposed to such acquisition; graph (Market Place column) (M)

headline: What Kicks the Continent to Life? (Not Politics)
abstract: Europeans, who showed mass indifference to elections for European Parliament, are in full bloom of soccer madness as Euro 2004 soccer championships get under way in Portugal; photos (M)

headline: A PC Game Piggybacks on a Surfer DVD
abstract: Hollywood producers looking for new technologies to make movie releases to DVD stand out are including extras like video games, alternative story lines and high definition versions playable on computer; video-on-demand services are driving trend; photo (M)

headline: Sharon Is Confident Cabinet Will Pass His Gaza Plan
abstract: Prime Min Ariel Sharon says he expects his deeply divided cabinet to give its approval for his broad plan to withdraw Israeli settlers and soldiers from Gaza Strip; solid majority of Israelis back plan, but Sharon's 23 cabinet members are split 12 to 11 against it; it is not clear any of them have changed their positions in recent days; photos (M)

headline: Report Says Aid to Weak States Is Inadequate
abstract: Report by bipartisan Commission on Weak States and US National Security warns that Bush administration has done little to aid weak and failing states that are breeding grounds for terrorists; co-chairman Stuart Eizenstat calls for more development aid that is not military-related; report's release is timed for Group of 8 meeting in Georgia

headline: Terrorist Who Left a Trail of Bloodshed Is Reportedly Killed
abstract: Profile of Abdelaziz al-Muqrin, leader of Al Qaeda's operations in Saudi Arabia, who was reportedly killed during gunfight with Saudi security forces just hours after his group posted pictures of beheading of American engineer Paul M Johnson Jr on Internet (M)

headline: Old Reflexes Hurting 2 Asian Economic Giants
abstract: China and India may be drifting back toward bigger government role in economy; India and China have folllowed similar economy policy arcs over last half-century: decades of pervasive state intervention, with mostly dismal results, and then shift in recent years toward deregulation and free markets, with spectacular results; investors have seen unhappy reminders of old habits in both countries lately; leftists have gained greater influence in India's national elections, threatening to slow sale of state-owned companies; China is trying to slow its fast-growing economy with more and more severe administrative dictates; stock markets in China and India have experienced severe downturns; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Payments In Cluster Bombing
abstract: Colombian government is ordered to pay $700,000 in restitution to families of 18 civilians killed during 1998 anti-guerrilla operation that dropped bomb on Santo Domingo; event led to President Alvaro Uribe government's ouster of General Hector Fabio Velasco, who allegedly covered-up bombing (S)

headline: Reluctant repatriates : Going home isn't always best option
abstract: VIENNA—  Dragan Majetic, 40, had been living comfortably in Vienna for two years with his wife and two children when his employer Eli Lilly told him it was time to go home. The drug manufacturer was downsizing and pulling all expatriates in its Vienna office back to their home bases.

headline: In a Nod to Niche Users, Sony Rethinks the MiniDisc
abstract: Sony introduces Hi-MD, new generation of MiniDiscs, first offered in 1992; device has one gigabyte of storage and two-way high-speed transfer to computer, but does not allow upload or playing of MP3 files; photo (M)

headline: GUIDANT GETS EUROPEAN APPROVAL FOR 2 HEART PRODUCTS
abstract: Guidant Corp receives European approval for its Multi-Link Mini Vision stent and heart catheter; approvals come one day after Guidant says it might redesign its Champion drug-coated stent, delaying by up to six months its application for approval in US (S)

headline: Bombs, Bullets and Kidnappings: Just a Quiet Day in Iraq
abstract: By the standards of most modern societies, today's events would have been labeled horrific. Iraqis saw it as a breather.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GE Consumer Finance plans to acquire WMC Finance Co (S)

headline: Plan for New Spanish Daily
abstract: Recoletos Grupo de Comunicacion, which is controlled by Pearson PLC, plans to invest $16.5 million this year to start newspaper in United States for Spanish speakers; it will be called Rumbo and appear in second half of 2004 (S)

headline: Genital Cutting Shows Signs of Losing Favor in Africa
abstract: Genital mutilation of girls is slowly losing favor in Africa as parliaments ban practice and women who have carried out traditional cutting, and were revered in villages for doing so, begin to lay down their knives; former cutter Isnino Shuriya works in Kenya to abolish practice after being convinced by religious leaders that cutting is sinful and violates Islam; activists in Kenya and Tanzania also shelter girls who run away to escape cutting (M)

headline: Guard Featured in Abuse Photos Says She Was Following Orders
abstract: Pfc Lynndie R England, prison guard featured in photographs that led to outcry over abuse of Iraqi prisoners at Abu Ghraib prison, says she acted on orders, television interview; shows little remorse; faces military charges (M)

headline: A Chronicler of Afghan Culture, Now Its Loyal Guard
abstract: Profile of Nancy Hatch Dupree, expert on art, architecture and history of Afghanistan who wants to build center in Kabul to house 25,000 documents she and her late husband, archaeologist and historian Louis Dupree, collected; Dupree estimates she will have to raise $3 million; photo (M)

headline: Walgreen Drops Havas for DDB in Chicago
abstract: Walgreen Drops Havas.

headline: In Indonesia, Discomfort on Return of the Generals
abstract: Activists who risked their lives to end the military regime six years ago are feeling queasy about the parliamentary elections.

headline: Simulated Prison in '71 Showed a Fine Line Between 'Normal' and 'Monster'
abstract: Several studies over the years have given some insight into how ordinary people can, under right circumstances, do horrible things--such as mistreatment of prisoners at Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq; studies recalled (M)

headline: RAYTHEON TO CUT EARNINGS BY $335 MILLION TO SETTLE SUIT
abstract: Raytheon Co will reduce earnings by $335 million in second quarter to settle class-action lawsuit from 1999 that accused company of misleading investors (S)

headline: U.S. Troops Die in Afghanistan
abstract: Four American soldiers were killed in action in southern Afghanistan, the scene of recent clashes between American and suspected Taliban forces. Page 14.

headline: Low-Carb Diets Hurt Krispy Kreme Profits
abstract: Krispy Kreme Doughnuts, the hot new stock offering of 2000 that stayed hot even as other new offerings plunged, has suddenly chilled. It blames the Atkins diet.

headline: BOB EVANS LOWERS FORECAST FOR 2005 EARNINGS
abstract: Bob Evans Farms Inc, which makes sausage and owns 559 restaurants, says 2005 profit will be $1.80 to $2 per share, below its previous estimate, as sales fell in May and hog prices rose; sales in May, first month of fiscal 2005, will decrease about 5 percent from year earlier (S)

headline: Nazis and Jews: Insights From Old Diary
abstract: United States Holocaust Memorial Museum will make public previously unpublicized diaries of James G McDonald, American diplomat who knew every major public figure in Europe in 1930's; diaries show that he believed as early as 1933 that Nazis were considering mass killing of Europe's Jews, and that Pres Franklin D Roosevelt apparently shared that view; says Roosevelt wanted to find way to send warning message to German people over head of Hitler; historian Severin Hochberg says this would seem to contradict claim that Roosevelt was indifferent to fate of Jews; diaries provide fresh material for long-simmering debate among historians about when Nazis developed their genocide plan; diaries also provide accounts of McDonald's unsuccessful entreaties to Cardinal Eugenio Pacelli, who became Pope Pius XII, to help Europe's Jews; photo (M)

headline: Asia Letter : Indonesian Islamist party is quietly gaining ground
abstract: JAKARTA—  Clean. Healthy. Caring. That was the slogan of the highly tuned Justice and Prosperity Party, a religious Islamic party led by well-educated men and women that performed surprisingly well in Indonesia's parliamentary elections on Monday.

headline: Negotiators Reach Accord On Pension Bill
abstract: House and Senate negotiators reach agreement on bill that would save companies estimated $80 billion in pension contributions over next two years; airlines and steel companies, which have some of weakest pension plans, would get additional break, worth about $1.6 billion; measure offers all employers with pension plans break by changing way they calculate, in today's dollars, value of benefits that they must pay in future; new method will make their future pension obligations look smaller, meaning they will not have to set aside as much money now; major airlines are expected to save about $1.3 billion in pension contributions over next two years; steel companies that still operate pension funds would save about $300 million; United Airlines stands to benefit more than any other company (M)

headline: China, as Summer Nears, Braces for Power Shortages
abstract: China's State Electricity Regulatory Commission chairman Song Mi says China's huge economic growth will continue to be dogged by widespread electricity shortages this year; tells meeting of electricity industry officials that country faces shortfall of 20 million kilowatts this year; photo (M)

headline: Airlines Drop Fare Rise
abstract: American Airlines, Continental Airlines and three other carriers drop fare increase of as much as $20 one way in some cities after Northwest Airlines refuses to adopt higher prices (S)

headline: Iraq's New Prime Minister Defends Presence of U.S. Troops
abstract: In his first address to the Iraqi people, Ayad Alawi warned that the departure of U.S. forces would amount to a "major disaster."

headline: Warden Plans to Reduce Size of Iraqi Prison
abstract: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 4 — The American commander in charge of military jails in Iraq said today that he had decided to dramatically reduce the size of the Abu Ghraib prison, the site of the suspected abuse of Iraqi prisoners, and to end some of the more coercive practices used against Iraqi detainees.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: NAVIGANT INTERNATIONAL INC., Englewood, Colo., a provider of corporate travel management services, said it had acquired Northwestern Travel Service L.P., Minneapolis, a privately held travel management company, for about $775,000 in cash, about $19.5 million in a short-term note and 611,000 shares worth about $10.4 million.

headline: Hollinger to Sell Telegraph To the Barclay Brothers
abstract: Hollinger International agrees to sell Telegraph Group, which includes Britain's Daily and Sunday Telegraph and Spectator magazine to David and Frederick Barclay for 665 million pounds ($1.2 billion) in cash; ousted Hollinger chief executive Conrad M Black lauds Barclays but questions price (M)

headline: Networks Speed Up Sales Talks on Ads
abstract: Networks Speed Up.

headline: Politicus : A decent American disappoints Europe
abstract: PARIS—  With Europeans lining up and shelling out to read Bill Clinton, he turns out to be a guy who insists on reminding people that two-thirds of the Democratic Party in Congress voted George W. Bush the specific powers he needed to make war in Iraq. Then, piling it on, he goes and says that France and Germany wrongly made light of the threat posed by Saddam Hussein.

headline: Outsourcing, Turned Inside Out
abstract: Foreign direct investment, once object of scorn, fear and recrimination in United States, is increasing seen as source of new jobs, production and exports; foreign companies are spending billions of dollars to build or expand operations throughout United States, lifting local economies and offsetting some of jobs being sent offshore by American companies; free trade proponents note number of new workers employed by foreign companies, 6.4 million in 2001, more than doubled in 15 years; number of jobs that moved offshore, roughly 10 million, grew by only 56 percent in period; graph compares trends; photos (M)

headline: Another Loan Chance Puts United in a Political Storm; Airline, Its Wings Clipped Twice, Is Given an Unusual Third Shot
abstract: United Airlines scrambles to revise its bid for $1.6 billion in federal loan guarantees; Treasury Department's decision to let it make unusual third aid bid, chance denied other airlines, stirs political storm; Treasury official says decision came after both White House and House Speaker J Dennis Hastert spoke with Sec John W Snow; industry analysts say airline would remain financially shaky even with loan guarantees; photos (M)

headline: Brazil's Armored Cars Find a Space in Iraq
abstract: Brazilian makers of bulletproof cars, facing slump in domestic sales, are turning to export market for growth; became big force in armored car business in late 1990's as nation's elite scrambled to shield selves from surging crime; see Mideast, particularly Iraq, as promising new market; most manufacturers armor cars to protect motorists from random street violence and stray bullets from handguns; cars for Iraq must withstand high-caliber automatic weapons and explosive devices, requiring technology that only biggest of Brazilian armoring companies have; photos (M)

headline: An Egalitarian Auction? Bankers Are Not Amused
abstract: Google has hired Morgan Stanley and Credit Suisse First Boston as underwriters for its initial public offering; gone is bankers' flashy road show to sell investors on deal, gone are complex valuation models that bankers toil on to set offering price, and gone are high fees; executives close to deal say banks will get fee of about 3 percent, or $81 million, of total offering, down from 7 percent they typically charge--in this case $189 million (M)

headline: Lithuanian Parliament Removes Country's President After Casting Votes on Three Charges
abstract: Lithuanian Parliament votes to oust Pres Rolandas Paksas, finding he violated his oath and Constitution through dealings with Yuri Borisov, businessman suspected of links to Russian organized crime; Parliament speaker, Arturas Paulauskas, takes over as acting president, pending new election to be held within few months; Paksas admits mistakes but holds none merited impeachment; photo (M)

headline: Credit Suisse Says Earnings For Quarter Rose Sharply
abstract: Credit Suisse Group says first-quarter profit was more than six times earnings in quarter year earlier; net income was 1.86 billion Swiss francs ($1.45 billion); revenue rose 13 percent, to 16.6 billion Swiss francs (M)

headline: The Scandal That Refuses To Go Away
abstract: Gretchen Morgeÿ

headline: Justices Will Hear Argument On Medical Marijuana Laws
abstract: Supreme Court agrees to decide whether Congress has authority to prohibit medical use of marijuana in states where voters or legislature have approved drug's use under doctor's care; case is appeal by Bush administration of preliminary ruling issued last Dec by federal appeals court in San Francisco; photo; court accepts appeal from Texas death-row inmate Thomas Miller-El, black man tried and convicted of murder in 1986 by jury from which prosecutor removed 10 of 11 black potential jurors by peremptory challenges; court accepts appeal by Central Intelligence Agency, agreeing to decide whether federal courts can consider claim that agency wrongfully refused to keep promise to provide foreign agent with lifetime financial support in return for espionage services (M)

headline: Today's Quiz: 20 Minus 21 (Answer Below)
abstract: National Council on Economic Education poll finds third of respondents aged 18 to 24 did not know that result of federal spending exceeding revenue is called deficit; result graph (S)

headline: Paris Looks Inward on Jobs and Industry
abstract: France's Finance Min Nicolas Sarkozy says government will move actively to keep jobs and crucial industries in France; also calls on European governments to join forces to keep core of economic bloc from turning into 'industrial deserts'; labels European Union's state-aid rules 'far too restrictive,' and calls for relaxation to allow national governments to give their corporate elites leg up in competitiveness; also proposes Europe-wide push for tax incentives aimed at forging industry hubs to spur regional growth; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: KB Toys, Pittsfield, Mass., the toy chain that is seeking to emerge from bankruptcy protection, said it had sold most of the assets of its retail Internet operation to Toy Acquisitions, an affiliate of the D.E. Shaw group, New York, an investment firm. Terms were not disclosed.    First Union Real Estate Equity and Mortgage Investments, Boston, an owner of shopping malls and office buildings, said it had agreed to sell the Park Plaza Mall in Little Rock, Ark., for $77.5 million. The company did not identify the buyer.

headline: Call Me E-Mail
abstract: Eric Brown will market new software interface, DEN WriterWare, for epistolary novel writing; interface mimics e-mail and instant messaging programs, Web browser and pager screen to convey story to reader; photo; drawing (M)

headline: Suspect Items From Iraq Shipped Abroad, U.N. Says
abstract: Demetrius Perricos, acting head of United Nations inspectors office, tells Security Council that equipment and material that could have been used to produce banned weapons and long-range missiles have been emptied from Iraqi sites since war started and shipped abroad; says many of items bear tags placed on them by UN inspectors as suspect dual-use materials; cites discovery of engines from banned missile in scrap yards in Netherlands and Jordan (M)

headline: Bush Renominates Alan Greenspan for Fed
abstract: President Bush, sticking to a pledge he made more than a year ago, this afternoon renominated Alan Greenspan as chairman of the Federal Reserve.

headline: Nigerian State Says It Will Vaccinate Against Polio
abstract: Ibrahim Shekarau, state governor of Kano, Nigeria, whose eight-month moratorium on polio vaccinations has been blamed for spread of polio widely across Africa, says he is ready to resume immunizations; suspension was prompted by claims of some Muslim clerics and political leaders that polio vaccine contains hormone that could lead to infertility; World Health Orgn says tests show no scientific basis for that charge; 2003 Demographic and Health Survey shows that only 13 percent of Nigerian children received all basic vaccinations, lowest rate of any African country studied; Shekarau has been meeting with political and religious leaders to assure them that state has found safe source of vaccine; every other northern Nigerian state that expressed reservations about vaccine dropped its complaints, and Pres Olusegun Obasanjo has publicly endorsed vaccination drive; photo; map (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: 17 Militants Killed
abstract: United States military reports that 17 suspected militants were killed during heavy ground fighting with Taliban in remote area between Kandahar and Zabul Provinces (Afghanistan) (S)

headline: Executive Pay: A Special Report; Two Pay Packages, Two Different Galaxies
abstract: Article in specil

headline: Miscellany
abstract: J Walter Thompson expands its Brand Entertainment Group, division devoted to seeking ways to integrate advertising and entertainment content, by combining it with Showcase, part of WPP Group sibling, Hill & Knowlton; merged division will be known as Amplify and work mainly for Ford Motor Co (S)

headline: Market Place; Loosening up some Depression-era limits on selling stocks short.
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission unanimously approves trial lifting of rule that stocks can sold short only when share prices are rising; trial is for one year and involves one-third of stocks in Russell 3000 index of largest companies traded on American markets; SEC will weigh removing rule for all stocks after trial; adopts rule barring naked shorting, requiring that brokers determine that shares are available to borrow before executing short sale; votes, 3-2, to require that mutual fund board chairmen be independent directors, rather than head of management company; photo (M)

headline: Uneasy Greeks Focus on Olympic Safety
abstract: Greek authorities, already on defensive because of delays in completing sporting sites for Athens Summer Olympics, are confronting renewed fears about security at Games; have asked help of NATO, which is expected to deploy ships and Awac surveillance planes to patrol coastline and provide other help to protect against terrorist attacks; Greek officials note they are spending nearly $1 billion on security operation that is by far costliest and most extensive in Olympic history (M)

headline: At Least 5 More G.I.'s Are Killed in Iraq, 2 in Unraveling of Militia Truce in Kufa
abstract: At least five American soldiers die in Iraq during 24-hour period, two of them fighting insurgents in Kufa during unraveling of cease-fire agreement with Moktada al-Sadr; two are first to be reported killed in combat in Najaf-Kufa area since operation began to put pressure on Sadr to disarm his militia; elesewhere in country, violence continues; car bomb explodes near American headquarters in Baghdad, killing at last four Iraqi civilians and wounding 25; American generals are giving contradictory information about state of violence in Kufa and Najaf; photos (M)

headline: Braving Bullying Hecklers, Simulants Run for President
abstract: Alphaville, virtual community that exists in role-playing game The Sims Online, will conduct second annual presidential election; central issue of each campaign is how to cope with belligerent group of players; according to Electronic Arts there were 57,500 players in March 2004; photos (M)

headline: Reality Intrudes on Promises in Rebuilding of Iraq
abstract: Iraq's economic renewal progresses at slow pace over year into massive United States aid effort; fewer than 140 of 2,300 promised contruction projects are under way, employing under 20,000 local workers; economy that is supposed to be come beacon of free enterprise remains warped by central controls and huge subsidies for energy and food, leaving politically explosive policy choices for new government; Pentagon, scrambling to speed up revival, has recently begun pumping out long-awaited money and work orders, committing $1.4 billion in just last week even as spreading insurgency cripples ability of Western contractors to oversee projects and targets Iraqi workers; American authorities insist rebuilding will proceed; graph of progress on funded work; photos (M)

headline: Dispute Rages Over Attack That Killed 40 In Iraq Village
abstract: Makr al-Deeb, Iraq, residents say US troops fired on innocent people sleeping after wedding, killing at least 40; US military officials say that village was smugglers den used for ferrying in from Syria foreign militants to fight US troops; photos (M)

headline: Legal Scholars Criticize Memos on Torture
abstract: Legal scholars asked to assess recently released Justice Dept memorandums concerning torture all but unanimously agree that quality of legal work in them is poor; law professors, who are generally liberal, could be expected to differ with conclusions reached in memos, which take broad view of presidential power; but their attack on professional quality of memos is unusually sharp, using words like 'embarrassing' and 'abominable'; some professors quoted; photo (M)

headline: In a New Nigeria, a Once-Exiled Nobelist Still Finds Trouble
abstract: Wole Soyinka, once-exiled Nigerian writer and Nobel laureate, takes part in political protest in Lagos; police at first lob tear gas at demonstrators and whisk Soyinka away, only to release him hour later with apologies; demonstration had been called to check 'dictatorial tendencies' of Pres Olusegun Obasanjo and demand end to rigged elections; Soyinka lives in California; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Senegal: Prime Minister Out
abstract: Senegal President Abdoulaye Wade removes rival Prime Minister Idrissa Seck from office (S)

headline: 60 Years Later, a Division Takes Stock on Different Sands
abstract: Maj Gen John R S Batiste surveys operating bases of his unit, First Infantry Division, based in heart of restive 'Sunni triangle' in northern Iraq; presides over ceremonies awarding patches for service in combat zone and gives speech about how division spearheaded invasion of Omaha Beach in France exactly 60 years ago; comments on differences between the wars, interview; photo (M)

headline: The Gold Diggers of Baghdad
abstract: While political power in the new Iraq is becoming a hotly contested commodity, Iraqi clans and foreign pioneers are in the process of rebuilding the country's economy. They lack power, money and security, but at some point they plan to be the winners in this war.

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: NORTH KOREA: Assessing Train Disaster; AFGHANISTAN: Taliban Attack In Center Of Country; MYANMAR: Opposition Leaders Meet With San Suu Kyi;.

headline: Technology Briefing | People: Priceline Chairman Resigns
abstract: Priceline.com's chairman Richard S Braddock resigns; board member Ralph M Bahna succeeds Braddock (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Report Faults Shell
abstract: Washington consulting firm PFC Energy says Royal Dutch/Shell's oil operations in Nigeria play role in feeding continuing conflict in country; Nigerian labor unions are in second day of nationwide strike to protest recent increase in gasoline prices, latest in decade of demonstrations protesting that little of profits reaped from oil-rich country reach some of its citizens (S)

headline: Afghan Officials Deny Reports Of Soldiers Beheading Prisoners
abstract: Senior Afghan officials deny report that soldiers from country's new American-trained national army beheaded four Taliban prisoners; Namatullah Tokhi, local militia commander who made claim, retracts his statement; reversal comes after Human Rights Watch says beheadings would be war crime (M)

headline: FIRST TRIAL SET TO BEGIN MAY 19 IN ABUSE IN IRAQ
abstract: Army Specialist Jeremy Sivits will be first American soldier to face court-martial in abuse of Iraqi detainees at Abu Ghraib prison; military will permit broad public access to trial and will invite Arab news media, in effort to address outrage over abuse scandal; officials say Sivits, military policeman, took some of photographs of Iraqi prisoners that captured abuse as it unfolded; he is one of seven American soldiers to face criminal charges; his trial date is May 19; speed with which his trial is announced, and type of proceedings he faces, suggests that he has reached deal with prosecutors that could include testifying against his comrades; Brig Gen Mark Kimmitt says trial might be held in Baghdad's huge convention center, in anticipation of intense interest from around world; says military is mindful of need to have Arab news media see American justice being carried out; photo (M)

headline: Canada Leader Loses Ground As Opponents Draw Closer
abstract: Canadian Prime Min Paul Martin fares poorly in televised debates in advance of June 28 election; separatist Bloc Quebecois appears poised to sweep Quebec elections and New Democratic Party is doing so well in urban areas that neither main conservative nor liberal party is likely to win majority; Martin also faces unexpected threat from Conservative Stephen Harper, who has moderated rhetoric to broaden appeal; Martin's hope is that enough voters will turn away from New Democrats back to Liberals in order to stop Harper; photo (M)

headline: Radical designs try to go beyond time
abstract: NEW YORK—  Trip the Light Fantastic, a wristwatch made by the Japanese company Pimp, has no numbers, index marks or hands. To tell the time, the wearer must decode the red, yellow and green light emitting diode lamps that flash, disco-like, then freeze into a bar-graph pattern on the watch's oversized rectangular face. (Yes, instructions are included).

headline: In Class, the Audience Weighs In
abstract: Educators find using wireless keypads helpful in classroom give-and-take because they make shy students participate and know-it-alls lose monopoly of dialogue; device sends signal to computer that tabulates and analyzes responses; photos (M)

headline: First Grader. Model Student. Great-Grandfather.
abstract: Profile of Kimani Nganga Maruge, 84-year-old great-grandfather who enrolled in first grade so he could learn to read and write when Kenyan government declared year ago that primary school education would be free through grade 8; photo (M)

headline: UNIT SAYS IT GAVE EARLIER WARNING OF ABUSE IN IRAQ
abstract: Military personnel who worked in Iraq's Abu Ghraib prison say small unit of interrogators at prison began in Nov reporting charges of prisoner abuse, including beatings of five blindfolded Iraqi generals, in internal documents sent to senior officers, interviews; disclosure of documents raises new questious about stand by top military officials that they only learned about abuses in Jan; members of unit that screened prisoners for possible release cited abuse charges in routine weekly reports to military judge advocates and others; reports were to be sent for final approval to board that included Gens Janis Karpinski and Barbara Fast (M)

headline: Barred as Rivals, Doctors See Some Hospitals in Court
abstract: Growing number of doctors are suing hospitals for right to practice at community hospitals while setting up separate facilities for specific ailments; Baptist Health in Little Rock, Ark, is warning Little Rock's cardiologists that to invest in competing hospital could mean no longer treating patients at Baptist Health hospital after seven years of watching Arkansas Heart Hospital vie for patients; cardiologists have sued in state court to stop Baptist Health from carrying out threat; doctors in Columbus, Ohio, who have put money into new orthopedic hospital have lost right to practice at hospitals in OhioHealth network; similar fights are brewing elsewhere, as doctors pursue business strategies that put them in competition with community hospitals; hospitals argue that doctors are threatening their viability by skimming off most profitable cases, while leaving hospitals with too many of patients least able to pay their bills or those whose complicated conditions run up high expenses; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Tycoon's Trial Is Next Week
abstract: Trial of Russian businessman Platon Lebedev is scheduled to begin April 15 (S)

headline: More on the Toyota Prius
abstract: Iwas pleasantly surprised by the feedback from last week's column about the delightful, high-tech Toyota Prius and its hybrid electric/gas engine, which the EPA rates at 55 miles per gallon. I expected, "Hey, get back to writing about palmtops"-but received instead some of the most thoughtful questions and commentary ever.

headline: Social Issues Tug Wal-Mart In Differing Directions
abstract: Social issues are pulling Wal-Mart Stores in differing directions; company's management broadcast two-part message to its one million employees over television monitors in stores after Federal Judge Martin J Jenkins ruled last week that lawsuit charging retail chain with discrimination against women could proceed as class action covering about 1.65 million current and former employees; employees were told that ruling means there was no finding of guilt and it was all about class, but company plans to appeal; second part of message said that when lawsuit is over, company will be better place; Wal-Mart's plans for future appear uncertain; on one hand, it bans certain magazines from its stores, fights matters ranging from shareholder proposals to federal lawsuits, and justifies strategies by quoting long-dead founder Samuel L Walton in obsolete manner of Chinese quoting Chairman Mao; on other hand, in last year, Wal-Mart created office of diversity, announced it would protect gay workers from workplace discrimination, and pledged to promote women in same proportion that they apply for management jobs, promising to penalize senior executives if that does not come to pass; photos (M)

headline: S. & P. RAISES DEBT RATING FOR YUM BRANDS TO BBB-
abstract: Debt rating of Yum Brands Inc, operator of Taco Bell, KFC and Pizza Hut restaurants, is raised to investment grade by Standard & Poor's (S)

headline: On the Job in Iraq, And in the Glare
abstract: Halliburton chief executive David J Lesar discusses difficulties and dangers of working in Iraq but says company is committed to staying the course and serving US military there; interview; photo (M)

headline: Sharon May Pursue Gaza Withdrawal Even If Party Objects
abstract: The prime minister could still pursue his proposal even if his own party rejects the plan, a government official said today.

headline: Hong Kong Journal; City of Immigrants Begins to Find an Identity of Its Own
abstract: Pride and sense of community is emerging in Hong Kong, city of immigrants; it is manifesting itself in everything from new interest in old buildings to willingness to call for free elections; city's democracy movement plans huge march; this has unnerved Beijing, which sees parallels to much more developed independence movement in Taiwan; China's Foreign Ministry has accused United States Senate of interfering in China's internal affairs with its recently passed resolution supporting democratic reforms in Hong Kong; photo (M)

headline: Civilians at War
abstract: The American military's reliance on civilian interrogators and translators in Iraq is so great that many are hired without complete background investigations or full qualifications for the jobs, government officials and industry experts say.    Article, Page A15.

headline: New Battle in Falluja
abstract: Article on fierce fighting between US marines and Iraqi insurgents in Falluja noted

headline: Jordan Sentences 8 Militants, Linked To Qaeda, to Death
abstract: Jordanian military court sentences to death eight Islamic militants linked to Al Qaeda, six of them in absentia, for Oct 2002 Amman assassination of American diplomat Laurence Foley; Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, most prominent of those still at large, is believed to be operating in Iraq; Islamist Web site features audiotape supposedly from him threatening further attacks on American and other foreign forces there, as well as American officials; tape accuses Kurds of being agents of Americans and takes responsibility for some of deadliest attacks in Iraq; Salem Saad bin Suweid and Yasir Friehat are two men present in court sentenced to death; two others get jail terms and another is released (M)

headline: Fannie Mae Says Its Equity Fell By $1.6 Billion In First Quarter
abstract: Fannie Mae says shareholders' equity fell $1.6 billion in first quarter, to $20.8 billion, as long-term interest rates fell; reports profit of $1.9 billion (M)

headline: U.S. to Aid Antiterror Plan in Philippines
abstract: United States and Philippines will hold joint military exercises in Philippines in counterterrorism training program aimed at destroying local cells of Jemaah Islamiyah, Southeast Asian network with links to Al Qaeda (S)

headline: Powell and Annan to Press Sudan to End 'Catastrophe'
abstract: The secretary general said he would join the secretary of state in an effort to compel Sudan to end the "catastrophe" facing its people.

headline: A Real Following; The Ultimate Cable News Guru, When Not in Class
abstract: Cablenewser is blog about cable television news created by Brian Stelter; he comments; photo (M)

headline: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Orange County; Upstate Area Is Becoming Brisk Market For Retailers
abstract: Retail development is growing, as well as charting new course, in Orange County, NY, and nowwhere is change more apparent than at new Gander Mountain store that opened in late March in Middletown; photo (M)

abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.00   4.00   4.25       Federal Funds   1.00   1.00   1.29       3-month Libor   1.29   1.29   1.28       3-month T-bills   1.06   1.05   1.10       6-month T-bills   1.39   1.37   1.08       10-yr. headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Penalty For Trade Violation
abstract: Worlr

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Better Late Than Never.
